description:
I love this place but since they reopened after being closed for repairs they seem to be struggling to get their groove back. They state the hamburgers are cooked medium rare but mine was medium well. It was still good but a bit over cooked for me. I ordered the burger on another occasion and made sure to request that it was cooked medium rare and it was perfect. However, the fries were limp and way too greasy. We asked they be exchanged but the replacement fries were equally inedible. Their fries are usually pretty good and crispy. 

I'll still keep going back but just hope they get back to form soon.
author: Rude G.

description:
Stopped by on a Sunday afternoon for a quick brunch with my sister. The wait was around 10 minutes, which we utilized to decide what to order. 

We were seated on the other side of the restaurant which didn't have the best ambiance. They definitely skimped on the lighting, making the entire room feel really dull and uninviting. The water served was lukewarm and tasted funky. 

My sister ordered the buttermilk hot cakes that came with salted butter and one slice of orange garnish. In terms of flavor, although fluffy, we both came to a consensus that it was somewhat off-putting? I wasn't sure if it was the flour they used or their over all pancake batter, but there was this grainy floury aftertaste the more you ate it. 

I ordered the French Toast Delight that came with yogurt, granola and fruits. With how it was worded on the menu, I originally assumed the parfait-like portion of this dish would be on the side, INSTEAD it was on TOP of my French toast... Amongst my fruit, I was lucky to get a nice piece of the apple core, which humans can totally just ingest those apple seeds no problem (if you didn't get, sarcasm). Anyway, for $10.50, all I wanted was some good simple French Toast, but got played hard. The yogurt toppings in my opinion was a terrible pairing. The sourness from the yogurt literally overpowered everything and the dryness of the granola ruined the texture I hoped from the fluffy French toast... The selection of fruit was quite sad, just raisins, apple and cantaloupe chunks, strawberries and grapes, which are some odd pairings with yogurt and toast? As for the toast, I was disappointed.... just didn't satisfy those cravings and wished I walked a bit further or something to go to some other brunch place. 

TL;DR: don't recommend the pancakes and French toast Delight. However I'm sure their other brunch items may be better.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Of course it's a hipster brunch spot. If you don't mind man buns and skinny jeans serving you up plates of scrambles and hash then this place is worth checking out. 

It's definitely not pretentious. A small, 50s-style diner with tiny wooden booths and counter seating complete the vintage appeal. 

We had a friendly server who helped me customize a vegan version of the Veggie Mess, which was delicious, filling, and reasonably priced - especially for SF. 

The menu is a little jumbled for vegan options. They're definitely there, but a lot of things (like vegan chorizo) get mixed in with egg dishes, so it's a little misleading and you have to clarify if you want your plate fully vegan. This is my only gripe about the place and what's preventing the fifth star. 

Bonus: they have soy milkshakes :)
author: Bridget W.

description: 4 stars, what was I thinking. This place has friendly staff, good coffee, options for omnivores, carnivores, and herbivores. What else could you ask for?
author: Patricia K.

description: It's like going back in time.  The place feels like the 1950's or 60's.   Except for modernizing the food a bit, you will be transported back.  And the prices were not outrageous for such an experience. If gets full so you will have to wait if you get there after 10:15am on a Sunday
author: Leung T.

description:
Diners are one the top Americana icons that comes to mind. It's something that was created in America and holds a piece of my heart tightly.  

I love an old school diner! I am super happy my friends are so cool and they suggested I hit up St. Francis Fountain while I was in San Francisco. It transported me into the 50's era (been around since 1918)  but in liberal SF mental state. It was my last meal on my trip. My friend Susie picked me up from a local brewery and we headed over. We easily found a parking spot and had no problems getting a table for two. This place is long and skinny and it might be tough to have large groups or the weekend wave could also be a damper. 

The prices were so cheap! I really could not believe it. And there was a ton of veggie and vegan options. I could to omelettes, 2 eggs special, breakfast sandwich, a veggie hash with vegan chorizo, huevos rancheros but the "Nebulous Potato Thing" won this breakfast battle. It's potatos, salsa, sour cream, melted cheese tiled with an egg.  I will definitely return on my next trip and try out lunch options too. 

I ordered biscuits because it's a specialty and this spot. It was a great suggestion Susie. They were small, fluffy and the perfect indulgent accompaniment for breakfast!! 

Maybe I will get wild next time and go for a fountain drink. One will never know the levels of crazy brunch I get....tbc.
author: Carolina S.

description: Banana bread is really good! A must try! Also love the mess and omelettes. Can get really busy after 10:30am on weekends, so get there early if you could.
author: Allan B.

description:
This place was pretty busy during lunch time and I hopped in just to try some of the mitchell's ice cream. I elected to go with the chocolate chip and it was very good for about $3 a scoop.  

Old school diner feel and the service was very hospitable and took care of me fairly quickly even though I was there during a busy time.

Who doesn't love Chocolate and Ice Cream? (If you're raising your hand you can stop here ) 
I like making lists what can I say. I have lists for Ramen, Steakhouse/Brazilian , Milk Tea, Egg Tarts, Chicken & Waffles (super random list right). Give my profile a follow if you like them. 

Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top)  is my favorite/ #?  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. Check out my latest reviews for my latest up to date Rankings. 

Rod's San Francisco Chocolate and Ice Cream shop Rankings: 
1 Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous
2 Marco Polo Gelato
3 Dandelion Chocolate
4 Chocolate Covered
5 Smitten Ice Cream
6 Teuscher Chocolate 
7 The Ice Cream Bar
8 Coletta Gelato
9 Cako Creamery
10 Humphry Slocombe Ice Cream
11 Bi-Rite Creamery
12 Miyako Old Fashioned Ice Cream
13 Mitchells Ice cream
14 St. Francis Fountain
15 Christopher Elbow Artisanal Chocolate
16 The Baked Bear- Custom Ice Cream Sandwiches
17 Recchiuti Confections 
18 Poco Dolce Chocolates
author: Rod M.

description: We love coming here for a yummy vegan breakfast when staying in SF! We get the potato hash vegan style with vegan chorizo and avocado and the vegan pancakes. Yummmmm!
author: Megan J.

description:
St. Francis Fountain is a pretty solid brunch spot that has plenty of vegan options which is awesome. There was quite the line when I went there for brunch this afternoon & signed up on the clipboard outside. I was seated fairly soon though as I chose to sit on the counter. 

The vibe here is interesting as is pure hipster w/ a 1980s nostalgia meets a 1950s dinner. They even sell Alf & Garbage Pail Kid Trading cards along w/ Nerds & Twizzlers old school candy.

I have an appreciation for many of the counter culture scenes including the Beats of the 1950s, the hippies of the 1960s, & the punks of the 1970s along w/ the Grunge alternative scene of the 1990s yet never got into the hipster scene.

The vegan brunch here was great though. I went w/ the Devil Burger which is fully vegan as comes w/ lettuce, tomato, onion, & pickle on a sesame bun along w/ veganaise & a pile of marinated & grilled thinly sliced seitan. I added avocado & grilled onions. It comes w/ a choice of a side which I chose the fries.

I will be sure to be back to try a vegan version of the Nebulous Potato Thing. Despite not being into the hipster scene St. Francis Fountain does have plenty of vegan brunch options so recommend it for that alone.

FOMO
Whatevs, if you are a hipster vegan then this place is for you. 
YOLO
author: Shane S.

description:
This is my favorite spot in the entire city to eat. They have a lot of vegan options but also non-vegan options, so there is something for everyone. 

I took my parents here when they visited. My dad is very picky about his chocolate shakes. He said the shake at St Francis was one of the best he's ever had! Amazing. 

It's usually very busy, especially on weekends but everyone is always working super hard and usually you can get a seat pretty quickly. 

I think they are closed for renovations at the moment, I can't wait for them to re-open.
author: Teresa C.

description: I'm new in the neighborhood and just popped in for breakfast... I LOVED IT! Everyone is super friendly. It has a great soda fountain vibe. The food was amazing and large in portion. Also want to say, I saw a manager give breakfast to an elderly woman, for old times sake, because it was nice to see her. I love compassionate people! This place is my new fave...
author: Jenn D.

description: AMAZING vegan breakfast!!! Breakfast is definitely the hardest meal to get right for vegans - and this place nailed it. So many vegan options and/or replacements on the menu - tofu scramble, chorizo, sausage, cheese, etc. I had pesto tofu scramble with non-dairy pepper jack and it was flavorful without being oily or greasy! My dad had ranchero tofu scramble and raves about it. We split a side of the chorizo hash - SO GOOD. Not to mention, the place has an adorable 50's diner vibe: telephone booth, a playlist filled with rolling stones + the beatles, novelty artifacts, etc. Would recommend to any vegan looking for a hearty and unique breakfast with tons of options!!!
author: Samantha O.

description: Yay!! Finally, they open. I love this place. The food was good. The service was great! Love the way that they keep as the past.
author: Pinarat S.

description:
This was my first time and it was honestly a pretty stellar brunch experience! I love the unpretentious and cozy diner-like atmosphere and the service is friendly but quick and no nonsense. It's a small place so they seem to churn through the tables fairly quickly, but we never felt rushed and actually appreciated that we didn't have to spend our whole afternoon there. 

Anyway, on to the good stuff! We had the tofu scramble with mushroom, green onion and ranchero sauce. It came with potatoes and toast, and since my girlfriend is vegan they were kind enough to tip her off about asking for vegan butter since the toast usually comes pre-buttered. The scramble could have had more flavor and pizazz to it, for sure. The potatoes and veggies were great but I think marinating the tofu or throwing some spices on it would have really kicked things up a notch. 

On the sweet side, I had the vegan pancakes with strawberries and I can honestly say they were the best vegan pancakes I've ever had. They stood up to your standard pancake and were clearly made with love! 

I can't wait to go back and try more from the menu, and I love that they have plenty of vegan options without sacrificing diner favorites and classics. They've got something for everyone!
author: Alex K.

description:
My sister and I met for breakfast one morning while I was out and about making sales calls for work.  I got the best front parking spot.  So come early!

The neighborhood is, how you say, interesting?  Even that early in the morning I had some concerns.  Definitely hide your valuables.

Its a page straight out of an old school diner in here.  I could imagine coming here during the 50's,  We got a nice little booth in the back of the restaurant.  We ordered a round of coffees and sat and talked.  It wasn't too busy and the staff kept everyone moving.

I ordered the Biscuits and Gravy with a side of two eggs over easy.  The Biscuits were not your normal flaky fluffy buttery biscuits.  They were like wheat or something.  I cant confirm that exactly but it was not what I expected.  The Gravy was ok.  Very chunky.  More chunk than gravy.  It was ok, but it was a twist on the usual biscuits and country gravy.  

If I have a chance to come back I would but I think I'd go with something different next time.
author: Ivy R.

description:
Had a tuna melt on sourdough-grilled crisply without being hella greasy. Hit the spot! Then felt bloated afterwards lol
It seems to be like a Mel's. I would come again to try something else when in a diner mood.
author: Summer S.

description:
I came here on a Saturday morning with my mom after I heard you could get vegan brunch here even though overall it was a non-vegan place. 

First of all, I thought this place was going to be a little more upscale, but found out instead that it's a dive that's been around for a very long time. While the menu had a few vegan options, it seems to cater more to vegetarians than to vegans. I didn't actually see too many clearly marked vegan dishes and felt that I had to scan the menu a bit to see what I could actually order. 

I decided on the vegan blueberry pancakes and thought they were okay, but not worth coming back for. I'm pretty sure I could make something equally good at home if I tried. My mom isn't vegan, so got a standard breakfast of eggs, fried potatoes, and toast. She seemed fairly satisfied with her breakfast, so maybe this place is a-okay for omnivores. On the plus side, I thought the prices were reasonable and appreciated not getting ripped off. 

Overall, I won't come back unless they create a separate vegan menu and up their game on quality.
author: Regina W.

description:
Whenever I come to San Francisco, somehow, some way, I wind up at St. Francis Fountain on at least one morning. It's a place I've spent so, so many mornings - usually suffering the effects of outrageous nights on the town - and every time SFF has been there for me with welcoming hot coffee, super kind servers, and mountains of greasy bacon.

It's a classic diner, and it's been in this location in one form or another for a long, long time and is one of the places that's maintained a lot of the original history and feel of the place. It's a place that not only has been good to me, but has always been there and been good to me time and time again for years :)

Portions are good, prices are decent, the menu has a great variety of food from breakfast staples (and not-so-staples) on through greasy-spoon burgers and shakes and malts.
author: Noah H.

description: Came here for their vegan-friendly brunch options. Food was good but service was BAD! One of our servers was a total sourpuss with an attitude. She was clearly stressed by the Sunday brunch crowd and was very unpleasant when addressing our questions. I was also dying of thirst throughout our meal as we weren't offered any water refills until we had finished.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Keeping it short and sweet....

I liked my biscuit and gravy and my friend liked his vegetarian chili. As he put it, it's a rarity to find a good tasting vegetarian chili 

As for my other two friends they chose poorly and were not fans of their dishes (veg chorizo and corn beef hash). I tried both and agreed, the chorizo was too sweet and not enough heat/savory elements. As for the hash, it was cut up too fine and had no seasoning

Seating is tight and wait time can be long 

Overall Thoughts

Wouldn't go out of my way to go back to St Francis but wouldn't steer people away either
author: Eddie W.

description:
I can't reasonably call this place average - I've had better meals at Denny's.  Hence the two stars.

My first visit was for breakfast.  We had a large spread of different items and they were all pretty lackluster, with the biscuits and gravy being actively bad - extremely hard biscuits and very unpleasant gravy.  

I was ready to write St. Francis Fountain off, but when I saw that they were one of the few places open offering a tuna melt sandwich on the day I was craving it, we went back for a late lunch.

Mistake.

The tuna melt and accompanying fries were awful.  The tuna was super dry and there was hardly enough cheese.  Plus, it was mostly hardened once it reached the table.  Oh, and the tomato slices even managed to be bland.  The french fries were revolting.  See attached photos.  They looked as though they were fried and then refried in old, stanky oil....and then let to sit out for....some time.

My boyfriend's meal was no better.  His french toast tasted totally of salted butter - so much so that it overpowered the maple syrup, which is hard to do.

I realize this review sounds pretty dire, but I think the place is cute and service is quick and I'm sure their ice cream sundaes are enjoyable, so maybe just come here for the dessert...

P.S. They have an inexplicable policy of ending outdoor seating TWO HOURS before they close (maybe three, but definitely no less than two).  This was hugely disappointing to us, as we brought our dog and I was very freaked out to tie him up outside (even though we literally sat on the opposite side of the window).  I really can't explain why anyone would have this type of policy, and even though we didn't make a stink when they informed us that we couldn't sit outside (literally just "oh, ok"), the waiter told us repeatedly and even went so far as to suggest we "remember this for next time." Very bizarre...especially since another couple with a dog was sitting at one of those tables when we arrived, at least an hour after that supposedly ended.
author: Tay H.

description:
I've come here twice now... both on a weekend around brunch time. I love that this diner has vegan breakfast! And good vegan breakfast. 

My husband and I always order the tofu scramble with vegan soyrizo, spinach, mushrooms and chives. It's always delicious. Their house breakfast potatoes are always perfectly seasoned and crisp on the bottom and edges. We also split a short stack of vegan banana walnut pancakes. I love that also, especially with the hint of cinnamon in it. It's great they give us soy milk with our coffee and vegan butter for our toast and pancakes. 

The service is great, the people that work here have always been accommodating and friendly. If you're looking for a good breakfast joint for carnivores and herbivores, this is the place for you.
author: Reese E.

description:
Food: WORTH IT.

My friends and I used to go to this other AMAZING brunch spot that experienced a fire and hasn't opened up over 1+ years since :( so we're doing our due diligence to find a comparable "replacement" (in our stomachs, not our hearts) to bring back the brunch bash. All I need in life is eggs bennie and finally, we've found a worthy opponent.

This place serves up an awesome Weekend Benedict Specials with various toppings--my go to is Bacon (chopped thick cut) and Avocado (fresh and plentiful) which is DELICIOUS--for ~$13.50 (your usual SF prices...). It comes with your choice of Fruit or Potatoes (the shredded then fried flat kind, not cubed or roasted.) You can also add bottomless coffee and a Champagne Drink (mimosas!) or Large OJ for $4. They also have 3-4 other types of champagne "mimosas" and a large menu of Egg breakfasts, omlettes, french toasts, and tons of other carnivous, herbavorious, and vegan options. Great for the diverse group of friends!

Came on a Sunday and there was a couple other groups in front of us--someone hunching near the door said they were me and took my table :( but the server was quick to fix that. There's actually 2 food sections and an outdoor section but they might've been short staffed because service was really slow (-1 star) and only half of the inside tables were full.

However, this is the next best thing for my friends and I at the moment so we'll be back for those bennies! Don't you dare leave us hanging!!!
author: Nerissa C.

description:
Cool little place,  vintage feel to it... didn't try the fountain drinks but i should have. Came in and we were immediately seated.  Customer service was excellent, the guy that helped us was super friendly and made u feel right at home. 
Started off with the french toast, Chef's mess, and, Fried egg sammich.
 The toast was killer, TONS of fresh fruit, granola,  whip cream,all the goods... 
The fried egg sammich... was a fried egg sammich...everything was good but nothing extra...
Chef's mess was a whole bunch of everything omelet, with way to many things to list but it was tasty... it was definitely a great way to start a busy morning. 
Everything has a old school feel including the meals which are built for hearty people. The portions are generous and delicious. Service was excellent. I'd definitely recommend this place to anyone.
author: D I.

description: Good value on a very nice meal. Clean, friendly, quaint, good. Nicely prepared, clean bathroom, booths a little uncomfortable but average.
author: Big D.

description:
Came here on a Saturday morning around 9:15. Le bf and I were promptly seated in a booth. 

We always study the menu before going to a place, and this time was no different. We read on Yelp that the pancakes were good so we knew we had to get them. Le bf also enjoys his biscuits and gravy so we knew we needed to get those as well. I was contemplating a milkshake the night before we went, but decided against it once we were there.

The pancakes were really good. Would highly recommend them. I got mine as part of the pancakes+2 eggs+spuds. I like my spuds extra crispy, and they delivered. The spuds weren't the hash brown type of spuds. These were more like country fried potatoes that were spiced and had onions in them. Very, very goodd. Le bf "thinged" his spuds, and that was a good call. I regret not "thinging" my spuds. When you "thing" spuds, they add cheese, scallion, salsa, and sour cream on top. The biscuits and gravy were really good, although Pork Store Cafe's are still better. He got his eggs poached and they were poached perfectly. Total price was under $30 before tip which is great for SF. 

This place has a lot of character and the staff were super nice and provided excellent service. We will be back. Next time, I will get my milkshake.
author: Carolyn Z.

description: I love this place and have been coming for years but I feel with the menu change there are less vegan options. No sandwiches are vegan unless you ask for modifications, like the vegan burger but you have to ask for no mayo and no cheese. Or the Oh Hell, but you have to ask for no aioli or cheese. Do the vegan pancakes still come with vegan butter? I'm bummed the sausage Patty is gone and now just a dinner style link is available.   our server today was super nice but didn't have all the answers, I felt bad asking for so many edits. Please please please, add a few straight vegan sandwiches and breakfast items, and maybe another salad dressing option. We love you and want to keep coming back. PS we always have awesome service and the vibe here is great too. Vegetarians and meat eaters I'm sure you will love it. Just a little tricky now for vegans.
author: Heather B.

description:
Cute diner with some decent vegan options. If you're looking for a vegan breakfast in the hood, look no further. I'm a plant based meat and potatoes kind of girl so I was definitely happy to see several sandwiches on the menu. The soyrizo hash was yummy, and I think my omni friends would like it too. Loaded with potatoes and seitan, it makes for a great combo with your breakfast. 
No frills, fast service, delish vegan food. I'm sold. Will be back asap thanks for feeding these hungry vegans :)
author: Jennifer A.

description:
An old-school diner with lots of vegan options? Let's go!

I was amazed by the sheer number of vegetarian and vegan options offered at St. Francis Fountain. They have tofu scrambles, vegan chorizo hash, vegan pancakes, vegan sausage patties, veggie chili, garden burgers and seitan melts! They even have veganaise and Earth Balance Buttery Spread.

I ordered the vegan blueberry pancakes with a side of vegan chorizo hash. The pancakes are more dense and chewy than your typical buttermilk variety. This is neither better nor worse, just different. They were bursting with blueberries, which was a treat. The vegan chorizo hash is quite oily (as hash often is), but it's quite tasty. They served it with the Earth Balance spread, which I had never tried before. It's pretty similar to a salted, whipped butter.

My partner ordered the Polar Melt on light rye. The seitan is well seasoned. If you like patty melts and the like, this is a great veggie option (it came with jack cheese, which you can probably leave off it you want to go vegan). It's one of the best melts I've tasted in a long time!

They carry Mitchell's ice cream and La Copa Loca gelato for desserts and fountain drinks. They also have vanilla soy as a non-dairy option. We didn't try any of these since we were so full from our meals. Maybe next time.

Their brewed coffee is pleasantly strong and their staff is quite friendly. Combined with a big, tasty meal, it's hard to leave without a smile on your face. It's not the healthiest place to eat (it is an old-school diner after all!), but the veggie and vegan options really show how almost every other restaurant out there is really dropping the ball when it comes to plant-based dining!
author: Ed M.

description:
Counter-Culture

Two words: Vegan Thing 

We try to hit up this old-timey diner every time we're in town.

Situated in the ever-gentrifying Mission district, (the neighborhood used to feel more edgy) the place is a slightly grungy, cool-as-shit spot to enjoy a hearty breakfast. 

It expanded years ago, so snagging a table isn't as tough as it once was. 

The coffee is your typical diner brew. 
The food offerings are suitable for almost anyone's dietary needs. Vegans, vegetarians, and omnivorous are happily commingling. 

I've tried a few things over the years but the Vegan Thing aka: Gut Bomb is my favorite. It's enough food to hold you over until dinner and give you the strength to climb those San Francisco hills. 

The pancakes don't suck. 

The restroom situation isn't pretty. If they offer to sit you in a booth next to the restroom, politely decline and wait for another spot to open up. 

Service has always been spot on.

If you're in the neighborhood, I might suggest you check out the (debated) crookedest street in San Francisco, (possibly the nation's) located on Vermont Street between 20th and 22nd Streets. It's a 15 minute walk from the St. Francis. 
The same neighborhood (Potrero Hill,) was used in the film 1990 thriller, Pacific Heights. 

Bon appétit
author: Brian D.

description:
This place is so good! Really friendly staff, excellent food, cute diner vibes... I love it. They have really good vegan options too: I love the banana-walnut vegan pancakes (which come with *vegan* butter!), the tofu rancheros, and the vegan nebulous potato thing. They have non-vegan stuff too and I'm sure it's good as well.

Portions are very filling and you will leave here satisfied and happy.
author: Morgane M.

description: Amazing place for vegans and veggies! Vegan pancakes, vegan butter, vegan sausage, vegan cheese, vegan ice cream!!!!!! All the best items for a great vegan brunch in the city! Can't wait to go back! Oh & they have mimosas .... !! Thank you for having options for us, and for your amazing staff!
author: Kelly W.

description:
Admittedly my perspective on the St. Francis Fountain will differ from most of you...

Recently I found myself in the place for the first time in around 35 years.  It was surreal in that the place pretty much looked the same including the booths but alas it was only a caricature of what it once was...

It is nice young people took over the place and preserved it BUT alas it is a lot less than it was. The reason I had not been in there for 35 years has to do with location.  Although I have been here in SF a very long time I don't get to every corner of the city and until recently had no reason to visit 24th street.

It is a rather odd feeling when you are in a place that feels familiar down to the correct old booths but you can't order the old 49er special which was trademark of the place.  Supposedly the long gone special is what the local businessman who got the 49ers going in San Francisco so very long ago ate in the back booths when they were considering their options.  If I recall correctly it was something like  1/2 of a grilled cheese and  1/2 of a club sandwich.  With most of the kids infesting this place parents probably not yet conceived I doubt any of the 30-40 folks in the place when I was there having breakfast have a clue about it.  We're talking old time San Francisco grub - legendary grub which is sadly lacking from the place.

Being an old fart, it is nice to see respectful hard-working young wait staff and I'll give them 10 stars for their efforts (even thought I did not get the 10% Senior Discount). The service was fast and friendly which is refreshing.

Sorry to say the food was pretty tasteless due in my opinion to trying to be too many things at once.  I had hoped for a classic breakfast from the old days but it was not in the offerings.  Instead was a mishmash of things trying to mix Latino inspired and classic American breakfast at once which vaguely tasted like an enchilada with cheap sauce and a dash of a classic breakfast.  If I want a classic Latino breakfast I can get one which has flavors which sing down on Geary Street for less than half of the $22 I paid for Breakfast at the St. Francis...

I'm left with the Height Street metaphor writing this.  Younger folks think hanging on the Height is reliving the Summer of Love.  They are trying to feel something now which has little if any resemblance to what happened there so long ago.  So, The St. Francis will remain a caricature of the once great place it was now full of young people making their own St. Francis Fountain reality in 2017.  There is an old saying you can never go home and this is clearly the case with the St. Francis.

I do wish I had a time machine to revisit it 35 years ago...
author: Dalt W.

description: The place is an establishment and came from an earlier generation hipsterization if the mission. But the food and drinks are quite mediocre I must say and not worth the wait. It can be for hours on weekends. But it's exactly the diner food you'd want on a Sunday to nurse a hangover for some.
author: Xiu L.

description:
I had the vegan rancheros, and they were great. Too bad they recently discontinued their nacho cheese that's in Vegan Thing and a lot of other dishes you see photos of on Yelp! 

Next time, I'll try the soy vanilla milkshake :)
author: Katherine G.

description:
I saw this place in the San Francisco Chronicle about a week ago. The article touted it as "legendary". I was taken aback because until then I'd never heard of it.

So this morning my wife and I, up for a holiday getaway,decided to check it out. When we arrived it was empty, except for a young man behind the counter named Jared.

Long story, shortened. I had a scramble. It was great. Right amount of food. Jared always kept my cup filled with coffee.  One minor negative, the booth  are super tight. There is no way more than three people could sit in it. The other choice is sit at the counter, but I hate doing that when I'm with people. 

I would recommend getting there as early as possible. 

I can't wait to go back. Watch out Dottie's, you have some competition.
author: Darryl L.

description:
I visited more recently and the food just wasn't what I remembered. They've really let it slide, and this makes me sad as it was once my favorite brunch spot in the area.

Vibe is still retro/old school cool & the service is still on point. The Chef's Mess just lost all it's flavor. Maybe the other options are currently better.

In any case it's still a cool spot.
author: Joseph B.

description:
Food:

French Toast with Blueberries - This was a sourdough French toast which I thought was ok.  I can't say it was anything to rave about really.  

Service: Staff was friendly but because it was a bit busy we did get forgotten slightly.

Ambiance:  It was a cool neighborhood diner feel to it.  Pretty hipster too.

Overall:  It was ok.  I'd probably give the pancakes a try at some point but if that's a bust then I won't return.
author: Spencer Q.

description:
Pretty good, pretty good. I've come by a few times and been turned away by the long wait. This past weekend, the line wasn't too long so we got in quickly.

St Francis has a nice old-timey diner feel to it, and there's a large variety of options on the menu. A friend suggested the banana bread, and I made the mistake of getting cornbread instead. Don't get me wrong, the cornbread was still good! But his banana bread was better. Live and learn.

My bacon, cheddar, and green onion scramble was pretty good, and the side of potatoes added to the heartiness. My knock is the time it took before the waiter came around to take our order. I hear it's an anomaly though, so maybe they'll get 5 stars if they're faster next time!
author: Nikhil S.

description:
I've visited St. Francis Fountain for a few years now, and it's become a frequent lunch spot when I'm working in the area.  It's my go-to, solid option when I'm looking for diner food.

I usually stick to getting sandwiches or getting breakfast/brunch food.  I've tried both their BLT and chicken club, and both were filling, tasty, and well-made.  I often get the french fries as a side, and they never disappoint.  Most recently, I tried their hotcakes, even though I only got 2, I was beyond stuffed. (It probably didn't help that I got one of their fabulous milkshakes, and I love that they have an option where you can blend fruit into the shake.  Try the pineapple!)

There's definitely a hipster ambience, which may be a bother to some if you think "hipster" is a 4-letter word.  However, I've always found the staff friendly and welcoming, and it has a quaint, old-school diner vibe.  You should definitely visit!
author: Keith H.

description:
St. Francis Fountain is my favorite diner in the city. The decor offers a sense of nostalgia. For example, there is borax soap in the bathroom. The waitstaff is generally pleasant, especially Carlos. He's the man! 

There are plenty of vegetarian options. On a nice day, it's great to sit outside. The tofu scramble is my favorite and the milkshakes are all great!
author: Rishi S.

description:
Cutesy diner atmosphere with very hip and young staff -- they were nice, but the place was definitely understaffed for a Sunday brunch. I definitely enjoyed the food here, but the wait was long and somewhat convoluted. Really convenient location on 24th Street, just a 10-15 minute walk from the BART. I live just steps away from this place, so I'll be back, but maybe not when it's so busy. 

Our wait experience: The guy calling names out didn't try very hard, so you had to be leaning in on your tippy toes to hear if he called your name. Oftentimes people would leave and come back after their name had already been called, and they would have to talk to the host about putting their name back where it was before. Overall, it was a slight roller coaster of emotions before we even got seated. It took about 45 minutes to get seated, though he gave us an estimate of 20 minutes (we arrived at 11:15am). 

Our pre-dining experience: They were obviously busy; our host plopped menus down on our table and our server took about 15 minutes to take our order (he acknowledged us every so often, so I couldn't be too mad). A lady came around serving coffee, and before we could say no, she started pouring for us -- we were a little taken aback by this. 

THE FOOD: Fortunately, the food was delicious. I ordered the corned beef hash with over-medium eggs. Everything was rich, flavorful, and cooked to perfection. Decent portion size too, which was expected but appreciated from this diner establishment. They do have plenty of vegan and vegetarian options here if that's your thang. 

Protip: If you're a larger person, I'd recommend sitting at the bar -- the booths are quite small.
author: Christine L.

description:
Looking for a place to have breakfast for a vegan and non-vegan? THIS is the place! After Herbivore closed its last location, my boyfriend (vegan) was devastated. It's one of the only places we always go to when visiting San Francisco, which is often. After searching around, we found St Francis on Yelp and decided to give it a try. There was a short line outside the door but it was only a 15-20 min wait and it was well worth it.
They had several vegan options including a vegan pesto scramble the boyfriend got and loved. I had the eggs benedict and they were delicious. Long story short, we went back the next day and I know we will definitely be back on our next SF trip.
author: Ellie V.

description:
No wait for six of us around 1pm on a Saturday! At first we were split between a booth and a couple seats at the bar. After a few minutes, we were all able to sit together at the bar.

They did mess up a couple of our orders and were a little slow to get them out, but we did end up with a free scoop of mint chocolate chip ice cream! You can also personalize whether you want ice cream or cream on top of your floats, and what topping to get on your banana split (caramel, chocolate, etc). 

The ice cream is not my favorite in the city, could be more creamy, but it's still good.

FOUNTAIN CLASSICS
* Dreamsicle (milk, oj, vanilla syrup, vanilla ice cream, orange sherbet, whipped cream, cherry. $5.75) - 4 stars
Tasty, thick, not too sweet! Like an orange soda with vanilla.

* Guiness Float ($7.25) - 4 stars
My boyfriend really liked this!

We also got a banana split in the group. This was a monster of a dish, delicious!
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Reverse bias, bigotry and racism Or just pretentious hypocrisy? 
(Read the end of the message so you can conclude for yourself)

This is a true record of the events as they occurred.

After a short early morning SFGH hospital visit which I was required fasting, as In no food I walked down 24th St. and thought out treat myself to a nice breakfast.

I walked into St. Francis fountain which was sparsely occupied sat down (seat yourself) at the diner bar. I was not given a menu card and had to ask twice for it. After a brief while I saw and grabbed the menu card that was lying a few seats down on the diner bar. 

A waitress whizzed by few times but I was unable to get her attention or a simple few word response. After about 10 minutes I leaned over a little from my stool and said: "Could I have some coffee please". 
No reaction, no response as if I was surrounded by blind deaf mutes. In my third attempt asking for coffee, I finally got heard and got a cup of coffee.

But nothing much else happened. I tried to get the attention of another diner bartender but he seemed to be "not seeing me". Finally was able to get the attention of a waitress which promised me she'll be right with me. But, that never happened either.

Having made my choice for breakfast, I mentioned upon receiving the coffee that I'd like to order XYZ  from the menu. To my astonishment, I was not heard.

So I sat there with my coffee trying to get the attention of the person behind the diner bar or the waitress. However, despite the sparsely populated restaurant it appeared that all waiters were extremely busy when it came to me trying to getting their attention.

Another attempt failed, I was not heard but I was ignored. The ignoring continued and I started to notice that a man that came in after me and sat several seats down from me got recognized right away, placed his order and received is breakfast within about five minutes.
Hmm...

Still trying to get the attention of the waitress or diner bar waiter I noticed a couple coming in and sitting down. Right away they got service, ordered the food and again within about five minutes got their food.
hmm... hmm...

I made one final last attempt to get the attention to what my breakfast but I was ignored as if I were the invisible man.

I finally I had it, got up walked upfront to the cash register and said: "I want to pay for coffee and would like to know why I am being ignored, sitting here for almost  1/2 an hour and people coming in after me are being served. Did I offend anyone? " 

The reply was: "It's okay, you don't have to pay for the coffee, have a nice day." 
I said: "Thanks, but I ordered the coffee and of course I want to pay for it but I just like to know why no one would take my breakfast order as I'm here for over an hour and I noticed people Coming in after me getting served fairly swiftly."

Again the reply was (irrelevant to my question):  ...The coffee is on the house, just have a nice day, goodbye."
One could say that that reply was basically falling short of saying "please leave the premises" so obvious it was.

So anyone who reads this tell me now why? What did I do wrong?
I was formal friendly, nicely dressed, patient and with a calm voice...
What possible offense could I have done to be treated like that?
I have no clue.

When I left the establishment and walked out I looked one more time back through the window and saw briefly in the window a reflection of myself:

Tall, white-haired, fit white male, dressed in brown leather shoes, beige slacks, a blue blazer, a white shirt two button open at the collar and a red, neutral with no advertising or any label of sorts baseball cap on my head.

And then it dawned on me!

Those employees there are in my opinion the bottom end of lowlife presumptuous and judgmental bigots lower than pond scum.  
The reason I'm saying it is that from their behavior they likely were making a judgment based on my race, age and the way I was dressed (which coincidentally happened to be similar to what the current president was dressed like during campaigning Although I dressed like that years before that man appeared like that And can prove it with a family snapshot taken years ago)

The fact that I'm tall, a white male and dressed evidently and obviously a little better than all those drab, somewhat raggedy dressed down around me folks has absolutely nothing to do with my true persona, character and behavior.

So much for open-mindedness, fairness and equality as once again those who preach the most, practice the least and are the most intolerant themselves!
author: The N.

description:
St. Francis is nothing if not consistent. It's consistently Just Okay all around. The interior design is quaint, and they sell vintage candies and toys, and their signage is reminiscent of a 50's diner (fitting considering the location has been a neighborhood staple since 1918). 

I remember when it was purchased in the early 2000's how nervous we were that it would be razed or turned into a gentrified tech-heavy faux-diner, and I'm stoked they kept the same vibe. The service is consistently fine, the food is consistently mediocre, the servings consistently generous.
author: Tessa M.

description: I was visiting a friend on a long layover, and he suggested St. Francis Fountain. It was a busy brunch hour on Sunday, but they got us in within 15 minutes. It took a little bit to get food service, but that's okay, because we were enjoying our drinks and good company. The chef's mess was amazing, and Guinness floats are a thing! Unique fare and pretty cheap compared to what I was thinking an SF breakfast would cost.
author: Erica S.

description:
Such good brunch! Lots and lots of food choices. I will make it a point to come back to this place during my next visit. There were 6 of us brunching on a Sunday and everybody was very pleased! 
Loooove this place, what a great discover!
author: Eva M.

description: There was a crowd outside when we arrived. We were told the wait was about 10-15 min for a party of 5 over the phone. When we saw the crowds of people waiting outside, I can tell that my bf's mother was a bit anxious Bc she had work too. Luckily, you can see that they were moving along fast tho. We got seated within 30 min. by 12:15pm. We ordered by 12:20pm and we was served our food by 12:40 and we were out of there by 1pm. I guess we eat fast lol. We all enjoyed our food. I ordered the vegan hash and added avocado and rancheros sauce to it and it was amaze balls!!!!!! I thought the place would have had more vegan options but I was still very happy with the vegan hash. It was actually on the sides menu tho, so I kind of had to put my meal together. I also had the vegan banana and walnut pancakes, which were fantastic!!!
author: Melissa P.

description:
Amazing weekend brunch. The eggs Benedict are never over cooked and the floats and shakes are very good. 

Brunch seating is a bit annoying. Sometimes they do not have the kitchen or wait staff to have all tables full in both rooms so you wait outside looking at empty tables (at least I assume that is the issue as it is so common). Once seated there can be a bit of a wait again. Not for those in a rush. 

However the food is great and the staff are very good once you start ordering. I appreciate that twice they have not served guacamole or avocado because of last summers avocado shortage. Far better than the places that gave you gross avocado.  The staff is happy to make alterations for picky kids and always keeps your coffee full. 

Never been here for dinner but the sandwich I had once for lunch was as good as their brunch food.
author: Julia S.

description:
This place never disappoints. This place has amazing brunch and sweets all in an a 1950s style decor. You can also see collectably candy and bubblegum card in a case.  I used to live closeby and made sure to bring my friends from out of town here. 
Now that I no longer live here I made it a point to bring my bf here when we came to SF on vacation. He now knows what I meant about how amazing this place is. The egg scrambles are delicious as are smashed country potatoes. The pancakes are rockin and the ice cream is devine. A must visit place for anyone coming to San Francisco.
author: Marlene S.

description: Service was good.  I have always loved this place but this last visit was a bit disappointing.  The corned beef hash consisted of bits of corned beef with loads of potatoes.  Should've been called breakfast potatoes with bits of corned beef.  The waiter was kind though and brought a plate of corned beef.  "Thing" fries are listed on the menu at $2.75.  It's a bit deceiving because they actually cost $6.  However the $2.75 price is listed in larger font with a box around it.  When I pointed it out to the waitress she wasn't sure either and had another waiter come over and explain it.  Very deceiving and they still charged me $6.
author: Lisa E.

description:
When you are a sad vegan because you can't get "normal" breakfast anywhere, come here to get your world rocked! Amazing pancakes, potatoes and vegan sausage patties. You don't need to eat an overpriced fruit bowl with black coffee here!

Worth the wait!!

EDIT: Knocking off two stars since I found out after coming back the French toast is not vegan, which was what we were told.
author: Katie B.

description:
Hands down the best banana walnut pancakes I've had in my life! These were so good and deliciously perfect! Plus it comes with a side of eggs (the spinach feta is my fav) and some fruits !
Refill on coffee free
What more can you want ? Oh and the staff are super nice!
author: Balqis A.

description: I've only tried the buster brown ($7.25), an ice cream sundae with warm fudge brownie, vanilla ice cream, raspberry sauce, whipped cream, and walnuts. The portion size was generous, and it was rich, decadent, and delicious. There's a cute little park across the street if you want to sit and eat outside.
author: Elaine L.

description:
Fun, funky, genuinely historic- a very nice combo. Add much better than average diner food and a commitment to serving disabled patrons (I'm on wheels) and it's as good as SF gets. 

I had a Mexican omelette - very nice - and coffee that was strong without the excessive burnt-bitterness fashionable of late. I'll be back.
author: Ruth A.

description: This cute little place! My milkshake was made by the "Shake Master", who was beyond adorable. The best food is in the mission, and this is definitely true here!
author: Becky F.

description: They had vegan banana pancakes that I liked!  And I also got a scramble and added soyrizo, yum!
author: Laure D.

description: One of my favorite breakfast places. Get there early if you don't want to wait on the weekend. Great for meat eaters and vegan/vegetarians too. This is so helpful to me because we have a blended family. Service is always prompt and attentive.
author: max k.

description: I love this place. The line's never too long, the eggs Benedict are always well done: I've only had one firm yoke in 5 years of eating here at least monthly. Mimosas are $4.75, and in a real glass instead of a BS Champaign flute, and they make them well (strong). Other highlights of the menu: their homemade banana bread, the corned beef hash, and the chefs mess are all great.
author: Thomas R.

description:
I love this place it's a total classic. Their milkshakes are rich and delicious and their breakfasts are filling, tasty, and well priced. 

Yesterday I had the best corned beef has I've ever had. It was so tasty. The potatoes were perfectly done, the onions and peppers were soft and richly flavored, the meat had little crispy bits. I will definitely be getting this next time. 

Their Huevos rancheros are  also really good another crowd favorite. They have an interesting and delicious savory pancake too that my friend declared his new favorite item on their menu. 

If you're looking for a no frills brunch spot with local flair, st. Francis is the place!
author: Sam L.

description: I don't know why I keep giving this place chances. I'm always disappointed and frustrated. Waited for 20 minutes for someone to take my order and when they finally did they had run out of what I wanted. Never again.
author: Haley T.

description:
Worth coming for the soda fountain atmosphere.

FOOD: I have never eaten anything here I have liked. The sourdough french toast is off-putting in how sour it is. The hash was too greasy for my liking. I could buy better huevos rancheros a couple doors down in either direction. 
- I do appreciate there are vegetarian and vegan options. 
- Ice cream is no longer homemade--though they do make an effort to pick local brands like La Copa Loca or Mitchell's. 
- Price point is what I find ridiculous relative to what I'm getting. I'd feel more satisfied if "cute immersive experience" were a line item on the bill. 

SERVICE: Perfectly polite. It is of course busy in the morning, and I am impressed by how the servers keep their cool in the middle of it. Very easy to go in and buy something from the candy counter if you're not there to stay for the immersive fountain experience.

AMBIANCE: Adorable. Enter the soda fountain of decades ago, with cheery decor, classic candies (Pixie sticks, ring pops), and old school aluminum and felt letterboard with dessert choices :). The kind of place where you want to buy a milkshake in your poodle skirt and ask for two straws to share with a girl :). Let's be clear though--there are no poodle skirts here. It's all about that Mission hipster/grunge look. Seating is limited in the main room but expandable--you need to add your name to a board to be seated, so come on the earlier side if you're a group and enjoy a walk around a vibrant neighborhood pre-meal!
author: Helen W.

description:
'Nebulous Potato Thing' is delicious! Pile of baked spuds, melted cheese, fresh salsa, sour cream (I subbed guac though), and chopped green onion. $5.50 for a small; $7.50 for a large. Add an egg for $2. Worth it. All the flavors blend together nicely. 

St. Francis Fountain is an old school diner. You'll get seated quicker if you choose the counter or outdoor option. Lots of good breakfast options here, with an unique, home-comfort twist.
author: Joanna L.

description:
AMAZING BREAKFAST SPOT! 
I had the Veggie mess and it was SO tasty. I had the option of a side and chose banana bread. It came out warm and it was mouth watering. Service is super fast and friendly. They get busy so reserve a table for a party of 3 or more. Soooooo good.
author: Laura T.

description: I've been intrigued by st Francis for over ten years but had never gone in, partially since they're not open at night and partially out of wariness that the main thing is heard about was its hipster quotient. I was in for a nice surprise when I stopped by for a late weekday lunch. The employees were all exceptionally and seemingly sincerely friendly while at the same time remaining unintrusive during my lunchtime reading. My grilled cheese arrived quickly and the fries especially were delicious and tasted homemade. And I had the rare experience of receiving a check that was a lot lower than I'd been anticipating! All in all, it felt like a true diner experience in a way that I find rare in the city.
author: Lisa K.

description:
I came here Sunday morning around 8:30am and the crowd was very light. I sat at the bar and the waiter was right on it taking my order. I had the vegan rancheros and vegan pancakes..both dishes to DIE FOR!!! 
Great service, prices and nice classic location.
I'll be back!
author: David R.

description: Good food and service. I had the veggie thing and Pancakes. I would go again. Sorry I can't write too much on the subject. I just feel it was good and not incredible or memorable. I do recommend it. Go forth and do good things.
author: Edward M.

description:
I love that they serve breakfast during lunch and I can get a milk shake for breakfast. They also have a Guinness float! I usually go there for lunch when I'm at work. Parking is not bad, street parking. 

They have these old school collectible cards like garbage pail kids... old school candies too.
author: Eugenia W.

description: Was recommended to try this place for breakfast...and was not disappointed! The staff were friendly and attentive. They serve great coffee, and of course the food was delicious! We had the combo, with French toast, eggs & a side. It was the best French toast I'd had in awhile, so was pleasantly surprised. Also, this restaurant is very cute, with wooden booth seating. Definitely worth checking out if in the area :-)
author: Amy O.

description: This is a great place.  Wonderful traditional breakfasts with some interesting twists.  Good service, and while not inexpensive, in the SF context, especially the Mission, not too outrageous.  There are some vegan and vegetarian options, and I see a lot of complaints on Yelp from vegans, but c'mon - it's a 50's style diner that's been open 99 years.  Do you really expect it to be a vegan haven?  I swear, in SF Speak, Vegan translates into, "listen to me whine".  They give it a try to have something for everyone, but leave them alone when they don't meet your all-veggie menu standards, Princess.  The Chef's Mess is awesome and the eggs benedict is tasty also.  I'll have to stop in and try a shake sometime.  The street parking is ok in the mornings, but gets worse and worse throughout the day
author: Ken P.

description:
This place is amazing! Super cute and funky. The perfect mix of nostalgia and hipness. From the moment I walked in, I loved this place, with its wooden booths and candy counter and old menu items hung on the wall as decoration (the pineapple and cream cheese salad sign is hilarious!).

The service is super friendly. We walked in and were immediately seated (though that was before 10 am. By the time we left shortly after 10, the place was pretty packed) and given water and coffee. Two servers were handling tables, expediting food, taking orders and checking refills, and they were very attentive. Even when most of the booths were filled, our coffee cups were never empty.

And the food is AMAZING. It's what you only dream diner food can be. The sourdough french toast is absolutely the perfect balance of sweetness tempered by sourdough tartness. The eggs are great and the potatoes are salty and delicious and addicting. My only regret is that I got full and couldn't eat more!

Definitely check this place out!
author: Victoria B.

description: Went here for a late brunch on a Saturday. I'm a vegetarian and the yelp reviews was what got me here. We had a 20 minute wait before we were seated. The place has s very hipster diner feel. The server was very accommodating of my dietary needs. The best part about the menu is they have a lot of vegetarian options other than the typical pancakes and waffles. We ordered the buttermilk pancakes with strawberry, a veggie mess replacing the egg with tofu and a vegan chili bowl. The pancakes even though good were the last impressive of the lot. The bowl of chili came with the most delicious cornbread I've eaten. The vegetarian mess was a winner as well. This is definitely going to be a regular spot for me when I'm craving a hearty brunch.
author: Jeel J.

description: THANK YOU FOR HAVING VEGAN OPTIONS! This place is amazing! My friends and I all loved everything we got! Will definitely be back!
author: Lindsay M.

description:
It was 12pm on a Friday and I had a sudden craving for milkshake....so I headed over to St. Francis.

Like any typical diner, this place has the sandwiches, burgers, fries, and most importantly MILKSHAKE. They had the classic, then the ONES made with MITCHELL's ice cream! I obviously got the mitchell's ice cream shake, and it was bomb diggity!

As for my entree, I had the Modesto Pesto with grilled chicken, tomato, red onion & pesto and additional avocado. What can I say, i'm an addict for avocado. Chicken WAS grilled just right. The sandwich was DARN good, I devoured the whole thing before my stomach told me I was full! They also gave a huge portion of fries, which I shamelessly finished too. 

Best of all, it was decently priced! I'm stroked this is walking distance from my work AND can't wait to DRINK more milkshakes!
author: Josie H.

description: Not the greatest but far from bad. The coffee wasn't awful, the food was a bit too basic but we (admittedly) didn't get milkshakes or typical soda fountain food. We may return if were in the area but won't travel again.
author: Kyle V.

description: Cute little diner that makes you feel like you stepped back into the 70's. Old feeling does make the place appear unkempt but the service is great and potions are big. Fun location to walk around after and see lot of street art.
author: Cassie J.

description:
This place is awesome! Obviously came from the Yelp reviews and hype and I must say it's worth it. I got the banana walnut pancakes (vegan) and they were delicious. My friend got the blueberry pancakes which she also loved. 
A little upset though because I wanted to try the "Vegan Thing" but realized it want on their menu when I went. although when I asked, they did have it, but they did not have the guacamole so I decided to pass. 
Customer service was great and we waited probably 15 minutes for a spot on a Sunday morning. I would definitely come again!
author: Cynthia R.

description:
You would be stupid to pass up any of their weekend Benedict special. It's one of those local treasures that makes you value local eateries. 

We came with our dog, and had a wonderful table outside. We were even offered water for our dog, SUPER PLUS. 

THe bitch next to us was the only problem....so I obviously can't dock the restaurant for that. 

I will never, ever, EVER, eat at a Denny's/IHOP because restaurants like this exist.
author: Jackie Z.

description:
Overall: Great little neighborhood spot with all the typical and delicious diner foods you need along with a friendly vibe. Lives up to the hype.

The good: Very friendly service that was attentive and fast. Food is solid (not very healthy but it's a diner). Good sized portions. Atmosphere is great, old school that is homey and reminiscent of the good old days. Pretty cheap prices

The bad: Small amount of seating, especially with more than 4. Not a huge menu to choose from. 

Atmosphere: 9/10
Service: 9/10
Food: 9/10
author: Kyle D.

description: Really excellent service and I enjoyed the food! Nothing fancy, very small inside with no a/c but the service and food was worth the slight discomfort. Vegan food was excellent and our server knew what was vegan and what wasn't which is kinda rare lol. Omni's in the group liked their burgers too.
author: Anahi B.

description: This place is not just a quaint spot to travel back in time. The food and service are great. Great vegan and vegetarian options. I had the veggie Ruben. It was great. The pancakes are also delicious.
author: Guillermo M.

description: Was in SF for business and tried this spot because of its vegan options. The banana walnut pancakes had everything right and nothing wrong! I also ordered the vegan chorizo as a side. It was pretty good. Food sizes are super generous and the service was quick and friendly. Highly recommend! Go early and avoid the crowds especially on the weekend
author: Katie R.

description:
I can see the appeal and old school, retro charm to this place being established in 1918. But my recent visit did not leave a smile on my face which is normal after visiting a ice cream establishment.

I ordered a hot fudge sundae and it was hardly a sundae more of a hot fudge debacle. It literally had 1 scoop of vanilla ice cream and was served in a thick glass cup that didn't proportionately do justice to the ice cream. They serve Mitchell's ice cream which is aright but nothing special to me. What made it worse was the price for this sundae was $6.00. I could have gotten just a scoop or two for that price else where. 

I like the feel of St Francis Fountain but not the ice cream. There is something about a place that makes there own ice cream compared to others that don't. But I can't complain, this place has been around for quite some time. My search continues for the third best ice cream spot in S.F. Stay tuned...
author: James H.

description:
My mouth is watering just thinking about the Devil's Burger I ordered today at St. Francis Fountain.  The Devil's Burger is not actually a burger but a pile of paper-thin sliced marinated and grilled seitan on burger buns.  It was the best seitan I've ever had and almost tasted like pastrami.  I added grilled onions and avocado to my sandwich it was really one of the best sandwiches I've had in a long time!

My friends and I arrived at 11am on a Sunday and we were seated right away and got served coffees almost immediately which was a great way to start our brunch.  Our waitress was great and made good suggestions for my friends while they were deciding on what to order.  My friends ordered the breakfast burrito with vegan chorizo, the vegan thing with vegan chorizo and tofu scramble with mushrooms and spinach.  When the food came out and everyone had their first bites of food, we were all raving about how tasty and good everything was.  Even the coffee, which was replenished quite frequently, was delicious.

I can't wait to come back!  Definitely will be returning!
author: Rosanne P.

description:
We went to the St Francis Soda Fountain for breakfast on a recent visit to San Francisco and was very happy with our choice. Obviously, the diner is really old, but the interior is very clean and the staff was very friendly and attentive. We came in on a Monday morning around 10:00, and took a seat at the counter as all the booths were taken. We were immediately greeted by a server, given menus and water, then approached for our order a few minutes later.

As a vegan, my wife usually has trouble finding anything other than oatmeal or fruit for breakfast at most places. Not so at the St Francis. In addition to Vegan Pancakes(!), there was a vegan scramble with different options for sauces, and tofu could be substituted in on most of their egg dishes. She ended up with a tofu scramble with a ginger peanut sauce, while I opted for the Veggie mess, which was assorted veggies scrambled with eggs and veggie chorizo. The orders came out in a reasonable time and both were delicious. Would have liked to order a milkshake, but maybe next time. Solid choice for a reasonably priced breakfast in the city - we'll be back!!
author: Paul B.

description:
Yes, come here! When you eat at St. Francis, you feel like you're taken back several decades. The old-fashioned booths and design are so fun.

Service is outstanding. Super friendly servers who are quick and easy-going.

I had the Huevos Rancheros. They weren't the best I've ever had, but very tasty and they are generous in their portions. I definitely want to come back for the soda fountain and ice cream :)

I heard there can be a line, so best to come early on the weekends.
author: Emmy Q.

description: Delicious food. Affordable. Old School. Great people. I love St Francis Fountain. I've been going several times and it's always a great experience. My favorite brunch there: oj + cranberry mimosas, the tofu scramble with pesto, red peppers and feta cheese as well as the veggie mess. So happy I live close by to this gem.
author: Cannelle H.

description: Local favorite. Great breakfast and brunch spot. The Poor Man Soup and the Country Breakfast are amazing.
author: Marisol R.

description:
I have been to this hipster paradise twice. Initially caved in out of curiosity ... you can't help but see them youngsters flocking to St Fran from far and wide any time of day as you go about your business on 24th. Payoff! We were wowed by the 5 star service, the large creative menu and the Very Good Food! Lemme say that the interior is strikingly authentic 1950"s " lunch counter" and the charm will make you lean in to it.  The food:

Chefs Mess- a very tasty mix of eggs, cheese, potato goodness very satisfying

Pancakes- fluffy good flavor and cooked to perfection

Although no formal dress code, get out your skinny pants, beanie and detachable beard just for laffs cuz that will put you in the mood for a great experience & good time at StFranny's!

Large creative menu
Delightful selection of vegan options
Quality ingredients 
Exceptional waiters
A unique experience don't miss out!
author: Lisa S.

description:
I've only been here once and it was around January 2015, a weekday.  I remember because I was coming from a prenatal appt and I was almost due. 
I don't remember what we got here but clearly it didn't make that much impression.  It was okay for me, maybe didn't have enough oomph.  This is popular with the hipsters as every brunch places are.  Not impressed though.
author: Claire J.

description: I love this neighborhood diner, however, weekend Service is the absolute worse. The servers are pushy, rude, lack social skills, and make for an awkward and uncomfortable dining experience. (Especially the brunette male with the rainbow pin. If you constantly have an attitude, service industry is not your calling). The food is great and comforting, and service is great during the week. I live in the neighborhood and cannot go on weekends any more, which is very unfortunate.
author: Es B.

description: Omg! Really found this old school diner today and loved the food. Had real corn beef hash and the flavor was dynamic. Their servers were friendly and very helpful and I definitely will go back there again. Lots of vegan and veggie options that would be perfect to come with my other friends.
author: Ingrid O.

description:
I came here with a friend for Sunday afternoon lunch. We were seated after a 15-20 minute wait. Overall, it was pretty good. It didn't particularly stand out to me. However, the chicken cilantro soup is AMAZING. So warm, wholesome, and uniquely flavorful. I definitely recommend getting it as a side order next to your main course. Extra star for that! Besides the soup, I got an S.F. Reuben which was alright, as far as a veggie sandwich goes. 

Random: The kind of folk that come here seem to be hipsters in their 30s. Also, when I used the bathroom one of them kept trying to yank the door open repeatedly when I had clearly locked it, so I banged back on the door and he scrammed. :P So that's a thing. That works. If you're ever in that situation.
author: Ani R.

description: While visiting San Francisco, we sadly discovered our favorite restaurant Herbivore had closed down permanently. So we decided to search for something new and we came across this place on yelp. They offer a variety of vegan, as well as non vegan options to choose from. Their portions are great and the food is savory and delicious. Another plus, their staff is very friendly. I absolutely can not wait to eat here again, the next time we're in town.  :)
author: BlackSails 1.

description: This is somewhere between a 3 and 4 star place. The decor is kitchy and cute diner aesthetic without going over the top to the point of being annoying. The coffee was hot, and perhaps slightly weak, but totally passable. The Chef's Mess was a very missable breakfast item, it wasn't bad, but it definitely did not impress me or my partner at all. Prices totally reasonable for the amount of food you are getting. You definitely will not leave hungry.
author: Justin B.

description: Fun, old school diner that serves up a comforting breakfast at a great price. The service is really friendly.
author: Felipe P.

description: This place was amazing! The service was awesome and fast. You do have to write your name on a clipboard out front to wait in line but it's worth it and the line moves fast! I am vegan and tried the tofu  scramble with mushrooms, onions, tomatoes and ranchero sauce and my partner had the tofu scramble with peanut sauce and veggies. They also had a vegan hash and some vegan pancakes on the menu that I will try next time we vacation here! We didn't try it, but they also have vegan soft serve and other desserts! Def a great place for vegans ( there are multiple options) and non vegans alike!
author: Kelsey M.

description: Breakfast was delicious! I came because there were so many vegan options. The atmosphere was very casual and comfortable. Service was great. Will definitely come here for breakfast every time I'm in town
author: Jessica L.

description: This place is the awesome sauce!  Everyone who works in this super cool diner/ ice cream parlor is super friendly and on the ball.  I had the Caesar salad with grilled chicken and it was really good and fast and not expensive.  The menu has some hilariously named items that I will have to try on another visit such as: nebulous potato thing (I had a good laugh about this one with one of the very friendly waiters).  I will definitely be back to this place and I would recommend it to anyone who wants a quick lunch or ice cream cone.
author: Amanda G.

description: Everything I had was so delicious: the Benedict, chicken cilantro soup, spinach salad, and fruit. The staff was so accommodating and friendly. Honestly such a cute atmosphere.. the server and the host both treated me like I was their friend. I had to write a yelp review for them and this is the first one I've ever written I think so.. pretty cool.
author: Gwendelyn R.

description: Their flexibility to create plant-based (Vegan a Term I don't like LoL) options is awesome. The banana walnut pancakes
author: Walter H.

description: I actually came to this spot a couple of weeks ago and fell in love.  As someone now labeled as plant based, it was amazing to be able to eat brunch with my best friend as she is an omnivore.  I ordered the tofu scramble and got the vegan pancakes on the side.  They were so fluffy with a hint of cinnamon and sweetness.  I can't wait to come back, the place gave the diner's vibe that I love to be a part of.  We were also seated after a quick 10 minute wait.  It was at the bar but the staff were all so friendly and considerate.
author: Megan T.

description:
Came here for breakfast with a friend. The places is really small  but they do have outdoor sitting. The wait on a Saturday morning wasn't too bad (5mins).
 The prices were reasonable. 
The portion sizes of the food was big and the food was just OK.  I wasn't blown away by the food.

But I didn't like getting my hot tea in a water glass, I would of enjoyed it more in a mug.
author: Asenath N.

description:
My family and I had been wanting to try this place for a long time. We heard about this place from other relatives, raving about how great this place is. So when we decided to come here, it was about ten minutes to 2pm on a Sunday. My mom, my brother, and my elderly aunt and I walk in, all smiles, hungry, and hoping to a good meal! The stoned looking hipster guy at the counter looked at us, rolled his eyes, and let out a big sigh as if we were bothering him. He then seemed to force a smile and walked up to us and said in quite a stern manner, "We close at 3. We're not seating anyone." Umm. Wow. Hi. Not even a, "Hello, how are you?" or a, "Hi, welcome! What would you like?"

As waitress and hostess myself, I was appalled by his attitude. If I was to ever do what he did to MY customers, I'd be fired on the spot! Anyways, I kindly stayed smiling and gently replied, "But your website says you close at 4pm?" then he snapped back. "Yeah no, we're closing at 3pm. To-go orders only." and hands us all one menu. One. Single. Menu. My family and I looked at each other in shock. Did did we do something wrong?

A group of hipster kids (perhaps friends of the server?) came in after us as we're still standing by the door. And the server smiles, laughs, welcomes then in and seats them all. Meanwhile, my party had been standing near the entrance for about ten minutes. I was about to order just a couple things, a milkshake and a grilled cheese, we couldn't get anyone's attention, because all theirs was focused on their friends. Unbelievable.

My dad finally comes in to join us, about five minutes after that. Then he asks us, "Why are you all standing here?" and my mom replies, "They refused to seat us..." so my dad finally says, "Forget it. Let's go." and we all leave. I could see the server look at us through the window as if he was relieved to see us go.

My family and I are Bay Area locals who've been here for five generations. Never in my life have I been to a local joint and treated like trash. So sad this place lacks local charm, and also sadly seems to be overrun by entitled hipsters and yuppies. Not saying they can't enjoy this place too, but when you make your fellow neighbors who know the area inside and out feel unwelcome, that right there is bad business.

I was truly looking forward to this, but I'm appalled by what I experienced yesterday. All we wanted were some shakes and maybe a sandwich. Instead, we got service with attitude, dirty looks, and no food. Maybe hire some new people or train your current servers in courses for attitude adjustment. So sorry to give such a negative review to an old local joint.
author: Molly M.

description:
No frills divey diner American food. It's not complicated. The portions are huge, you get your money's worth and it is damn tasty. 

I was so happy with corned beef hash but of course I couldn't say no when my friend offered me some of his brunch: Nebulous potato thing. Uhhh, 5 stars alone for that name! 
It was like a giant, fully loaded, smashed potato. SO GOOD. 

The wait isn't too bad, everybody's friendly, and the food is good.
author: Susy C.

description:
A solid 4 star experience. 
I am always looking for a place where my meat eater boyfriend and my vegan-self can go enjoy a meal together. Kodus to the server over at Soul Groove who recommended this spot to check out for brunch. St. Francis Fountain is a great little authentic diner, totally separate from pretentious brunch spots you tend to find in the Mission. 
We were seated immediately (no wait for brunch, yay!) when we arrived and greeted with some waters from the server. I went for the "griddle combo" 2 vegan pancakes, a tofu scramble and side of fruit. My boyfriend got the huevos rancheros and side of biscuits and crazy. Our food came pretty quick for how busy it was, tasty, hot, SUCH BIG PORTIONS. I was pleasantly surprised with this spot. The flavor was spot on, service was quick, friendly, and casual. 
I wouldn't recommend coming here with a large group, the tables are pretty small and there seems to only be one booth large enough to fit about 6 at once, but overall great and I will be back!
author: Kelsey B.

description: My first visit to this place. Being a vegetarian I have limited options for food always. But this place turned out to be great. Tried the vegan rancheros and it was just amazing. Very flavourful with the right blend of spices. Would strongly recommend it to all vegans.
author: Monishika G.

description: I've had breakfast here about a year ago. I was good. Was in the neighborhood this morning at 9:00 am. Walked in to a totally bad scene. One server, no busboy on a Friday morning. I sat down at the counter among dirty plates and no menu? I could see the sever was in the weeds. Waited 10 minutes until he said that I would have to outside and get online before I could be seated. Outside there was a party of three and a party of two. The counter was empty, but I still had to go outside. WTF. This was not the servers fault. The problem lies with the owners/ management. Get your shit together. I'm an Uber driver and never recommend this place again and I'll never eat there again!!!
author: Dan L.

description: Wow this place was delicious! It had a pretty solid 50/50 mix of carnivore and vegan (as well as vegetarian) menu items. I got the Veggie Mess with tofu scramble and made vegan (if you just ask for a menu item to be vegan they already know what to substitute for you). Top notch! The plates look smaller but the portions cover the whole plate to the fullest and I was stuffed. The service was incredibly fast as well (less than a 10 minute wait for an indoor table at the iconic diner and our food arrived within 15 minutes of ordering). I'll certainly be back with more friends! The staff was very attentive as well. A hidden gem in the Mission.
author: Sarah E.

description:
I didn't get the hype here. Granted, I did not try their ice cream or shakes, but I came here for brunch. Their french toast was nothing special. The banana bread was burnt - literally one side of it was completely black, how do you serve that?! The omelette that my boyfriend had was smothered in sour cream. 

Maybe I'll need to come back to try their shakes, but the food here was mediocre.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Booths, tall shakes with whipped cream, patty and tuna melt make this place an iconic.  We need an old man serving.  But this place is too hip.  Great fast service.  Love their sides, especially the fresh fruit cup, french fries, and 3 bean chili, can't  go wrong wit the sides. The sides are the bonuses.  Hamberger was great, old fashion.
author: Helen L.

description: This might be my favorite brunch spot in SF! The piggy pancakes are SO good, the service is super friendly and efficient, there's rarely a long wait, and the prices are really fair. It's also in a super cute part of the Mission, fun for strolling around before or after brunch.
author: Dresden J.

description:
