Had the chef's mess even though it was past lunch time because that's supposedly what they are known for... And I can see why! It was absolutely amazing, just enough cheese with the blends of eggs, potatoes, bacon, and so much more. Basically like a chicken pie that you open and dig through. 
Also got their banana shake but I would order it 5 minutes before asking for the bill so it doesn't melt while you're enjoying your food. 
I would highly recommend
author: Frank S.

description: Took a friend there the other day. My banana nut pancakes were pretty good. She ordered blueberry sourdough French toast after asking the waiter if the blueberries were fresh. He said yes. The blueberries may have been fresh days before that, they definitely were not fresh. The waiter didn't show back up to out table after, I had to grab a different waiter to pay the bill. I finished my pancakes, her French toast was pretty much left intact. I lost points that morning. Fellas, don't take a date there.
author: Aaron T.

description: This place was recommended by my brothers fiancé. And she did not disappoint we loved all the food that we ordered. My husband wanted to go old fashion and order BLT on a sourdough and he can't stop telling me how good his sandwich was. The wait time wasn't bad maybe less than 10 min. Staff are very friendly and on point when it comes to refilling our water. We will definitely come back to this place and highly recommended.
author: Jane R.

description:
This place is your regular diner with a niche for vegetarians. I'm not really into the vegetarian breakfast so I'm glad they offered other meeting delights. I had an egg scramble, it was about salty but delicious. 

The service was good. The place though like I said is a regular diner, the table smelled like a dirty rag was wiped to clean it... But the smell left right away when the food came
author: Ladonna A.

description:
To me their tuna melt on toasted sour dough tastes like tuna (yeah, I'm into that) and buttered popcorn (i'm into that too).  

Strawberry milkshake also phenom!
author: Liss T.

description: ahhhhhh-mazing food and very affordable.  great ambiance!
author: Kyra W.

description: We love the great friendly service. Usually packed on the weekends, but great to come into on the weekdays too.
author: Anthony B.

description:
St. Francis Fountain looked surprisingly empty today so grabbed a seat.

menu: fountain ice cream/shakes (mitchell's), burgers, sammies, breakfast, etc.

eats: hamburger, med. rare (8.25) came with a side, choice of  12ish items.
-burger med. rare, slightly juicy, traditional lettuce, tomato, onions, no dressing
very good burger, good value
-added mustard, didn't see grey poupon.
mac cheese very good
*lots of cheddar cheese.

take outs:
-burger with side an excellent value.
-service not a problem, place almost empty.
author: Victor G.

description: Today was the second day I came here. I am a Vegan and They have vegan options on the menu. they are really good. The first time I came in the service and food was prompt and perfect. The second time I had a different server and he messed up my order. He gave me corn beef hash with eggs Instead of vegan chorizo hash. I haven't ate animal products in over a year. When I told him he gave me the wrong thing he kept asking what kind of eggs I wanted on my VEGAN chorizo hash. I told him it's not vegan if you're adding eggs. Then he said he would comp my meal but actually only gave me the difference. It also came with bread with regular butter but I didn't know that it was regular butter or meat I thought they just accidentally put egg. So now I'm disappointed and I have a stomach ache. And to top it off I'm late for work. Smh I was telling all my friends about this place too. Oh well
author: Mishaune G.

description:
I tried their veggie mess which was a VERY decent serving size and VERY delicious. It had a great number of flavors - from eggs to potato hash and some nice, crispy bread. I would definitely come back for it again. 

I would come last year at nighttime for ice cream but they changed their hours such that they close by 3-4pm, which is sad. I hope they change back their hours soon!
author: Raakin H.

description:
I had to give St. Francis Fountain a try after so many vegan friends have sworn up and down this is a great place to eat, very much vegan comfort food at it's best. I took one of my daughters and we went for brunch, I was in the mood for some vegan pancakes. We found parking right in front and it wasn't super busy, so we took a seat and made our decisions, she got the strawberry vegan pancakes with a side of vegan sausage patties and I got the vegan blueberry pancakes with a side of potatoes, we split everything and were stuffed by time we finished.

Everything tastes so good, I can't believe we ate it all! The blueberry pancakes are loaded with fruit with an option for vegan butter too if you'd like. The potatoes are done perfectly, just enough crispyness and softness inside to make them perfect, plus the herbs in them rock! My daughter ate all the vegan sausage patties, mumbling how good those were too, all in all, it was a great success, we'll definitely be back soon.

Keep up the good work and thanks for offering the non-animal meals, its nice to have those options for the whole family.
author: Garden R.

description:
I'm not a vegan, and I don't have any vegan friends in the neighborhood, but St. Francis Fountain is my favorite brunch spot in the Mission. No contest. 

I've had the milkshakes and the egg scrambles and the vegan sausage and The Nebulous Potato Thing and maybe (maybe!) one time I had all of it in one sitting. Maybe. What can I say? I live abroad, so when I get back in town I hoover everything I know I can't get across the Atlantic - like pancakes and decent avocados. 

There's often a wait to sit, but they have quite a bit of space inside and if the weather's nice, they will sit people along the side of the building right in the sun. I've never waited more than 15-20 minutes which, for brunch in San Francisco, is unheard of. 

The service is friendly, and food comes out quick, and I've never felt rushed out of my booth or table. The menu has a little (or a lot) of something for everyone, so it's a great place to drag friends - even your gluten free, lactose intolerant friends nursing a hangover. 100% satisfaction guaranteed. 

Go here. Eat the things. Get a milkshake with your brunch, there ain't no shame.
author: Brittany B.

description:
Now I see what all the hype is about... this place is top-notch! 

I'm surprised that I have never come here, as I've had it on my list of bookmarks for quite some time, and so many of my friends are fans. I guess I'm just never in that neighborhood, so a few of us East Bay/ Contra Costa County folks hopped in a car and drove to the city specifically to grab their grub.

Surprisingly, we were able to get seated right away. I think we must have just beat the morning rush, since we did leave Walnut Creek at around 10:30 in the morning. A quick drive over the bridge, and we made it to our destination. 

First impression: cute, old-school diner atmosphere. Cozy wooden booths. Hustling and bustling, the place packed full of customers, which is usually a good sign. 

Their coffee is delicious, a mild and tasty brew, and they have soy milk for your dairy-free needs. This started off our meal on a high note, as we ordered 4 coffees and scanned the menu, our little vegan hearts pounding with excitement. 


There are plentiful vegan and vegetarian options for both breakfast and lunch, so we took our time reading over the menu. Everything looked and tasted spectacular!!! We ooh'ed and ahh'ed when the food was brought over, as our dishes were quite aesthetically appealing, especially for diner food.  

Rosanne P. opted for the Devil's Burger (actually not a burger, but thinly sliced seitan), Richard A. got the Vegan Breakfast Burrito, and Laura C. ordered a killer tofu scramble with spinach and mushrooms. 

I was going to get the Vegan Rancheros, but they didn't have vegan cheese, so the waitress suggested getting The Vegan Thing instead ("pile of spuds with vegan jack cheese, fresh salsa, guacamole, and green onions") with added vegan chorizo instead of cheese. Great tip! It was everything a great breakfast should be: starchy, spicy, sweet and savory. The potatoes were cooked so that one side was a little well done crunchy (but not burnt). I thought that really elevated the dish. Even the guac had a good flavor; not sure if it is housemade, but it sure tasted like it was. The chorizo was mighty spicy and set my mouth on fire... I loved every second of it. It hurt so good! 

I tried a bite of Rosie's sandwich... that seitan is phenomenal! It almost had a roast beef, pastrami-esque texture and flavor, without being as overpoweringly salty as its meaty counterpart. I've never seen seitan sliced so thin. I would love to order this on my next visit, as it comes with a heaping side of fries if you so choose. It looks fantastic, especially when you choose to add grilled onions and avocado on top. 

We each must have had at least 2-3 cups of coffee, as they were quick to come by with a fresh pot to give us a warm-up. I really appreciated that! The staff is excellent, very attentive and well-mannered, especially for a Sunday morning (when I know my demeanor can be a little bit cranky). Diane was our main waitress, and she seemed quite knowledgeable about the menu. I hope we weren't bothering her with our demands (more soy milk, please/ a side of jam for my toast, thank you). 

Would I return? Abso-friggin-lutely! This is probably my new favorite brunch joint in all of San Francisco. I left there feeling very full and yet energized, ready to take on the world!...  or at least Rainbow Grocery right down the street.
author: Brandi W.

description:
I just had the sausage/eggs/toast/potatoes typical greasy spoon breakfast order; this is usually a good indicator of the capabilities of a diner.
All was tasty.
It's a shame they do tortured/greasy homefries instead of better-but-labor-intensive hashbrowns.
High point was the sausage patty.  Well seasoned, generous and yummy.
Low points were:
1) greezy homefries
2) sub-par rye bread for toast (tasteless)
3) $16 bucks for a diner counter eggs breakfast??  With so many options in the area... I won't be back.
But it was OK, and the retro ambience, while forced, is still present.
author: Josh K.

description:
Mediocre diner food with some of the worst service I ever had the misfortune of experiencing. 

I guess if you are friends with one of the continuously stoned looking hipster servers, you'll have a good time there. If you are in the vast majority of people that have no direct relationship with the staff, get ready for long waits and surly ass attitudes!

The food is decent diner fare, for new mission prices (i.e expensive).

Additionaly, people waiting to be seated block the entire sidewalk and could not be less self aware about it. God damn, just thinking about it boils my blood.

Would have given it two stars instead of the one but the customers that frequent the place (especially weekends) drop it down to a 1 star.

Last weekend, friends of one of the servers where sitting on the outside portion under the awning, crushing beer cans and throwing them at cars. Staff saw it and thought it was the funniest thing ever.

If the mood strikes you for diner food, go the Mexican diner 3 doors down, La Torta Gorda.
author: Dennis A.

description: Horrible customer service. I've been coming here for 10 years. This morning my husband and I both order over medium eggs. His come out perfect, mine come out over hard. I didn't send mine back or anything, I just asked for an order of over medium eggs. After 30 minutes, mine come out over hard again. I told the server very politely, thinking I'm just order scrambled instead, but he very rudely tells me that they can't make eggs two different ways, that I can't order over medium eggs when I want them over easy (I didn't, btw. Over easy and over medium are 2 very different things), and he tells me that they can't make me anymore eggs! An hour wasted, somehow it still cost us $38. So rude! The cooks really need to learn the difference between over easy, over medium, and over hard. I'm appalled by the way I was treated. Sadly, after 10 years of patronage, I won't be coming back.
author: Eme C.

description:
I sought this place out on a recent visit to San Francisco (September 2015). We walked quite a distance to get here from where we were staying. My partner and I arrived just after 2:00 on a weekday and didn't realize until we arrived that they actually close at 3:00pm. As a rule, I generally do not stay to dine at a restaurant if I arrive less than an hour before closing, but since we only wanted to grab a soda/shake/ice cream treat we figured we could be out in less than an hour. 

When we walked in we got glared at and I can only assume this was because of the time - but it was literally not even 2:15 yet. We were off to an awkward start. There were two people standing behind the counter, but to use the word "working" would be a stretch. We sat at the counter and as the kid handed us the menus, he warned "we close a 3". Not the friendliest greeting. I assured him we only wanted ice cream so we would be quick. 

There were two other people at the counter who were already eating so we were the only two people in the place that required service, but the server never came back to ask if we had questions. It felt like he was hoping we would go away if he didn't approach us... and we nearly did. It was only the fact that it was such a long hike to get there that kept us determined to order something. He pulled the fence across the front windows while we were trying to figure out the difference between shakes and sodas, etc even though at that point it wasn't yet 2:30pm. 

We finally had to call him back to us. I asked a question about one of the ice cream items and he seemed like he couldn't be bothered. He prepared our order and brought it to us with 25 mins to spare till closing. The ice cream itself was good, although I think it had been a bit over-hyped and not necessarily detour-worthy on our course. Halfway through our shakes / ice cream, he came back and gave us the tumblers with the remaining third of our treats as if it was an afterthought to offer it to us. At other restaurants, my experience has been that you get what remains in the metal tumbler along with your poured shake, but it was weird, as if he was doing us a favor. 

At one point we were trying to wrap up and get the bill (still before closing time) but couldn't get the attention of the server who again couldn't be bothered. We were also hoping to get the glass of water we had asked for when we placed our order. At one point, a guy who had been eating at the counter a few seats down from us walked behind the counter and standing directly in front of us AND facing us at the counter he filled himself a glass of water. My partner politely asked if we could have a glass of water to which he replied, "Yeah", we thanked him and his response was, "I'm actually on break" like he wanted us to know he was doing us a favor filling a glass of water for us while he was on his break 30 mins before they closed. 

The entire experience was so off-putting and rude. They truly made us feel like we had wronged them in some way when all we could honestly think of was that they were mad that it was 2:00pm and we were going to make them do something during their last hour. We finally got the original server's attention by signaling to him during a break in his casual conversation with his friends at the counter. We asked for the check and he seemed so disgusted to have to prepare and give us the bill that we wanted to leave without asking for it just to avoid one more unnecessarily awkward interaction with the staff. 

We paid the bill and heard them yell something as we walked out the door. We don't know what they yelled, but I will guess it wasn't "have a nice day". The customer service was non-existent and they seemed like our presence and request for two simple ice creams and a cup of water was beyond comprehension. All of this being said, we were out the door before 3:00pm, so it was NOT because we had over-stayed our welcome. Very disappointing, uncomfortable, a very strange experience.... and now after reading these Yelp reviews, I see that we are not alone in being treated this way by the staff. These little turds do not deserve jobs until they learn some basic human decency. Grow up, kids.
author: Lisa P.

description:
I've been wanting to come here for a while. I came with my best friend at about 7:15 on a Thursday night, and the place was practically empty.

The menu looked promising, full of delicious American food with lots of vegetarian options.

We ordered the side platter and a grilled cheese to share. I also ordered a chocolate milkshake.

Food was pretty good. Not incredible, but no major complaints. Milkshake was awesome if not a little grainy. Service was subpar, we were not asked if everything was okay with our meal until we were finished with it.

The place is full of flies, which isn't the biggest issue but when one landed in my friend's water we got kind of grossed out.

I probably won't come back here as a special trip, but perhaps if I'm in the neighborhood and having a milkshake craving, maybe.
author: Morgan B.

description: Ended up here on Mothers day because the place I planned to go to for breakfast was closed.  Food was just ok.  Nothing crazy to write home about.  Got the hotcakes, eggs and turkey sausage.  Turkey sausage had a tangy taste, not quite sure what ingredient would give it that. The cakes were good though and very filling leaving no need to really eat the eggs (not cooked to my liking but after the 2nd try I gave up) nor the sausage.
author: Dawn B.

description:
St. Francis Fountain is good for those days when you: (1) want a low-key brunch, (2) are feeling lazy and don't feel like eating more than one meal that day, and (3) are channeling your 5-year-old self and want an ice cream soda.  

Sometimes I wake up on a Sunday feeling like 1, 2, and 3.  So I drag myself out of bed, drag my brunch partner-in-crime with me, and go to St. Francis Fountain. As I sip happily on my ice cream soda, along comes the Chef's Mess, my favorite item on the menu.  While the brunch partner-in-crime is partial to the eggs benedict (and its variations), I love the Chef's Mess.  It has everything  delicious in it, all mixed together.

Bacon? Check.  Mushrooms? Check. Spuds? Check.  Bacon? Check again.  Yes, if you are a bacon lover, you'll love the ample amount of Bacon in the Chef's Mess.  Don't forget it also comes with cheese, sour cream, and green onion.  

The best part about something so delicious is that there's so much of it that you can make two meals out of it if you want. Nom and nom.
author: Nancy C.

description:
Classic American diner vibe, nailing the details -down to the powdered bathroom soap- without feeling kitschy. Tasty vegan options. Knowledgable servers. Great tunes.
I will make it a point to return.
author: Katrina H.

description: I Love St. Francis.  I Love it EXCEPT on the weekends.  No because of the wait.  But because of the awful servers (except for Carlos).  We had some Norwegian friends in town and took them to Frannies.  Girl asks "how big is the large?"  Dude with the rainbow pin responds "I don't know how much you eat". Damn dude!  This is only one example.  The weekday staff is amazing.  Weekend staff has some serious social issues to say the least.
author: Nicky T.

description: Small cute diner very laid back and good comfort food nothing fancy but worth trying their food
author: Lorena C.

description:
This place is employed by arrogant hipsters.  Nothing but bad experiences the 3 times I've been. This last visit I rushed to arrive at 2:30 knowing they close at 3 and was turned away by the staff because they stop seating at 2:30. Why the hell advertise you close at 3 if it's actually 2:30? Just gave me attitude like I had the nerve to impose upon them by not understanding this insider information. 
Done trying. Good luck.
author: Deckard C.

description: Very nice food with a diner feel to it. The burger is delicious, and I would also endorse the "potato things" as a side. Service could have been a little faster considering that there weren't that many customers present during my visit, but the food quality compensated for the speed
author: Juan M.

description:
The bf and I went to St Francis Fountain on Sat for brunch and it was a full house. There was a small crowd outside but the wait wasn't too bad. They started seating next door which made the waiting period go by even faster! Sadly- I think it took longer for a server to come take our order than it did waiting for a table.. :/ 

We're back on trying to eat "healthy" so we both created our own scrambles and said no toast and no potatoes. Boo dieting! BUT! We added vegetarian chorizo to make it not so healthy and that was deadly! The server was nice enough to let us substitute our spuds/bread for a bowl of fresh fruit! It was a generous portion as well! The food was decent but I think I'd like to try their spuds and gluten-filled meals the next time I come back!
author: Michelle L.

description:
This place is the bane of false advertising!  Despite broadcasting all over their website that they take delivery orders from postmates they actually do not on weekends!  My very friendly driver went all the way over there to have them inform him that to get ANY food on a weekend you have to physically sit down to eat it! My driver informed me that in over a year of delivering via postmates he has never, ever had a restaurant enforce such an absolutely ridiculous policy.

Well they have seen the last of any of my money.  I don't support business who participate in false advertising.
author: Matt W.

description: The Devil Burger destroyed my soul, had me reciting Anton LaVey in an ancient tongue of R'lyeh, my head spinning around, and the earth combusting around me. When I awoke, I was pregnant with the harbinger of the end times and I was seited.
author: Mark B.

description: Nebulous potato thing and the upside down hog cakes were amazing!! No complaints. Service was fast and friendly.
author: Samantha C.

description:
Why I Heart Burning Man:

1)  Rockstar parking.

2)  No wait.  At St. Francis Fountain.  At 11am.  On a Sunday. (!!!)

3)  Less time to Dreamsicle-time.

4)  Less time to Grilled Buttered Banana Bread time.

5)  Less time to Ranchero-Sauced-Breakfast-Burrito-Food-Coma time.

6)  Less time to Extra-Crispy-Hash-Browns time.

(More time while waiting a long time for the check though.  Go figure!)
author: Amy C.

description: I love this spot, period. Scrumptious breakfast options, fast and friendly service, awesome historic decor and worth the wait. their omelettes are my favorite, their milkshakes satisfy your cravings. Sourdough french toast or vegan banana walnut hot cakes (yes, vegan, though I'm not, is SUPER yummy), everything is tasty.  They have all the original decor (down to the shelves and benches), which is pretty cool and features of old-school candy that you can purchase :).
author: Zara S.

description: Vegan service industry vet here. Quick, efficient, but still warm and friendly service! I love pancakes but it's so hard to find vegan ones! The strawberry ones were the bees knees. Get some vegan chocolate chip or maybe vegan sausage patties up in here and I'll be here every day. My omni brother and his vegetarian friend also really enjoyed their dishes and we had a quick walk around Mission afterward to help us digest. 10/10 will go back soon with friends. PANCAKES
author: Danica N.

description: I never leave yelp reviews, but this place is incredible (from a vegan experience). The food exceeded expectations, friendly staff, and clean environment. I'd give this place a 6/5 if I could.
author: Juliana R.

description: Finally got a chance to eat at this place. There always seem to be a line on the weekends, so weekdays may be your best best. We were seated promptly. The breakfast hash and nebulous potato thing is very filling, The decor is a throwback to the old world soda fountain shops. I have not had a chance to try the desserts yet.
author: Long C.

description: Nice hole in the wall place.  Customer service was a tad slow, but the food was worth the wait.  They offer a lot of vegan and vegetarian options which I like.  I ordered the egg and avocado sandwich which was really good.  Also ordered the chorizo scramble which was tasty as well.
author: dina d.

description:
This is a stellar breakfast place to go in the Mission. It's in a perfect part of Mission that has still retained its beauty.

The food was delicious. We got the Potato Something and French Toast to split between 3 people. We were stuffed by the end of it! 

The ambiance is really nice and the waiters are so friendly and funny! Definitely going back again!
author: Akshaya V.

description:
Went in on a normal weekend day... it was great!

Great food !!

Hint, ask for the check when the serve the meal so you do not have to wait when you are ready to gooooooooo !
author: Michael P.

description:
Good breakfast place.
I never had to wait too long to get a table and the food is great.

I'm a fan of their milkshake an flavored sodas.
author: Jr P.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place out since it's been on my bookmarks for a while, and my bf and i had time to finally go and try it out! I guess we were pretty lucky, since the place was pretty empty. 

I love creamsicle! And their make of it in the form of a shake was superb :) Very orangey and creamy, especially with the vanilla ice cream nommmm. We ordered their 24th street special, which is basically hash browns, two eggs, and biscuits with sausage gravy. It was okay, to be honest. But i give the stars for the creamsicles.

I am definitely gonna go back for their ice cream and banana sundaes :).
author: Jerianne G.

description:
Great hot cakes, decent eggs, bacon was horrible. Service was not great. Atmosphere has a cute vintage diner feel to it. Definitely a place to go at least once. 

Ps they have ice cream - need I say more?
author: Nick R.

description: So many many vegan option. I had the devils burger. They even use veganise in it. I saw the server making an amazing ice cream for a kid with using the cone as a hat and the scoop as the face. It looked awesome. I make him create a Sundae for me the way he wants with butter scotch ice cream. It was delicious, dripping in chocolate, whipped cream, almonds and with a cherry on the top. The people who run the place are really really nice. I was here for a birthday party and they handled every one so well and with a smile. The place itself is like a old diner and they sell some cool things like old tattoos etc. Food is great, people are awesome, place is spacious, i would want to visit here again.
author: Shreyas P.

description: Dope dinner in the mission district of San Francisco. Plenty of culture and history here, you feel like you are dining at a national landmark. Awesome vibes awesome food.
author: Anthony I.

description: This place is pretty ridiculous. Drove 15 min to get here, spent 10 min finding Parking. Walked up hungry and excited and went to check in and the server tells me they won't be seating outside till 9:30. I look and all the tables are empty. I check my watch and its 9:27. I ask him if he wants me to stand around and he says yes, those are the rules. I understand rules are rules but being rude and losing customers must be pretty common here judging from the other reviews.
author: Shant M.

description:
Story: My friend told me about this place and it's unique old school ambiance. 

Location: Like most restaurants in SF it's on the side of the street so street parking is a must. It can seat about 40 people.

Ambiance: 
This place really does bring an old school feel from the paper straws to the their classic candy. You can sit stool diner style or booth. It seemed like the "Prince" playlist was playing (which is totally fine by me).

Service: 
Our server was quick and attentive. Our orders came in less than 10 minutes. He politely followed up with every now and then.

Food: 
SF Reuben - I honestly thought this would be light especially since there would be no meat but this actually filled me up. I was hesitant at first but this was a tasty alternative to the usual corned beef rueben.

Nebulous Potato Thing - We ordered the small but this small dish was flavorful and surprisingly fulfilling

Old fashioned Vanilla Ice Cream Malt - The taste was rich and the texture of the malt was on point. The paper straw was quite a struggle at first since it would get soggy after quite sometime and it would be hard to suck through the straw. Be sure to stir so the malt is distributed evenly throughout the shake.

Overall: 
I would rate this place 4.5 stars. I honestly can't complain about this place. The music was pleasing, the service was quick, and food was delicious. Their menu was had a wide variety from their breakfast menu to their authentic shakes. Meals ranged from the high $5-10 range and well worth it. Whenever I'm back in town and in need for that old school American feel, this will be the place to be.
author: Leland S.

description: Yum! Best breakfast burrito ever! This place reminds me of an old school diner. Love the warm, friendly environment here.
author: Michelle G.

description: Chill spot, great food, and awesome service. The egg sandwich and trench toast were pretty damn delicious too. Great local spot!
author: Christina R.

description:
A truly old-school diner and soda fountain reborn as a retro hipster hangout, complete with novelty gift items. Even the servers are textbook hipster from head to toe; that having been said, service-wise, they're super positive and friendly.

They've got a large, vegan-friendly, day-long menu to suit all tastes, whether traditional or Latin-inspired brunch fare; soups, salads, burgers, and sandwiches; or, of course, fountain sodas, shakes, and sundaes. They've also got some good mimosas and you can try them really cheaply as an add-on to one of their weekend poached egg dishes.

There's a variety of seating options, from a long counter with stools, to several tables at the windows overlooking 24th Street, to about a dozen wooden booths - one of which was supposedly the place where the 49ers were founded on the back of a napkin. 

Lots of comfort food that's reasonably priced and a quirky, retro feel to the entire diner. Another gem in the Mission.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Great food, great environment, and great prices....that's all I need!

I definitely recommend this place, especially the banana bread mmmm
author: Karina E.

description: Loved the diner style eggs Benedict with tomato and bacon. Potatoes are delicious too!
author: Archana P.

description: A decent breakfast option in the area, though many of the options are fairly heavy. The portions are huge! Had an experience where I ordered The Veggie Thing and the waitress immediately assumed I wanted the large. Regretted it as I could not finish it. The small is much more reasonable. There are waits during peak hours. The service is alright, I feel like they need more waiters. Often times they have open seating outdoors that is open for a good 15 minutes before people actually get seated.
author: Elisa L.

description: We came to the neighborhood to get donuts but they were closed so we found this place right down the street. It was SO good! I got the breakfast burrito and my boyfriend got the country style breakfast and both were so delicious. Great atmosphere too, it was packed but the servers were totally on top of everything. I definitely recommend this place!
author: Vanessa S.

description:
You know that thing that happens when you meet someone and think they're awesome but can't remember their name? Then you hear all these great things about that person but you're like, wow, how could I have never met this person? And then you actually see them again and still don't know their name but think they are just as awesome as ever? That's what just happened to me about St. Francis Fountain.

Hungover mornings never encountered such a soothing and all-curing breaking of the fast than at St. Francis. My roommates just call it "the diner", and I had been there plenty of time with them but never pinpointed the name. Even after people had asked me if I'd been to St. Francis and boasted of it's goodness, I would sadly shake my hanging head. Then after reading an article about awesome places to try in the Mission, it hit me like a sack of potatoes, and viola! Here is my review!

The Huevos Rancheros came the to the rescue on my first visit: two perfectly runny, over-easy eggs sat atop flavorful black beans, melty Jack cheese, and ranchero sauce. I asked for avocado and sprinkled hot sauce over and made little breakfast tacos with the warm corn tortillas. 

Another encounter with St. Francis brought me back to my Corned Beef Hash roots, as I'm a CBH whore and need it on the reg. Theirs is made in-house and it's just delightful and very filling. I took some of it back home as I layed in bed and recovered from the night before and ate it sparingly throughout the afternoon.

Sitting in the pew-style booths or on a spinny chair, chatting with my pals, and licking my spoon of vanilla milkshake, it gets no better than a morning at St. Francis Fountain.
author: Crystal C.

description:
Is it possible to give ZERO stars? The food was mediocre. Not bad, but I'd certainly not ever go out of my way to come here. 

My 1 star rating is for the customer service. 

I had been waiting at the counter and after 5 minutes I let the man making a sundae know that I was ready to order. He looked at me and replied "I'm not a waiter." I apologized and asked if he could please let my server know I was ready. He then replied "No." I asked "seriously?! Are you kidding?" And he replied "No." I was appalled! Later my waiter came (15 minutes later) and I was livid, I mentioned my interaction with his employee and he said "oh, he is just busy. He is making sundaes and running around. He didn't mean to be mean. If you don't want to be here then I understand (and starts to take my menu)." Seriously? I was floored. There is no justifying the poor attitude the sundae maker had towards me. The fact that my server tried to excuse it was a slap in the face. 

Shortly after this, one of the other employees pulls his coworker to the side and they start talking about me (it's so obvious!) and they both look my direction and quickly look the other way when they see I am aware of what's happening. 

Unreal. I had never been here before so for a first impression it was pretty low. I will not be returning and will advise colleagues, family, and friends to stay far away from this place. The food wasn't superb, anyway.
author: Kiara E.

description: I love diners and this place is my favorite in San Francisco. I always bring my family here for a relaxed brunch. The prices are fair, especially the sides.
author: Henry T.

description: It was my first time here, a friend of mine suggested this place for breakfast before we headed out of town. I got the potato things with the egg on top. That hit the spot, especially with the Fresh squeezed oj to wash down the food. The pancakes were good too and the tofu scramble.
author: Daryl M.

description:
St. Francis, you're the one
You make breakfast lots of fun
St. Francis, I'm awfully fond of you
(woh woh bee doh)

St. Francis, joy of joys
I eat Chef's Mess and make a happy noise
St. Francis, you make the very best shakes, it's true! (I adore the hipster staff, too)
(doo doo be doo)
author: Colleen C.

description:
One star only for the staff that were all polite with great customer service, although like previous post where people stated i do agree the staff seemed high.
Everything else a blah. Food was extra salty and meat looked as if it comes out a frozen bag of patties from Costco. Package of saltine crackers were stale. The shake was ok. Nothing that stood out or made it special. I expected something similar to Beeps or Whiz burgers. Seems as if the place was bought out and not one person decided to redo the necessities such as missing tile, a crack going down the booth on the wall. I understand keeping it original but a little maintance for safety wouldnt be bad. Prices do not match quality of food. I remember 20+ years ago the place was clean and had a positive vibe, quiet but still going. Now it seems unkept, rundown and busy only for the fact of all the hipsters that have moved into the neighborhood looking for something 'original'.
author: tania t.

description: This review is long overdue! Whenever I want a delicious breakfast this is my go to spot! I don't know it is they add to their food but it is all very delicious from the pancakes to the waffles to the bacon! Every single thing on the menu is cooked , prepared , and served with love! I can't not express how amazing their food is! Yes, the wait can be a little long but the food is WORTH it! The service is amazing, everyone is very friendly and helpful. The only thing that could be better is the hours of the restaurant they close pretty early, but hey early bird gets the worm right?
author: Veronica G.

description: Awesome breakfast food! I am already looking forward to going back bc I had such a hard time choosing what to get. The spuds were incredibly tasty, I could've easily had a second plate. We were seated quickly, had great service from their staff as well, and the food came out fast. Loved the retro diner atmosphere and location. Will definitely return when in the area.
author: Olga G.

description:
St. Francis Fountain is a classic, old-fashioned diner. The ambience was great - very low key with big booths and lots of space to sit at the counter. The servers were all very friendly and relaxed. 

The food was overwhelming in an awesome way. Massive plates of spuds and melted cheese and eggs... Everything tasted delicious - we tried both the nebulous potato thing (even the small is huge so no need to order the large, although I recommend adding on some over easy eggs!) and the veggie mess (vegan chorizo is seriously tasty and I'm not even a vegetarian).

Another awesome touch was the fantastic egg cream in an ice cream sundae glass. We loved the old school feel! Great breakfast!
author: Sol C.

description:
I ordered the infamous Nebulous Potato Thing of course. And it was definitely something I would order. Potatoes with guac, pico de gallo, and sour cream? Perfect in my mouth- seriously. And I'm really glad that they offered it in a smaller order because it was just right. The boyfriend ordered an omelet and his order was huge. Also ordered the egg soda thing. It was okay, like carbonated hot cocoa powder.

I had to knock off a star because our waiter was nowhere to be found. They had one waitress who kept flirting with a customer even when we asked her to get our check. Then after we got our check it took them forever to ring us up. Almost half an hour waiting to pay. Kinda unheard of right? Foods good, they could probably work on their service.
author: Dara S.

description: This place is the oldest ice cream joint in SF which houses some pretty cool snacks from back in the day! Food was stellar including the chocolate milkshake- yum yum! Service was fabulosity as well as our guy was very attentive and super personable. Definitely worth trying! Oh and they have $3.50 mimosas!! Sold.
author: Ashlyn R.

description:
This is our home away from home!

It surprised me to discover that the huevos rancheros here are out-of-this-world... like, best-of-the-Mission quality. Add jalapeños and avocado and you've got yourself an amazing share.

Other faves:
- Sandhya benedict (on the weekend specials list) - the English muffin base is homemade, like a tender juicy savory pancake-crumpet
- Thing your spuds... it is good
- Side salads are crunchy and delish. Caesar is dressing-heavy. Italian vin is awesome.
- Biscuits, banana bread (not too sweet), and toast... all yum.

Things I'd not necessarily recommend: the mac 'n' cheese, the veggie reuben, veggie chili (which is real sweet). None's a bad choice, just not as relatively special as the true stars here.
author: Megan G.

description:
If you are hungover and you go here, the probability is very high you will feel better.  They advertise that they offer hearty breakfasts and by hearty, they mean greasy.  But it's a delicious kind of greasy. 

They have an anxiety-inducing array of choices for breakfast, with every possible permutation of a scramble.   I say go big every time and get the Chef's Mess, it's basically a superset of every ingredient possible like eggs, bacon, potatoes, sour cream, cheese, etc.  It's essentially breakfast nachos.  

Service is spotty, the decor lacking,  and the waits can be a little long but again, if you're hungover and want an effective remedy, this is the place for you.
author: Saminda W.

description: How cute is this place? I was pleasantly surprised to get a table relatively quickly on a busy Sunday.  This is classic Greasy Spoon diner food, including all the bells and whistles that come with a vintage soda fountain dining experience. Being that it was late brunch time---and I have NO self control,  I got the short stack of piggy (bacon, cheddar, chives. no, I'm not kidding) pancakes, and a old fashioned milkshshake. Yes it was too much, but it was also everything I wanted right at that moment. The service was super friendly, and I really enjoyed sitting outside soaking up the Portrero Neighborhood vibe. I dig it!
author: Caddy M.

description:
This place was deserted all through the 90s as soon as hipsters found out about it , it's become a huge hit in the neighborhood , of course I have to see what these non native people think San Francisco flavor is , so I tried it not once but twice ...
Reaction - mcdonalds breakfast is served with more flavor and you don't have to wajt 44 min in line with hipsters talking about mommy and daddy's trust find to sit down
author: Angelo G.

description:
The Mission is a microcosm of the ultra-diverse San Francisco. The dot-com boom and subsequent gentrification were responsible for the development of its "micro-culture". It has its own distinct identity and is pretty diverse in its own right. This translates into the diversification of eateries and drinking spots as well.

On one end of the spectrum, there are of course the taquerias which are the equivalent of Starbucks: there's one in every corner. Then there are the fine dining establishments that have put The Mission on the map as the center of the foodie revolution. On the other end are the dive bars, the late night hotdog vendors, the liquor store delis... 

And then there's St. Francis Fountain. 

This retro-diner sticks out like a sore thumb in the predominantly Latin-inspired stretch that is 24th Street, Mission. 

As soon as you enter the place, you are transported back in time. Once an ice cream parlor/candy store, they still retain some of their merchandise in glass display cases (for display only). From Gobstoppers to Mork & Mindy collectible cards with bubble gum to Pez dispensers and a bucket of Bazooka Joe. Give that section a quick gander and you will literally feel like a kid in a candy store. 

The food is nothing to be excited about. All standard breakfast fare. They do have a good selection of Mitchell's ice cream and I feel obligated to order a milkshake the next time I'm here because let's face it, that's what 10 year old me would do. 

The novelty of having an ice cream parlor around the corner from where I live that serves breakfast while reminding me what it was like to be a kid is definitely enough to rank this among one of my favorite places to go to in The Mission. 

4.6 stars
author: Angelo B.

description:
I love diner food and this falls easily in that category. Quick, tasty and clean.
Pancakes are good all over the US and this place is no exception
author: N A.

description: Typical diner food in a classic diner vibe.  Lines are a bit ridiculous though and staff seem stressed because of it.
author: Kim K.

description:
Recommended item: Chef's Mess and a root beer float for dessert. 

Good for brunch, good service, nice place.
author: Joy A.

description:
The feel of the place is cool, they have super old school candy for sale, mostly just to have.. not to eat, it's that old school. The customer service that night was not too great though. The servers were very inattentive, but friendly at the same time. 

The food was not anything special for a diner. I tried the side platter which was a cup of chilli, a garden salad, and a cup of Mac n cheese, its a good deal. The Mac n cheese was really good. Then I tried what tasted like a chocolate soda, delicious!! I forgot what is was called but it was so good, it was their basic ice cream soda.. Must try!

The chocolate ice cream soda is what really won me over and made it possible to give them 4 stars.
author: S F.

description:
Good thing going.

Do not underestimate a small "pile of spuds". Part of the Vegan Thing specialty topped with vegan cheese, salsa, guacamole and onions. Added a side of egg whites.

Perhaps they made a large instead because a massive mound of food was delivered. And consumed because each and every bite was outstanding.

Really didn't have room for a vegan chorizo hash side but couldn't say no to the rich delicious flavor.

Definitely didn't have room for a parfait but couldn't stop devouring sweet local granola, bananas, pineapple, strawberries, apples and what tasted like nonfat plain yogurt.

Also good was the enthusiastic and infectious service. And we were equally happy to be eating outside on a warm February Saturday. Wait was a short 15min.

Reasonable $20/person included my dining companion's much enjoyed dish, orange juice, coffee and being so full we didn't need lunch.

More than good. Five star great.
author: Jason B.

description:
Great for vegans and meat eaters.

Good vegan chorizo, good potato thing, decent breakfast burrito (could've used more seasoning or beans or veggies).
author: meaghan d.

description: Delicious food, great service and a lively atmosphere where you can still relax. The decor is can and the waiting staff very helpful in guiding us through the menu.
author: Jen V.

description:
Every time I've wanted to eat here the line has been really long so I've always passed.  The gods must have been on my side a few weekends ago though because I got a parking spot right out in front and there was a list but we had a larger group so got sat right away.  It's an awesome diner spot with really good food.  I had the chef's mess and it had everything in it which was exactly what I was looking for.  My wife had the country breakfast and loved it too.

If you can get here and there's not a line check it out.  Heck, even if there is a line, stay in it because it will be worth it.
author: Blake B.

description:
Long wait (45+ mins) on a Saturday morning for mediocre food here. I had the chef's vegetarian mess, which was not very good. The portion was very large, but the veggie chorizo wasn't particularly tasty and the dish was definitely mostly potato. Not a ton of flavor and the potatoes were quite plain. 

The service was ok; no thank you's or smiles but met expectations I suppose. It wasn't a terrible experience, but I wouldn't go back.
author: Adam S.

description:
It's a long walk from the 24th street BART station but it's well worth it for these yummy breakfasts. Get there early to avoid the lines (there's a bench outside if you don't) and indulge in hefty portions for bargain prices. My fave? The scramble with green onions, cheddar and bacon. Comes with spuds and toast and you're done til dinner.

Oh, and super veggie/vegan friendly!
author: Leigh W.

description: Just like grandma used to make served by hipsters.  Just fond this place and I have been back twice already.   Simply one of the best breakfast in SF.  Staff is great and the only old fashioned soda fountain that I have seen in years.
author: brett b.

description:
St. Francis Fountain is one of those places I've been meaning to go to for the longest time, but for whatever reason, just haven't. 

This past week, that finally changed. After striking out at Golden Era (closed on a Tuesday?!) and Weird Fish (closed for a private party?!), we decided on St. Francis. Since it was a week night, there were a ton of empty tables, which was a nice welcome compared to the last time I tried to eat there (a weekend morning) when we were told our wait would be an hour or two. 

When we walked in we were told to sit wherever we pleased. So we sat at a nice table in the back. "Oh wait, not that one, in case a party of more than four comes in" is what we were told. Oh, okay. So we moved to another table. No big deal, although no larger party did come in during our time there (about an hour before closing).

I get the menu and I'm stoked to see all the vegan options. A bit later our drink orders are taken. A friend gets a Diet Coke. Another gets a Vanilla Coke. I hold off because I'm eyeing the soy milkshakes.

Server comes a bit later. A friend orders first. She wants one of the Things (not certain if she orders the Vegan one or the Nebulous Potato one). Only catch, she wants black beans instead of homefries. We are told that the chef will refuse to make it this way, because the homefries are important for the "structural integrity" of the dish. OK fine. So she orders something else.

I am torn between a few items, so I decide to ask some questions. 

Since the Chorizo and Eggs is calling out my name, I think that maybe I'll get that with tofu instead of eggs, even though that substitution costs an extra dollar or two. So I ask if they have vegan sour cream. The answer of which is no. 

This is surprising to me, because they have vegan cheese and vegan other things. Additionally, anyone who KNOWS breakfast knows that sour cream is an important component in the "structural integrity" of potatoes. So why they cater to the vegan crowd on almost everything else but sour cream is baffling, but again, fine.

Instead, I decide to get the Vegan Thing. I really want black beans instead of homefries, but I'd rather have vegan cheese than no sour cream. I need some kind of fake dairy to satiate my hunger.

Alongside this, I order that shake I've been lusting after since the second we walked in.

Moments later, our server returns to inform me that they're out of soy for the shakes. Insert sad face here. Instead, I decide to get a vanilla coke as well, since I've just tasted my companion's and it's quite good. Server goes to get it and returns shortly, saying they just ran out of vanilla coke - in fact, my friend got the last one. Which is annoying because not only are they out of it, but I'd also assumed that a diner like SFF would make their own - you know, regular coke with vanilla infusion. I mean, even Denny's does this on their own. But oh well, I settle for a diet vanilla coke, which is just fine in my book.

So we're sitting and chatting and waiting for our food when our server returns again to inform me that the chef has just begun making my meal and realizes that they're out of vegan cheese. Uh what?

Begrudgingly, I settle on the Vegan Chorizo Hash & Tofu instead. Which is twice-removed from the meal I really wanted, but whatever, I'm starving.

A minute or two passes and he comes out with my friends' meals. Mine doesn't come out for another 10 or so. So by the time they've finished their meals, I'm less than halfway through. As their plates are being cleared, I just ask for a to-go box, because we have some place we need to get to, and my food just isn't that good anyway.

The check comes, and my coke is comped. That's all. While I'm not expecting handouts, and I don't blame anyone for my subpar dining experience, it was still super disappointing that my entire time there felt more like a hassle than a pleasure. And while any singular instance of what happened wouldn't have bothered me, the fact that so many things went wrong, one after another, was discouraging.

I don't know - call me a cynic, or an asshole, but if a menu boasts having lots of vegan options, I'd think that actually having those vegan ingredients on hand would be important to the "structural integrity" of its claim.
author: Natalye R.

description: I've been here about 3 times now I must say each time gets better!! This place is one of those places that surprises you with what's inside. If you like flavorful breakfast you must order one of their omelettes or their potato dishes-- and definitely get banana bread on the side. Overall, this is one my favorite breakfast places in the city!
author: Reina C.

description: What a great breakfast joint! Being new to the Bay Area, I have been craving a greasy spoon dinner that takes me back home. Oh man did this place exceed expectations. An amazing fluffy omelette and dressed spuds are the way to go.
author: Sabah R.

description:
Love the whole atmosphere of this place, I really wished there was something like this in Vancouver. The classic booths, posters, candy shop near the front, and the retro style menu completes the whole place. 

Menu consists of lots of great choices for breakfast food, eggs, tofu scrambles, potatoes...After much deliberation, I settle on a scramble with avocado, cilantro, cheddar & salsa. In lieu of toast, you have your choice of English muffin, homemade biscuits, cornbread, or banana bread. Of course, I choose the homemade biscuit. 

Coffee served in one of those classic style cups and handwritten bills make this place even cooler. 

My scramble was delicious. Lots of avocado, and a fresh cilantro salsa, all within the eggs. Biscuits were warm and soft, and the homefries were crispy enough and not too oily. It was also a generous portion.

Watching them make the sundaes almost tempted me to have one with my breakfast. The large dallop of whipped cream at the top was almost too hard to say no to. With a full stomach from the food, I simply had to refuse. 

Their candy collection is also impressive- Nerds, Bazooka bubble gum, pop rocks, jawbreakers; it brings me right back to my childhood days. 

If I lived here, I'm sure I'd be a regular patron, even if it's just for the ice cream.
author: Vincci L.

description:
If only we could keep the Mission as genuine as this place.. 

Food is amazing.. Surprisingly complicated.. Don't argue.. Can you make biscuits like that? Didn't think so. 

Service is diner style.. Not 5 star but effective and friendly. 

Value is the star here- lots of food for great prices. 10$ for a plate big enough to share. Beautiful.

Bonus points for the random hidden menu treasure: Champagne+Apple juice. Yum.

As far as the wait: we showed up at ab 10 on Sunday and had no wait- by 11 there was ab 10 people waiting. Still not bad for the value.
author: Sydney S.

description:
My wife and I went here for a late breakfast, this past Wednesday last week, while we were on our vacation in San Francisco.
I ordered the three egg omelette served with salsa, avacado and cheddar w/ home fries and she had two eggs over easy with bacon and home fries...we also had coffee.....we finished with a couple of egg creams as a light dessert.....Our breakfasts were very filling, and everything was very good, and gave us the energy for our 1.5 mile hike through the "Muir Woods" later that afternoon, which was part of our bus tour around San Francisco! The server was very nice also! This was a memorable
part of our trip to the San Francisco/Bay Area....
It makes you feel like you were time traveling in the early 1900s,1918 to be exact! The vintage decor and the variety of details, are very atmospheric and added to the breakfast/dining experience! St Francis Fountain is definitely a great place to visit when in San Francisco because this is where the locals /natives eat!
Their menu is pretty big and has a lot of great choices for breakfast, lunch and dinner and many
delicious fountain favorites! This is the oldest ice cream parlor in San Francisco! Enjoy!
author: Joseph P. A.

description: Breakfast was great here. The menu has a lot of variety, I almost didn't know what to choose. The biscuits with gravy were delicious! The area is pretty cool and worth the trip if visiting San Francisco. We left with quite a few trading cards and old time candies  that brought us right back to the 80's.
author: Traci P.

description: We were looking for pancakes and stumbled upon this gem of a restaurant. Great diner environment and food was excellent!  We will definitely go again!
author: Cindy S.

description: What happens with you take an old-fashioned soda fountain and mix it with healthy food -- HEAVEN! They have the best food in a great ambiance and the service is awesome too. Expect a wait on the weekends but it is worth it. The huevos rancheros are awesome and I lived in Mexico for 4 years so I should know!
author: Cynthia N.

description:
This is the first place I ate at in San Fran.  Great service and tasty breakfast.  
I love how they have tofu as an option (don't find that too often at a diner). 
This place is historic, check it out!
author: Nikki A.

description: Awesome staff really good Mexican food! And great great service!  I'd come back for breakfast any day!
author: Anonymous T.

description:
Where do I begin? I've been here 3 separate times and each time I've been more than satisfied, a bit remorseful (gluttony) but satisfied nonetheless.

Vegan Pancakes: Fluffy, soft and flavorful. You have the option of fruit, I opt'd for the strawberries first time and blueberries the next. Each time the fruit is fresh and crisp

French Toast Delight: If you need to make weight for a boxing match or just want to beef up quick, this is the breakfast plate for you. A couple pieces of French toast drowned in diced fruit, granola, and a drizzle of yogurt. Absolutely F#%^ING DELIGHTFUL. You'll feel fat but with a healthy twist.

I wish I would've tried other things besides breakfast but I can only assume that they're just as awesome as their counterparts.

Overall really good food, warm and attentive service (considering how busy and how they're staffed), and just good vibes.

If you live or are in the SF area check them out, you won't be sorry.
author: Clouob P.

description: Maybe I'm nostalgic for the original St. Francis' homemade chocolates and actual fountain feel, but this place just doesn't cut it. And I really don't get the hype. Food is not good, service is super slow and sometimes verges on apathetic. My husband likes it but I say no to him 3 out of 4 times he suggests it. It's so close that I sometimes relent and regret it each time. I've tried just about everything on the menu. Blah.
author: R A.

description: Drove and walked by St. Francis Fountain numerous times wondering what the big deal is with the long lines.  In my mind this was known as the small diner with the long lines in the Mission.  One random weekday while I was off from work, I decided to try this place out because as fate had it there was no line.  We decided to order the Chef's Mess, the Nebulous Potato Thing and a Banana Split.  Everything was delicious.  The Nebulous Potato Thing looked small, but was VERY heavy.  Both dishes had tons of flavor and seems like they were coordinately thrown together.  I'd probably return to this place if I was lucky enough to go back with no line.
author: Christine D.

description: Mediocre food, filled with douchey hipsters. I'm a San Francisco native who had to sit across from a sign that read "It's your San Francisco too" to only make these entitled gentrifiers feel more comfortable. Never going back. The breakfast burrito was one I could make at home.
author: Nia B.

description:
"My family is going to be so happy that you're 'refining' me..."

Attempt #1: Foie gras at Fifth Floor: *disgusted look*

Attempt #2: Sushi at Ino: "So how is this different from Sushi Rock?"

Attempt #3: Wine tasting in Napa: "BIG BOY SHOTS!" *chugs and pounds fist on table*

FAIL. Hey, at least I tried. 

OK, Back to Basics...

Founded in 1918, St. Francis Fountain operated as a candy store and ice cream parlor. 10 years ago, the current owners installed a kitchen turning St. Francis Fountain into a greasy spoon diner while keep the nostalgia of the early 1900s ice cream parlor with swirly retro stools. Serving breakfast ALL day, St. Francis Fountain has an extensive all-American breakfast menu with weekend specials (5 eggs benedict variations), a nice vegan selection, and $4 mimosas! They also have soups, salads, sandwiches and burgers on the menu. Don't forget to stop by their candy counter to revive the fat kid in you (mines never left) with Pop Rocks, Necco Wafers, Ring Pops and Sugar Daddys. 

Since Mr. NSS loves breakfast food, I thought St. Francis Fountain would be a great place to bring him. Do expect a wait on the weekends. On a Sunday afternoon at 2:30 PM, there was still a 10-15 minute wait. On the bright side, parking is much easier in this part of The Mission and Humphry Slocombe Ice Cream is just several blocks away.

While enjoying the 80s and 90s throwbacks playing in the background, Mr. NSS had the Chef's Mess ($10) which was an artery-clogging behemoth of a thing in a bowl. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Zx_VDLeaFdnMFkGyorDZtQ?select=8-4ip_RG5nlesdN-19dNog#8-4ip_RG5nlesdN-19dNog Crispy homefries with scrambled eggs, bacon, and mushrooms topped with melted cheese, tomatoes & sour cream. If that wasn't enough, he added avocado (+$1.50) and KILLED the entire thing. How he doesn't gain weight is beyond me. *shakes fist* I went with the Cheese Omelet w/ Jack Cheese, Sausage & Spinach ($8.50) and substituted the homefries for fruit. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Zx_VDLeaFdnMFkGyorDZtQ?select=8-4ip_RG5nlesdN-19dNog#jgh1aNh3Bw5YrkaQMrXu0w My fluffy omelet was filled with just the right amount of cheese for that slight oozing effect once cut. The sausage gave a rich porky bite while the spinach was added just to make me feel better from the cholesterol-filled dish. Umm, at least it was Atkins-friendly (I didn't eat the bread)? =X

Service was friendly enough and drink refills were promptly made. This is very much a hipster place so make sure to come with your skinny jeans, fedora, and black-rimmed glasses. 

After several FAILED attempts of trying to "refine" Mr. NSS, I've come to terms that guys like and appreciate simplicity. I can't fathom the thought IF I had brought him to The Rotunda for brunch that day. http://www.yelp.com/biz/the-rotunda-san-francisco#hrid:KJ8pg1WEqrfmHuGxan9yiA 

*PINKY UP* anyone?
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
This place is a classic. Just great food, a relaxed atmosphere, and great staff.

The breakfast burrito is a favorite (add bacon, etc.), the huevos also good, griddle combo is wonderful (French toast or pancakes, you can't go wrong), never had anything here I didn't like.

The wait is probably the shortest of most brunch spots in the mission, but beware for parties of 4 or more.
author: Wilson L.

description: Adorable restaurant, adorable waiter. Food was cold, but edible. Fruit cup was good and fresh. Probably better for sandwich and ice cream. Unfortunately we were going for breakfast.
author: Alyssa C.

description: Amazing service, great food!!! First timer and will return!!! It was a great experience!!!!
author: Anais E.

description: I love this place!! It is such a cute diner and they have great vegan breakfast options! The food and service are always excellent!!
author: Wendy T.

description:
If you love breakfast food, you've come to the right place. St. Francis Fountain serves breakfast all day.

If you have a hangover, you're in luck. They've got a lot of egg dishes and enough coffee refills to set you straight. 

If you're looking for huge portions, search no more. Bring a friend for sharing.

My boyfriend and I split a Chef's Mess, which is basically a delicious mountain of scrambled eggs, bacon, mushrooms, tomatoes, cheese, and sour cream on a plate. We were both stuffed and there was still some left over!

We were there on a weekday so we didn't have to deal with the lines. Plus we got pretty attentive service and were able to savor our eggy forkfuls in peace.
author: Racquel N.

description:
I've been frequenting St Francis' on and off for almost twenty years.

Twenty fugging years, ok?

Before the Mission became the new Beverly Hills, before the dot.com era and long before Christies' was ever interested in real estate around the 24th and York neighborhood. My girlfriend went there as a child in the 70s, over 40 years ago. That adds up to a lot of egg creams over the years, pal.

So when I sit down in a booth and proceed to wait for a half an hour for a coffee, I get annoyed. Granted, it was a Saturday, it was busy and it was understaffed. But you know what? That's not my problem. Its just not. I'm a restauranteurs' kid and if I ever had provided that kind of service, I'd of gotten fired, family be damned.

Get a new manager and provide better service or get out of the business by selling out while you can. Not to be a dick, just being honest. I don't want you guys to go out of business, if you're reading this.. I just want the kind of service I had gotten before the neighborhood turned into fucking Connecticut.
author: Sam P.

description:
I am on a streak of giving out 5 stars, but this place deserves nothing less. It doesn't look super welcoming from the outside but maybe because it's so old fashioned. Good thing I don't judge a book by its cover because this place is great. It's like a time warp. Metered parking outside, $2 an hour.

Water was served right away. I appreciate this because a lot of places you have to request it. I had the Modesto pesto sandwich with fries. Toasted bread with pesto spread on both slices, chicken, tomato, onion. Yum. The fries were also nice and crispy. Bomb. Coffee was great. My GF had a sandwich with side salad. She liked it. They made someone a shake and gave us the leftovers. How nice.

Best of all, the price: something like $22 for 2 people. I gave them a decent tip for the pleasurable experience.
author: Marty J.

description:
My cousin was visiting from out of town and I would like to say that I am hip and with it enough to know to take her to this place, but that would make me a liar. I'm not even sure how she found out about this place, but I'm so happy she did. It's so good and it's just a short bus or BART ride away from my school!

The portions are quite large so we shared two breakfasts: the French toast and the small nebulous potato thing. I think this was more than enough food, but she also ordered a shake because they serve Mitchell's ice cream and she really wanted to try Mitchell's. Everything was amazing!

One tip I will offer is to try to go on a weekday. We went on a Wednesday morning and there was plenty of open seats. We got a booth and it was great, but I could see the experience having been very different if we went on a weekend.
author: Rezal G.

description:
My own little slice of Portland, OR, right here in the Mission. If you're looking for your hipster fix of brunch hashes, benedicts, and wraps, this is your place!

Considering I haven't lived in hipster-heaven for nearly a year now, I found it refreshingly not-San-Francisco-upscale-breakfast. However, a word of warning: I got very lucky by plopping myself down at the front counter and ordering a coffee from one guy who was just on his game in terms of customer service. Later, when he had to check my reservation for table to sit down at with my friend, his co-worker responded with "I don't care, I'm not front of the house anymore."

So very very hipster.

Luckily, my waiter just said eff it and sat us down and delivered great service anyway. Turns out, you can be a hipster without being a jerk, and that was nice to see. However, if he hadn't been my waiter, I'm worried this review might have dipped a star.

The hash I had was tasty, although the menu didn't mention it having Bell Peppers in it, which I'm mildly intolerant of. I ate around them, but I think menus should list all major ingredients, and it wasn't like there was a small bit of peppers involved here.

Coffee was good, and flowed freely at the counter -- a little less so at the table. The noise level was quite manageable, and the overall quality of ingredients used was solid. I'd go back to be sure.
author: Amy P.

description:
This was one of my favorite spots, this was the first brunch spot we visited with my bf together. 
This might be last time visiting this place. Many many times in the past, i had terrible service experience. 
That time we came, they said they run out of eggs benedict, only 1 portion left, cool, we ordered 3 others, and eventually last eggs benedict didnt arrive as well... Oh sorry, i thought u ordered this. 
Always a situation with seating. They have this list, but oh well, enforced it! When some ppl walk in and seat, they did nothing, just let them be there. That time when we arrived and asked for table, they give the table to the one who arrived after us, because they just feel like it. Disclosure, it happed today, at closing, when the place was half full, and it was raining, we were by the door, so yes, we asjed to seat, they like dont u want to seat at counter, why would we if so many tae are open?! Then they say wait, then a couple came in and they seated them.  
Occasionaly forgeting you ordered a milkshake. It's done, leaving, then i need to take my milk shake to go. Constantly making you wait forever to order. Just being transparent there. 
Then offer free 1 dish for apology, i dont need that, i came to have brunch, with line, wait and eat i want it to be in 1.5 hrs, never come at times when the line is super long. But it takes 2-2 hrs 15 mins, cuz they dont seat you, they seat someone else, they dont serve you or they forget the order! 
Havent visited here for a year, went back today, again dissapointment. I guess no more. The food isnt that good either, worth than before, so overrated.
author: Nataly S.

description:
Not impressed but maybe I went in with too high of expectations?

The only reason I can think of why there are people lined up outside for a table every weekend is that its a hipster hot spot.

The food is just breakfast diner food - greasy, cheesey..potatoes, sour cream, eggs.  Also try biscuits that although are homemade, are not worth getting.

Maybe it was my fault - I love brunch...but maybe "new american brunch" if that even makes sense.  I'm thinking plow, bar tartine, universal cafe.. I guess if you love that kind of stuff this is not the place for you either.  

At least now I know.
author: Melody T.

description:
One of my favorite breakie spots in the city! 

Perfect for those mornings when your stomach needs to be greased up a bit, if ya know what I mean. I have had vegan rancheros (great twist on one of my favorite dishes from back when I was a "regular" vegetarian), the vegan "thing", a banana walnut pancake, and the vegan sausage patties. I can't complain about any of the above but I'm definitely more of a ranchero kinda lady than I am a potatos-for-breakfast kinda lady! 

I love the vibe, the diner style, and the no-frills service. My dining compadres have all loved their meaty dishes as well. I make it a point to venture here whenever I am in town! YUM.
author: Bailey M.

description:
great breakfast place serving all day! old school "fountain" serving surprisingly good food, great shakes and malts. If you're not familiar with the neighborhood, 24th St. corridor is true to the "real" Mission district, with lots of small eateries, bars and shops under a leafy canopy.

Pros:

Veggie lovers will enjoy the menu choices.
Food is very good.
They use Mitchell's ice cream in the shakes. Oh yeah.
There is outdoor seating on the sidewalk.
Servers care about what they're doing, and are very helpful.

Cons:
If you're not a smoker, sidewalk seating may not be for you.
You'll wait awhile on the weekends.

Afterward, take a stroll up 24th and check out the Balmy St. murals ( http://www.yelp.com/biz/balmy-street-murals-san-francisco ) and walk off that huge vanilla malt you just gulped down!
author: John H.

description:
While Yelp searching places in the area for a good Vegan breakfast/brunch I found there are several quality options around here. St. Francis Fountain just happened to be the pick of the day. And what a good choice it was...

Old school 50's style dining brought to you by Mission Hipsters. I had read reviews that stated the servers here are aloof or dirty. I found the opposite to be true for the most part. Our coffee and water never got empty without being refilled. The food came out to the table lightning quick as well. 

The only mishap was when our waitress was a bit... ok, very confused while taking our order. Vegan Blueberry Pancakes were repeated back to us twice with "Buttermilk Pancakes". So once that confusion was solved our order came out extremely fast to the point were we thought it wasn't ours. So what did we get instead of Vegan Blueberry Pancakes? That's right, a Vegan Breakfast Burrito... Huh? It turned out to be a good thing since they asked if we would like to keep the burrito while they would whip up the correct pancake order. Free food? Score!

The Tofu Scramble with Ranchero was delicious even though it appeared to be undercooked and not very scrambled. Since I don't eat with my eyes I dove into the flavors of all the Ranchero sauce mixed with the tofu, mushrooms and green onions. One of the better tasting scrambles I've had in awhile. Coupled with a generous portion of tasty spuds along with a few slices of toast, this is a huge shareable dish.  

Those Vegan Blueberry Pancakes that took some haggling to get weren't too bad. I like blueberries as much as anyone but I think they went a little buck wild with the blueberry scooper. The entire center was blueberries. They were good, not great. I would probably get one of the other Vegan options next time.

That free Vegan Breakfast Burrito plate was something I would consider ordering next visit. The black beans on the side had a bit of a chili kick to them. Very tasty. The filling was consisted mostly of a Vegan jack cheese. Not sure what they use but it was a change of pace from the usual burrito. 

A pretty cool atmosphere along with all the great Vegan options makes this a place you should check out at least once to see if it's for you.
author: John B.

description: The corn beef hash is out of this world! Was craving pancakes and simple eggs... Lets just say it was ALL gone and I was stuffed to the max. My friend subbed her toast for banana bread, please do this! Higher prices simply because they give you great portions!
author: Morgan R.

description:
Coming to St Francis Fountain had been on my list for sometime but the thought of huge lines & long waits always put it farther down my list so on a random rainy Saturday we took a chance & made a drive by & lo & behold, the line was teeny!  BF jumps out to get our name on the list while I find parking.....

We stood there for maybe 5 min then we were in, baby!

Now the tough part....what to get!  Seeing that the dishes all around us were ginormous, we knew there'd be no now & later action & it was time to commit....

Veggie Chef's Mess is what it's all about!

Veggie Chorizo & ground soy all mixed in w/ scrambled eggs & the tenderest potatoes all covered in cheese, sour cream & guac.....YUM!!!  This was soft, creamy, & savory & the perfect remedy for a cold rainy morning

And what made it even better was pairing it w/ their homemade biscuits - those fluffy, doughy dreams were perfectly dolloped w/ the table strawberry jam - so we got a little sweet w/ our savory b/c afterall, there should *never* be a meal w/out dessert!

OJ was good but mighty small - next time it'll be a large for sure

And seeing all the pancakes & delish eggy dishes floating by us only made us want to come back soon as possible.....we're fans!
author: Adrienne G.

description:
St Francis is an institution, a relic, an antique and a classic.
It is also, a dump.

The food here is clear diner with nostalgic treats and a few twists of this century. You won't come here for the atmosphere - or maybe you will, if you're looking to get down and dirty with the bearded hipsters and just not care if you washed your hair at ALL this...month.

Dishes stand up to anything the grunge detracts. Nebulous Potato Thing is something you can only get here, and so, you should.

Sweet, thoughtful waiters and personality, that's that.
author: Katie W.

description:
Items Selected:
Dreamsicle - Milk, Orange Juice, Vanilla, Vanilla Ice Cream, Orange Sherbet, Whipped Cream, Cherry on top
Warm Brownie
French Toast Delight - Yogurt, Granola, Apples, Bananas, Strawberries, Pineapple

Exiting east out of Knead and waltzing down 24th Street towards Dynamo Donuts it was with long-held interest that I once again passed by St. Francis Fountain and with daily selections less than inspiring from the small storefront at 2760 I finally decided to quell my curiosity, a short walk back just one block landing me at a two-top in the 1918 soda fountain.  Kitschy in décor with toys and trading cards from my youth available for purchase in a glass case while booths and tables sat tightly spaced juxtaposing the Formica bar it would be mere moments before I was greeted by the diner's lone server and confirming hopes of an 'all-day' menu my order quickly took shape, a duo of childhood favorites readied at the counter along with French Toast arriving less than ten minutes later.  Eschewing coffee in favor of things far sweeter it was in the classic Dreamsicle that my indulgence began and with Mitchell's vanilla ice cream beneath a hefty scoop of orange sherbet plus just enough liquid to make the concoction sippable through a straw memories of meals at Friendly's as a youngster came flooding back, a warm wedge of brownie delivered simultaneously equally worthy of reminiscence in its sheer simplicity - a lack of 'artisan' details oddly satisfying given the setting.  Already all smiles as patrons aged five to seventy-five slowly began to trickle through the doors it was with my drink still half-full but the brownie long gone that my two slices of griddled sourdough next arrived and buried beneath a mountain of granola, fresh fruit, and tangy yogurt there was only one thing to do - a $1 supplement of pure maple syrup quickly flooding the plate adding an exclamation point to my 'delight.'
author: Michael U.

description:
+Breakfast served ALL DAY
+Got a full order of corned beef hash. You can get it as a side order, too: awesome
+Got the banana bread with my corned beef because why not?
+Good coffee
+Tasty jam
+Diner prices without having to deal with Flo as your server
author: Adena B.

description:
We dropped by here on Saturday morning, expecting a long wait for a table.  Surprisingly, we got a table in 3 minutes.
My partner likes this place so he was very happy.
For breakfast, I had a country breakfast with biscuits & gravy while my partner ordered a ham and cheese omlet.
