I am very picky about biscuits and gravy and was mildly disappointed.  The biscuits were dense and heavy rather than being light and fluffy.  The gravy was not very tasty.  But the potatoes were good, although a bit charred.  The eggs were fine, but I wasn't that hungry so I didn't eat much of them.
My partner enjoyed his breakfast very much and nearly finished the whole plate.
After such a big breakfast, we took a stroll down 24th Street to walk off some of the meal.
I would return again, but choose something else from the menu.
author: Philip C.

description:
Okay, I went back to give it another try.  Again, the service was awful.  The men who work in this place are punks with terrible attitudes.  It's like this restaurant doesn't hire actual servers.  It's like they hire frat guys, who are rude.

I give the food 4 stars, the decor 5 stars and the service 1 star.  A few days ago I went there with my husband.  When we walked in, we saw the sign that said "please wait to be seated".  So we waited.  Just then one of the male employees told us to have a seat anywhere.  We walked in and saw a booth.  I was concerned whether it was okay for 2 people to take a booth, but it was really the only table that we saw and when I looked at it I noticed that it was set up with TWO place settings.  I thought to myself that if it has only TWO place settings, then it must be okay for 2 people to sit there.  And besides that, they are really small booths. So we sat down.  A couple seconds later, some other guy comes over and tells us that they want to save the booth for 4 people.  So I immediately get up and say that we will move to another table if there is one and they point to one near the door.  

As we are walking I commented to the one who asked us to move that the only reason we though it was okay to sit there was because there were only 2 place settings there and that to prevent confusion, maybe they should put 4 place settings there.  So, he throws me attitude and says "usually people wait to be seated!!!"  Inferring that we sat there without permission.  I was very insulted and that rude guy never came over to apologize once he found out that a different guy had told us to take a seat anywhere.  

This whole experience ruined our whole meal.  The female server we had was fine.  Not super nice or anything.  Very business like, but did a good job.  

Oh and by the way.  $12.75 for an omelette.  Come on now!  Isn't that a little ridiculous for an omelette in the Outer Mission.  You guys are gonna become the next Joe's Cable Car restaurant!!
author: Daniel S.

description:
I have been eagerly anticipating eating at St. Francis after reading the description of the Neubulous Potato Thing on a blog. My heart skipped a beat when I saw all the veggie options on the menu. Phoenix is hardly veggie-friendly so having all those choices was overwhelming.

Although I studied the menu a few times before my trip, I still had trouble making up my mind. I decided to go with veggie burro with scrambled tofu. I'm not a vegan, but I figured I should take advantage of the tofu availability since it's almost non-existent at home. The burrito was good overall, but I was disappointed in the bland ranchero sauce. I guess that's one area where Phoenix usually shines.

My husband had the Nebulous potatoes which were just as awesome as promised. He loved his fluffy biscuits and gravy too. We gulped down lots of their strong coffee since we got up at 3am for our flight. It did the trick!

I really loved the staff here. Not only were they efficient and friendly; I also dug the laid-back, hipster vibe. Again, coming from super homogenized Phoenix, it was so refreshing to see people with unique style rather than the whole Ken and Barbie thing I see at home.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Best hangover cure in the city!

I'm pretty certain that of the times I've come here, I've been a bit hungover basically every time, and I've always left feeling completely better.

They have a fantastic array of vegan options, and they aren't significantly more expensive than the regular options, which is a nice change from the "vegan tax" at most places.

They have super thick vegan shakes, which is awesome, but for some reason, they tell me that the vegan ones take longer to mix, so when I ordered one, the wait was something ridiculous like 20 minutes before my shake was done. Whaaaaaat. And then the straws--while being super cute, old school-style red and white swirl straws--lose their integrity in fairly short order and basically dissolve and stop transporting shake from glass to mouth. Paper straws: probably better for the environment, but freaking impossible to use to drink a thick shake.

The hipster quotient here is painfully high. I'm always turn between rolling up my sleeves so that they'll see my tattoos--you know, waving my feathers and strutting and clucking and whatever to show that I'm not afraid of them--or deliberately disguising anything about myself that doesn't look hella yuppie so that they will be forced to deal with this odious outsider among them. Alternately, in my surly hungover state, I want to shake both waitstaff and patrons and scream "Why do you deliberately wear outfits that clash and fit you in unflattering ways so that you are actively making yourself uglier? WHYYYYYYY?" However, I can tolerate absurdly high levels of hipsterdom in exchange for tasty brunch and hangover amelioration.

So, on the one hand, the food is awesome and the shop is super cute. On the other hand, your hangover might elevate from unpleasant to genuinely nauseous based on some of the things people there wear.

I guess I'm just getting old. Goddamn kids these days and whatnot.
author: Vivienne P.

description: Staying in San Francisco in an AirBNB for our honeymoon, and this place was on a list of good local places given to us by our host. It was great! We went for breakfast, and while we were surprised by the high prices ($12 for omelets), we quickly saw why it's so expensive: they give you SO much food and it's delicious! I got the omelet with avocado, salsa, cheese, and cilantro and added bacon to it. I couldn't even finish it, it was piled so high. The atmosphere was sweet and vintage with fun, old music playing. Our server was very attentive, especially for being the only one at the time we came in. Overall, great!
author: Amy F.

description: This place is located in san francisco and it has been open for 100 years.  This place probably has the best corn beef hash I have ever tried.  Seriously nothing can compare to any other corn beef hash.  Its nice and extra crispy with onions and green onions on it and the seasoning on it just makes it taste even better.  The ambience is casual and this place looks really vintage.  They close really early so they really are only open for breakfast/brunch.  I wish that we got to try different things but when we are back in san francisco we will definitely come here again and I will get the same thing and maybe a milkshake.
author: KM H.

description:
During my last visit to San Francisco I ate here TWICE.  Why you ask?  Because the Vegan Thing was SO GOOD.   It took a while for me to go here because I heard that the lines were usually stupid long, but both visits proved different.  We were seated almost immediately by opting to sit at the counter.  I ordered a side of vegan sausage and the chef masterfully mixed the spuds and sausage together, it was so very tasty, tasty, tasty.  I'm so happy I have another place to go to that is vegan friendly. 
Plus, their trading card collection is BONKERS.
author: Dee J.

description:
St. Francis Fountain is one of the best brunch places in the City! It has all types of food that would make any meat-lover, vegetarian or vegan extremely happy. We didn't eat any breakfast foods - but opted for sandwiches instead. I got the Devil's burger and my husband got the polar melt. Both were delicious! For sides - I got the Mac N' Cheese and he got vegetarian chili fries! The food was top notch, and there was so much, we did not get close to finishing off the sides. (Fair to note - we even got small milkshakes.)

Great experience, great food, and awesome diner ambience. We cannot wait to go back and try a scramble or their vegan pancakes!
author: Vrinda S.

description: The only thing negative I have to say, which I can't fault them for, is that they are not closer to where I live. This the ultimate diner/soda fountain but BETTER. Seriously. Just go. You will not regret it.  I had a cheddar-bacon pancake.....if that doesn't get you there I don't know what will.
author: Brie P.

description: This place is awesome! We decided to try it randomly and it was fantastic. I got the "vegan thing" and it was the best vegan dish I've had. My friend got a two egg scramble which was awesome too. I will definitely be coming back in the future.
author: Hunter M.

description: So I wasn't really crazy about the Patty Melt I had but my daughter loved the pancakes. I usually see a crowd waiting outside so the food must be good.  Perhaps I just ordered the wrong dish.  I need to give this place another try...
author: Rose A.

description:
How on earth did these people make such yummy vegetarian and vegan diner goodies?! The last place I experienced such goodness was in Santa Cruz.

(caveat - I'm neither vegetarian or vegan. I just like to go meatless every so often)

My faves include the;
- SF Ruben - wowza I don't even miss the meat! 
- Breakfast burrito w/ soy chrizo
- Pancakes. Yay pancakes!
- Soy milkshake... great for lactose intolerant folks like me

I've come many times, and will most certainly come again :)
author: Joyce L.

description:
I came here with my mother while she was visiting me from Washington DC.  I was hoping to give her a great showing of the food offerings of San Francisco.  We came to this diner hoping for some killer country biscuits & gravy and buttermilk pancakes.  The pancakes were pretty good, as was the coffee.  The potatoes that came with the country breakfast were *fantastic*!!  But the biscuits and gravy were awful.

The ambiance was typical for that of a diner, which was exactly what we were expecting and wanted.  The service (at 10am on a Thursday morning) was less than stellar.  The server came only to take our order (late) and deliver our food and check.

Next time I'll stick with what I know...Higher Grounds Coffee House in Glen Park is ahhh-mazing!!!
author: Michele S.

description: Everything was amazing! Had the Nebulous Potato thing and my other half had the Chefs messy scramble ....HELLA GOOD! Banana Bread was on point ....this is def a must try again and again and AGAIN!
author: Char B.

description:
Amazing, vegan friendly restaurant. Come here with a mixed group, please the meat eaters and the vegans all at once. The best vegan item on the menu is by far the Devil Burger. It's the marinated seitan burger with vegan mayo, lettuce, pickles, onion, and tomatoes on a soft bun. I wish there were more items on the menu that use the seitan- it's to die for. Other great vegan items: milkshakes, the Vegan Thing with potatoes, guac, salsa, and vegan cheese, vegan pancakes, and their black beans. Great for brunch, and I recommend sitting outside when it's nice out.

Not great for groups because of limited seating options. They only accept a maximum of two cards per table- so if you're splitting the bill, we recommend that you bring cash to avoid the eye roll.
author: Nick W.

description:
Perfect Sunday hangover diner cure for carnivores with veggie/vegan friends!

The Veggie Mess has the best of all worlds: spuds, chorizo, gooey cheeses. Ask for jalapeños to get that extra kick! Order is large enough for 2 ppl or an extra kick in' hangover.

For the bread options, choose cornbread over banana bread... Unless you have a sweet tooth. Nice n toasty, Thick like a brick! 

Espresso milkshake is perfectly executed - vanilla loves cafe. Order the large. Just when you thought the fun was over, the shaker has a whole extra glass of frothy goodness waiting for ya!
author: Alison R.

description: Stop serving vegan cheese? No stars for you.
author: Stephanie N.

description: This is an authentic, old-fashioned soda fountain, established in 1918, that was rescued by new owners a few years back. They kept the vintage look, but other changes make this less than what it used to be. The ice cream, once made in-house, now comes from Mitchell's, which raises no major complaints but doesn't quite match the quality of what was once served here. Ditto for the one-time house-made candies, now replaced by pre-packaged novelty chocolates. But the menu, which features sandwiches, soups, and salads, is still moderately priced, as are the excellent sundaes.
author: Robert W.

description:
Date & Time:  Monday September 7, 2009 @ 1:30pm
Company:  Michael & Jack
Crowd:  Groups of Hipsters
Vibe:  Nostalgic
Decor:  Charming Old-Fashioned Soda Fountain & Ice Cream Parlor.  Counter-Seating for Burgers & Shakes, Wooden Booths & Al Fresco Under Red & White Stripe Awning & Chocolate Brown Walls
Service:  Nice & Friendly Hipsters
Imbibe:  Egg-Cream Soda & Guinness Float
Devour:  The Griddle & Breakfast Burrito
Total:  $27.48
 Note:  Happy Labor Day, Everybody!!!
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
Gee, with such an ecclesiastical name, I was expecting to see the apparition of the Virgin Mary at the soda fountain with the white light shining around her, uttering her opening words, "I am the Immaculate Conception...you want fries with that?" But alas, no such miracle occurred for me, though there did seem to be a pilgrimage coming to the place. OK, maybe not a pilgrimage...it was like three people, three burly, grubby-looking people with leather jackets and handkerchiefs tied to their heads. They ordered chef's salads, I think, with the dressing on the side. 

Anyway, Jamie W. and I came in after facing bitter disappointment over the depletion of the maple apple bacon donuts at Dynamo across the street. Embittered, I thought a visit to St. Francis Fountain would cheer us up. Indeed it did with its old-fashioned, creaky wooden booths like you'd see in those WWII-era movies where Mickey and Judy are doing the Lindy Hop and sipping through straws into the same ice cream soda. You know you just have to have a burger at a place as retro as this, and before you can say, "This is so Mel's", here it comes... 

Jamie had the $8.75 Patty Melt with Fries, which was good, diner-level fare, but I have to say mine just hit the spot, the $7.50 Burger with Swiss cheese and sauteed mushrooms for an extra $1.50 (see photos). Not huge but juicy and full of fixings. I went for a cup of veggie chili instead of the fries, and like the burger, it was chock full of veggies if a bit too watery. It was at this point that we got over our disappointment in missing the maple apple bacon donuts because we realized we could get good-tasting carbs and calories anywhere on 24th Street!

FOOD - 4 stars...satisfying diner fare
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...I kept picturing young George Bailey getting slapped in the ear by Mr. Gower in "It's a Wonderful Life"
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...hipster waitress seems to fit in with the dated ambiance
TOTAL - 4 stars...I didn't see the Virgin Mary, but I think I was miraculously healed from my disappointment over Dynamo
author: Ed U.

description: I've eaten here many times, and was looking forward to it. I walked in and the two staff people were just unfriendly, and unhelpful. There were at least half a dozen tables that needed to be bussed/cleaned (nobody was doing anything about that) and we were told we could either sit at the counter or wait. We chose the counter, sat down and continued to be treated rudely by the staff- barely acknowledged we were there, were brusk when managing to utter a word.  Walked out.
author: Paul D.

description: I will miss St. Francis Fountain for sure. I love everything they offer from the food to the ice cream goodness.
author: Josie C.

description:
Best diner in SF. The nicest waiters and staff of any restaurant.

I also would like the savory pancakes as my last meal before I die. 

I love you St. Francis.
author: S R.

description: This place has great breakfast!  Pancakes and eggs are hard to beat, but try the IceCream shakes.. mmmmmm.
author: Steven S.

description:
I'm frugal, so, naturally, I don't give 5 stars unless I feel like I am getting an incredible deal. Yes, to someone not from SF, St. Francis Fountain may seem a bit pricey, but I believe it is worth every penny. 

Why? 

1. Great portion sizes: 

I ordered the "Chef's Mess." It was 2 in the afternoon and the last time I had eaten was before my flight that morning. Not only did it fill me up (in conjunction with half a milkshake) but I had enough left over for breakfast the next morning. 

2. Excellent Service: 

If I can walk out of a dinner with a slight tremor because my coffee cup never runs dry...

3. Vibe: 

1918. Really. It feels like you are stepping back in time. There is a little candy stand opposite the counter that sells classic candy. If you dig nostalgia, this is the place to get your fix. 

4. Oh, yeah, good food:

Can't complain. You will not be dissappointed.
author: Luke V.

description: This place may indeed have great food, as many reviewers have suggested. I can only say that their web site says they are open daily from 8:00 AM to 10:00 PM, but when we arrived this afternoon at about 2:30, we were turned away and told they were closed for the day. What does "breakfast all day" mean if you close at 2:00 PM? #fail
author: David K.

description: Pretty good. Ordered biscuits and gravy instead of country meal by accident and when the dish came the gravy was barely luke warm. Bummer. However flavor was good. The biscuits were very powdery like a dry snickerdoodle. I wont order again. Added potatoes and over easy eggs to the side to make it the country meal: eggs were overcooked and potatoes were blah. Maybe this was in part because I ordered breakfast at noon and perhaps they rushed the eggs and potatoes since I added them on after I got the biscuits? Service was great and atmosphere was great. I'll try it again for lunch.
author: Alex C.

description:
I have been a happy diner here for years, but they recently took vegan cheese off the menu. Nowhere is that posted and they don't tell you when you order, you find out when you get your meal. 

I had the vegan rancheros and it was just 'eh' at best without it. The menu still says it has vegan jack on it and it's still $9.75, mind you...for three corn tortillas, some black beans, tofu and ranchero sauce. I barely ate it. I don't like wasting calories on mediocre food.

When I asked the waitress she said she just came in one day and it was gone. She said I'm not the only customer who's unhappy either. 

Just seems so bizarre since so many of their menu items are melts or messes. My favorite dish is the Polar Melt. Hello! MELT!

They either need to bring back the vegan cheese or change the menu descriptions and prices. 

They are getting two stars because their staff are always so nice, but I'm not wasting an hour of my life waiting for a table again unless they bring it back. Ridiculous.
author: Susie D.

description:
Have you ever feel imminent and in-demand to try a restaurant, but for some reason your proposed target spot(s) is/are closed and/or crowded with a "long" wait. We all experienced that many times, have we? "Stop lying and admit it that we all been through that!" 

Whenever I've needed to work in the 24th Street area, I've been here nearly a dozen times on my quick break; just for the milkshakes. But when I'm hungry, this 50's-like corner-diner has a long wait. So I ended up eating elsewhere for my lunch intermission. You want to talk about perfect-timing in desires and apathy. Go figure! 

Today and with the recent nice weather, lunchtime at noon was crowded with a long wait. So I, like I aforementioned, ate elsewhere. I did came back like around three o'clock where everybody is working or enjoying the weather elsewhere so I can enjoy the Coffee/Espresso Milkshake. For $5.00, the milkshake is made with coffee ice cream and espresso shots and other dairy mixture with a cloud of whipped cream and a cute maraschino cherry on top for that perfect shake. (I get too overwhelmed by saying "cute maraschino cherry"). 

I also got a $3.00 bowl of fruit that has sliced apples, pineapple, strawberries, grapes and cantaloupes to complete my snack on my break. I actually enjoy the variety of milkshakes made at this diner, but my review is incomplete until I eat something from here. 

Paid my meal in cash and a favorite of Yelp too.
author: Matt G.

description: I've eaten breakfast here and taken the kids for ice cream.  Breakfasts are great; big and hearty.  Ice cream tastes homemade.
author: Roger S.

description:
St. Francis Fountain - where the hip come to dine and the tourists come to watch them.

We head to St. Francis @ 9:50 something AM on the weekends and catch an outside table as soon as the open up @ 10 AM.  There's just 4 or 5 of them but there's plenty of space for two people and one dog.  Lately the outside tables are getting claimed by tourists with suit cases and Noe drive-ins with their strollers and SUVs.  Stay away from my table people!

The breakfast food is top notch!  Some favorites include:
* Blueberry pancakes - the wife must have blueberry pancakes fairly frequently or suffer the ills of some unstated dire curse.  Along with a side of eggs, these blueberry pancakes appear to stave off the evil.
* Hogcakes - pancakes with cheese, green onions, and bacon cooked into them.  So very yum!
* Omelets - Big two egg omelets with whatever you want in them.  They come with a side of crispy, spiced, fried potatoes that people who eat potatoes seem to love. 
* Nebulous potato thing - Uh... it's like potatoes and other stuff like kinda put together.  You know?
* Banana bread - sweet and yummy
* Corn beef hash - greasy, with peppers and potatoes and beef.  It'll make your stomach cry out, "No more!" and then "Okay, a little more!"
author: Ivan L.

description:
Ok, first off, the food is about 3.5 stars. I'm a foodie, so 3.5 stars is pretty good by most peoples standards. The reason I'm giving this place a 5 star review is because of the atmosphere. 

If you want to feel like you just stepped onto the set of Pulp Fiction, this is the place. The disinterested hipster waitstaff adds perfectly to the decor, which is very 50s diner/candy shop/San Francisco. It's a very cool place, perfect to get rid of a hangover. 

If they're busy I hear the service is pretty bad. I didn't have problems when I was there.
author: Chris P.

description: Get the nebulous potato thing - that is all! Also, be prepared to wait a bit if you are going for breakfast on a weekend after 9:30AM
author: Crystal R.

description:
Well my first review got removed ... ugh.   I have my issues with yelp removing negative reviews.

Bottom line:  We walked out due to indredibly bad service.  Plus, the food did not look like anything special.

The longer story:    First there was on one to let us know if it was first come/first serve or signup list only, or what.    After 15 minutes we got to sign up for a table and then watched 2-3 people just walk up and get seats.

In those 15 minutes we got to see a party of two looking all around for their waitress.  We watched as the pair got more and more disturbed.   When the waitress finally did show up - she made it seem like it was their fault because she was 'busy'.

25 minutes in we got seated.  Then we continued to wait.  The restaurant was not busy.  

Attitude goes a long way.   If someone is genunine, and they set fair expectations... then fine.   I can wait.  It's OK.

What I do not appreciate is the feeling that you (the customer) are there for the convenience of the staff.   And that you should be grateful that they acknowledge you at all.    Wow!  Did we get attitude.       Honestly, it was grotesque.   

I wanted a late brunch and a nice experience.    What I got is the satisfaction of walking out of a poorly run restaurant.
author: mario w.

description: I always enjoy going here for brunch because of good food. I would give it 4 stars normally, but last time I went there with my friend, after the 1 hour wait we finally got a table and we were already starving. It took them 1 hour to come to our table to take orders. Nobody checked during brunch if we needed anything, coffee, syrup, ...etc. and it took them 45 minutes after we finished to just let us pay. I even went up to the cashier and tried to pay, but they sent me back to the table. The service was horrible and I'm never going there again.
author: Sal R.

description: I really enjoyed my meal today. I had their delicious orange juice and the fried egg sandwich with avocado and tomato. It was so yummy. The bread was toasted and buttered, the cheese was sharp and my eggs were cooked perfectly. I was really happy. Service is still friendly. Wait for the food is still a bit slow and flies are everywhere. Place looks a little dirty. That's why the three stars stay.
author: Walerz B.

description: I don't know how this place is so popular. The milkshakes are homemade and they're good even if they're not my favorite. The food is pretty much crappy diner food and yet there are lines of hipsters here constantly. It adds nice culinary variety to 24th street but doesn't live up to its promise
author: Matthew G.

description:
Pistolet & Wonder Dog Rescue love the St. Francis!

Wait staff are always friendly, fun, and quick.....    I've been going there for years and love it....   
SF Ruben - favorite sandwich!
author: linda b.

description:
Disappointed. I've been here before and was very pleased with the place.

the service
I have a real problem with service not meeting basic standards. The staff was nice, but after we got our food, no one came to check on us and we actually wanted some condiments, etc to enjoy the meal. The staff was super busy, busy, busy working, but has kinda forgotten about the "customer experience" perspective and with all their running around they pretty much ignore you.

the meal
My meal was watery, Huevos Rancheros? Hard to explain but it became soupy once you started to eat it.

The side sausage patty was a hockey puck. Seriously, really really overcooked and hard.

I will spend my money elsewhere.
author: Jen T.

description:
Little bites of heaven...

I just tried the Hogcakes this time... Meredith, meet heaven. Heaven, meet Meredith's mouth. I'm super into savory cuisine, but tend to always want pancakes when I'm at a yummy breakfast diner. This is my PERFECT dish. You can choose from 2 or 3 cakes (2 is enough) and I asked for an over medium egg on the side. When it all came out, I threw the egg on top of the pancakes prior to diving in. The yolk was the perfect savory syrup for my savory cakes, which are filled with shredded cheese, chopped green onions, and... of course... CRISPY BACON!!! Yum-mah!

I'm a regular at St. Francis, so other delicious dishes that keep me coming back are: 
~ Chef's Mess: It's a whole scrambambled mess! Scrambled eggs with homefries, bacon, mushrooms, melted cheese, tomatoes, sour cream & green onions, your choice of toast on the side. 
~ Fried Egg Sandwich: 2 eggs over-hard (I ask for over-medium) & cheddar on grilled sourdough. Meat eater? Ask to add crispy bacon!
~ Huevos Rancheros: 2 eggs over-easy (I ask for over-medium) on a corn tortilla with jack cheese, ranchero sauce, salsa salad, black beans, sour cream & cilantro. 
~ EGGS BENEDICT: my favorite dish in the world: Folks, I'm a Benedict FIEND. A Connoisseur, if you will. Hollandaise sauce is the make or break, and St. Francis has got it right. Trust.   

I love their breakfast menu so much, I haven't even gotten to their lunches, dinners or ICE CREAM! Before it gets too cold out, I'll be headed there for a milkshake. I'll be sure to tell you all about it!

The menu is seemingly endless and full of all flavors you fancy and for any time of day, many vegetarian AND VEGAN options, sweet treats, and a display case full of candy for sale; makes you feel like a kid again! Adorable, old-time diner vibe, great atmosphere and outdoor seating. Weekend brunch time? Expect a short wait. The wait used to be pretty long, but they recently took over the small room next door to their main dining room which has improved the wait. It's a shorter now, most recently I had a 15 minute wait.
author: Meredith S.

description:
Years ago (2004) ,when I lived in SF, I loved this place.
I'm not sure if it has gotten worse of my standards were lower.
I feel gross after eating the corn beef hash. 
It was a dish obviously made in a hurry with no love or pride.
Its pretty expensive for what it is.
I'll never go back.
author: Francesco P.

description: An interesting retro place. Coming in for a burger and a chocolate shake.  You might take a walk around the neighborhood and see what else is here.  There is a great Mexican bakery across the street.  I can imagine this place gets crowded on a Friday night.
author: S C.

description: A friend and I were looking for a place to grab breakfast in the Mission and this place popped up in our Yelp search. It's a small and cute diner that serves your typical American breakfast dishes: omelets, corned beef hash, and pancakes. It was nice to see that they also offered a few vegetarian and vegan options. I ordered the Chef's Mess and it was pretty tasty and hearty. The staff was nice and service was fairly quick.
author: Frances V.

description: Highly recommend this old-timey soda fountain. Felt like I was transported to my youth in Ohio in the 1960's. Was seated almost immediately in a cozy wooden booth in the back. Ordered a patty melt, Mac and cheese and a dish I like to call potato nachos, which aren't nachos at all. More like grilled potatoes, cheese, onions tomatoes and sour cream. A must have. The patty melt was tasty and the Mac and cheese was perfect. Had a hot brownie for desert that melted in my mouth. The only thing better than the food and the atmosphere was the enthusiastic staff.
author: NEIL L.

description: Food was fabulous. Service is excellent. Best homemade corned beef hash ever! Wonderful homemade biscuits with hint of rosemary. Price is right
author: Karen E.

description:
I am impressed and highly satisfied! Stopped by here around noon earlier this week and the service was phenomenal. Super nice guys and they were very knowledgeable about the menu. I was also impressed by how attentive they were. They checked on us regularly, and brought us refills for our coffee and water without us ever having to ask. 

I ordered the breakfast burrito and it was amazing! Tasted so great, and it's a huge plate for only 9 dollars. It really hit the spot. 

I would definitely come back, and if you're ever in the mission and looking for some good food and great service, I would highly recommend this place.
author: David N.

description:
Man, I forgot about how dope this spot is. Always busy (because it's the shit), tons of vegan options, and a patio. That's about all I can ask for right there.

For the record: short stack of vegan strawberry pancakes + vegan sausages + apple juice + coffee = perfect hangover remedy, and crazy delicious. You heard it here first.
author: Justin N.

description:
Date night/day with the bf brought us here for breakfast to start off.  The place had good reviews so we gave it a try.  First off, the staff was friendly and we were seated immediately at the counter.  I had the mac 'n cheese with strawberry milkshake.  Forgot what the boyfriend ordered.  Felt that the mac 'n cheese lacked creaminess and the full bodied cheesy flavor I was looking for.  Too dry - 1 star.  The strawberry milkshake - now, that one I left with wanting more but had to fight with myself to resist ordering another one - 5 stars.  

The level of cleanliness was something I was not pleased with.  There were silverfish bugs near our foot and I just couldn't bring myself to put my bag on the floor.  There was no where to hang it which is why we initially wanted a booth or table but those were all either taken or reserved.  Wouldn't come back.
author: Hanna Y.

description: When I walked into this place I didn't know what to expect with the soda fountain and all the ice cream drinks but this is hands-down the best breakfast I've had in San Francisco. Tofu scramble onions jalapeno tomato, and the best fried potatoes I've had in my life. End of story.  The crust on these potatoes was half an inch tick and is possibly most delicious thing I've ever tasted.  |drops mic|
author: Eric C.

description: Had a great 1950's feel inside. The food was fresh and delicious especially the spud's. It's a great start to the day to come here for breakfast.
author: Easy E.

description: Cool spot in the mission. I should have ordered the ice cream or a shake from the place. Definitely had the SF feel to it. Got the breakfast sandwich, you can't go wrong with breakfast or a sandwich.
author: Josh H.

description:
Do you know what an egg cream is? I didn't either until I shared one with my mom at St. Francis (it's basically chocolate soda, which is delicious). 

This place is my perfect morning after a too-fun Friday breakfast joint. The nebulous potato thing with a scrambled egg and side of cornbread will soak up the excess booze and leave you comfy and full for a very reasonable price. Plus it's really cute in there. 

Yum.
author: Natalie S.

description: Very very cute spot.  Love the decor, food and staff!!! Only thing I would like to see changed is the music they play overhead.  50's and 60's would be nice :)
author: Alice K.

description: Brilliant place for a great breakfast in Mission. Went here with a hangover and a girlfriend. Had a "Chefs Mess" with lots of scrambled eggs, bacon, cheese, potatoes, sour cream and avocado. Large milkshake was far too much. GF had scrambled with bacon, cheese and green peppers. Friendly and fast service from the guys here. Great coffe too.
author: Hans Lukas H.

description:
This is a breakfast review only -- I have not tried their ice cream creations (yet).
Walked by this Sunday and there was uncharacteristically hardly anyone there/no wait, so I decided to pony up to the bar for a simple breakfast.  I wasn't starving so just got the basic breakfast with 2 poached eggs and bacon.  I also ordered a fresh squeezed oj, which was fantastic.  The breakfast was, like it sounds, basic, and what I wanted, though I wasn't thrilled that I thought it came with bacon but they charged me +$3.25 extra and the bacon was overcooked and gnarly, especially for that price.  The waitstaff was friendly and the atmosphere fun.  I'l come back if there's no wait and to try again, possibly a shake next time!
author: e w.

description:
I was so excited about the all soy milkshakes since I'm lactose and I try (but fail quite a bit) to stay away from dairy.  too bad it tasted like playdoh.

Chili and corn bread I was also excited about.  Chili was bland, and the corn bread heavy as a brick and dry. C'mon. Give me salt and butter!!

But why you HAVE TO COME HERE::

cheesey-green onion-bacon-buttery-pancakes. holy moly. Come get it.  And then go to humphry's afterwards and get their secret breakfast icecream. what a perfect dinner.  

On the weekends I hear there's a long wait outside, but they use their small diner area + outside + the art area next door so it shouldn't be too bad.  

Sketchy area completely, I definitely flipped my ring around, and made sure I was in my car before dark.
author: Hannah W.

description:
Food: Okay. I ordered the sourdough french toast and added strawberries and whipped cream. The french toast was eggy the way I like it but more salty than sweet and I really couldn't tell the bread was actually sourdough. $1 for strawberries and $1 for whipped cream...I definitely expected more on my plate. However, milkshakes are excellent here. 

Service: Half of the waitstaff is very off-putting. Unfortunately, this half tended to our table. They aren't very friendly and have no sense of urgency to actually wait on you. Plus, of the three tables in our area, we got there first, placed our order first, and received our food last.  

Ambiance: Love the diner feel and all of the 80s stuff they sell behind the counter but with a name like St. Francis Fountain in the Mission District, I just expected the restaurant atmosphere to feel a bit different, more warmer and homey. Fact is, it's definitely not the actual residents of the neighborhood eating at St. Francis Fountain.
author: Maya S.

description:
I live about 5 minutes away so this is automatically my default brunch spot in the city since a) it's convenient and b) I am broke as hell and I agree with the prices here.

Seriously, you really can't beat these diner prices compared to other places in the city. Additionally, there's never a super long wait even during their brunch rush from 10am-11:30am here in the city. I don't think I've had to wait more than 10 minutes for a table for 2. The service here is decent, they could be a little more forward with refilling our waters. I do giggle when I think about this place having been open since the early twentieth century and wondering what the original owner would think of this place turning into a typical Mission hipster place. I can see him on his rotary phone complaining to his housewife now.

Food is standard diner brunch fare. For the east coaster in me, I do have a love for their Egg Sandwich, particularly with avocado and that tomato thrown in. That combination is just killer. The veggie mess is also the weirdest clump of egg mass that can be plopped in front of your plate, but once you dig into it, you realize it's a good value at $10. You could split it for 2 if you're not too hungry!

All in all, good food, decent service and I'll roll up here if my friends don't drag me anywhere to brunch first.
author: Tony H.

description: Went in for a late breakfast, glad I made the choice. An old time soda fountain atmosphere. The staff and customers were smiling and interacting. Most important, the food was presented excellently and tasted delicious.
author: Clyde E S.

description: I visited this place with a friend and the shakes here are very tasty. The employees there are very friendly and nice. The prices are very good to.  I highly recommend this company.
author: Davon T.

description:
We dropped in from a cold day's walk for a cup of soup and maybe some Nebulous Potato Thing. We walked in to a time capsule stuck in the 50's with a dash of the 80's helping out the candy section. 

Our server was a late coming of Andrew W. K. and while he was polite enough, it was obvious he didn't want to be there. There was another server who was hardly wearing any clothes and created some popped cherries on children's eyes when she bended over. 

I was pretty happy with the Nebulous Potato thing as it has all the nasty stuff you wouldn't expect from a vegetarian friendly restaurant. I honestly wouldn't eat anything else from this place but their milkshakes and maybe their pie. They were out. Of course.  

The service is a little lacking and I'm not into the hipster thing but if you're one of those people who have to be different and cool, you'd enjoy being seen at St. Francis. Ask Mr. Andrew W. K. look-alike for an autograph while you're there.
author: Jessica K.

description:
A cool little spot located in a sketchy part of the Mission.  You'd never know this little gem was open and operating except on weekends when you see people pouring into the streets trying to get their 50s diner fix. 

I've heard great things about their potatoes and their menu seems to be pretty extensive for a small local diner.  Their ice cream is what I went to go check out.  They serve Mitchell's Ice Cream so even though I was a little disappointed by the fact that they didn't make their own batches of creamy goodness I knew I would be safe on any choice I made.  I went for the "Love's Delight" which consisted of 2 scoops vanilla ice cream, strawberry sauce, sliced bananas, whipped cream and almonds.  it was good.  Kind of brought me back to childhood a bit.  Back when the ice cream didn't have to be amazing to satisfy your taste buds and remember that it's ok to be young again. 

Although I probably wont be back anytime soon, this is a great spot to meet friends while sitting in a booth enjoying the rest of the misfit crowd that occupies this space.
author: Kevin J.

description:
S atisfies the 4pm breakfast and confection cravings
T he hipsters here are ready to serve you

F ixtures, decor and signage just reek of history
R etro collectables sit in a glass case near the door
A LF had trading cards?
N ot consistent on their booth seating rule
C ouldn't sit at a booth cause we only had a party of two
I nstead, we were forced to sit at the bar
S o why did the couple who came in right before get a booth?

F airly extensive dining options on the menu 
O rdered the Corned Beef Hash, which was decent
U sed to larger corned beef chunks, so this wasn't my cup of tea
N ebulous Potato Thing was mighty delicious and filling
T op it off with an over-easy egg -- breakfast of champs
A glass of "large" OJ here isn't as large as it seems
I  liked the taste and creaminess of the Dream shake 
N ot too thick, so it's straw-friendly
author: Anthony N.

description: SO hipster, lol! Great food at a good price. We went for breakfast, but their shakes look delicious! Don't be fooled by this place if you're looking in. They have much more to offer than a typical diner.
author: Sofia M.

description:
I always wanted to go to this place since a child. The pros about this place is.

-Wait wasn't bad as I thought
-Food was good
-Prices are reasonable
-Great menu selections
-Love the way they keep the tradition of this restaurant

The cons about this place.

-Normally is a longer wait due to lots of people going there
-Not family friendly
-Not clean
author: C G.

description:
Thanks to Yelp, new awesome brunch place!! From the pictures posted, I saw the long counter, the wooden booths, the decor in general. An old diner style differing from many brunch places here in the Mission. But what surprised me when I got there was the people! Instead of the moms&pops I was expecting, the place was filled with trendy down-to-earth workers. The atmosphere was hip and vibrant! Awesome!

Must try the Chef's Mess & the Nebulous Potato Thing! http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/XAiTKvUQe9ZV1LqCnV8YMQ/l The Chef's Mess is a scramble with homefries, bacon & mushrooms, topped with cheese, tomato & sour cream. It was sooooooo good! The bacon & homefries added nice crunch and flavor, while the toppings kept the scramble moist and gooood. *drooooooooools* The Nebulous Potato Thing is the hearty filling version with solely homefries, cheese, salsa & sourcream. Personally, not as satisfying, but nonetheless delicious!

There's always a wait for tables, but never too long. And service may get a bit slow. Can't blame them. They get swamped!! 

Fyi, the menu is very vegan and vegetarian friendly, also heart healthy (ie. egg whites option)
author: Marti L.

description:
I love St. Francis Fountain.
I've been there quite a few times since I've had the good fortune to find an apartment 4 blocks away!
The food is consistently delicious.
The servers that I've had experience with are all super nice, even to the crazy drunk dude that was screaming Depeche Mode lyrics.
The vegan food is legit, too. That used to be all I ate, but now that I'm on the meat wagon again, I still have a spot I can eat at with my vegan friends (no complaint from either side). Want a beer with your dinner? got it. Want a fancy flavored Italian soda? Sure.
The only bummer is that they switched from paper straws to plastic at some point in the past couple of years that I was stuck in NJ. You lose a couple nostalgia points and a couple enviro points.
author: Matt D.

description: Great customer service, line is never excessive. I like coming in at 8:45 pm for a scoop of ice cream (mitchell's!). I have eaten breakfast and lunch here. Unlike many people I do not enjoy standing in line for brunch, the line is usually quite fast and the food is good. I like the Chefs Mess (just a bunch of yummy breakfast stuff piled together). I also enjoy the griddle special (more traditional). They have a great patty melt as well and the chocolate malt (YIA) is bomb too.
author: Alex C.

description: I love this place. I never have to wait more than 5 minutes for a table during brunch hours. Every dish I've had is good and the service is great. The breakfast burrito with added spinach and guacamole is probably my favorite.
author: Randi P.

description: Your experience here will totally depend on who your server is. We arrived well before 1:00 for brunch, having read the Yelp comments about the attitude of some hipster staff and the ugliness one might encounter near closing time.  When we were the next up to be seated, the guy seating customers told us that we could not have the nice, shaded table that had just opened up outside.  Why, we asked?  Full of self-importance, he told us with relish that there would be no server after 1:00 and he couldn't allow it.  How he *loved* to say no!  He then promptly left to go smoke a cigarette or something, and a very nice guy graciously led us to the outside table -- and we hadn't even asked for it.  He told us that he would be our waiter, so at that point, we told him that the guy who had been seating customers a moment ago had forbidden us to sit outside because there was no waiter.  He looked puzzled (perhaps the other guy was playing a game with him, steering customers away?)  We proceeded to have a nice brunch.  Our waiter was very attentive, and continued to seat people outside as long as we were there.  We gave him a very nice tip, and we went away wondering, St. Francis Fountain, WTF?
author: Lira K.

description:
I love the feeling you get when you first walk in here. Its gives off a 50 era feel. Which I loved! The food wasn't bad either, it was delicious actually! 

I had the sourdough french toast with strawberries. It wasn't dry, but it wasn't too wet either. It had a really good crunch. My mom had the hamburger w/ fries. Which I had a bite of and woah it was good. She also said the coffee was really good. It came with refills too.

I just wish the staff was a little bit nicer. I mean don't get me wrong they weren't rude or anything, but a smile goes a long way. I'll defiantly be back though!
author: Tonie F.

description: My work hosted an 85th birthday party in the Candy Kitchen for about 25 people and we couldn't have been happier with the delightful and professional service. A heartfelt thank you Keri and her team for making it such a special day.
author: Antonella B.

description:
Going here will definitely upgrade your Mission hipster cred. Warning to fellow yuppies, yes there is a high skinny jeans per capita and you will definitely see funky hats and stockings. That said, all the staff members I've dealt with so far have been quite friendly and they didn't give my yuppie butt a hard time at all.

Whoever owns this place has an admirable attention to detail. They've got the diner theme going and all the details are there down to the funny food names on the menu and the Garbage Pail Kids on sale at the counter.

My first time here I had eggs over easy and the pancakes. The eggs were runny, but the pancakes rocked. I don't think their syrup is the real deal (as in maple). On my second visit I had the ham omlette with veggies, a generous portion and nicely prepared. 

I'll recommend St. Francis for your basic "get grease in my belly" after a big night. The outdoor seating is cool too if you can get it. So don't just stick to Boogaloos upgrade your cool game and give it a try...
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Authentic old-school feel, down to the suspenders-wearing, unusually courteous and enthusiastic server.

Decent spinach omelet.

Sinful shakes and sundaes.
author: Inigo M.

description: Best corn beef hash and banana bread I've ever had! Great to explore the Mission district afterwords as well. Next time ill be sure to have an ice cream Sunday here!
author: Clare R.

description:
I'VE BEEN COMING HERE SINCE I WAS A KID! YOU HIPSTERS GET OFFA MY STOOL!

Yeah...I've had a love affair with this place since I was little and they only served sandwiches and the like (seriously, I'm not that old...). I used to skip culinary school and just hang here instead. Woops...sorry, Mom!

The food here is good, the cutesy collectables and candy are good, the malteds are divine. Their breakfasts are amazing and plentiful. I really love that they kept the integrity of the building and inside--I can only imagine how awesome it was to the beatnicks (yesteryear hipsters) back in the day.

However, all of the hipsters come here and there can be a crazy long wait on the weekends. Be prepared. Come early or be prepared to put your name on the list and wait the full 45 minutes to an hour to be seated.  

Also, the seating is limited and this place is small if you need a table. There isn't a lot of room to leave your American Apparel bags or your super cool skateboard. Chain your damn fixies outside, tbh. 

Oh, and the owner is super hot. I'll pay $5 for a malted to watch that shake.
author: Bianca U.

description:
OMG

vegan breakfast and non vegan breakfast and old-school fountain shoppe style diner filled with young beautiful babes and of course, delicious food!!!

everything is amazing. the vegan pancakes, the french toast, the eggs, "the vegan thing" with a bunch of shit, the jam, the soy shakes, everythinggggg!!!!!

super popular, expect to wait, but worth it. 
not too pricey, but not cheap.
author: Samantha S.

description: St. Francis Fountain is definitely a neighborhood classic. I cam here with my wife for some ice cream and a snack. We ordered the chilli cheese fries, a vanilla malt and n ice cream dish called the Battleship. Everything tasted really good. Although the chilli cheese fries were not spicy at all! Nt my milkshake tasted really good. It was creamy, thick n not hard to swallow. Only bad thing service it's a lilttle slow.
author: Papi R.

description:
Go during the week to avoid the "hipster" scene if you can.

:: Great vegan breakfast/brunch options.
:: Awesome service.
:: Bottomless cup of coffee.
:: Super old decor, booths, counter, etc.
:: Super picky annoying dude next to me = great entertainment.

Easy to park during the week!
Will be back soon!
author: Katie S.

description:
"YUCKKKKK, this coffee tastes horrible.  What the hell?!?!"  
Oh, being half asleep I poured salt in my coffee instead of sugar... -_- ZzZzZz

Man, this is my breakfast spot when I'm in SF.  I dig the old diner feel, never have to wait long, and the food is fairly priced, good portions, and good quality!!!
author: Chris P.

description: Everyone who works here is cute as balls. Look for the guy in the black SF hat. I looked really cute too.
author: James P.

description: This place is tiiiiiiight! Super good vegan and veggie options
author: Sierra W.

description:
27-September, Thursday:
Ok, this place does have a lot of regal charm.

But my vegan chorizo egg scramble was inedible. I was already in question of it as it took 2 minutes after my order to bring it out, which was surprisingly quick. But of course to no avail, the quality was worse than that of a half frozen t.v. dinner alone. 

Old school Americana doesn't have to echo the Great Depression, but sadly this place was deflated my morning.  Ick.
author: Ty T.

description: A charming and casual diner with hipsters behind the counter at your service. They have a fun menu of ice cream drinks and shakes. I saw her make a drink with fudge, milk, and soda. What? For you mimosa seekers, Yelp says they only have beer and wine, but they actually have mimosas too. Came for brunch on a Sunday morning 11am. We had a big group (12) so it took about 45 minutes to get seated. It looked like groups of 2-5 got seated within 10-15 minutes which isn't bad for a Sunday brunch in the city. I got the veggie mess which has vegan chorizo in it. It was very heavy and can be shared with another person or for 1 very hangry person. Also tried the Huevos Rancheros which were OK. The potatoes were probably my favorite because of the herbs they put on it. Oreo milkshake was heavenly as all milkshakes are. I'd definitely come back to try their other dishes.
author: Ann P.

description:
I love the extensive menu at St. Francis Fountain filled with assorted egg combinations and different breakfast choices along with great burgers and of course, ice cream treats.  I have yet to try anything bad at this restaurant.  In order to be thorough they also have soups, salads and some vegetarian items on the menu that I have never tried.

On my most recent visit I ordered one of my menu favorites, the Chef's Mess (pictured).  This is an egg scrambler that combines their homefries, bacon pieces and sliced mushrooms.  Cheddar and jack cheese are melted on top of the scrambler then diced tomatoes, a dollop of sour cream and chopped green onions finish the dish.  Your choice of toast comes with this selection.

On my second most recent visit I had the Hamburger with Bacon and Cheddar (also pictured).  All of their burgers are cooked medium well unless of course you ask otherwise, and these are thick, lean, beefy patties.  The menu states that they are 6 oz. patties.  The base burger comes with shredded lettuce, sliced tomato, a few thin strings of red onion and a couple of pickle chips.  The burger had a thick slice of cheddar melted on top of the patty along with two thick strips of crispy bacon that I had to crumble in half in order to make it fit.  The price is on the steeper side, but the burger is delicious.

Burgers and sandwiches come with French Fries on the side.  I like how they are fried up crispy with the skin intact.  If you are not into the fried potatoes however, there are several other sides you can choose from including salad, soup, chili, mac and cheese or fruit.

They serve Mitchell's ice cream at St. Francis Fountain with about a dozen flavors.  I don't let my lactose intolerance bother me ever.  I carry Lactaid tablets with me at all times, and I enjoy ordering ice cream items.  My favorite flavor combination has always been vanilla ice cream with orange sherbet.  That's right the Dreamsicle combo.  Perhaps that is why I love the Dream Shake (pictured) so much.

I sit at the counter most of the time because I enjoy watching the waitress make my shake with a light pour of whole milk, a shot of Torani vanilla syrup, orange sherbet and vanilla ice cream.  One of the waitresses with short dark hair makes a real kick ass milkshake.  Sorry but I always forget to ask her name.  She leaves the shake on the mixer for a super long time and the result is a shake so thick the long metal spoon will stand up in the middle of the glass for a good half hour after the shake has been made.  Don't ask why, but I tried it once (the spoon caper, that is).

The service is usually pretty good as the wait staff are really cool.

Although I have a long time to go before I can exercise the ten percent senior discount here I'm hopeful that San Francisco's oldest ice cream parlor will still be here serving up a great menu and delicious ice cream treats.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
I'm a huge diner/soda shop fan. Saw this place on Saturday when I went to Dynamo Donuts. Wanted ice cream yesterday so we thought we'd give them a try. 


Really cool retro 50's diner look with a very laid back vibe. Got good service by the laid back hipster staff. As soon as we walked in the door, we were acknowledged and pointed to a seat. 

We only ordered ice cream ---a Busta Brown and Hot Fudge Banana Split with the bananas on the side (yep...I'm allergic to bananas). It was a pretty mixed crowd of young to old. And GOSH darn it! If this crew doesn't make a yummy sundae. 

We saw other dishes they brought out which looked pretty good. Unfortunately we already had lunch so ice cream was all we had room for BUT I'm sure we'll be back to try some of their other diner fare.
author: Troy R.

description:
I had the Nebulous Potato Thing. It was very good with a blend of cold and hot, with the salsa and chives counteracting the sour crème and yellow cheese. 

Before coming here I noticed quite a few reviewers complaining about service. I had great service, I think you have to be proactive about service here. Not to sit and wait like a mushroom on a log waiting for someone to come over.

You merely need to get eye contact and smile first.

I also had a coffee ice cream shake that was very good as well. St. Francis has a bar in which quite a few people would come in just to get the ice cream.
author: Gerald S.

description: The fold was great and the service was excellent. You have to try their veggie mess and milkshakes. So good.!!
author: Nikka A.

description: I had the Vegan Thing and my boyfriend had the Veggie Mess. Both of us were extremely satisfied! The waitress was attentive and suggested add-ons like soyrizo and guacamole. My boyfriend and I are homefry/breakfast potato addicts and St. Francis Fountain delivered. Very affordable and left us full!
author: Bailey B.

description: Hands down my favorite brunch place in San Francisco. Though it's not my partner's favorite---but I'm a lot more down to earth and more food-obsessed. It's total diner food---excellent menu creations of potatoes, cheese, bacon, and sour cream. Big portions. I usually can't decide between the Chef's Mess and the Nebulous Potato Thing. But if you go, you MUST THING YOUR SPUDS, it just makes everything even more delicious. There is usually a wait on weekends, but it's totally worth it. I've also come here on evenings and had a milkshake and those are quite delicious as well. Very fun, diner, hipster vibe. Not the place to go to impress your parents or your boss, but it's a favorite place for friends on the weekend.
author: Sarah D.

description: I came to St Francis Fountain a few weeks ago, and we were a group of five.  The waiters were really cool and helped us pull together some tables to sit together.  It was pretty quiet when we went, and the vibe was cool.  I ordered a breakfast burrito, and it was pretty good.  The portions were decent, and the prices good.  It's not really anything amazing in my opinion, but I did enjoy my experience.
author: Amanda J.

description: Went for a Monday breakfast, had the nebulous potato dish with egg, which was fantastic.  Son had bacon cheeseburger, which he would have every breakfast if he could, he was happy with that too.  Waitress was lovely, helping explain how we could get into the city center by bus.
author: Adam G.

description:
Got breakfast here and and it was pretty good for what it was. The food here reminds me heavily of east cost dinner food with, of course, a west coast hipster twist. I ordered the biscuits and sausage gravy with a side of fresh fruit and my boyfriend got the "Nebulous Potato thing" with an egg. My dish was tasty and the fresh fruit i got was actually fresh and ripe. I didn't love the biscuit i got but i think that's more to do with my own expectations of what a biscuit is then it is due to anything wrong with the one i  got. The biscuit was very soft and fluffy, kind of like a very light tender roll rather then flaky and crisp like i was expecting. The potatoes that came on the side of my dish and as the base of my boyfriends were VERY good; spiced right, cooked with onions, and perfectly tender. 
I'm going back but next time i'm definitely getting a milkshake.
author: Sara G.

description: Amazing food and service! The Nebulous Potato Thing was the jam!! So stinking yummy!!! 4 of us ate for under 50 bucks and are full!!
author: Jessica G.

description: Got seated at the bar, when my friend and I requested for a booth. The booths were empty but we still had to sit at the bar. Super small and uncomfortable to eat a meal. The food was alright, basic dinner food a little like Mel's Diner.
author: Perry A.

description:
Good solid food, prompt service, and no wait on a Saturday morning?  Done.

I had one of the veggie scrambles with cilantro and it was very flavorful.  The housemade potatoes were also delicious.

Service was prompt and attentive.
author: Melanie R.

description: The pictures of Chef's Mess drew me over to St. Francis Fountain. Eggs, Homefries, Bacon & Mushrooms, Topped w/ Melted Cheese, Tomatoes & Sour Cream ($10 + $1.50 Avocados). Yum.
author: Christine C.

description:
I've been on a run in photographing dives and diners.

I find that the vintage counters and the age associated with the decor captures nicely on film, not to mention adding more texture and a nostalgic trip back in time to the viewer.

St Francis Fountain invokes this and so much more.

I can't believe this is the strip where I would mosey along in search of the gigantic burritos that have long set a standard for me and the amazingly fresh ingredients for homemade pico de gallo (purchased all items for 5 cups worth = $3.00!?!@#!)  One such stop was on the typical cooler evening after a stop at Humphrey Slocombe and I was craving coffee.  

The interior is typical of a fountain shop from long ago, but what makes this place charming are the remarkable number of candies from a time long ago.  On top of that, sitting at the counter makes for the best escape ever from the busy strip of cars and pedestrians.

The coffee? Burnt.  And not terribly good.  

I'll come back for their ice cream and other treats, however.  It looked tasty and somehow, in my current state of mine, need a little sugar.
author: Miika M.

description:
Went here the other night with the husband and a friend, after catching Eddie Izzard at the (sweeeet!) Brava Theater. 

My husband, who evidently grew up at the St. Francis and has a really annoying photographic memory, says the prices have changed since the 1960's. This is the kind of detail that makes absolutely no difference when you're in a relationship with the hot fudge on the sundae in front of you.

Things to know about the St. Francis Fountain:

1. GET THE HOT FUDGE SUNDAE.
2. The straws in the milkshakes? Are made of stripey paper! Not plastic! (head explodes)
3. The marshmallow sauce is also delicious.
4. The music's a little loud. I think the staff keeps it like that to drown out the ecstatic moans of customers.

Finally, I am engaged to the hot fudge sauce at the St. Francis Fountain. We're thinking a June wedding. 

You can probably guess where we're registered.
author: Anne B.

description: Nice American diner with the added bonus of beer and ice cream. Separate or together. Try the Guiness Float! Sadly, now closing at 3pm instead of 9pm.
author: Kokoe J.

description: What an interesting restaurant! 1950's diner like place - but with hipster atmosphere and dishes. I got the veggie mess. Wow. Really weird dish. Delicious though. And definitely try the banana bread. Pretty crowded restaurant too. I got to sit at the bar.
author: Gilad P.

description:
Good fresh sandwich. Great ice cream. 
Nice vintage originality. (hole in floors, old signs, funky seats...like it! Adds character)
My friend's husband owns the place. It is ok for what it is. Nothing fancy, just homey and good.  I think I need to try it for breakfast.
author: Cindi W.

description: Sweet little old school diner/soda fountain. Had the nebulous potato thing and it was super good (if not just a tad bland). The dreamsicle soda was AMAZING as was the old-fashioned shake (yeah, i pigged out). My gf liked her reuben but both the soups she tried (brocolli and chicken) were very bland. Loved it though!
author: Alan J.

description:
Established in 1918, the St. Francis Fountain has been serving the Mission District over three generations until an ownership change in 2002 which was initially intended to inspire community renewal that later became consumed by the larger gentrification project. According to a local source, they used to make their own ice cream but had since resorted to using Mitchells' most conventional lines of flavors. I came here to meet fellow Yelp buddy Tom R on a sunny sweltering afternoon and was able to grab a quick ice cream sundae to get an impression of this place.

In spite ongoing efforts to shift its focus from an old fashioned confectionary towards a modern diner that serves Missions' growing numbers of hipsters and young professionals, the venue still embodied the retro charms that preceded the contemporaries in the area. There was the candy counter situated by the entrance followed by rows of wooden booths juxtaposed by a lengthy dinette counter and red topped stools which were raised from the floor and spread across the middle of the diner. We were seated towards the back at the counter and I was treated to a Black & White Sundae ($6). It came with big scoops of Mitchells chocolate and vanilla ice cream layered with melted marshmallow sauce, chocolate sauce, whipped ice cream and peanuts. The concept was nothing path-breaking as I had a chance to observe how the sundae was prepared, but thanks to Mitchells the double scoops of ice cream were outstanding despite a lack of twisted imagination of Humphry Slocombe and other confectionaries in the area.

Personalized service and developing a sense of belonging for customers are two essential qualities that historically have defined what a good diner is all about. The quality of service was a major disappointment as I was ignored at the doorstep for a good 10 minutes until Tom showed up. Without hesitation, the server flocked to him instantaneously to offer seating and if we weren't together I would have been invisible and completely dismissed. Poor service didn't stop there as the server offered to settle our bill as soon as we were finished with our snack. There was little consideration about making this place communal and friendly to hang out, and the attitude of the servers were unresponsive and ignorant about the restaurant business. Overall, my experience was marked by a pretty decent ice cream sundae with an original ambiance and décor. Since service was unresponsive and stink-face offensive, I must admit that I will not be coming back unless they hire a counter staff that is capable of communicating and relating to individuals from various backgrounds, and one that reflects the demographics of the local community at hand.
author: Daniel L.

description:
One of my favorite places to go in the Mission. Great atmosphere and vibe. It def can get a bit hipster, but nice hipster, not annoying over-achiever Williamsburg hipster. 

With that being said, I love going early on the weekends. The eggs benedict (weekends only) with avocado and tomato is amaze.
author: Priscilla M.

description: The food was ok but the waiter was rude. He told us when the food can't and we are eating, he might move us while we where eating if more people came in.  Weird
author: Kelvin C.

description:
I'm keeping it a secret from my dad that I went to St. Francis Fountain today. I don't need a lecture that includes the words "dangerous" & "gangs." My dad still remembers the Mission of the 70's, 80's & very early 90's, a time before suburbanites, transplants & newbies started calling it "The Mish." 

Anyone who lived in SF before the whole gentrification of Mission Street thing (that includes my family) knows that Bryant & York were not the friendliest, safest streets to be 'trollin back in the day. What we see now is the hipster version of this area & of this diner, but I remember a time when you would not have ventured into this part of town if I paid you to. Some call it progress, I just call it, "yay, we don't have to worry about getting mugged anymore!"

Even though St. Francis Fountain is a cleaner, douchier representation of it former self, I still appreciate it for what it is--a greasy spoon that serves breakfast (my favorite meal) all day, everyday at pretty affordable prices. 

My friend & I both ordered vanilla milkshakes. I had a 2 egg scramble w/ avocado, jack, green onion, ranchero sauce & ortega chiles (tasted homemade, I'd order it again.) My friend had the corned beef hash, which did not come out of a can, we were told. $31 not including tip.

The old fashioned ice cream parlor decor is complete w/ counter seating & nostalgic food posters. Service is a little slow, but friendly enough. The benches reminded me of the pews from Catholic school (both scary & familiar.) Also, I think it may be a requirement to have tattoos & wear vintage t-shirts with witty sayings like "Nebraska is For Lovers" before eating or working here. You've been warned.

Before walking out, check out the old school candy & trading cards. I spotted NKOTB ones & "Three's Company" ones. Groovy.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
This place is really cool. Old school feel and their food is pretty good too. They have Italian Sodas (I got a pinapple soda) and my husband got a Guiness float. The Modesto Pesto sandwich was really good and their fries were awesome. I love the small booths. They have a candy counter which I think kids would really enjoy. 

This is not an awesome place to bring all your friends all at once. Its a small place and they do have bar seating but its more for the small groups and locals.
author: Lizzie D.

description: Terrible service, the servers did not respond to us even when we asked to place an order we waited about 15 mins. They were not understaffed nor busy, i am never coming here again.
author: Stefany L.

description: The perfect place for a hangover curing brunch/lunch. The menu has so many options from the standard breakfast fate to their more creative options (many of which are vegan/vegetarian friendly).  Everyone in the group I was with ordered the breakfast special with "thinged" spuds and loved their meals (no one was able to finish completely) and I was in a mid-day crisis where I couldnt decide between breakfast or lunch, so I ordered the Baltimore (BLT with Avocado, but they forgot the avocado and brought a side out after the order) and split the pancakes (which were pretty good but nothing amazing).  The milkshakes were what pushed this from a 3 to a 4 star review.  So many options & I ordered the gelato milkshake with strawberry that had soooo many delicious chunks (ha) and was the perfect ending to a great Sunday morning brunch.
author: Raina D.

description: An Island of normalcy in a sea of over priced pretentious gluten free wannabe unique cafes. Come here for a Usual Breakfast with no BS.
author: Justin J.

description: Was here on a weekday and there was still a short wait--unbelievable! This place is small and so I don't think I would ever try to come here on a weekend. I had their scramble with spinach, cheese, and sausage. I selected their banana nut bread instead of their regular toast. I didn't care for the potatoes but I did love their banana nut bread. It was moist and not too sweet. Their scramble was great too. We sat at their counter table and it can get a little squishy but overall it wasn't a bad experience. I think aside from the wait time and the lack of parking, I would come back.
author: Anh W.

description:
In general I love the food here. They make a great cheeseburger and mac and cheese but the service is typically bad. The servers have too many tables to manage to provide adequate service. I really wish St Francis could pull it together and have more servers working and improve service and table turnover but they don't seem real interested in that, I guess it's part of being hipster and unattached. 

It's best to go during non-peak times but I don't often eat at 4pm. Also parking is rough in the Mission in case you weren't aware.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
If you're a hipster kid living in San Francisco and you've yet to have brunch at St. Francis, you haven't lived.

While I think the term "hipster" is about as watered down as a buxom female in a Jay Z music video, I've accepted the fact that I dress like one and I enjoy the things in life that are consistent with a hipster counter culture. So sue me if I like Jon Stewart and a $2.00 PBR from time-to-time! If you can't get down on arguably the smartest man to ever grace the silver screen and affordable American lager, then spend your potential 401k money as you please. 

St. Francis gives greasy spoons a good name. They've got all the markings of a truck stop diner, but with features suitable for even the pickiest of bleeding heart liberals in the Mission. Along side fatty slabs of bacon, eggs benedict and breakfast burritos laced with hunks of pig rump, you'll find enough meals made with soyrizo and tofu scrambles to make even Sir Ben Kingsley proud he stopped in for breakfast. 

Get there early (and by early, I mean roughly 10:00am), as the place gets jam packed once 20-somethings in the 'hood stumble out of bed with a raging hangover from last night's Busch-a-thon on Valencia.
author: Ruggy J.

description:
Yum. Everything I've had here is delicious. Some of the best breakfast spuds in the city. I judge a good breakfast spot by their potatoes. :)
Vegan options are awesome. The people who work here are normal and laid back - makes dining out not awkward. 
Come during off times cause this place gets slammed. All in all, my fiance and I love coming here for a no frills, good cheap eats.
author: S. M.

description:
Absolutely fantastic place to come for breakfast, which is served all day. The retro ambiance was fun, and the waitress was very friendly and helpful. We came on a weekday morning right when the place opened so there was very little traffic and we had none of the issues other yelpers seem to have had with waiting or service.

There are a lot of delicious menu choices but we finally settled on the Corned Beef Hash ($9) which was outstanding, and we LOVED the Nebulous Potato Thing - a half order (which is huge) was only $5! We heartily recommend both. Really great house coffee, too! Can't wait to come back and try one of their delicious looking milkshakes, yum.
author: Athena T.

description: I am from New Jersey and this place makes me feel like I am back in my favorite diner. It is a small place- be prepared to wait. But I assure you, the wait is worth it. Great place for breakfast, with many choices to please pretty much what ever type of eater you are. The vibe is so hipster while being nostalgic. I love coming here when I visit my cousin. We go here for brunch and make sure to also stop by Dynamo Donuts as well, which a little bit up the street from here. All in all, a wonderful establishment to support: the combination of food and ambiance make for a memorable meal.
author: Jenny S.

description: There was a waiting list when I went for brunch here on a Saturday, but it was quick. It's an old school diner with a great variety of vegan options- I got the tofu scramble and was really satisfied! Milkshakes are are so really nice! Seating is at the counter, booths, or outdoors.
author: Karen J.

description:
Before today, I have never walked out of a restaurant convinced that the bad service that I received was due to discrimination. Apparently, in order to be served in this establishment now, you are required to be young and cute and skinny. As someone who is not, I am not a valued customer.

While no one was available to help me in any way at the counter and no one could even be bothered to look at me to see if I needed anything, the cute skinny girls on my right and the hipster guys on my left got excellent service.

The staff literally served the people on one side of me, looked down to pass me, then offered service to the people on the other side. Not once-- the entire time that I was there. And not one employee-- five. The only person who seemed to care in the least if I wanted something appeared to be a cook.

Perhaps the staff there is confused, so let me clarify for them what their job is: it's to take my order, serve me food, and bring me a bill, with occasional checks to see if I need anything, even if the check is only to look at me long enough to see if I'm WAVING AT THEM. No part of that job description involves taking me home with them.

The French toast was great. The overt discrimination against chubby ladies? Not so great.
author: Jen L.

description: I got a burger and fries with guac and grilled onions and it was amazing! good location if you hate places with bad parking, the staff was super nice and would come back the next time i'm in frisco
author: Imani C.

description: This is one of my favorite places to go for breakfast on weekends.  I've tried an omelette and the homemade corned beef hash.  Both are great.  Minor complaint is I don't care for the seasoning (it might have rosemary) they put on their breakfast potatoes but that's just my personal taste.  Wait time seems to be 20-30 min on average during weekend brunch so not bad at all.  Service is pretty quick and friendly once you're seated.
author: george c.

description:
Stepping into The St. Francis Fountain is like taking a step back in time. The decor probably hasn't changed much in over 50 years. But, that's ok. It's a clean, cheerful space with a counter, glass serving bowls, padded bar stools and quaint wooden booths. It all the servers wern't cute hipsters, and Pat Benetar wasn't playing it would be easy to think the 50's were alive and well.

My friend and I went for The ice cream (courtesy of Mitchell's) and we amply rewarded. They have soy flavors available, but go for The dairy. I really loved The fresh flakes of coconut in my coconut ice cream, and it worked perfectly with The hot fudge and walnuts in my brownie sundae. Now That's The way to break a vegan fast!

Soda's, milkshakes, malts, sundaes, banana splits and egg cremes round out the menu. They have lots of regular menu options (including several vegan ones), but why waste time on those when you can go straight for a good dessert.
author: Nicole M.

description: Had a good Sundae with generous portions.
author: Steven G.

description: Considering how things change, I felt the need to come here for a late lunch, to support a long standing business.  I had the grilled cheese, with avocado and tomato, which was tasty and hit the spot.  The service here was great and on point.
author: Carlos C.

description:
God damnit, I love St. Francis. This is a great place to go with a couple of friends for brunch and a couple of beers or sodas or whatever you choose to imbibe. 

The food is so delicious and you get SO much of it for a pretty good price. Also, it's relatively vegetarian and vegan friendly. I like the two-egg scramble with soyrizo, mushrooms, and spinach, hashbrowns and cornbread. My friend swears that their hashbrowns, which are spiced very well and kind of blackened on the outside, are the best in the world. And the biscuits and jam are freaking delicious. 

St. Francis has a bit of a reputation for bad service, but I've never experienced it. Get here before 2 on weekends to grab a seat on the lovely outdoor patio.
author: Anne W.

description:
Delicious vegan brunch dishes. Tried the Chef's Mess, huevos rancheros and pancakes. As a non vegan/vegetarian (but aspiring to be least 80% of the time), I thoroughly enjoyed my meal. 

Great service despite being super busy during weekend brunch time.

Hipster Central.
author: Jolene T.

description:
