The service here is not bad, although when it comes to the staff, a shower couldn't hurt. Not sure what the situation with management is, but a lack of personal hygiene seems like a prerequisite for working here. The food is not bad either, but you get kind of skeeved out by the disregard for basic cleanliness.

I've had the Hectors Waffle, which is tasty and super light for a waffle. It has orange zest and pecans and you can get real maple syrup if you pay extra which is a nice option. 

I've also had the grilled chicken sandwich, pretty average and bland. The fries are good though. 

It is shocking that people wait in such long lines to eat at this place on weekends...I've only popped in during the week when it is super empty. Sometimes I wonder if this is the spot that dirty hipsters go to on weekends to compete over who can go the longest without showering. 

Anyway, this diner is very kid-friendly with spacious booths so if you are looking to eat out with kids it's not a bad choice.
author: Oly O.

description: Came to this place the other day with a few friends. Atmosphere is nice with really cool servers who give great service. Asked for a food recommendation and he gave us a ton! I had the veggie mess and it was delicious. My friends had the chefs mess and they loved it. We also tried the upside down hog cake, different but surprisingly great! Savery and sweet at the same time (: Bill was $58 for four people. 2 drinks, 1 hog cake, and 4 meals. Definitely a good deal!
author: Leeana B.

description:
I'm going to keep this brief. I really REALLY want to love St Francis fountain because it's an old timey soda fountain with pretty decent breakfast food. (Sourdough french toast? The spuds? nomnomnom)
However the service is TERRIBLE.
To qualify, I worked in restaurants for years. I am very forgiving when you're slammed, when things go wrong, etc but it also means I'm fairly unforgiving when you ignore your customers or cop attitude.
The last time I was there was a Saturday morning. It wasn't that crowded. At all. It almost seemed like the staff outnumbered the customers. There were two of us and we sat at the counter. A very harried waitress took our drink order and when I asked for soy for my coffee she pushed the almost empty pitcher from the last customer over to me. (are you f*cking KIDDING me).
We waited to order.
And waited.
And waited.
The staff was bustling around, doing sidework, and talking amongst themselves. Looking busy doing anything OTHER than taking our order.
I asked someone if we could order, without making eye contact I got just a blase "You have to order with a server." 
He didn't tell anyone.
We waited.
And waited.
And asked another staff member working the counter. 
"Oh, this isn't my section but I guess I can take your order."
Thank you so much for inconveniencing yourself by DOING YOUR JOB.
Turns out it was OUR fault for our waitress ignoring us, as we were informed by this server, because we put the menu away. (yeah, I'm rolling my eyes too)
We got the food. It was good. She checked in. Hooray.

I do want to say that this waitress was busting her butt, as she usually does, while most of the other stuff was doing god knows what. However we still got ignored and weren't able to order for almost 20min.

I've been there, serving is rough, especially when hung over, but it feels like the staff that morning thought they were god's gift to the breakfast crowd.
I won't be going back until service improves by hiring servers who actually want to take my money.

(I said I'd keep this brief. Womp womp.)
author: Jacqueline M.

description:
The breakfast here is five star.   Go here today.

This is the true old school 1950's coffee shop from the movies. Bursting with charm and appeal  with wax-paper straws and an old wooden phone booth. Come for the breakfast, it is not to be missed.

This hipster run coffee shop is extremely friendly and makes the dinning experience wonderful with their attentive manner but the coffee is absolutely horrific. The coffee is bad, just don't drink it. Next time I'm having the Guinness Float for breakfast.

Total: $27. for two great breakfast and a really bad coffee.
author: Justin S.

description:
Definitely comes off as a old school diner vibe. Seating was a little small, so you feel a little cramped around your neighbors who are also eating, and there is almost always a line waiting outside.

Their diner food is excellent, very hardy. I had their spinach, mushroom omelet. I've also tried their huevos rancheros, eggs were perfectly done with a great salsa sauce, served with yummy black beans and a side of veges. Best breakfast food I've had at a diner across the country no doubt.
author: Doriancita X.

description: Great diner with tons of vegetarian options and delicious shakes. Plus pretty cool music and vintage remakes of candy from the 80's.
author: elizabeth m.

description:
It was 4 PM on a dreary Saturday afternoon, my husband and I found ourselves on 24th Street.  We eyed St. Francis Fountain earlier in the week and made plans to give it a try.  We found metered parking right in front of the restaurant.

The place had a nostalgic diner look with a long counter and wooden booths (with old fashioned coat/hat hooks).  We immediately opted for a booth.  Being a larger man, my husband found the booth more than a little snug.  I found that while charming in a vintage way, the wooden booths were a little uncomfortable (the 90 degree angle made one practice good posture) and the torn leatherette seats could have used some refurbishing.  

Menus were retro in style, though I felt selections were a bit pricey.  We ordered a NY Reuben sandwich (w/choice of 1 side) and Turkey Club, each was 9.25.  My husband also ordered a large malt.  Food was delivered quickly enough but without the malt.  Sandwiches were okay, I thought both could have used more meat.  My husband loved his reuben sandwich.  When he asked about the shake, our waitress replied it was not ready yet (I thought it was forgotten).  It was delivered halfway into the meal and presented with two cute red/white waxed paper straws in a heavy milkshake glass.  I forgave our busy waitress as the malt was definitely worth the wait.  It had a subtle malt/vanilla taste and was very smooth and creamy.  

Though I'm on the fence about St. Francis Fountain, if I do return I'll probably select something from the soda fountain as the malt was delicious. My husband, on the other hand, would return tomorrow.  He enjoyed everything about the place.  I think 4 stars is a good compromise.
author: A O.

description:
This food at this diner is really, really good.  I tried the pesto tofu scramble, which came with potatoes and toast. I could not finish it for the life of me - portions are humungo! All of the flavors blended superbly.

Anyhoo, the service was pleasing and efficient, and the surrounding decor was so fun.  Pez, He-Man, She-Ra cards, anyone?  If you want a dose of your childhood, come here.  You will squeal at all that you thought you forgot.  Good memories and times.
author: Megha S.

description:
Great food, even better milkshakes and malts! But what's with the attitude? On a recent Sunday night, I stopped by at 8:45, jonesing big time for a chocolate malt, and the door was locked.  The hours say open until 9pm. Three employees were cleaning up, trying to leave early on a slow night perhaps. I shrugged my shoulders, and gave them the What's Up look. One of them bangs on the window, pointing to the closed sign, which Only adds Insult to Injury. Wow, thanks for introducing me to Hipster service with a smile! How about "I'm sorry sir, we closed early tonight, Sorry for your inconvenience".

I have been stoked about the St. Francis for years; I hope the owner can restore some pride to the old fountain before the ice cream melts.
author: Charlie M.

description:
Can this place be any more awesome and ironic? An (almost) hundred year old classic diner serving amazing food, run completely by hipsters, clientele being mostly hipsters, sprinkle in some elder folks, situated in the middle of a latino neighborhood, reggae music overhead and most importantly, down the street from my house (!!!).

I had the corned beef hash and coffee today. hash turned out way better than expected, plenty of green onions sprinkled over corned beef and potatoes, over two eggs, and toast. the coffee was nice and strong, refilled quickly. the orange juice must've been squeeze by the hipster jesus bcos it was super fresh and sweet. tried some of their pancakes and sausage patty as well -- pancakes looked burnt but unbelievably still tasted amazing and fluffy, sausage patty was flavorful and looked homemade! 

Tried their malted shakes a few days ago too; though it was sweet enough to give me diabetes on the spot, every sip was worth it. share it with a significant other, or friend and be cute with two straws in a shake ;)
author: Jennie L.

description:
Seriously delish and they have a really good little area that sells vintage cards and candy... Quality stuff. The devil burger is on my mind most days...

My bf go on dates here frequently it's cute
author: Avery M.

description: Great food here.  The nebulous potato thing is the best.  Coffee is decent.  Service is average
author: Zach H.

description: I love old school diners like these. They're few and far between so when I stumbled upon this place, we had to try it. The menu is full of yummy breakfast and lunch items. I opted for a veggie scramble of some sort which was way more filling than you can imagine. My friend ended up getting the messy one which he actually finished. You also get a choice of toast or a baked item. This is way more food than most people can eat in one sitting. I like the old school feel to it though and I'll have to try the ice cream next time. The prices were really reasonable for all the food you get.
author: Amy J.

description: An average  old timey little soda fountain. Some cool old cards and candy in the front. The food is decent. But if you want a nice old fashioned diner this is for you. Overall 3.5 stars. I would come back
author: Nick W.

description:
I heard this diner has been here since the early 1920's from a friend and I wanted to explore the Mission area so we went to enjoy a good breakfast.

I loved the decor, its classic and very chill - it did not look fake and cheesy like some diners can look. I'm only sad I didn't get to try a milkshake after reading reviews.

I got one of their breakfast specials that consisted of 2 eggs (scrambled with cheddar cheese), home fries, and 2 homemade biscuits with sausage gravy - along with a side of bacon. 

The bacon was fabulous, smokey and not too greasy but crisp! Home Fries were made of real potatoes and tasted cozy and warm. My eggs were great. I wasn't the biggest fan of gravy though...however I mainly got them to try since I've never had sausage gravy and biscuits ever, but the biscuits were still pretty tasty. 

The waitstaff is calm and friendly, dressed very casual and always smiling. Very attentive, prompt, and even brought me a carry out box without me asking :).

The prices are relatively inexpensive for a good breakfast, and are comparable to the prices I pay in Ann Arbor, MI. 

Definitely coming here again.
author: Lara E.

description:
Noms.

St. Francis Fountain solves my cravings for classic diner fare. I've come for hangover breakfast (godsend), emergency burger and milkshake (sometimes you just NEED it), and an ice cream sundae extravaganza (Mitchell's FTW). They have a fantastic menu and the diner is just downright fun, from the music and throwback-style advertising, to the classic candy counter and great service.

Don't fret about the perpetual line outside. You should totally go.
author: Tysen C.

description:
Great brunch place with a lot of options for vegans and others. 
The line goes fast, milkshake is amazing, staff is very professional.
author: Phil B.

description:
First time here today.  Service was good, food was good, atmosphere was pretty cool.  Why 3 stars you ask?  Well, I had the "Veggie Mess" and it had soooo much cheese on it plus a pile of sour cream, I wasn't quite expecting that.  It was good once I attempted a little cheese removal.  

Reason #2 for a 3 star rating:  They have a second room for seating that was completely open (only 3 tables sat in there) and yet there was  a wait list.  I get it if they are short staffed but that didn't seem to be the case.  Either way, the wait was only about 10 minutes but it just seemed odd.

Reason #3.  I get that its a place that employ's the hipsters... goes with the whole Mission Schtick... but I have a problem when dudes that are serving food are wearing tank tops.  I have only witnessed such behavior in places like Springfield Missouri where I was surprised they were wearing shirts at all.  But here in SF, I figured even the hipsters would realize I don't want to see an eyeful of armpit hair as you pass a plate across the table.  Also, one of the other servers was wearing his pants way low on his ass so most of his boxer briefs were showing and they did not appear to be brand new.  

So Reason #3 is the main reason for the 3 star rating..... A rule one of my beauty school teachers used to preach should apply here... "No Pits, No Tits, No Butts, and No Guts people... not around food.
author: Nicole W.

description:
St. Francis Fountain feels like a 1950s diner. Upon entering, you are transported to the past (for me it's Back to the Future!). Everything about this place is old school except for some of the food. Unbelievably, there are more than a dozen vegan options! Vegan breakfasts, burgers, and even desserts! 

I've been going to St. Francis at least twice a week for the last few weeks. My coach and gym-mates come here after our 8 AM workout. I am in love with the plates of potatoes that come with guacamole, onions, tomatoes and a variety of other toppings. Last Friday night, I came here on a "date" and sat at the counter. My dining partner even ordered a milkshake! It was a very sweet and 1950s kinda night and there are few things better than sitting at the counter holding hands with a super cute boy while a vegan burger is on its way!
author: Valerie L.

description: This place must be surviving on nostalgia alone. Our experience there was awful. Got the feeling it was a normal day for them. We arrive around 9:45am with the place less than half full. Waiter came to take our drink order within a few minutes. Five minutes later his buddy walks in so he chats with him  for about 10 minutes about his night and his "girl," etc, then takes HIS food order. We still have not received our drinks. Five minutes after his friend leaves, we get our water and he takes our order.  When our food finally arrives, the pineapple in the fruit bowl was old, one of the three slices of the side order bacon was nothing but fat, oj was old and gross, too (@4.75/glass). Pancakes were ok. Waiter never checked with us to see if we needed anything. Was rude to other customers when they asked for something. A new waiter came in with even more attitude. Nothing of merit here for me to even reconsider another visit. Shame bc we love divey places.
author: Renee F.

description: What happened to the fabulous waitresses who used to work here? I can't even believe how rude the two hipstresses were when we attempted to eat here. We left before we could order, the hostile greeting was so unfriendly I couldn't stay. Unfortunate... I used to love this place.
author: Jordan M.

description: Nebulous potato thing! It was pretty dang good, but next time I go I am definitely going to get the half order instead of the full. Service was great. The atmosphere is really laid back so don't be expected a fancy breakfast place or anything. My friends and I came in with a pretty big party around 10:30 AM I believe and we got seated pretty fast. It's great that they have two spaces to accommodate more guests. I would definitely come back here when in the area.
author: Jeanette L.

description: Went for breakfast and it was excellent. The staff are very friendly! Had the 2 eggs any style with potatoes and banana bread. I highly recommend the banana bread! Also you can order lunch anytime which was perfect for us! I will be returning for breakfast very soon!
author: Victoria M.

description: A neighborhood institution, and a great brunch spot.  Expect old fashioned vibes and  greasy food.
author: Cambridge Y.

description:
I'm a big fan of hole-in-the-wall diners, primarily for the breakfast food.  This place is the quintessential old-school diner/soda fountain, well, except for all the alty, tattooed folk. I usually get the same thing, which is the basic breakfast with biscuits and vegan sausage.  Why?  Because you can make a vegan sausage biscuit with them that is fantastic.

However, last time I did a sort of custom Joe's special with no cheese.  Ground beef, spinach, and mushrooms.  Oh my god.  Amazing.  The ingredients were super fresh and the beef was cooked perfectly.

So anyway, I've also had their pancakes and French toast which are both really good.  Coffee is not my favorite (over roasted), so I doctor it.  Whatevs, I'm there for the food.  THE FOOOD.   My parents love it too.   Also, the service is excellent.
author: Shannon W.

description: I came here for breakfast on a Monday, after reading the reviews. I wouldn't say I was blown away, but it was definitely strong and lived up to a solid review. The corned beef hash is fresh and herby and not very greasy and the egg inside was cooked perfectly. I got the banana bread too, which initially seemed a little under sweetened for my taste, but with a little butter added it really got it to "like mom used to make" status. Def worth it for a breakfast run, especially if you want something hearty but better and less greasy than a typical corner diner.
author: Rylan C.

description: 5 stars, everything is perfect, no reason to write a long review. Employees, dining space, food, location, all wins, especially great if you're hung over and partied till 6 in the mornin.
author: Captain Muffin D.

description: One of the best breakfast places in the Mission. Their omelettes are fantastic, and worth the wait - although I'll often plan to go alone because it's much faster to get a spot at the counter than waiting for a table.
author: Rajesh S.

description: Came here on a Saturday morning and waited around 20 mins to be seated for a hungry group of 5... and boy was it worth it. I ordered a veggie omelet for myself and also tried a few bites of the nebulous potato thing and my goodness! Everything about this place was great. Fluffy eggs, fresh veggies...their avocado melted in my mouth. Breakfast potatoes were flavored perfectly with a hint of onions. So glad we tried this place, it was simply amazing. Even my picky 4 year-old loved it. Service was great too. Friendly staff & the food came out fairly quickly once we ordered. A must try!
author: Darlene R.

description:
This has got to be my new favorite brunch place by far! Apparently St. Francis has been around since 1918 and I only JUST found out about it?? This is preposterous! Better late than never I guess! =P It has an old diner feel that really takes you back in time. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Zx_VDLeaFdnMFkGyorDZtQ?select=L1r-MnDtTjlARMkBtRruFw). I love the little candy stand as you walk in too! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Zx_VDLeaFdnMFkGyorDZtQ?select=oITQEEiugUWwGgcQPI8s5A) There was a mannequin set up there but I wonder if we would have been able to purchase the candies. Definitely has a hipster crowd/vibe.

The wait took only about 30 min so the smaller the party, the better...my sister and I sat up at the counter space and saw that they made milkshakes, fountain drinks, and ice cream sundaes! Awesome! Our server was super busy so he didn't refill our waters until we asked but more importantly, our food came out hot and in a timely fashion. As usual, there was the dilemma of sweet or savory? We opted to share one of each so it worked out perfectly!

Savory:
3 egg white omelette with spinach, mushrooms, and jack cheese ($9.50 plus $1.50 to sub for egg whites) - $11 was worth all the food we got! The omelette tasted amazing...the spinach and mushrooms were on top of the eggs and the cheese was melted inside. A different approach but SO good! The home fries with a drizzle of tabasco sauce was heaven...thick crispy layer on the outside (the way I like it) and didn't need salt or pepper. And to top if off, the corn bread was TO DIE FOR! It was fresh and crumbly with a crunchy crust...not dry at all either. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Zx_VDLeaFdnMFkGyorDZtQ?select=lJxtbZmSNZ_5NVLtOrFtdw)

Sweet:
2 chocolate chip pancakes ($6) - Wow I never imagined having that many chocolate chips in each bite from a pancake...until I had the pancakes here. Extremely chocolatey with abundant melted chocolate chips so it may not be for everyone but I really enjoyed it since I loooove chocolate! The pancakes were GIGANTIC so it was an incredible deal. Epitome of perfect pancakes...fluffy and sweet with a nice brown color. Maple syrup not needed in this case unless you have a major sweet tooth!
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Zx_VDLeaFdnMFkGyorDZtQ?select=qg70YmosCoEeBZ0QOC6qRA)

In conclusion, a very filling and delicious meal perfect for 2 people! Extra points for having tons of menu options that will keep me coming back for more. I recommend everyone go check it out!
author: Karen Y.

description: These were the best pancakes I'd ever had.  I have no idea why, but they were. I was a bit skeptical as they were a little brown, yet they were delicious.
author: Amanda W.

description:
Success!  Scored a table for 4 with no wait!

Ate here yesterday with my 4 member Birthday Girl Club.  Every month b-day or not we go for an outing which always includes eating!

I was thwarted in my attempt to eat here last year since there was a humongous line!

We could easily have spent an hour reading their extensive menu.  There is something for everyone.  If you can't find anything to eat from the menu then you must be from another planet.

The breakfast menu has at least 20 different kind of 2 or 3 egg omelets, french toast, pancakes, waffles, 4 kinds of tofu scrambles
and much more.

They have lots of choices for Vegans including Vegan Ruebens!


They also have malts, shakes, sundaes, floats including a Guinness Float!

So collectively we had:

Pancakes, Biscuits, home fries, eggs, pesto tofu scramble.Vegan sausage, Vegan chorizo hash, an omelet, ww toast,Chocolate malt, coffee and tea!

So yummy and filling!  We had little and big tastes of each other's dishes and give St FF 7 thumbs up!

The pancakes were fluffy, the potatoes had crispy edges, the tofu pesto scramble was yummy, the biscuits were light and buttery-mmm,
and the malt was luscious!

We're looking forward to eating here soon and having lunch!

Our server was super sweet and attentive,


The candy counter had wax lips!  Sugar Daddies!  Bubble Gum packs from Three's Company, Bo Derek, to name a few;  Button candy!
Garbage Pail kids candy!  Pop Rocks! 

Talk about Blasts From the Past!

We'll be back again during another hopefully uncrowded time!
author: Rinky N.

description: Really great vibe, delicious food, local, unpretentious. A great city diner!
author: Joe B.

description: These guys are great! We had a party of six, were worried about getting out on time, but they seated us quickly. Super friendly, and the food is tasty. I love their corned beef hash and that's all I've tried, but friends have had their eggs florentine and the nebulous potato thing and similarly loved the food. This is what Mel's should be.
author: Faceless E.

description:
We've been here twice for breakfast, and both times we've loved it. 

This last time, we split a Chef's Mess and Blueberry Pancakes. Both were outstanding. I loved that the pancakes actually had blueberries in the batter as opposed to just compote on the top, which so many places are doing these days. I also ordered a side of bacon which was cooked perfectly.

The staff is always super friendly and attentive.

I'd love to go back here for dessert - some of their sundaes and banana splits sound amazing!

I will definitely go out of my way to come here and highly recommend it.
author: Tara M.

description: Kudos to having Growing Pains and Alf trading cards, not to mention Duran Duran and some others.  That alone is worth the trip over there -- I did think there was going to be more of an oldie candy selection here -- did I miss something?  Regardless, a nice spot.
author: Mel G.

description:
I have searched far and wide to find a place that sells my beloved chocolate chip ice cream only to discover it right under my nose at classic soda fountain, St Francis. This seemingly ordinary flavor is surprisingly hard to come by these days, mark my words. Modern ice cream has so many bells, whistles, and foofy ingredients and not many places stock the frozen perfection that consists of plain vanilla and chocolate chips. Get it in a milkshake and thank me later.

Other than shakes, brunch is the jam at St Francis. Their soyrizo is da bomb (the menu is very veg and veeg friendly... because we're in SF after all) and the huevos rancheros are nothing to sneeze at either. If you shake a stick at their burger, I'll shake one at YOU. 

In short: greasy spoon grub served up by good-looking hipsters.
author: Christina S.

description: Great food, friendly service in an old-fashioned soda fountain. I enjoyed biscuits and gravy, hash browns and eggs with a side of bacon.
author: P S.

description: The best breakfast that we have ever had!!i got the nebulous potatoes and they were super tasty. He had the country breakfast which he really enjoyed. The atmosphere was very hipster and cute old school dinner. The service was prompt and very friendly.
author: Kim A.

description:
Hey, St Francis? Yeah, you. I have something to say: 

Stop being dicks. 

I have given you six chances -- six!! -- since moving to your neck of the woods. And the sh*tty part is I REALLY like your food. But my god, your service is abysmal. Why would I go to you and be treated like a herpes outbreak when I can go to any of the restaurants next door and be treated like ... well ... like a patron? 

In fact, I'm curious as to your hiring process. I'm guessing the hiring manager is a friend of the wait staff, right?Because I was in restaurant management for 15 years and I can not, for the life of me, figure out who looked at the current St. Francis crew, compared them to the rest of the potential candidates in San Francisco and said "Yes. This is the best of the best. These are the people I want to be the face of St. Francis and everything we stand for. This is the right decision."

It doesn't make sense any other way. 

So what was the straw that broke the camel's back, you ask? When we had friends from Portland in town who wanted to try you out. I told them it wasn't a good idea, but hey, it wasn't busy and we were hungry so we figured, what the hell? It can't be bad when it's not busy, right? 

Wrong. 

You seated us in the new addition, which was awesome. And you were kinda-sorta friendly, which made me think you were going to change my opinion of St. Francis' staff. But then everything unraveled. You forgot about us until I tracked you down and asked if we could order. You brought each of our meals at different times. You forgot one of our orders completely. You also forgot a milkshake, then tried to give it to me when I was paying the bill, then looked confused when I said we no longer wanted it. And I think you might have charged me for it, had I not taken care of the matter myself. 

But you know what? I still tipped you 20%. Because it's not your fault that someone thinks you're great as the face of St. Francis. It's the hiring manager's fault. 

And to that guy/girl, whomever you are, I have one last thing to say: Quit hiring people based on their super-duper-hip haircuts and skinny jeans and start hiring based on competency levels. Because I still really like your food (hence the extra star), and would really like to come back someday. And my god I want to give you my money. 

But until then I'll go next door to La Torta Gorda, because Armando makes amazing food, has a kick-ass patio, and appreciates every single dollar that walks through his door, regardless of the dollar's hairstyle.
author: Mel H.

description: So good and cheap! If you want high quality, all American food then definitely come here. I'm a vegetarian, and I've been extremely satisfied with their options. The long lines during weekend brunch should be enough to convince you this place is worth trying. Just expect a 20 minute wait. ;)
author: Shala M.

description:
Really great low-key brunch place. I've been twice and once we were seated right away, another time we had to wait about 40 minutes-- not sure why there was a huge difference between the two times, but it was worth it the second time. 

The mimosas are crazy cheap and my favorite thing is the "nebulous pile of spuds" which is basically a giant pile of breakfast potatoes with peppers, cheese, onions, sour cream, tomatoes, etc. and you can add an egg for a dollar. It's nothing fancy, but it's the perfect hangover brunch and definitely a place I'd recommend.
author: Will A.

description:
The main reason I drove ALL the way here from San Jose was just to buy all of their cool vintage trading cards. They have Michael Jackson, Garbage Pail Kids, and Cindy Lauper just to name a few. I was throwing an 80's party and I thought these would be great party favors, which they were! But the service here was bleh! I wasn't ready to pick out the items I wanted yet but they girl insisted on standing behind the counter, rushing me. I was there with my Nina, and I was asking her which ones should I get, and if I got enough. And the girl replied, "Yeah, you have enough." Hello! I wasn't asking you. That's just so rude. I am a paying customer. And paying a lot of I may add. I paid over a $100 on cards alone. That wasn't including meals for 3 people. 

The food was pretty good. And the shakes are delicious. Kinda expensive. But I have experienced better for cheaper.
author: Adina C.

description:
I got major food coma post St. Francis Fountain lunch BUT I think it was worth it.  

Little hipster joint in the mission with some bomb breakfast food that really hits the spot. Got the Chef's Mess which was great. Blueberry hot cakes were also fantastic. Their hot cakes taste really fresh and you can really taste the blueberry in em. 

A few things about this place that I did not like:
-It's a cute diner, but the booth seats are very small.  I consider myself a pretty regular sized asian girl and I fit just right in the booth. It may be uncomfortable if you are a larger sized person!
-The food takes a while. And service is also slow. My waiter was pretty nice but he kept forgetting or mixing up things we asked. For example, we asked him to put our shakes in to-go cups but they came in glasses. I asked for jam but he never got around to bringing it. I wanted a vanilla shake but he kept asking me what flavor I want to put in it, and I ended up with a rocky road shake. 
-Ugh the STRAWS! I love the planet. I love being green but for goodness sake's, the straws are made of paper and mine pretty much flattened and wilted to a deflated wet newspaper texture after a few sips of my shake. How do I enjoy the delicious shake if it refuses to be sipped through the straw?
-They did not have tabasco. Only tapatio... 

These things aside, the food was satisfying and ingredients fresh.  It's not at the top of my list of favorite lunch spots in the mission, but it's definitely a unique hiptastic diner! 

3.5 stars!
author: Gloria C.

description:
God, I would have given St. Francis 4 stars based on my months of experience here, but today really rubbed me the wrong way. I work in the area, so of course I love that St. Francis is there for all times of the day. I've had the omelets for breakfast when I'm a bit early for work, call in for the takeout lunch of the sampler (side salad, cup of mac and cheese, and cup of chili for $8), and have nothin but great things to say about their burgers.

But. Today. I took a man friend here for late breakfast/lunch, and we couldn't decide what to order. I finally chose the French toast with yogurt, granola, and fruit with a side of bacon - it comes to me heaping and plentiful, takes up the whole plate, and a drizzle syrup starts my eating game, all for $10. My dining partner wasn't so lucky. He didn't like some of the breakfast burrito options, so decided to add some extras - bacon, cilantro, avocado, potatoes - to a burrito that was listed on the menu.

My dish was tasty. So was his. But imagine our surprise when the bill comes and his breakfast burrito  - modified, sure, to add some extras - is fucking TWENTY FIVE DOLLARS. I'm sorry, why? Because our smart (I'm obviously being ironic) server added all of the extras for the breakfast burrito a la carte. Here's the thing - we were more than willing to build the burrito on its own, but $25 fucking dollars for one? It was a dick move for the server to charge it all separately, especially since each item wasn't in full on the side and was mixed ultimately for the burrito. Of course, we don't realize this until my credit card is charged, and I had to get back to work.

Dear server at St. Francis: if you're seeing that someone's BURRITO is totaling $25, don't be an ass and bring it to their attention. You can also mod that shit in Aloha. Play fair.
author: Jenz y.

description: Nice menu and the place seems from outside like it might be fun but the service here is terrible. Even if there are only three tables in the place the staff walks right past you, doesn't check on you, doesn't bring check if asked for, doesn't do much of anything. Once upon a time this place was great but that was like 15 years ago. This place is a real drag.
author: Owen S.

description: I have walked in here at least 20 times and it always feels the same. I love when The St. Francis Fountain made a cameo in season 1 episode 5 of HBO's Looking.  The scene was spectacular due to the 2 hotties that walked in during Patrick and Richie's date and completely stole my attention, if not the whole scene.  Oucha magoucha.
author: Wesley W.

description: Plenty of great vegan options. Crowded and cozy. Staff are efficient and polite, though not exactly ebullient. One small unisex bathroom if you, like, pee a lot and this is important to you.
author: Squeaky T.

description:
The Food: 
1. I am gluten-free and they know what that is and how to help me.
2. I love ice cream and they know what that is and make it AMAZINGLY.
3. My wife is vegetarian and they have a TON of options that are delish.
4. My wife is vegetarian and I'm gluten free and we can eat here happily and healthily.

The Ambiance:
1. Since they opened the other dining room the wait is MUCH shorter. 
2. It can get a little loud BUT they have seating that allows for a little more privacy.
3. It has that old diner feel which i love.

The Price:
1. It is priced perfectly for what you get. Love it.

The Con:
1. I hate their paper straws they serve with the shakes.
author: Min M.

description:
St. Francis is now my favorite diner in the city. (Don't get me wrong- there's a lot of great places here- I love Eddie's on Divis, the Pork Store, Mo's Grill, and Pat's Cafe too, but St. Francis is tops.) 

I went here for breakfast with a friend before they left to go back east and immediately loved the ambiance of the old-school diner. It wasn't kitschy in the way of being fake- they weren't trying too hard. The service was really great- friendly staff without being all up in your business, and they refilled the coffee often. 

The food- wow. I didn't know what to choose because it all looked so good, so i went with the basic eggs with bacon. it came with biscuits and potatoes. It was a lot of food for the price, and really tasty! I could see how it would be the perfect cure for a hangover, but it's good anytime! I can't wait to go back and try a milkshake.
author: Leigh H.

description: I can always count on the food being on point everytime which Is why I always suggest it when the conversation to go somewhere great for breakfast comes up. Great place.
author: Gabr R.

description:
Decent food HORRIBLE service.

Ate lunch here on two diffferent occasions. Its a super hip place with decent food but my god is the service bad. The first time i went there everytime I said thank you to the waiter he responded only with the word "totally". If you can get a thank you or a welcome out of any of the staff you must be lucky or caught them on a good day. The second time I went, I signed up to be seated and while waiting to be seated watched as another group who had just arrived was immediately given a table before me. Once I was sat the waitress acted like we were a mjaor inconvenience to her the whole time.
author: Chase G.

description:
Here is a St. Francis Fountain Haiku for you:

Hipsters baring T and A
Tots and eggs with coffee to boot
Wait ten or twenty minutes

Put your hoo-hah away while serving girlies! But the food is pretty good, so I will keep eating there, just make sure your hoo-hah doesn't get in my food and we have a deal.
author: Shira O.

description:
PLEASE NOTE:  I am the said "co-worker" in this story but I'm mad for her, so I've been compelled to go online and write this diatribe as a public service announcement.  

"I  was introduced to this restaurant through mutual  friends, while doing a play at the BRAVO theater at the street (yes, I am an actor).

The experience was pleasant enough, it warranted to be added to my file of places to go to while I'm at my real job struggling to pay the bills...yes, I have a day job too because  I love cable and my big 60" screen t.v. ...

So, on this glorious Friday, I decided to treat myself and a co-worker to lunch at the famous...oops now "infamous", St. Francis Fountain.  I called ahead, was disconnected but didn't give up, I called back.  A nice female took my order and  I requested an itemized bill, so I could collect money from my co-worker. I also ordered a milkshake, but did not indicate the size, small or large, just a milkshake.

Upon arriving, I saw my ready order sitting sideways on the counter.  I waited patiently while several individuals paid and left and several more were waited upon.  Finally, I said, "My food is to go and it's right there - UPSIDE DOWN..." The wait attendant appeared irritated, I asked about my milkshake, he said it was coming and proceeded to attend to another patron who had ordered a milkshake in a cup that appeared to be a 16 oz cup.  My mouth watered with excitement as I anticipated my milkshake in a 16 oz cup, as well.  Much to my chagrin, my milkshake was half the size.  I mentioned to the waiter, I did not order a small. HE replied, "Yes, you did I took your order."   I thought "Wow, I know I was talking to a female."    Extra stars deducted b/c when I went back to office, found out he overcharged me than when you compare it to the menu, not a huge amount but just the principal, it looks like he was just coming up with the figures as he rang me up (even though I called ahead of time, asking for the amount).  Also, I didn't get any utensils with my order to eat the dish.

Long story short, I did not feel welcome.  It used to be one of my favorite old school, diners to get a sandwich, good diner food but now I will no longer patronize them.  

So, disappointed, long time loyal customer and local.  Guess I have to get a skateboard and some tattoos to fit in if I ever do return next time."
author: Elle F.

description: There is never a time when I don't love St. Francis soda fountain. Whether you're having a me day and want to leisurely eat a rather large breakfast while getting caught up on that magazine collection or taking your little kids for an early dinner because you're tired of cooking/cleaning up. Whenever they ask you what kind of bread - always answer cornbread. Always get the homefry potatoes - the best.
author: Craig S.

description:
I went here today for a Sunday morning brunch with friends.  I ordered the Eggs Valerie (avocado & fried tomato) with a side of sausage patty. The hollandaise sauce was perfect, the pan-fried potatoes yummy. The sausage was a wee bit over cooked, but tasted great (was it in-house made?). 

My veggie friends got the veggie chorizo scramble & some mac-n-cheese. I sampled it and was surprised that I would actually order the scramble on purpose despite being a meat eater. It was that good! Oh, and they make the man-n-cheese with onion--noms! So creamy too!

Service was great. The staff found a table for the 6 of us relatively quickly. The server was nice & accommodating for my friends' baby. Also a added bonus: as we were wrapping up our meal, they happened to have an extra meal that was made by mistake, as asked if we wanted to take it home for later. So nice!

Anyways, this was my first time here, but they certainly made a good impression.
author: Nifer K.

description: Yummy brunch spot. The huevos rancheros were really good and the potatoes are cooked nice and crispy.  That's all I ate here, but I would go back and try out some other things too.
author: A K.

description: What to expect: Smelly punk rock kids, SMELLY. No greetings or pleasantries and absolutely NO eye contact. Even when you see 5 employees walking by not one looks up or at you. I've been asked 2 questions every time I've come here: "You ready?" & "Is that all?" Before a check is thrown at me. I come once a week, no one even bothers to say hi.
author: Griddly B.

description: This is one of my go-to places for taking out-of-town guests for breakfast, as it is a historical site, unique, and not as crazy crowded as the trendier spots in my neighborhood.  I even took my father there.  He was the only guy in the place who could remember going to original soda fountains and he loved it.  Extra star for the servers being very nice to us.  The food was fresh and satisfying.  Be aware that the food and prices are not historically acurate, but the menu has lots of options.  There should be something to please everyone.  The music was upbeat reggae,  not too loud or frenetic.
author: Disa L.

description:
Last night I tried to go to Bombay Creamery but they were closed. I cruised on over to Humphrey Slocombe but they were also closed. Pissed off and ready to forget about my craving for ice cream I really just wanted to go home but my boyfriend insisted we go elsewhere. He found SFF on Yelp and I was so happy that he did (he's awesome, isn't he?!?)

 The folks that work here were incredibly friendly and attentive. They serve Mitchell's Ice Cream which is fabulous (dense, creamy, deliciousness). The best part about this place is that they sell old fashioned candy and trading cards (Garbage Pail Kids, A-Team, Alf, Beverly Hills 90210, and more).  Oh and they have those red and white swirly paper straws!!
author: Grace C.

description:
I think St. Francis Fountain is just fine, though it has plenty of room for improvement. 

Let's start with the good: 
- The food is really solid. The Reuben is a great sandwich, and they have great hand-cut fries. They have vanilla and cherry syrup to add to sodas, and they have lots of vegetarian/vegan options. This provides flexibility when you have friends with restrictions. 
- The location is great. It's a 10-15 minute walk from my house, but you're in the middle of the 24th street corridor. 
- The place is a landmark, been in existence since 1920 or something. The decor is very old-timey and true to its original form and purpose. 

Overall, I think these are the ingredients for a solid experience.

But there are some bad things: 
- The crowd and waiters are too cool for school. Oh my goodness, the entire place is filled with ironic hipsters. 
- The prices are kind of high for diner food. $6 for a milkshake is a bit much. 
- To get very nitpicky: GET RID OF THOSE ANNOYING STRAWS. They have paper straws, perhaps in an attempt to seem authentic and "green." Authenticity I don't give one whit about, and for "green"ness just buy normal compostable straws. I go through 2-3 of those dumb paper straws in a meal, and it's annoying as heck. 
- I don't think they do a very good job of clearing out tables or getting new folks in tables on the weekend. There can be 15 people waiting for a table, with three tables empty and three yet to have the previous occupants' dishes cleared. 

Overall, I really do like this place. With a few changes, it could earn 4 stars. With a few changes and a couple of bucks off each menu item, it could easily earn 5 stars.
author: Tom P.

description:
If there's no crowd and you can sit out on the east side of the building, do it.  I wouldn't wait 45 minutes to eat here but on a sunny Mission morning, this is my preferred brunch spot with the lady and dog.

Super Sample the dog friendly - I think they brought her water the last time we ate there.
author: AP R.

description:
St. Francis is my neighborhood go-to since I moved down the block over 3 years ago. For dinner, for hangovers, for consoling a friend through a break-up, for surprise birthday parties, I have never had a bad experience here. The service is very friendly and helpful! Everything is delicious. I love listening to Tina Turner or the Ramones over brunch. Cats doing people stuff trading cards??!!!!!!

The only frustration I've felt here has been witnessing entitled tools treat the staff like crap. Just because you come in to spend $10 on breakfast doesn't mean you deserve a round of applause or to get your d s'ed. Treat people how you'd like to be treated. St. Francis is great!
author: April D.

description:
Everyone who works here is nice as hell and the food is amazing. The fact that they've added even more vegan options to their menu AND opened up that secondary room makes me love them even more. 

But a question for the rest of the Yelpers here: WHY, oh WHY do you feel the need to point out the fact that there are hipsters here? Way to go Captains Obvious! It is really sad that your secret jealously of people with better haircuts AND music taste than you overshadows the delicious meal in front of you. Stop worrying about other people's clothing and eat your nebulous potato thing.
author: Ginny M.

description:
Came to this neighborhood on a late weekend  and most everything was closed for food (at 10pm, really?). 

Loved their soup, "the Poor Man" that came with a biscuit in the middle of a nice broth souop. The buttery biscuit complimented the hot steaming veggies nicely and turned into the perfect concoction for a cold San Franciscan summer night.
author: Sue Y.

description:
This is my absolute favorite place for brunch, purely on the basis of deliciousness. 

I haven't been steered wrong with any dish, but my absolute favorite is the Chef's Mess. Potatoes, avocado, bacon, chives, cheese...I mean, what's not to like? The biscuits here are also fantastic - fluffy and buttery with just a touch of whole grain nuttiness.

The portions are huge. Expect a doggy bag, or share. 

The coffee is "damn good for diner coffee". Which means, it doesn't displace my morning cappuccino, but it goes down well with the meal.  

There'll inevitably be a wait, but at least it's a good spot for people watching on a lazy weekend morning?
author: Monica S.

description:
Knowing St. Francis Fountain exists makes battling life's vicissitudes more palatable. 

Ever since I was a kid, I have loved diners. My family is from NYC, but I grew up throughout the country. Wherever I lived I would seek out the best diner and call it my culinary home. In Boston, it was S&S in Inman Square. In NYC, it was too many to choose from (paradise!). In Santa Fe, it was the Plaza Cafe. 

So, when I moved to San Francisco last year and discovered I lived a block away from a diner people raved about, I got nervous. "What if it totally sucks? What if the place I like is miles away at the end of some trolley car, or whatever they drive here, line?" 

To be honest, my worries were not quelled when I saw the hipster crowds hanging outside. My experience is that the "scene" spots in life are not always the best eating. And why should they be? If a scene is what people want to pay for, give them the scene (and cut your expenses on those gourmet cheeses).  

By the time I had my first meal at St. Francis, a BLT and a cup of chicken soup, I was prepared for the worse.  But from the minute I stepped inside to my last slurp of chocolate milkshake, my fears were replaced by admiration for the quality, care and charm of this singular, homestyle, "write home about" worthy establishment. 
Here's why St. Francis excels, in particular: 

1. They have all the diner standards, but they use fresh ingredients and prepare the food with care. The flavors are clear, well balanced, and I find the dishes to be as rich, salty and cheesy as you want them to be, but they go easy on the grease. 
2. The staff is fresh, young and beautiful (ok, put up your hipster shields), but they are also sincere, kind and attentive (put your shields down). 
3. They don't rush you. If they are not busy you are free to leisurely finish your meandering conversation about the New Yorker article you and your friend both skimmed but have strong opinions about. 
4. Going alone feels great, even without a book. If you're a freelancer like me, this is a useful bonus. It's not Cheers where everyone comes rushing over and gives you a hug, but you will be looked in the eye, treated with respect and served amazing food. 

I wish I could recommend lots of menu items, but I'm now stuck in the most satisfying ordering rut, the veggie reuben with spinach salad and a chocolate milkshake. They also make great hamburgers.

The things I've had that were ho hum (no bad, just meh), were the macaroni and cheese and the hot fudge sundae. As in all kitchens, there are things that soar and things that just fly by. 

If you're looking for a place for reliable culinary comfort, this is your spot.
author: Siobhán K C.

description:
I've been here three times in the last year or so. I gave this place another chance today, but only because of the nostalgic factor, it was a family treat when I was a kid. From now on, I'll just enjoy my good memories from across the street.

The food is mediocre at best and the service is just as weak. There were four customers in there this morning (counting my grandson and I) and two servers. For some reason it still took way too long to place an order and they forgot my drink. Really? I only ordered three things. The best service I got was when I went there with two of my white female friends. (i'm a brown dude) That did nothing to improve the food. How hard is it to make basic "american" breakfast and lunch taste decent? Apparently, it's very challenging. Or the chef hates the crowd.

I would assume that if you have the money to take over a business in the Mission you can afford to do a better job with hiring and ingredients. 

Bad service leaves a bad taste in my mouth. Maybe that makes the food taste worse than it might be? Nah. The only good thing about this place in it's current incarnation was the pez I got for my grandson.

Farewell old friend.
author: P G.

description:
Late night...early morning?  Craving breakfast any time of day?   St Francis Fountain can satisfy your all-american diner food needs, and do it well.   I may be biased because I'm only a few blocks away, but this is definitely my go to place for eggs, hash, pancakes and the like.  Try the Potato Thing.

They also have a plethora of vegan and vegetarian options, including a really yummy veggie rueben if you are in the mood for lunch/dinner type fare.    Milkshakes also get a star all by themselves.

Atmosphere is very 50s diner = hipster.  Only complaint is the rather uncomfortable booths that feel more like church pews than diner booths, but that's nitpicking, and really, I like it better that way.
author: Travis B.

description: Really good place to eat, its like a little mom and pop's diner that's been here (looks like it) almost forever. I got a milkshake cause i was coming down from a high and my girlfriend ordered some kind of steak and eggs. Great place to chill, hangout, people watch. I mean, this area is a hipsters hangout neighborhood, but its not a bad thing. Go down the street and get some coffee and overhear a couple of the neighbors talk about "Shoop" by Salt N' Peppa and whether or not Spinderella was the third member of the group or not.
author: Richard A.

description: Authentic and delicious. My chocolate banana shake was perfection.
author: Megan J.

description: Lovely service, yummy diner food, caters to vegetarians & omnivores alike
author: Jessica R.

description:
Been here for breakfast a few times, and the food is pretty good - it's just too bad the environment sucks. I can't imagine this place passing any kind of health inspection, seriously. 

Dude with open shirt with a ton of chest hair along with super long dirty, greasy hair, working behind the counter pouring me coffee? For real? I know this place is the hipster HQ, but come on. At least make sure the people making the serving the food are clean and are sanitary. So most hipsters are dirty and don't bathe, that's awesome, but I don't want that person making my food and serving it to me.

On top of that, the last time I went in there I had a cup of coffee. The cup was cracked; it cut my finger and leaked all over the table. I was offered a new cup, poured about 1/3 of the way full so "I wouldn't spill it". Thanks?

It's really a quaint classic diner type place, and the food isn't that bad, it's just too bad the owners aren't more concerned with cleanliness and not poisoning people. But I guess having all the local hipsters think you're super "kewl" is good enough for some people...

I can't imagine I'll return to this place until I hear the employees get a bath. Seriously...
author: Erik B.

description: The food would be 3 stars but the ambiance gave it the 4th star.  It took the waiters about 20 minutes to take our order after seating us which isn't horrible but it was noted by my friend. The waiter was very friendly.
author: Rachel F.

description:
Thank you, Vegan Saurus, for letting me know that there is, in fact, a place to go for vegan hangover food (note: it has a lot of vegan options, but is not all vegan). Actually none of the times I've been here had anything to do with hangovers, just fun, sunny cheerful afternoons on a fun block, with good conversation over the devil burger. The decor is also pretty amusing. Because this place is so good, however, it is also popular, so the wait can be long on a Saturday or Sunday afternoon. 
(I don't recommend the milkshake. Everything else is yummy though.)
author: Bean H.

description: Great diner for curing a hangover. Hilariously to-the-point menu and decently amiable staff. They get you what you need. Be prepared to wait, it's a small but popular place. I had corned beef hash and it was okay by my East Coast standards. Coffee isn't anything to write home about.
author: Patrick M.

description:
One day I woke up and was craving tofu scramble and ended up at St. Francis because it's one of the few places in the city that serves it. 

I got the Tofu Scramble with ranchera sauce, avocado, tomatoes, onions and goat cheese. It came with a side of potatoes (Nebulous Potato Thing style) and cornbread. This was a huge portion of food and could easily have been split by two people. Everything was delicious, service was great (and surprisingly quick).

There's always a wait to get a table so get a milkshake in the meantime. They're some of the best in the city.
author: Shreya O.

description:
We came here (the two of us) this past Saturday around noon and waltzed into a table with no problem.  

Staff were very friendly and though the skinny jean look can sometimes equal rudeness or snobbery I didn't find that to be the case here at all.

The diner is filled with a wide range of customers: hipsters, yuppies, families with kids, etc.

The food is.... well, what do you expect with a diner?  It's basically good diner food.  Nothing too special.  I would like it if they used real maple syrup instead of the fake stuff - but I guess that's to expected with a diner.  The scrambled eggs plain were not good though.  It was like imitation scrambled egg powder - way too overcooked. The Chef's Mess was good though.

Bike Parking: designated bike racks right outside on 24th St.
author: Jean K.

description: SFF gets 5 stars for the kind staff and because even when I was full I couldn't stop eating my simple sunny-side up eggs and bacon with potatoes (that are easily in my top 5 potatoes in the city).
author: Shahrzad K.

description: Old school, but totally cute. Food was good. Great portions. Couldn't finish mine... Had to pack it for the roommate!
author: Krystal T.

description: Food is good but they totally suck at table management - after waiting half an hour we were finally shown to the same seats that were open at the bar when we arrived the other 8 vacant seats are still vacant despite a huge line and people dropping out
author: Andrew N.

description: This cute diner in the Mission takes you back in time with its vintage vibe.  For Saturday brunch, the hubs and I were seated promptly upon arrival - woohoo!  I ordered the Nebulous Potato Thing I've heard so much about and it did not disappoint.  If you are craving diner food, don't skip this spot!
author: Vanessa L.

description:
The food here is pretty decent and it's a good place to go with vegetarian/vegan friend's since there's a lot of veg options. Can get busy on the weekends with mission hipsters (but on the weekends for brunch it's usually a toss up between hipsters and yuppies and I can stand the hipsters) and the wait can sometimes be near an hour. 

And like so many have mentioned, they have old school trading cards for sale.
author: Aaron M.

description: Update: gets better and better! I've introduced so many of my friends to this place, great hang out after the movies.
author: Trinity L.

description:
Ohhhhhh my fav.

This is not your average "diner". I'm a self-identified food snob, and I must say that I go here at least once a week. 
(vegan disclaimer here)
There is no other restaurant in town that's non-specifically vegetarian with such amazing/extensive vegan/vegetarian options. This is top of the line carnivorous-vegetarian true love marriage.

FAKE MEAT +fake cheese (thank you!)= I'm yours forever.

Go for a breakfast burrito. Best breakfast burrito in the city. I've tried 'em all. Tofu scrams and cornbread are also delicious. You won't be disappointed. Big portions, good crowd, and breakfast all day! As it should be. 

I don't know anyone's names, but the folks who've been working there forever are awesome. Great service and they somehow amazingly don't seem to get annoyed (I don't know how they do it) with all the kooler than lyfe hungover morons that come here. I can't help but leave them big tips every time. Only there's one newer waitress that really needs to lighten up. I just recently had the most unfriendly service in my 4 years of patronage. She needed to get over herself. (She's all omg I work at St.Francis how hip and aloof am I!) All the veteran waiters are stellar though!!!! I love them. 

This is my one rock-steady breakfast joint. Any meal, any day. THANK YOU.
author: Deadly B.

description:
The most delicious burger I have ever had. Everything about this tiny diner was over the top good. And it's vegan friendly too, which is how my vegan sister Abigail found this place for us to get lunch at. 

I will come here again, and not just with vegans, although with them too.
author: Peter L.

description: Slow service....hipster haven...could care less if you have been waiting 10 minutes for water...food is decent...
author: Ashley A.

description:
Welcome to the St. Francis Fountain.  Here exists a place where you can step out of everyday, busy life in 2010 and set foot into a 1950's time-warp.  If there was a television in this place, I would have expected to see a black and white episode of "I Love Lucy" playing in the background.  From what I understand, this establishment was already old-school by the 1950's, and actually is closer to 100 years old!  

It doesn't take much more than that to get me excited about "hip" little diners like this; you already have a pretty clear idea of what is being served up at the St. Francis: Breakfast, Burgers, Coffee - Oh, and a selection of Mitchell's Ice Cream, so Milkshakes, Banana Splits and Hot Fudge Sundaes (if that's what you want for lunch!).  I went with the Turkey Bacon Club on Sliced Sourdough with Cheddar and a Caesar Salad...not one bit disappointed by my decision at all.  

Surprisingly the parking is pretty easy here, considering that this part of San Francisco can be a little challenging at times (and many spaces limited to 1 hour only).  Just bring a handful of change ($2/hr...wow San Francisco!), and be ready to sidestep the panhandler with the shopping cart after you feed the meter.  Really, though, it actually is a pretty nice neighborhood!

Also be prepared to "chat it up" with the person sitting next to you if you come alone and sit at the counter: the place fills up quick, and the "hip-girl" with the Oversized sunglasses (which never came off) sitting next to me wanted some conversation in addition to me passing her the sugar for her soy-infused coffee.  

"What was I doing in the neighborhood?" was the general tone of the conversation.  

Just passing through...and I will be sure to do that here again sometime soon!
author: Christian H.

description: Meh.  I really wanted to like this place - I do love little diners.  But the portions for lunch were small - and my side order of banana bread was ridiculously small given the price.  I should've gone with a breakfast meal, but it's two stars for lunch here.
author: Shannon N.

description:
3.5
Finally went here after living in SF for about 25 years! 
I had a hankering for an old-fashion fried egg or grilled cheese sando, malt, and fries. Not my typical fare but sometimes you need that comfort food.
hi-lights:
+banana malt was delicious - creamy; rich; banana-y enough - appreciated being able to order a small 
+prices - very reasonable; good portions
+décor/ambiance - cozy, old-school; dug the counter and booths
+fried egg sando- eggs perfectly cooked;  they use shredded lettuce instead of leaf lettuce which was a nice surprise
+French toast  - just right - classic - good egg wash/bread ratio 


lo-lights:
+service - slow despite not being too crowded
+fries - just ok - not worth the waistline - maybe slightly over-cooked 

and I really wanted a classic grilled cheese w/ American cheese on white bread - they didn't seem to have either American cheese or white bread -- I didn't ask ---
I tell ya it's hard to find a real old-fashioned grilled cheese in SF - everyone wants to give you fancy cheeses; multiple cheeses; extra ingredients; and "healthy" bread....
author: Carson R.

description: This place was awesome!  Great food and great vintage souvenirs.
author: Jane K.

description:
Love this place! Feels authentic and neighborhoody, with character and good food. Just what you're looking for in a fun breakfast joint.

Note: the booths are tight, so its not going to be super comfortable for larger people.
author: Jay S.

description:
Oh I love this place. I discovered it not through Yelp (shocker!) but rather by walking by, seeing a huge crowd, and figuring it was worth the wait. I'm so glad that I put my name up on that sheet. 

I was there with 4 people and waited for a good 45min to get a table on a Saturday morning. Totally worth it though. The waiters are nice, fun and quirky and will tell you exactly what they think about certain dishes if you ask them. Ask them their opinion and tell you and not settle for the annoying "it's all good!" 

Get a milkshake. They are fantastic. My boyfriend and I shared a large (around $5.50, i think) and struggled to finish it. After a little bit of playing around, I have now found my standard, which is with strawberry ice cream and banana flavouring. The large will come in a pretty diner glass, with the leftovers in the metal tin. Basically you will never run out. 

The breakfast menu is fantastic and I usually order off there. The chorizo, although fake meat, tastes really good! Breakfast burrito is solid. I have now had the burger and it's actually good. I don't know why I am surprised, but it was good. I don't even know what to tell you to order. Everything that I have had here has been good. 

If it wasn't for the insane wait that you have to endure on the weekends, I could possibly make St. Francis an even more frequent stop. But if you want to avoid the line, go in the early afternoon of the weekend and you might get a table almost right away!
author: Mariko F.

description: This place is totally adorable and the food is AWESOME! They are vegan friendly and this even includes MILKSHAKES, yay! The people who work here are totally rad and the price is right. I like the vibe of the place, as it reminds me of an old-school diner. anyway, hope this helps yelpers - enjoy!
author: Emily P.

description:
I don't really have anything witty to say like the prior reviews from my friends. 

This place is simply a badass diner with great food and attentive service. My friend recommended the Huevos Rancheros ( $7.50) served with black beans and cheese, a salsa salad. Proper portion, insanely delicious. 

I couldn't stop staring at my other friend's Biscuits and sausage gravy with scrambled eggs and home fries. The best gravy I've tasted outside of Milbrae Pancake House. The home fries were seasoned and distinctive. 

I couldn't stop eating. They kept my coffee and water filled. The place is filled with hipsters but none of them were smelly or irritating or singing Arcade Fire songs. 

Parking is an obvious issue since you are deep in the Mission so maybe taxi or walk the 7-8 blocks from BART. 

On a sunday at Noon there was a 20 minute wait for a party of 5....but it was so frickin' worth it!!

Can't wait to go back : )
author: Taj A.

description: Delicious. I had a cheddar veggie scramble, beau had something similar. Bit too much cheese on mine but hey, all good. We shared vegan blueberry pancakes, also scrumptious. Cool neighborhood with decent parking, good prices, yummy coffee, and we also didn't have to wait too long. Service was friendly and quick.
author: Jenn H.

description: This place is equally cute and delicious. My friends and I came in for a quick breakfast and were blown away. Simple and great food. Everything it should be. The service was equally just as awesome!
author: Alice K.

description:
Mmmmmmm St. Francis makes me happy. The breakfast entrees are nothing short of delicious. I've had a few of the egg scrambles with home fries, the vegan chorizo burrito, and most recently the French toast with vegan sausage. The French toast was wonderful--it's old fashioned just how I like it (spare me the fancy stuffed crème brûlée types of French toast). The perfectly browned edges, hint of cinnamon and sprinkle of powdered sugar made for a little taste of heaven in every bite. We brought my little sister here and she was stoked about the jawbreakers and "licorice jump ropes" at the candy counter....and being able to finish her meal with a scoop of homemade rocky road ice cream! 

Service has always been great for me :)

Hipsterville, USA? Kind of, yeah. But the vibe has always been pleasant and it's never bothered me.
author: Emily S.

description:
I freakin' love this place! 
All day breakfast! Can I say more! It is so hard to find a good place that serves brunch food past 2pm. And its GOOD!
I went there last weekend, and had the eggs + vegan chorizo scram, and the chocolate chip pancakes. Everything was fresh and delish! The chocolate chip pancakes literally put a huge smile on my face-I couldn't even control it. 
The place is affordable, the place is cool in an of itself--very old school diner, the food is yummy and it's in one of the coolest neighborhoods in all of SF!
author: S A.

description:
I usually love this place for the great combo of regular breakfast and vegan breakfast, and their willingness to customize my food for me (I have food allergies). Of course it's super hipster-style, but I just find that amusing, not annoying. BUT, on my last visit, this morning, I started getting soured on the place. Why?

-- The hostess did everything she could NOT to make eye contact with any of the patrons, let alone actually have to talk to one of us.

-- My partner and I got seated in the "Candy Kitchen", the annex next door.... where we were summarily forgotten.

-- The waiter came over and took our order eventually, then forgot to bring the coffee for 25 minutes.

-- When our food came, he asked if we wanted more coffee, we said "yes" and it was another 15-20 minutes, AND we had to ask for it. 

They MIGHT have been understaffed since it's 4th of July and maybe some people called in "sick". But we're regulars, and this is how it's been the last 3-4 times. 

It's a damn shame is what it is.

I will keep going to St. Francis Fountain because I LOVE the food and a couple of the waiters (like the guy who looks like Jim Carrey). But seriously, the experience was BAD this time, and I expect the service to get way better, and soon. I'm writing a letter (yes, a paper letter) to the owner ASAP to give this feedback, so I'm not just posting it on Yelp like a coward. :)
author: Jennifer B.

description:
My business has only been in the Mission a couple of months and I'm happy I found St. Francis Fountain! I like diners for their burgers, fries and milk shakes, so this is my new neighborhood fav.  I've been lucky so far to grab seats when I get there because shortly after I get my seat there is a line starting to form outside.  

Both times I've been (not the last time)I've been greeted and waited on very soon after. The peeps behind the counter were speedy on the refills of the coffee too.
author: Marty W.

description: This place rules! Its all that and a bag of chips (if you want chips...seriously, I saw them, they've got you covered!) and truly is my new breakfast spot. Friendly staff, clean, fun, interesting customers (all friendly) and their breads are a-ma-zing!
author: Bella B.

description:
I'm a brunch kind of gal and I must say this place has a kick ass country breakfast. It came with 2 eggs your way, biscuits, gravy, potatoes... that plus a small OJ was $11... tax and tip brought it to $13.80. It's not bad for brunch, considering how big the portions are.

The wait was about 20 minutes bc the place was packed.... tons of hipsters but that doesn't really bother me lol.
author: ALISHA W.

description:
Waited a half hour at the counter for our 2 espresso milkshakes TO GO.  Not sure if the guy who helped us was having first day issues.  He had to remake 1 of our milkshakes.  Our laundry at the laundromat a block away was finished and my bf was able to go walk our load to the car and return, where I was still waiting on the shakes.

$5 each for small milkshakes that were a bit runny.  

Note: small sized milkshake is the size of child sized soda from a drive thru. Not small sized normal soda size.  A lot of waiting  for baby sized milkshakes that were the consistency of syrup.  I guess that's what happens when they're left blending for a half hour.
author: Kristina F.

description:
I'll definitely be back to this place the next time I need some greasy vegan food and coffee to help me with Sunday morning hangover.
The place is kitschy and a regular spot for neighborhood kids (hipsters, I suppose), but there is an honesty to it all that keeps it from being annoying... even to someone as hungover as me.

Pros-
Vegan options that are tasty.
Decent bottomless coffee for a diner.
Good price/food ratio.
They have Cholula. That's always a pro.
Cute decor.

Neutrals-
Well, the water was bland. Heh.
I also think our waiter may have been hungover, too.

Cons-
None.
author: David G.

description:
Service, taste, and experience; things that make your food adventure.  This adventure service took a swim with the sharks.

Service: Friendly wait staff, but they forgot about the table once the order was in and the food was delivered.  It took many many minutes to flag someone down for a refill of water and some additional condiments.  The condiments took also took many many minutes.

Food: The food was good, with the everything scramble and eggs Florentine.  The biscuits could have used honey in the batter to sweeten it up, otherwise, the food was good and would come here for food alone.

Experience: 1950's dinner feel; fun atmosphere.
author: Po L.

description:
oh st. francis, the last time i had set foot inside of you, you did not have outdoor seating and didn't have 1/2 the vegan options you have now.

oh, and i was also an omnivore.

this visit, i had a hard time making up my mind over what to get since you grew your vegan menu since you somehow knew i wanted to fatten up for the winter.  if i eat enough of yout vegan spuds and tofu scrambles and seitan + vegan burger madness i wouldn't need to wear a coat for the next couple of months.

hello cute waitress in the red skirt with short blond hair, thank you for being patient as we asked your opinion on the different veg friendly items on the menu.

did i mention you were cute and ncie?  yes.  thank you.  i would marry you if it meant free vanilla soy shakes for life,  yes, the dr. can marry you too.  

i ended up with a tofu scramble dressed with spinach, mushrooms and peanut sauce and proceeded to inhale all of it on top of my rye toast.  

i will return for your seitan sandwich.  and your vegan thing.  and your vegan sausage.  and your vegan burger with seitan.  and your undying love.
author: Jen I.

description: I ordered a milkshake and it took 15 minutes to get it even though it was pretty empty and 4 in the afternoon. The milkshake was small and expensive but tasty enough. Also they do not let people use their wifi and the benches are really short and weird to sit on.
author: Sarah B.

description:
This review is for the take-out only. Because we thought that by calling our order in, we would avoid the clustercluck that is St.F.F. 

First: There is an issue with the menu here kids. There are TWO items on the online menu called "The Poor Man" 

1) is chicken veggie soup with a biscuit

2) is veggie chili with corn bread

Why do you do this St. Francis Fountain? Why do you have two completely different food items called the same exact thing? So my co-worker, in her infinite wisdom (adhering to the "anti-stupidity clause") ordered me a "chili with corn bread." She did NOT call it the "Poor Man" she literally said "chili with corn bread."

Upon their return to the office, what do I have? Chicken soup with a biscuit. Not the nommy fried delicious cornbread. I am saddened because we did everything in our immediate power short of opening up the containers to ensure that we had "chili with cornbread". 

I'd also like to point out that while I am not vegetarian, this could have posed a problem for someone that was. Pretty insensitive guys. I don't know who you have taking your phone orders and you probably won't care that you didn't get my order right. I'm just sad I'm not eating chili. But I thwarted your system and got 1/2 my co-worker's cornbread cause she felt bad. So now you have also deprived someone of 1/2 their cornbread out of sheer guilt. 

The soup is pretty good. The biscuit is pretty damn good. The cornbread is lovely. Your online order taking skills to the execution of said order? Needs some work to stop blowing.
author: Alexis W.

description:
I love this place! My girlfriend and I use to visit every weekend but now that we're mostly out in the East Bay it's kinda hard to get down here. :(

This place has a great feel to it. The staff is really welcoming and friendly (except for one little dark haired girl who always seems to be having a bad day). 

The food is straight forward. My fav's are the Chef's Mess and the Veggie Chili. Thats pretty much my standby when I go in, unless I want breakfast then I get the Hotcakes which are perfectly fluffy and delicious!

If you have never been here I would recommend you stop buy and give it a try!
author: Aaron V.

description:
might be great if you are in the fold of the desired customer - ie hip, not over about 40 old and in a group.  I cannot remember being made to feel so  out of place, so admonished (re asking for white bread toast) and so insignificant (I don't tell guests what the sides are. I can show you where to read them().  Food is OK (BLT with julienned lettuce..how precious) to sub mediocre (fading fruit salad..how hard is that to make?Bacon overcooked)  Straws positioned in root beer float positioned so that pushing down ice cream causes root beer to shoot out in a high arc. 
Snarky hipsters I can do without.Wannabe lumber jack manager (Really you can sit at the bar... (only to me, nobody else there) oddly disturbing., though probably the nicest of the oh so cool bunch. Somebody give those puppies a copy of Danny Meyers' book.
author: Otto S.

description: A good place to stop while in San Francisco. Food is great and inexpensive and the Mexican bakery next door is a great place to go while waiting for your food.
author: Evan S.

description:
After dining here for the first time today, I was DYING to go to Yelp and do a Search for how many times the word "hipster" appears in the reviews. Out of 635 reviews, "hipster" pops up exactly 175 times.

Yup, that's about right. If you have full sleeve tats, an asymmetric shaggy 'do, horn-rimmed glasses with mutton chops, low-rider skinny jeans (if you're a guy) or ironic 1950's circle skirt with hot pink hair (if you're a girl), you have found your dining Mecca. I mean seriously, what could BE more ironic than an old-school Americana diner in an intensely ethnic neighborhood?! 

The food is solid but nothing special. There are a TON of vegetarian and vegan options (of course). The hipster waitstaff was very friendly and responsive - except for the sullen-looking blonde girl who actually looked ANGRY when we asked politely for the check. All in all, not sure I'd consider this a place worth waiting 20 minutes for on a weekend morning, unless you're hoping some of the crowd's effortless cool will maybe rub off on you....?
author: SfMom O.

description:
Solid 3.5 out of 5 stars.

Waited about 45mins to an hour to be seated. 

Had the nebulous potato thing with a side of bacon and flour tortillas. 
It was delish, however not worth the wait OR the drive from Daly City. 

Immediately after devouring all my food I felt the worst case of food coma and even had a slight stomach ache which lasted all day (probably my own fault from eating so damn much).

I can understand why people love this place so much. The food is great...but personally i prefer breakfast food in the comfort of my own home.
author: Desiree B.

description:
My favorite place for a vegan breakfast.
