I consistently order their Tofu Scramble with Ranchero sauce....comes with amazing skillet fried potatoes and choice of toast, english muffin, etc... I've never been disappointed..always hits the spot.  Great taste, huge plate of food, what more could you ask for...

Definitely a hipster joint and I couldnt love it more. Service is great - food is always rockin.

I'll be back over and over and over.
author: Vanessa B.

description:
I understand the allure of old-timeyness; really, I do.  I'm a ridiculous sucker for old things.  Even if they're not particularly authentic, I'm usually a big believer in them.  Especially if they're kind of gross and musty and dusty and moldy.  OK, maybe not the moldy part, but really, there's not much an old place has to do to win my heart.

Sadly, St. Francis Fountain has failed to win my heart.

Yes, the neon sign is authentic, and yes, they serve breakfast, and yes, the crampedness--new word!--of the booths is both familiarly uncomfortable and an excellent reminder that Americans are fatter than they used to be, and this is remarkable considering the people who used to frequent greasy diners like this probably didn't have very much money and didn't see a doctor regularly and probably died at ridiculously young ages, but they were still thinner than us!

Anyway, the first thing that annoys me is the name of the place.  It's not really called St. Francis Fountain.  It's called just St. Francis.  Maybe it was St. Francis Diner or St. Francis Restaurant or St. Francis Coffee Shop, but it's definitely not St. Francis Fountain.  Why do people call it that?  Well, it's because the largest other word on said old neon sign is "Fountain," but so what?  "Fountain" just means they serve soda and shakes and malts.  OK, here comes one of my famous analogies.  It's like referring to regular old Safeway as Safeway Pharmacy.  Now why would someone call Safeway Safeway Pharmacy?  Well, some Safeways happen to have the word "Pharmacy" on their signs.  Do you call them Safeway Pharmacy?  No, so don't call St. Francis St. Francis Fountain.

Now that that's all cleared up, I'm pretty underwhelmed by their breakfasts.  I either want to be wowed by a coffee-shop breakfast, or I want to be in too much of a food coma to have heard you ask me how my breakfast was.  Sadly, I was right in the middle.

The main redeeming quality of this place is that they sell ridiculous candy.  It's not old-timey candy from the era during which said problematic neon sign was made, but it's pretty old and unique.  They have some cool stuff that I haven't seen sold in stores since at least the late '80s.  So they have that going for them.

I'm pretty sure the bathrooms are wheelchair inaccessible as well, so I'm dinging them a star.
author: John S.

description: I've been coming regularly to this place fo over two years now and love it. The service is good and food delicious. Its the best place in the neighborhood for burgers. I also love the chef's mess, omelettes and weekend specials.
author: Yara K.

description: The easy things they do well, like Mac and cheese and vegan chilly. My Modesto pesto tasted liked frozen chicken. I like the space, the staff and the hood. Food is not Much to talk about
author: Sean H.

description:
I keep going to St. Francis because there aren't any similar options in the hood for breakfast and sandwiches, especially not open late. But I gotta say, service is consistently really awful there. 

Tonight I called at 9:30 to make a to-go order, and they hung up on me three times in a row - like picked up the phone and hung it up - and on the fourth call (I kept calling back, thinking it was some technical difficulty) the woman who answered angrily informed me they weren't doing any more to go orders. Okay, that's fine*, but if why hang up on me repeatedly and then act like I'm the problem when I call back? Just tell me the first time? 

* it's not actually fine, since they don't close until 10:00. But I've come to expect St. Francis to randomly close early.
author: elly j.

description:
So the boyfriend and I just moved to the hood, and I'm pretty stoked that St. Francis Fountain is two blocks from our new place. This last week has been full of moving and unpacking madness, and I'm not ashamed to say that we've eaten here no less than three times. They have loads of veggie and vegan options, their milkshakes make me weak in the knees, and there's enough variety on the menu to keep trying new things and not get bored. All good things in my book. 

The service has been good, though I wouldn't recommend popping in anywhere near closing time. Expect some grumbling is all I'm sayin. I also am totally pissed about the straws. Paper straws aren't cool in that once they've been in your drink for more than two or three minutes they basically stop functioning as a straw. So while I appreciate the old-timiness of the paper straw, sometimes progress is good, folks. Give in to the lure of the plastic straw.
author: heather c.

description:
Okay. Okay, okay. I acknowledge that:

1. Not only are most patrons at this fine establishment "effortlessly" hip (at least that's the crowd for weekend brunch, with a few old couples sprinkled in for good measure)... but my date and I simultaneously cringed and laughed last Sunday when we realized that we looked MIGHTY identical to the surrounding hipster couples. Damn.

2. I've only ever chosen to sit outside, actually (which is lovely, and the tables are far enough away from pedestrians that they still feel somehow private) so I can't speak to the indoor seating/service/ambiance...

3. And, yes, it's true that the prices can be a little steep for - let's face it - a greasy neighborhood diner. But since I have yet to be disappointed by the food here (honest!), I'm willing to make some sacrifices.

It's true, dear Yelpers: I have been pleasantly surprised by (enamored of!) many a St. Francis Fountain dish, especially when it comes to breakfast. As a veg, I really appreciate the surprising amount of vegetarian/vegan-friendly options on the menu... and ones that aren't relegated to a fruit cup or a bland veggie plate, either! Several dishes are great (Toasted Vegan sandwich, Chorizo & Eggs, the oh-my-god French Toast Delight), BUT my absolutely favorite is still the "My Chef Jess:" 2 eggs scrambled with homefries, vegan chorizo and mushrooms, topped with melted cheese, tomato, sour cream & green onions. WITH A BAKED GOOD OF YOUR CHOICE! COME ON now, does it get any better than that?! Sure, the servers don't sprinkle goodwill and sunshine everywhere they go, but they are generally attentive enough to consistently refill water/coffee and provide some amusement (intentional or not).

If I could write a love letter to St. Francis Fountain, I surely would. "Dear St. Francis: You are dreamy and a half. Yours, Sam" (Okay, it could use a little work...)
author: Sam S.

description:
I must have walked by this place a hundred times without having any idea what it was. From the street it looks like a doodad shop, and they do have a doodad counter by the door but this place is really a great little old school lunch counter.

I can't remember why I was in the area but I wanted food but not Mexican or Chinese so I dialed up the old yelp app and this place popped up.

The staff is a little hipsterish but very friendly and they served me the best Reuben sandwich I've ever had.
author: Manny F.

description: This place is fine, for the most part. I don't get what the fuss is about? The food is average, decently priced, but I would never wait in a long line to eat here. The service, on a mostly slow Thursday morning, was seriously lacking. The let people stand outside even though there were counter seats and tables available. There were only two people working the front and they had a hard time managing the place. I won't go out of my way to come back here, but I would eat there again if I was in a group.
author: Brian J.

description: St. Francis is confusing. I am not sure if it's a vegan place, an ice cream place, or a diner. They could have dinner, I'm not sure. It's just weird and I've never had anything with ice cream there, or seen anyone indulging with even a float. The food is average for a diner and I guess vegans will be over the moon about it considering the thoughtful menu items for them. There is a fair amount of hype about this place but to me it seems uninspired and needs a makeover.
author: Jessica f.

description: I can't say enough good things about this place. I'm always telling people that San Francisco is a city of hidden diners, that there are fantastic gems of old-fashioned food places if you know where to look, and St. Francis Fountain has just topped them all. Great and friendly service, excellent food at reasonable portions, and frozen treats to beat the band. Go. Trust me. They even have vegetarian options displayed on the menu as if they're just as classic as chili cheese fries.
author: Joshua P.

description:
A nice alternative to the sometimes mob scene at Boogaloos, St. Francis Fountain offers similar items on its menu with quite a bit more.

They have a nice selection of vegan/vegetarian options, such as vegan sausage, vegan chorizo and tofu scrambles.

There's outdoor seating with umbrellas. The staff is fast and courteous. The interior is fun and the selection of candy is like walking down memory lane (Trading cards from the TV show Dallas, anyone?).
author: Sean G.

description: Two stars for the poor customer service. The waiters asked us to wait because it was crowded, but it really wasn't crowded. Then they told us to stand outside (while it pours!) because they did not want the group I was in to block the entrance. Instead of asking us to sit while we wait, we are told to go outside.   :(  Of course the ice cream is good. Mitchell's has something to do with that.
author: Ashley B.

description: Poor service and whiny waiters. Major slackers. Never eat here. The owner should fire those waiters because he/she is loosing money because of really bad waiters. Keep the cooks, they were trying to work.
author: Mark S.

description:
I love the food at St. Francis...I've been going there for years.  The diner food and dessert is amazing.  I especially love their grilled sandwiches and garden burger...oh and their veggie chili is delicious!  

Aside from the food, the waiters and waitresses are pretty damn racist.  They're all pretty much hipsters and I definitely notice the favoritism towards other hipster (Caucasian) customers.  I usually come here with another friend, and aside from taking our order and bringing us our food, they pretty much ignore us the whole time we're there.  And they usually bring us the check before even asking us if we want dessert.  One of the owners, I think his name is Levon, he's a sweetheart.  He's the only one I like there really.  And there's another waiter with long hair, who has kind of a surfer dude personality that's really friendly.
author: Cin W.

description:
Great food (savory pancakes!), cozy seating arrangement (expanded to include outdoor seating on weekends), attentive service by adorable, hip people, and prime location in the Mission (near Philz for a post-brunch pick-me-up). Possibly my favorite diner/cafe in the city, for the reason of food but also because it's a great example of a San Francisco eatery. Unpretentiously delicious. 

I cannot recommend the hog cakes enough (my table of five ordered four hog cakes). The fried egg sandwich with seitan is also fabulous. They need to get fresh fruit juices! A glass of refreshing grapefruit juice would be perfect with a syrup-doused savory pancake.
author: Jake m.

description:
I used to love her..

..when I would go there with my godfather as a boy and stuff myself and he would tell me of how he used to go with his godfather..

but i had to go outside and vomit..

...when I saw that it had turned into this stupid hipster brunch haven.  echeh..as hipsters do tend claim cool things as their own, way after their cool.  I still like TRex though, they can't take that away from me.

2 stars for the memories of yesteryear
author: Jack M.

description:
St. Francis has updated their menu since the last time I was there and the vegan stuff is clearly labeled. Also, they now have Follow Your Heart vegan cheese on the menu and I love that stuff all over some potatoes. I got something to that effect (potatoes + vegan cheese + guacamole + salsa) when I was here recently and it hit the spot. Plus I was experiencing the worst hangover I've had in years and after eating the pile of vegan potato goodness I no longer felt like I might die. So essentially St. Francis saved my life. My non-vegan friend got an omelet and she said it was good. Plus the two of us spied on our neighbor-table's fruit bowl and it was actually fresh'ish fruit, not just the sad, pale melon-grape-melon combo that comes in a 2 gallon bucket.

It's too crowded hereon the weekends for me to venture over regularly but it's nice to have a good omni+vegan brunch place to go to with friends.
author: M M.

description:
5 stars because it is soooooooo Mission Hipster.

One of our favorite brunch spots in the neighborhood and we love to take friends / out-of-towners here.  We'd go more often, but the wait is generally pretty bad and a bit of a walk for us.

Extensive brunch menu, good prices, good food, great vintage diner atmosphere.
author: marcie v.

description: I live a block from here and we eat here 3-4 times a month.  The food is consistently good and affordable and normally I love everything about the experience but lately the service seems like it's going downhill.  We had lunch here last weekend and had the worst server ever.  It took at least 10 minutes for him to even acknowledge we were even there, took our orders and then never returned to our table again.  Not once.  The busboy(?) delivered our food and filled our water once but otherwise we sat there the whole time without water or soda refills.  In the meantime, he was chatting with his friends at the table next to ours.  We then sat there for another 10 minutes after we were done eating before I flagged down the busboy to get our bill.  5 minutes later I had to ask the busboy again for our bill before we finally got it.  With a long background in the service industry, I never, ever tip less than 15% but the dude got a whopping $0.80 tip and that's only because I didn't have exact change.  Get it together St. Francis Fountain!!!!!
author: Double D.

description: This place is just the best. Great food, inexpensive, sexy waiter boys, chill environment sans snobbery. Try the Chicken Cilantro Soup and the French Toast
author: Johnny E.

description: Really good homemade American food. If you want the best greasy spoon in town, this is the place to go.
author: Michael S.

description: Just flew into California this morning and my friend picked me up from the airport and said we're getting breakfast at this place. It was so good! Coffee was sting and fresh just what I needed after a 5 hour flight from D.C. This is my first time on the West Coast and my first dinning experience. I am very pleased and want to go back before I leave. The menu is very veg friendly. I got the Potato Thing and it was mmmmmgood. I want to try the ice cream!
author: Chelsea W.

description:
It all depends on the waiters that serve you that make your experience more better~ The food is perfect almost every time I go there with a group of friends, I always love to have some dessert from here because their ice cream (Mitchell's-brand of ice cream) is always great to choose from. 
If you like coffee flavors... I recommend the "Dusty Road"
My personal Favorite is the "Buster Brown"!
author: Liz T.

description: Took my Dad and sister here for brunch on Saturday, and thought I should update my review!   Everything I wrote before is still true, but now that they've expanded into the space next door, it's helped a lot with the long waits for weekend brunch.
author: Jane A.

description:
Chef's Mess. The only thing that i could possibly find to complain about was that i didn't eat fast enough and the potato, bacon, cheddar, mushroom, biscuit mess of decadence filled me up and I willingly crammed the last bits of the savory breakfast concoction into my stomach. Topped it off with some solid diner (read: not the best, but expected. it's a diner.) coffee. Great service from a beautiful tattooed waitress. 

0 complaints.
author: Spencer T.

description:
A friend of mine insisted that the best mac 'n cheese was at St. Francis Fountain.  What I did find was a busy boy that was a dead ringer for Russell Brand.  Awesome.  

I ordered the irresistibly named "nebulous potato thing" and enjoyed the homey feel of the dish.  The mac n cheese was okay - it didn't have a sauce to it that I find crucial.
author: Monica L.

description: We were told this is a SFO institution that we absolutely should visit, and my family agrees! Two thumbs up. My daughter really enjoyed the vegan pancakes, and my son had the French toast.  I really enjoyed my Devil burger, and the three bean chili soup.  We topped it off with gelato for the kids. If you are a vegetarian or looking for vegan options, this place is heaven sent.
author: Ani M.

description:
Wow, what a great little old place! Potentially the oldest diner in San Francisco.

The St. Francis really feels like stepping out of a time machine set even before the 50s, there's not too much chrome à la Mel, Lori & Co. Instead, the place is welcoming you with wooden wall and booth panel. Oh, and there really is powdered soap in the bathroom - hadn't felt that one in what must be decades.

The staff is super friendly, the patrons' age stretched from four to forty, but it wasn't loud at all - a rare thing in the city.

Oh, food? At Mel's Diner, it's hit and miss whether they have to add more malt powder to my shakes - St. Francis has never forsaken me so far. Now I'm much looking forward to trying the burgers, too. They looked delicious. Actually, now I'm hungry. If only I didn't live on the other side of town.
author: Roland A.

description: Great hearty food. SHARE. The breakfast plate I tried was way too big for just myself. Great service!
author: Courtney H.

description:
I was so upset that I got off my butt and went out of my way to write this review!   By the way this order was to go!
Well let's start with the very very small $4.50 milk shake, that's half the size of every other place I've ever ordered a milk shake! Their straws don't work, the cup was about as big as my balled up fist, I have pics.  I've also tasted better! Now on to the burger, well I ordered a bacon cheese burger that came out to about $12 which is a little high for a burger that has old reddish lettuce ends. Now on to my GF order she had the side platter, the salad was fine on the top but on the bottom the lettuce was not fresh and they forgot our dressing, the mac n cheese had onions in it(?) She's allergic to onions. She orders mac n cheese at alot of places and we've never seen it w/onions. The chili beans could have been better. Bottom line if your going to charge outrageous prices (which I don't mind paying) at least have good food and generous portions!
author: chris c.

description: Nice vegetarian/vegan selection and great service.  Portion sizes are great.
author: Daisy A.

description:
I liked it better in the old days.  Where's the homemade chocolates?

Progress sometimes blows.
author: .Hon H.

description:
Food was OK, Service could of been better. 

I visited St. Francis Fountain because every time I go to the panaderia across the street it looks busy so for me is a sign that it might be good. I went there on Monday May 3rd around noon and it was slow. 

1. We got sited by who I believe is the hostess. She took our drink order and came back with 1 coffee and 1 orange juice and no soda for my friend we thought she was going to bring it but never did. 

2. Our waiter took our order and we told him we were missing 1 soda and said he will bring it over and Guess what???? He never did 

3. A different waiter brought us or food which was fast (I like this) but still no soda, so I asked him for one. 

4. Our original waiter brings the soda but not for the coke we asked for but a sprite I corrected him and he took the soda. 

5. the second waiter comes gives us our coke and our bill since we were done eating and never got the soda on time which we were being charged 3 times because they thought we order 3 sodas 1 coffee and 1 orange juice. After explaining the situation to the hostess who is also the cashier she took it off 2 sodas off the bill but still charged us for the one soda that we got at the end of the meal. 

I only have one suggestion. Have one waiter attend to your table this way there is no confusion on what you have order and might get your drink order on time before you finish your meal.
author: Vanessa L.

description: Amazing biscuits and gravy and french toast!  The "mess" had too many potatoes for me, but my friend loved it!  Everything was delicious! A go-to place!
author: Abbie F.

description:
St. Francis Fountain is a fun throwback diner, except with hipsters. Nothing on the menu is going to blow your mind, but it's darn tasty food in a fun atmosphere. The shakes are delicious, and the prices aren't bad.

The menu is especially vegan friendly, for those who dig their side of sausage without meat.

A word of warning on the shakes though - the mild paper straws they use will absolutely disintegrate before you finish. Ask for backups!
author: Nick S.

description:
WOW!...Hmmm, what can I say. Alot!, but I'll keep it short.

I've lived here, ( the Mission District ), all my life and would come here as a child to enjoy the ice cream, burger ,atmosphere and great service. I don't know if ownership changed, but now the food here is Blah , Frigid atmosphere and Sorry service.

If you didn't have much of a choice and could't find a good breakfast place on the spot.....you're better off going to IHOP.

*BOO! for this place.*
author: Ritz R.

description:
This place as simply incredible decor and feel - like stepping into another era - except your waiter is a hipster instead of a neatly trimmed good 'ol boy from the '50s. Service was solid btw. Only two people for the whole place but they kept it together. 

Overall this place rocks - great vibe, super authentic, not trying too hard epic milkshakes and a killer mushroom swiss burger...came here for the first time last night and realy liked it. Tried the reuben and the vegge scram, both of which were very good as well. Oh, and the spinach salad with homemade dressing was tasty too. 

4 stars, i'll be back for sure!
author: Ben B.

description: Few places have better milkshakes. That's reason enough to come here. Their food is good too. Really enjoyed the Country breakfast, especially the biscuits, most places don't seem to know how to make good biscuits. People here are friendly and quick to serve. Reasonable prices, you could easily spend the same amount at a fast food restaurant but you wouldn't be getting the same quality of food nor enjoy your meal as much. Casual dining. Parking is fairly easy to come by.
author: Ron W.

description:
I'm sorry, but let me first start off by saying yes - this IS a hipster hide out.
but who the hell cares?
hipsters are young, attractive and dress well.
sorry if you aren't and sorry if you don't.

also, i would like to say this place is not JUST aesthetically pleasing but the food is delicious. small portions? i mean maybe, if you eat way more than the normal portion for a human being.

all i know is that every time i hit up this spot the My Chef Jess fills me up for $9 and is more than enough to save half for another meal.

they have wonderful vegetarian/vegan options as well as the gold ol' fashioned hamburger.

sure, some of their servers are brainless narcissistic retards, but if you're assertive yet friendly you'll get what you want.

for the most part my service there has been great, and i have no complaints. oh - and before i forget, THE MILKSHAKES.

people, the milkshakes are fab. get a large and split it. trust me, you'll be more than satisfied.
author: Jena R.

description:
This place is officially (to us) called Hector's. Due to the irresistible Hector's Waffles. We were in SF for 4 days and we ate here every morning. The vegetarian/vegan options are out of this world... especially for breakfast. The service was amazing, the music was super chill, and everything we ordered was incredible. The Vegan Blueberry Pancakes, the Vegan Breakfast Burrito, and the Vegan Chorizo Scramble with Tofu was our favorite, (after Hector's). 

Support your local businesses people. Even if your an out of towner. The experience is well worth it.
author: Kai S.

description:
This joint is simply bitchin'. Should you happen to wake up in its vicinity, don't fight the gravitational pull. Consider yourself lucky.

Sure, it's unbashedly hipster but executed in the most awesome of ways, outfitted with 80s trading cards like Cyndi Lauper, Tron and Garbage Pail Kids. Throwbacks! And remember Chick-o-Stix and Big League Chew? They got em! 

Extra points for borax in the bathroom. Also remarkable is the variety of vegan and veg options: soyrizo, TVP and tofu are fixtures on the menu, dished out by the sassy staff. Make it happen.
author: Ligaya T.

description: My review is for my only experience of getting a chocolate malted to go.  It was superb!  A real old fashioned thick-shake malt with good chocolate flavor.  The young ladies working there were nice too.  I was there late and the place was dead.  I'll be back and then will give the full experience a review.
author: Judy E.

description:
I love using analogies when explaining how completely awesome something is:

You take the same way to work every morning, past the same buildings, through the same concrete maze - faces that were once strange, quickly become familiar. In a sea of beautiful and striking women, there are the ones who, at first glance,  appear to be simply ordinary. Your gaze remains concentrated on the superficial beauty that calls from miles away, the kind that draws attention from every man within close proximity.

One day, a young woman holds the door open for you an you enter your local cafe - you thank her her and smile, she smiles back. You engage her in small talk solely for the sake of politeness, but are suddenly mesmerized by the content of her dialogue and the kindness in her eyes.
This woman will end up becoming one of the best things to ever happen to you; she will teach you to appreciate humility, and how to embrace what is simple in nature.

Little did you know that she was there all along, muted by those whose visages screamed louder - she was the quiet thunder that would shake your inner being, awaken our senses and redefine "beauty". 

This is St Francis Fountain, a quaint, unassuming diner nested in the outer Mission. Don't pass it by without paying respect to its charm, great service and excellent food.
author: Dennis A.

description:
After a long night of ringing in another year of Amy goodness. Kristina, Adam, Christopher, Nanako, and I head off to brunch. I had just eaten 4 hours ago so I intended to have some OJ. 

The place is a total throw back to a 1980's burger/malt diner, complete w/ classics like Tron and Garbage Pail Kids trading cards (originals, not reprints!!!). There is a line outside and everyone in the party must be present to be seated, luckily it isn't raining yet. 

We are seated in a comfy booth and are drink orders are taken immediately. Just water for me. 

Perusing the menu, I give in and order the "Nebulous Potato Thing" ($6.75) which is basically home fries w/ sour cream, salsa, green onions, melted cheese. It takes about 15-20 mins for the food to come out. It looks smaller than it is because the plate it comes on is actually a wide bowl. There is plenty of food there. I slather on the ketchup, hot sauce and pepper until I have red hott mess in front of me. 

It was so good and filling, I didn't eat till 10:00 that night, and that is after a hike in Marin. I will definitely come back for the Guinness float or some of the other breakfast dish. Also it's time to start up the Garbage Pail Kids card collection again.
author: Angelo F.

description:
Which is a true statement about St. Francis Fountain?

a.) The food is terrible - yet the bill is a lot of money.

b.) The staff are nice when you're wearing your skinny jeans, but don't go in there in your pajama pants. Hipsters pack this place like breeding cockroaches.

c.) There are way tastier, less pretentious, better priced places to eat breakfast, brunch, lunch, dinner, a snack and/or dessert less than a block away.

d.) As another low-quality, overpriced 50's diner replica in the city, it's right on par with Sparky's.

e.) All of the above.


[The answer is: e.) All of the above.]
author: Josephine L.

description:
There are several things I love about the St. Francis.

First, they have the perfect balance of authentic and modern - you can get a real chocolate malt the way they would have served it 50 years ago, but they also use very fresh vegetables and a minimum of grease (which I'm sure is not authentic for diner food).

Second, they have the candy counter.  Where else can you get New Kids on the Block trading cards in mint condition?  Maybe your mom's attic, but they would be dusty.

Finally, it just had a great feeling inside - it's welcoming and unpretentious, despite the crowd of hipsters waiting for brunch, and you just feel like you can relax there.

In fact, they were very kind and accommodating when I took some photos there the other day for a contest I'm in - I needed an authentic background for my Mad Men era photo.

http://madmencastingcall.amctv.com/browse/detail/N1LTJV

Thanks to the St. Francis, I might have a chance of winning.
author: Leslie B.

description:
I usually don't have an appetite for breakfast/brunch, but since I was visiting SF my friend took me to this diner that's located around the corner from where she lives.

OMG! They're food is sooo good! I never thought breakfast/brunch could taste sooo good! I always thought: eggs are eggs and pancakes are pancakes. Nothing special. But I was wrong! If I lived in SF I would eat breakfast/brunch all the time!

Must try:
- Chef's Mess
- Corned Beef Hash
- Hot Cakes (chocolate chip & blueberry)

Pros:
- Good food!
- Good service
- Clean

Cons:
- Wait is usually long
- Tables are small
author: Lisa S.

description:
Do you like waffles with pieces of orange and crushed walnuts?
You probably did not realize you did because you have not ordered Hector's Waffles at St. Francis Soda Fountain.
You should go do that the minute you wake up tomorrow.
Get some bacon, too. And fresh squeezed OJ.
Oh, and bring your Ernest Hemingway Short Stories because you will wait for a while. (15-20 even when no one is there..)
author: Addyline L.

description:
"Sweet"

I haven't tried any of their food...But this review is dedicated for their old fashioned milkshake!
I found milkshakes are sometimes too sweet or too thick, but this one is just perfect :)
Lastly, love love love the paper straw for several reasons...
author: Verena S.

description:
Came here twice. 

First time, months ago on a warm sunny Sunday with my friend. We sat outside, and after ordering - and lovin' - the banana pancakes, we ordered a feast: B&G, black beans, breakfast burritos! It was amazing and I registered in my brain that was a fair priced, full of flavor, casual brunch spot in the middle of hipster land.

Second time, rainy Sunday post loooooong wine tasting the night before. In serious need of good confort food + coffee to balance out the headache. After trying different places with long lines, St Francis' 15 minute wait didn't seem so bad. 

We were sat at the counter and I was enchanted by the old diner vibe, the 80's candy bar and the 60's music they were playing. The menu, again, made me dizzy with so many options, and we both went for the vegan chorizo - I got the chorizo and eggs, he got the chorizo hash. And, of course, the fabulous B&G!

The food took a while, but when it came it was a fabulous experience! The service was friendly and they refilled our coffee and water promptly. I saw lots of dishes that looked delicious passing by me, and thought I need to come back many times to try them all. By the end of two hours, I was happy and even my headache was gone.

St Francis is the case of appreciating something for what it is - hipster crowd, good food, casual fun vibe, and yes:  usual lines + pricey.....like EVERY good brunch place in SF. I will keep coming back!
author: Simone W.

description:
I went here on a Friday night and it was empty! I was expecting a greasy dive, but it's really more of a retro throwback with a slightly healthier menu and this month in Pitchfork radio.

They make their own corned beef hash and it's pretty good. The people who work here were really nice and attentive. Paper straws are perhaps not the best choice for a milkshake though. My friend got mac and cheese which we both thought was pretty good for diner mac. They have a lot of great vegetarian options also, so I'll definitely come back with my veg friends.
author: Beth D.

description: Milkshakes rock. I had a mixed plate thing of mac and cheese, salad and some chilli. All was good!
author: Russell S.

description:
Just called them, Was put on hold for 10 min, They than hung up on me and when i called back the phone was off the hook : (

kept trying, i guess Im not going to spend 13 dollars on breakfast today : (


Call time 1pm
author: kenneth f.

description:
St Francis Fountain makes me so happy. it's fun to take a surreal trip back in time to a soda fountain where they are playing indie music and order a fantastic burger and fries or the super yummy baltimore. the shakes are exquisite, and ohhhhh my lucky stars when they've got pumpkin shakes, i'm so happy.
Update: 4/2/06 
Oh my god it still rocks.   i always yearn to go back here.   and there is nothing like trying to slurp a rocky road shake thru a straw. rad. the reuben is super super duper tasty.  yum.
author: sarah C.

description:
The short:
-Great food and atmosphere
-Shakes are made with Mitchell's
-Fairly cheap and breakfast all day!

The long:
Got here on a Saturday afternoon around 1pm and got sat immediately at the counter.  I ordered the fried egg sandwhich with no cheese and a side of home-fries (or "spuds") which were both awesome.  My S.O. had the Chef's Mess, which I gladly helped him finish!  Glass of O.J. was fresh-queezed but on the tiny side.  Shakes looked good (I was too full to have one), but will definitely be back to have one!  Bill came to $28 for two with tax and tip.
author: Stacey H.

description:
Its ok ... cool little hipster/retro kinda place to go. They do serve egg cream sodas which is great, they also have cool milkshakes ... espresso shake, guinniess float and things of that nature ... I been here for nothing but breakfast or brunch .. I never arrived later then 10am and I have never had trouble getting a table or even waiting for that matter .. 
Food wise pancakes are good (blueberry) omelettes are decent fried egg sandwich was ok ...  all in all its a decent little breakfast spot for me and for something sweet there are plenty of great places right at walking distance if your not in a mood for a shake or ice cream. :)
author: Anthony S.

description:
This has become my default breakfast spot for the past several weekends.  The wait isn't ridiculously long, there's a nice covered, outdoor seating area for when the sun is shining, and the tofu scrambles are to die for.  Not to mention, I just discovered that I can sub my "thing my spuds" for some vegetarian chili cheese fries, and this makes me happy.

If that's not enough to keep me coming back, then the Three's Company and Alf collectors cards will!!
author: Melissa M.

description:
St Francis offers a varied menu full of vegetarian, vegan, and carnivorous options - it's a great place to take out-of-town guests, particularly Midwesterners who are accustomed the diner atmosphere, but can't understand why you don't eat meat. 

It's good for older kids.  It's okay for babies, but it's better to go when it isn't busy because the interior is crowded and staff become snarky.

The place becomes overrun with hipsters. It's quite laughable, but it is what it is. The best time to go for breakfast is pre-10:30ish AM before they all wake up.  Thereafter, expect a wait, especially on weekends.
author: Who Knows N.

description:
So many options!! Not to mention the cute wait staff ;)

I loved the fried egg sandwich with vegan sausage and the dreamsicle orange sherbet float that I got. Did I mention the menu is very Vegan and Vegetarian friendly?! I'll have to go back several times to try all the other things they have.
author: Kaushal P.

description:
I've been here a few times. It seems to be a pretty popular breakfast joint, with all the cool kids going there. 
I'm down with any place that has vanilla coke, really. That's what gets me here. 
The food is decent enough, Though nothing really sticks out in my head. Typically messy breakfast stuff for me, they do serve sandwiches and the likes but I'd rather have breakfast over anything else, anytime! I'll tell ya, I'm not really wow'd by the food. but it's decent and service is friendly.
I will one day try a shake from here though :]
author: Lexie L.

description:
A for eating in an old school diner.
A for fresh squeezed oj.
C for playing old school Happy Days music. Too cheesy.
C for chorizo hash and corned beef hash. All potatoes. Where's the meat?
C for Nebulous Potato Thing. Mound of starch with little taste.

Would've been upset if I had to wait for this, but I slid right in, so it was just an okay breakfast.
author: Ezduzit S.

description: I seriously love this place. Yeah, have they gotten a little too big for their britches, probably. But still 100 % solid. I love the cheesy browns, crazy bacon pancake, the egg sandwich. It's all good.
author: Meghan S.

description:
I was not surprised to see the other negative stars on here. I used to come to St. Francis all the time, way back before it turned into hipster hell. It used to welcome people from all walks of life, but apparently now it is REALLY like a diner in the 1950s - except maybe in Alabama.  I always wondered why I almost NEVER see a brown face eating here. Now I may understand why. 

I walked in to eat.  A customer at the counter was asking the girl to microwave the to go coffee she'd just been served because it was too cold. The girl actually said okay and microwaved it instead of making her  a new one. 

I stood by the door and waited. The hipster girl with the ironic mullet and mustard sweater saw me, gave me a blank stare and kept walking. She started putting away cups. She walked past me. She walked past again. She cleaned. She saw me again. She went in the back. I stood there and looked around for the "please seat yourself" sign. Didn't see one. I finally said, "Excuse me - but do you see me?" or something to that effect. She looked at me and said "I'm sorry, I thought you were all together" and pointed to the latino family at the counter with two kids that was leaving with their cold coffee.  I am half Mexican, so I guess she thought we always roll in packs and never solo. They'd obviously been there for some time judging by the dirty dishes in front of them. I know she saw me walk in. I know she saw me looking at her expectantly. 

I walked out. 

From reading the reviews here, it looks like they don't discriminate in terms of bad service. You can be white and still get treated like dirt, according to what others have said here. However, there is something especially hurtful about the way this whole thing played out. 

I'll continue to drive by and be disgusted by the hipster spectacle like many I know are. But now, I'll do so with feeling.
author: Carla G.

description: My boyfriend wanted to come here back in the day when we were tourists, and I'm so glad we went for it. This place has the old-fashioned soda-jerk type feel, but with vegan options! Their vegan chili is super tasty and their milkshakes are always the perfect consistency. Love the atmosphere, love the food.
author: Amy S.

description:
Yes - I went there - 5 stars. It had everything a good Sunday morning breakfast should have.  Scrumptious food, nice laid back servers, The Cure in the background and striped paper straws to drink my diet coke.

Best trek off the beaten path in SF yet. Went for breakfast and wanted to stay seated for the next 2 meals of the day...

Had an omlette - delicious! Potatoes were great.  I just had the plain version, but I can only imagine the decked out version.

The strawberry preserves on my sourdough bread - delicioius.

Had a bite of Steve's pancakes and wished I had room for more.

Loved the retro honesty of the place.  It is now a mainstay of our San Francisco trips.
author: Heidi M.

description:
"Breakfast is the most important meal of the day"..Don't know exactly what nutritional authority came up with that notion...but since that gives me an excuse to start the day by chowin' down like a madman, no debate over here.

To help fulfill my absolute need for scrambles, omelettes and hash...St. Francis Fountain is high on the list.  The surroundings may make you feel like you've entered the Twilight Zone and  time-traveled into another era...but the food is what really knocks you out-of-the-park!  The tofu scrambles are absolutely perfect.  The banana or corn bread that you can choose to accompany your dish is heavenly as well.

Since this is a fountain, you're obligated to get some sort of ice creamery goodness.  My poison is the malted shake made with Mitchell's ice cream...elixir of the food gods.

St. Francis Fountain...does a body good!
author: Justin L.

description:
Shrug. 

Yeah people, it's good and they veggie it up, but there's not much to set it apart from plenty of other mission brunch spots.  Our brunch was good, but not so good I need to wait on the sidewalk for half an hour.  

It's a good excuse to wander down 24th, but nothing I need to go out of my way for.
author: Dana S.

description:
Huge portions, homemade milkshakes and more hipster servers than you can shake a stick at. 

After I recovered from how absolutely cool the whole staff looked (and admired all of their tattoos) we managed to take in the setting. 1950s diner scene, those little candy buttons on paper and garbage pail kids trading cards, great swivel stools and amazing set up for fountain shakes. 

We enjoyed a late afternoon breakfast- I an amazing avo/jack/salsa omlette with "thinged" potatoes (add cheese, salsa, and some other amazing items) and a cup o'joe. My compadre a chicken and peacan salad sandwich and an orange dream (cream, orange sherbet, sprite, other yumminess). 

Amazing grub, huge portions, excellent quality and a great ambaince, all for under $25 for the two of us. It's a winner!
author: Vee B.

description:
Could you like a place just because of the way it feels.. some random particular times? 

for instance,
during late summer nights' eves 
when the inky blue sky seems to blanket closer to the streets at this section
and the air's warm with grassy musk, street lights glowing
the city closing you in by the black vast girth of Portrero
a breeze out of nowhere brings in the cool fog..
Im walking somewhere to meet my best friend 
and whilst 
a peek by this place, some cute waiter cleaning up talking to someone
a transitive nostalgia
a modern ancient feeling the like of Manet's girl at the counter 
with slight melancholic Hopper's Nighthawks ghastly shadings
24th becomes suddenly otherworldly 

And then I had the food here during daytime 
and the spell broke.. it was a pastel colored sunny day,
I was happy sipping my mediocre athe counter- wagging my feet like a kid (I also did look a bit kid like back then.. a year ago).. but meh- 
it looks like some diner people are nostalgic for but really
has inklings
when they sit there- somethings (like diner kitsch for instance) cant last forever.. at least in real life

I wouldnt go here for the food- but the fact that it's here-even if infested by hipsters on brunch days- or that during full light it's a bit too cardboard kitsch.. 
but as well, come here when you like, life is full of surprises
author: Jonas D.

description: Another friend has reviewed this place and for me, I'd give it the 4 stars as well. Very hip place and I like the retro feel of the diner. As for the food, I wasn't very hungry that morning so I ordered a chicken cilantro soup over a biscuit which was savory and pleasing to my belly. My sis had corn beef and bf had the NY rye sandwich or something along those lines. Anyway service was excellent, definitely good variety of food and I liked how they focused more on healthy eating.
author: Vanessa P.

description:
My friend's and I were in the area and looking for a place to eat, so I pulled up yelp and found St. Francis Fountain with 4 stars and decided to give it a try.  

We were told to put our name on the list and they would call us when a table was ready.  We put our names on the list near the bottom of the first side of the page and wait.  As more people come the paper gets turned over so people can put their names on... which is fine, but when the guy checking the list comes out he doesn't turn the page over again to see the previous names and starts calling the names on the top of the turned side.  That excluded our group and two other groups.  

We tell him and finally get seated.  After getting seated we find that our server is to have a very sarcastic and annoyed personality.  She made some joke about serving us food that we didn't get right away and she was automatically stand-off-ish.

So, we order our food and I try the potato thing which was good but nothing special.

After finishing our food our table gets cleared and we get the check, we have money in hand waiting for somebody to come back to us and they never do.  We eventually leave enough cash to cover the tab and tip on the table and just leave.

I'm giving one star for the service, but I would give 3 for the food.  BTW I totally agree withe SFMom O.'s review about the general clientele.
author: Jason K.

description:
Excellent (albeit 'hip') service- Lackluster food, unremarkable quality.  

This historic soda shop has signs up that remind one of the idyllic 50s in San Francisco- when a Malt was a staple and comfort foods were still worth advertising on hand painted signs.

I ordered the Eggs Florentine with home fries, a Poinsettia (Cranberry and champagne) and a coffee- While the coffee is a great drip of Peerless and the poinsettia was well-balanced, the main dish was decidedly lackluster.  The presentation was certainly acceptable, however, the low quality of the foods meant that my yolks had no taste, the hollandaise shouted out it's powdered origins, the spinach tasted misused or perhaps even canned.  I had a few bites of my meal, and enjoyed the drinks and company instead.

Based on the other recommendations- I'd suggest one stick to foods that rely less on the quality of the original ingredients, and rely more upon preserved foods and spices.  This place has great ambiance, malts, and sandwiches made of meat, relishes, mustards, and bread.

The handsome and trendy staff and patrons range from my middle-aged Precita Eyes volunteer dining companions at the counter to the gaggles of 20-somethings in Valencia-styled capris and ironic t-shirts.  The gorgeous preserved interior is lovely to gaze at and imagine an earlier time.
author: Cameo W.

description: This is my new favorite place for b-fast. I am not a hipster, but I like to watch them and for them to be my waiters. It was like an old-fashioned diner perfectly melded with modern hipsterdom. The menu was full of reconceived/tweaked favorites. I went for the VEGAN CHORIZO breakfast burrito and was not disappointed. My friend had the hog cakes and loved 'em. They didn't rush me. They gave me lots of coffee. I left thoroughly fulfilled. I only give 5 stars when I feel like I have to text everybody to go them and that was the case.
author: Andrew K.

description:
This place is hot, love the environment! Old school American dinner, with a twist. The food is not all that, but darn good.
Food: 3*
Spot: 4-5*

YAY! I'M A FAN!
author: M S.

description: This is a great ice cream shop. Vintage feel & great flavors! The employees have lots  of tattoos and piercings. My kind of place! We get some french fries and dip them in our milk shakes.
author: Chase L.

description:
After a dozen visits, I need to update and upgrade.  A few reasons:
1.  Updated menu.  They ditched the ortega chiles for jalapenos.  I'm giddy.
2.  We dine-with-baby and the people that work here are fantastically friendly and accommodating.  
3.  The freaking banana bread.  Amazing.
4.  Borax soap in the bathroom.  You know, the dry, gritty powder.  I love it.
5.  They bought the space next door.  Which means more tables.  And shorter waits.
author: Kelli R.

description:
I'm a fan... 
I love the diner feel.. everyone was super friendly..
The breakfast burrito was delicious!
And the best part.. they serve Mitchell's ice cream! yummers..
author: Monica S.

description:
Uhhh, someone forgot to cook my chili cheese fries.  Seriously, it came out completely refrigerated and uncooked... the chili, the cheese and everything.  

The waitress actually never bothered to ask me how it was.  You'd think it'd be a hint when the wait staff brought the bill and there was only one bite taken out of the mound of ice-cold grossness.  

The staff didn't seem to notice much, in all honesty, including: the lack of ketchup or condiments on our table, my glass of water that was taken away before my food arrived but never refilled or returned, the empty soap dispenser and paper towel rack in the bathroom.  When I did manage to flag down the waitress, she kind of grunted and barely managed to utter a single word before slipping away. 

I will say, the atmosphere does have a cool, retro vibe.  And the menu had a nice, modern twist, with lots of vegetarian and vegan options.  But that didn't stop parade of mistakes from overshadowing any hope this place had.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Unless you are too-cool-for-school, ride a fixie, wear skinny jeans, indoor sunglasses, or sport an ironic hairdo---I wouldn't bother.  It's certainly is a cute vintage-y place. And, the food is decent.  However, the portions were really pretty small for the price, but my biggest issue was the service. Ya know, maybe I'm just particular, but If I am sitting at the counter, and you keep walking by with a carafe of coffee and a pitcher of water and pouring out for other counter customers, I get my hopes up that  you will also fill my empty coffee cup when I've got it sitting on the lip of the counter.  

Heavy on the kitsch, light on service.  Too bad.
author: Julie T.

description:
This place is amazing! But expect a long wait to be seated.

Every time I come here the food here is mouthwatering. I usually get an egg scramble something or other.

They give you a ton of food, it's always delicious, and the waitstaff are friendly.

I definitely want to come here more, and maybe try their sundaes.
author: Xavier G.

description:
First of all, expect a long wait on Saturday and Sunday.  Its difficult to be seated with larger groups because only 2 booths will fit 6 people at the most. If you do get past this one and only issue you will be rewarded with a fantastic meal, strong coffee and enjoyable wait staff.  

I had the Nebulous Potato Thing, which has now become my first choice at the fountain. 

Look for the great collection of 70's and 80's bubblegum cards.
author: Gina G.

description:
I get hot and bothered.

Everything I've ever eaten here has been amazing, huge, super veggie friendly. The price is right.  Is that jam homemade? Damn. Tasty coffee too.

Best of all, the staff is friendly and very easy on the eyes. And it must be noted that Pop's is directly across the street. Call it a day.
author: Stumbalina b.

description:
St. Francis's is probably the best diner food I've ever had.  That is, I consistently leave here feeling satisfied, not gross and all "ooh, why did I eat that".

I've been here only for lunch, but on a number of occasions.  The portions are hearty and the service is no-frills friendly.Their burgers are hearty and juicy.  I was thoroughly impressed, though, by the chicken club:  the chicken tender, the bacon crisp and plentiful, and just a well-done sandwich overall.  This sort of quality, I suspect, extends to the rest of their menu.

Next time, perhaps I'll give the chile a whirl, or one of their many milkshakes.  These seem to be frequently ordered items.
author: Anna L.

description:
I was so devastated by this experience that it has taken me a full week to finally write the review.  So Patricia P has been talking about how she's had this place bookmarked for months.  St. Francis Fountain looks/seems like it would be so much better than it actually is! Boo. 

It's a janky, dirty, hipster hangout gone completely wrong with crappy service, crappy food, and crappy bathrooms (broken lock).  Thank god we didn't arrive til 145ish pm, which meant we didn't have to wait in line. 

I had studied the menu a few times and couldn't wait to try it after seeing things like shakes, malts, the Nebulous Potato Thing (a large plate of homefries topped with melted cheese, fresh salsa, sour cream & green onions), Chef's Mess (eggs scrambled with homefries, bacon & mushrooms, topped with melted cheese, tomatoes, sour cream & green onions), chili cheese fries, mac and cheese, and a few bomb looking sandwiches.   

Patty got a turkey sandwich with avocado and I had to go with the Chef's Mess (seems like it could've been one of my own messy concoctions).  The turkey sandwich was on crappy bread that you get at Safeway, the turkey was clearly pre-packaged, and it just didn't look appetizing at all.  The Chef's Mess was gross.  I left at least half of it on my plate.  That partially could've been my fault, ordering something so heavy.   

The shake and malt were way too watery and the cheese fries, which we had ordered with bacon were no bueno.  They didn't get that we wanted bacon bits on the cheese fries, so they brought us a plate of bacon??!! What??? The fries were soggy and not seasoned well.  Yes, I know, we may seem like gluttonous pigs, but we were tired, hungover, and starving...

The service was also annoying.  We had to ask the poor water boy to get our waitress to take our order after 15 mins of being seated.

Gosh, I really didn't want to be disappointed by this place!!!
author: Jenny W.

description:
St. Francis Fountain has the charm of an old school diner, the booth seats and counter does at least. They have cool retro candy too. As some of the other reviews have mentioned, this place is full of hipsters. I don't have an issue with hipster but it does disrupt the old school diner vibe.

The food here is good fatty diner food, lots of veggie options too. I had the veggie ruben with a side of mac and cheese, and I also tried the side of spuds. The spuds were more flavorful than the mac and cheese and much better. Nice greasy diner food, don't go if you're in a healthy mood. 

A couple things didn't make me happy, we ordered 2 plates and a coffee for 3 people and they still charged us 1.50 to split, unless they charged us the 1.50 for something else that they didn't feel like telling us about. Service was a bit slow, didn't get the refill on my water, which makes me sad because I was really thirsty.
author: Angela T.

description:
The food here is pretty decent for diner food...nothing special.  EXCEPT for their freaking malt shakes.  The only thing that kills it, is their paper straws.  I understand the attempt to be more "green", however I can't enjoy injecting my myself with cholesterol, when paper bits infiltrate my mouth.  I think I ate more of the straw than my shake.  

So minus one star for that.
author: Ivy R.

description:
The place is a diner style restaurant with a 50s/60s motif. In a display case they were selling old type candies and trading cards. Hey I didn't know that cindy lauper and duran duran were popular during the 50s and 60s.

Hogcakes. Cheese, green onions and bacon. Sounds good in theory. Wrong!!! The whole thing tasted like a burnt massacre of bitterness. You couldn't taste the bacon instead burnt butter cheese was the taste that took center stage.

The wait staff was less than stellar. It took them a little bit to come to the table to take our order. I asked for a coke without ice. The person repeated it back to me a couple of times to make sure he heard me correctly and I said no ice thank you. It came back with ice.

Won't come back.
author: ryan n.

description: This place has a huge menu and awesome food.  The french toast with yogurt and granola on top was excellent, as well as the soup and the huevos rancheros. I love the old-school feeling of this place, and the "vintage" candy that they sell makes me smile :)
author: Laura P.

description:
St. Francis serves rotten food and treats their customers like crap.

Been going to St. Frannie's since it re-opened and it's always been consistant.  Not great, but pretty reliable.

Went in for breakfast on a Saturday morning, noticed menu had changed a bit, prices went up.  More Vegan options for those who care - I do not.  However, I did order the vegan choriso and 2-egg scramble, wanting something a little lighter and also subbed out a side salad for the potatoes and toast.  Something St. Francis has had no problem doing for me in the past.

Breakfast comes to the table and the salad out of the bag that they gave me was brown and rotten, covered in dressing.  The waiter never came back to check and after waiving down the busser had it sent back, explaining it was brown and rotten and asked for a new one.  After 15 minutes and some confusion on the staff's part my salad comes back to the table.  More brown.  More rotten than before.

I finished my breakfast, went to pay the bill and mentioned to the waiter that my salad, again, was brown and rotten.  I was told that that's all they have right now.  i said, "well why didn't you level with me and tell me that and offer me something else rather than serving me rotten food twice?"  Then the waiter said that there was nothing wrong with the salad after telling me loudly that I needed to "calm down."  I had the manager come out, walked over to my table, picked up the plate of salad and showed in to them and said, "I'm sorry, would you eat this?"  The manager shook his head no and the waiter said that he would eat it and that he saw nothing wrong with it.

It was a joke.  I'm not talking about a little brown around the edges - I'm talking about slimy, brown and rotten- old.

I punished them by getting out of there as fast as I could and leaving a $20 dollar bill.  Meaning I tipped about 25% and paid $10.50 for 2 scrambled eggs for my breakfast.

How hard would it have been to say, "I'm sorry, I wasn't paying attention, we're not ready for salad service."  Or "How can I make you happy?" or "Please don't call the health department."?

Their food is totally unremarkable, except the Guiness float, and their service makes me want to throw a flaming brick through the window.  To save myself the hard time, I don't need to go back.

Get bent St. Francis.  Choke on your kitchy display of stale jawbreakers.
author: Lauren O.

description: Ok, seriously this place just keeps getting BETTER and BETTER!! Every time I go here I'm just so satisfied!! Delicious fries, amazing breakfast, & yummy sandwiches! Mmmmm Love that i live so close!
author: Amanda R.

description:
I didn't see any Mission hipsters but then again my friends dragged me out of bed at 8AM to beat the crowd. I guess our waiter was kind of hipsterey but I'm sure he couldn't help it. 

Loved the blueberry pancakes - real Maine-style wild blueberries, not those fat tasteless ones from Chile - and thin cakes that I like, not the huge thick ones that will make you full after two bites. Yeah the booths are small, but they are real wood - this place has been there for fifty years - it's like stepping into a wonderful time machine and going back to 1947. 

I loved the sign on the wall that said "Ice cream is only served in dishes for here, and only in cones to go; NO EXCEPTIONS!"
author: Joe D.

description:
In a bright sunny place around the mission district, this is THE cafe that you want to dine at with in and out door seating. 

the scene: Atmosphere is busy but was seated right away on a busy Saturday morning. Right when I stepped in it felt like i reversed in a time machine and was giddy to see the cool oldies toys and memorabilia's  on the wall, now and later candy, and Mitchell's ice cream. tables all around and tall chairs at the bar area. Friendly hipster/fixie, band/art crowd, and cute waiters is a plus. 

the eats: breakfast buritto with a side of black beans and rice was healthy and a good portion size that wont get you too overstuffed. The bacon and avo egg's benedict w holl sauce lunch special ($12, $14 if you want to add coffe + oj or champange) was dericious and probably one of the best i had. it definitely hit the spot of my morning hunger and even had enough leftovers for next days bfast!
author: Shirley L.

description: We accidentally found this place on our way to Dynamo Donuts. Talk about stepping back into the past. We found this place to be very nostalgic. The Service was pleasant and the food was very good. We ordered their Corned Beef Hash (yummy), Chicken Cilantro Soup (yummy) and Chocolate Malt Shake made with Mitchell's Ice Cream (yummy). All in all, we were very happy first-timers to this establishment. We will definitely return in the future to this place that makes us feel like we're living in the past.
author: Chrissy H.

description:
This place should get 4 stars.  The reason I am only giving 3 stars is because they don't let you know when you order that the sausage patty is chicken apple sausage.  Breakfast sausage is pork unless otherwise noted.  Also the Chorizo is vegan?  If you are a vegetarian/vegan then why eat fake meat??

Otherwise the food is very good and the service is attentive.
author: Kevin B.

description:
I went here for lunch with a coworker. The place is really clean and open. It wasn't too busy, but it was a late lunch (4-ish). We sat at the counter, which was charming. I like how they set the menus and their little container of paper straws (which had red candycane stripes!) on the counter. They had a lot of cute touches, but the atmosphere was a little lacking. I am sure that it was because it was slow when we came in. 

The service was quick and food comes out at a moderate pace. I ended up getting the Poor Man Soup. I have a bit of a cold so it hit the spot. There was a lot of chicken meat and a moderate amount of veggies. The biscuit was pretty much the highlight of soup. It was comforting and exactly what I needed. Beware of the cilantro though. There was lots of it. So if you aren't into that I wouldn't get it.

I really want to try the Nebulous Potato Thing and one of their milkshakes next time!
author: Donna K.

description:
The local hipsters really dig this place.  I could see why.  I love the old fashioned, candy store booth feel.  But we were seated next door, which lacks the charm.  And the food just wasn't that good, which outweighs ambiance in my book. 

The biscuits and gravy were sub par.  I couldn't taste either the orange zest or the pecan in my waffle, which was what made the Hector unique.  Perhaps the server gave me a plain waffle instead by mistake. 

My by and I felt bad because we dragged our friends who were visiting us from Berkeley to eat here, when they really wanted to take us to their favorite breakfast spot in the East Bay.  Nobody was blown away by their food, which I was hoping for after the 4 star rating.  it is kid-friendly though, so that's a plus.  I really wanted to eat our friends' daughter's happy face pancake.  And the service is laid back and friendly.
author: nini t.

description:
The place was slammed on MLK Monday, hipsters huddling outside in the cold.  I skipped the wait by sitting at the counter.  
They seemed to have enough folks on staff, but although there was a lot of running around, not much seemed to get done.  
My server seemed harried even though there wasn't much turnover in the dining room.  I ordered a Chef's Mess and coffee - both were decent, but nothing fantastic.  
Waited some more to get the check.
Throughout, overheard the servers griping to each other about some drama.  
The food was: Fair.
The service was: Slow.
I'll go to Local Mission Eatery next time.
author: Barnaby G.

description:
The St. Francis Fountain takes the cake for the worst customer service I've ever experienced in San Francisco, and that's really saying something. I'm just amazed that the owner continue to employ people like this in the age of Yelp. Here's the deal:

I'm new to the neighborhood and went in for ice cream on Tuesday, Sep 15 at about 4:15PM. The store was empty, except for a foursome sharing a booth and two employees - a man and woman - behind the counter.

"Cup, or cone?" the girl asked.

After paying approx $4.50 for a double scoop cone, I proceeded to enjoy it at the otherwise empty counter. The girl who took my order was smiling and courteous and continued about her work. That is, until the guy - a muscly young man with blue eyes - working behind the counter literally shoved her out of the way in order to tell me that I had to leave.

"Huh? Why?"

"Because you have a cone. Cups inside. Cones outside. Leave, now."

I was flummoxed. "Uh...ok," I stammered as I walked outside, a bit shocked by the rudeness. I figured I'd walk around the block, finish my cone, and go inside to express my dismay that I wasn't told ahead of time that I couldn't stay if I got my ice cream in a cone.

When I entered the store again, a few more customers had come in, but the girl recognized me and asked, "is everything all right?"

I said, "I'm here to complain, but please go ahead and finish with these people." After a few minutes, the customers cleared out. But right then, the male employee came back out, saw me, and made a dash toward us. "What do you want?" he said, forcefully and visibly angry.

"I'd like to talk to someone about the cone policy. I've never been in here before..."

"Look -" he cut me off. "I can't even talk to you. You're going to have to leave."

"Excuse me?"

"If the owner even finds out I've been taking complaints from customers, I'll get in big trouble. It's store policy."

I looked at both the guy - still starting at me, eyes blazing - and the girl, who was looking at the floor in embarrassed silence. "Wait, are you telling me I can't come in here and talk to the manager about the service?"

"I'm going to get in trouble, in TROUBLE" he repeated.

I didn't buy it. "You're not going to get in trouble for listening to me."

"Sir, I'm going to get in trouble if I so much as even talk to you. You really should just get up and leave."

"Look, if it comes down to it, I'll tell the owner that I just wouldn't shut up. I don't want my money back, and I don't want anything free. All I want is to suggest suggest that you be more proactive about telling people about your policy."

 "THERE'S A SIGN!" he yelled, pointing to a small 12"x16" sign at the far end of the long fountain. "We don't HAVE to tell people." At this point I turned around to the four people in the booth who were staring, mouths agape.

I said, "Okay, what I hear you saying is that you want me to take my complaints to the owner. That's fine. Where can I reach him?"

The guy silently slapped a card on the counter that had the number of the store on it. "And I can reach him here?"

"Yeah, go ahead and try." the guy spit back. "Now leave."

I was literally reeling with shock at this welcome to my new neighborhood. I left the store, and called the number, and got the girl, who suggested I call back "maybe on weekdays, between 11 and 3, and on some weekends." She said the owner's name was "Levon."

I have called back almost every day since and left my name and number, and somehow "Levon" never calls me back. The guy on the phone recognizes my voice when I call. As far as I can tell, the guy is playing a game, and never intends to put me through to the owner.

Just today, I called the St. Francis, gave my name and number, and asked if the owner was there. "He's in a meeting," the guy responded. I called back 10 minutes later, asked again, and was told he wasn't in today and that I should try back later. "Well, someone just told me that he was in an in a meeting."

"Oh? Well, we have lots of employees here and I don't like being called a liar. Bye." And he hung up.

I wouldn't have imagined that level of service here in San Francisco. That said, I'll be living right down the street from them. We'll see how long the charade keeps up.

***
I finally connected with Levon through Facebook, and we met for coffee. He was very cordial, and listened carefully as I recounted what happened. He explained the (rather charming) purpose behind their deliberately old-fashioned policies, and apologized for the bad experience I had there. I'll keep private the details of our conversation, but he welcomed me back to the store at any time, and I look forward to taking him up on his offer once I get settled in to my new neighborhood.
author: Jason B.

description:
Great for hangovers. The retro diner feel is great including the vintage candy selection. Also, such a nice detail having the coat racks on the booths. It is so nice to step out of clothes and get into the booth. 

Having said that... the other day when it was pouring rain I ventured in to wait inside and was kindly told to wait outside by the waitress. It was at the tail end of the breakfast crowd and there were plenty of empty places at that point in service. I ended up scuttling off to another eating establishment to avoid getting soaked. 

Still a great place and truly great how it has maintained its look and clientelle for decades.
author: Jimi G.

description:
My favorite! Simple and fun
. You know what to expect. Great veggie section. Always nice staff.
author: Lori T.

description:
I've been eating here since birth. In fact, since before birth. Luckily, even with the change of ownership, it still feels like the old St. Francis. 
They may have added tofu scrambles to make the hipster crowd feel at home, and gotten rid of the tall glasses in favor of plastic ones, but you can still sit in the booth where the 49'ers were founded. It's a great place for the old that want to remember and the young to see what the missed.
It's comfort food done right, and when you have a yearning for a banana split or egg cream this is the place you should be.
They also have a candy counter where you can pick up some Tron, Alf, and Buck Rogers trading cards among others.
The place is almost 100 years old, so check out the prices on one of the old menus now hanging in the bathroom.
author: Jason D.

description: This is an excellent breakfast spot in the Mission. Perhaps it is my own baggage that I associate being hipster with being "too cool for school" and "full of yourself". My preconceived notions were shattered  by the excellent service I received from the wonderful staff who bend the laws of physics every morning when they somehow manage to fit into their skin tight pants and still delight with some of the best breakfast I have had in California.
author: Mo A.

description: Best tofu scramble in the city. I have tried a lot of places, and this place easily beatsh them all. The tofu scramble is nicely spiced and add Jalapenos for more kick.
author: Vinod K.

description:
St. Francis Fountain- woooo! yeaaaa! okaaaaaay!

We waited a good spell for our table, but it was 11 on a Sunday so I'd expect nothing less. The place itself embodies why I love SF so much. It's quaint, cute, retro and cozy.

They have a large vegan selection of breakfast goodies, which is great when you wanna take your non-veg friends out for brunch without relegating yourself to toast and potatoes. It has something for everyone. 

I had the no-huevos rancheros with guacamole and I enjoyed it, it's not the best I've had but it was pretty tasty. I had a bite of their biscuits and those were damn good (though not vegan). I also had the soy shake in chocolate and that was delicious. 

All around thumbs up for this place. Thanks Vegansaurus for another great recommendation.

Real rating: 3.5
author: Jessica L.

description:
I remember the desserts here since before I had the capicity to store memory. Like pre-Dot Com bubble bursting times. Rarely did I walk down as far as York since my little legs could rarely carry me that far from Folsom but when I did I was dully rewarded and reenergized for the trip back.
From a recent visit:
Thanks for letting us in close to closing time. No thanks for giving us the bill before we even got our orange juice. Thanks for sitting us at a booth and for letting me keep my 2 foot tophat on. 
The menu has changed a bit but the same greats are still there and some new favorites. Personally anything with pesto is my fav but therefore I am biased. Keep up the good work St Francis.
author: Jim L.

description: Small, and a bit cramped... but the mud pie sundae was delish and the service was very good!
author: Jwd F.

description:
Breakfast is good, but priced for the new money hipsters that are lining up the place. 

The tattooed waitresses are hot and they flirt with you. 
Service is good. 

Mostly, I like the place because they sell old collectible trading cards and stickers in a display case. 

I dont always feel cool enough to be patronizing this place. 

Theres cheaper places in the city. 

But if you want to take a group of out of towners or group of friends to just "hang out and be seen", this would be the place.
author: MacKenzie S.

description: The food is only alright and I sat there awkwardly for 10+ minutes waiting for my bill.
author: Kelly N.

description:
A quaint little slice of history with an up-to-date menu. The place is teensy but adorable and attracts locals, tourists and Missionites alike. The menu was updated a few years ago to attract a massive vegetarian and vegan-friendly crowd. Novelty, retro gum-packs and toys are available at the entrance.

I find the quality of the food to be nothing short of great. I love their french fries which are on the brown side, with plenty of crispiness and salt. Their shakes are indulgent and delicious. Their sandwiches and burgers are awesome. But don't get me started on their breakfast! If you're vegetarian or vegan you're in luck because they have many wonderful choices!

My only complaint is that I wish the spaces were a little bit bigger to accommodate a larger crowd.
author: L. L.

description:
mmmmm  I sometimes dream about eating at this place. 

When I was in SF last, I stayed like a block from St Francis and ate here several times during that visit. 

The burger hit the spot. The grilled cheese samich was great. There is always a wait on the weekends, but if you're solo, you can always snag a seat at the bar or take the food to go.
author: Andreena S.

description:
This restaurant is amazing. Each time I go, I fall more in love with this place. From the coffee, to the waitstaff, to the menu, the ambiance is very nice and settling. The menu offers vegan and vegetarian options as well as meat for the meat loving variety. The last time I went there was last Tuesday, March 1st, I ordered chocolate chip pancakes with blueberries on top. They have vegan pancakes as well. I had the vegan strawberry pancakes there before. The pancakes were hot and ready to be devoured. They tasted like victory. The two flavors, chocolate and blueberry were a great marriage of decadence. The addition of syrup wasn't extremely necessary, but if added, you'd get blasted with a hot and delicious bite of succulence.  Also on the menu are these "potato things" which look amazing, it comes with scrambled eggs and salsa which my sister got. She loved it. My two guy friends loved the burgers that they got and they said "good burgers are hard to find." I highly recommend this place to try. Here is a picture of my blueberry chocolate chip pancakes. You can see my friend's burger lurking in the background.
https://mail-attachment.googleusercontent.com/attachment/?ui=2&ik=26b4a113bf&view=att&th=135e6c8bfb50c243&attid=0.1&disp=inline&safe=1&zw&saduie=AG9B_P-oS00HGU7cP9pl2GgTjJpq&sadet=1331016865828&sads=WhKX9KhBxvmOkQrRoEJmNlWVKIo&sadssc=1
author: Jessica C.

description:
if you want to have ice cream COME HERE!  This is the RICHEST, BEST TASTING, TRUE ICE CREAM IN THE CITY.

well, that was when my friend used to be the owner.  I assume it still is because he sold the recipe and the place to the current owners.

when i went there it was clearly the BEST ICE CREAM because it was FULL CREAM and iced the way its supposed to be.  I could feel the richness and how savory and pick a word and if its in the great to better category...that would be it.
author: Bing D.

description:
This place was a fountain for many years, and still sells sodas and shakes, but it's mainly a vegan/vegetarian resturant still trying to masquerade as an old fashioned fountain/diner.  They need to change their name.

Went there for breakfast and ordered sausage and biscuits. They said the biscuits were homemade, but they would have been better off using Pillsbury. The biscuits were heavy, starchy and undercooked. The sausage gravy had a weird herbal taste to it. Fine if that is what you are expecting.

My friend had vegan chorizo and eggs, which really was pretty good (the reason for the three stars).

She also had a root beer float. $4.35 for a tablespoon of tasteless ice cream in the bottom of a glass only 3/4 filled with root beer.

If you're a vegan/vegetarian you will like this place, but you won't if you're expecting a diner.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
My hangover cure. Does it every time.

Yes, it's crazy hipster, but people like me who are wearing the same shit from the night before, smeared make up, a come-and-go gag reflex, bangin headache are also there, and are made much happier after gorging on their homefries, malted milkshakes, toasted sandwiches, or bacon infested chef's mess. They saved my life today, they'll do it again the next time I party with the devil and get punished like shit for it.
author: Chieh T.

description: With all the good reviews, I was expecting more.  the food was very average.  I had a BLT and it was good, but the fries were very salty and cold.  my friend has a burger and enjoyed it, but said, he can find this kind of burger almost anywhere.  We had to have shakes, certainly good, but small and nothing we haven't had at many other places.  the ambiance was definitely a hole-in-the-wall and we loved it.  nothing was really wrong except the service.  there was nothing kind, friendly or good about our server.  he seemed annoyed we were even there and then wanted to take our order before we even had opened the menus.  and then when we wanted to add shakes at the end, we almost didn't because we hated his attitude.
