I am certainly glad I tried St. Francis Fountain, but certainly will not go back.
author: Glenn G.

description:
Kaylie Says:

The second I walked into St. Francis Fountain I was happy solely due to the well designed interior and light rays coming in through the windows. I felt as if I was back to the past and should have slicked back hair, trousers, and a white t-shirt with the sleeves rolled. Unfortunately Southwest Airlines lost my luggage, but that's besides the point. What's important is the food right?

I was delighted to eat  but once again was wounded by the atrocious construction of a breakfast burrito. I guess that's what I get for ordering a burrito in The Mission from a hipster cafe.  My burrito was tofu and soyrizo wrapped in a tortilla. That's it. I did get bland beans on the side and if I recall correctly a few potatoes, but honestly where's the vegetables? The saving grace for this dish was the ranchero sauce which definitely added the only distinguishable flavor on the dish. With this being said I would definitely go back for the cute servers, retro atmosphere and a plethora of vegan options available. Maybe I just had bad luck? Malloreigh will tell you... her sandwich was wonderful.

Malloreigh Says:

Yeah, my sandwich was wonderful. I got The Toasted Vegan, which was a delicious toasted tomato and portabello mushroom sandwich with Vegenaise. It was big and tasty and satisfying. It reminded me of my mother's toasted tomato sandwiches, which was definitely a bonus. I also got a nice side of organic greens, pretty standard. Kaylie forgot to mention that we also got bottomless coffee and some seriously delicious mimosas with our meal, which were another highlight. Her burrito did suck, though.

Moral of the story: vegan breakfast burritos are usually garbage.
author: Malloreigh M.

description: After sitting down and waiting 1/2 hr for someone to bring coffee and take our order ( you'd think a diner with over 80 years experience would know how to do this a little more quickly by now), I think they screwed up my order.  Corned beef hash usually has corned beef in it, but I sure couldn't find any - it was all potatoes, and very greasy.  The other person's pancakes were actually decent so I'll add a star.  As we were leaving we said 'Next time we come here we know not to get the corned beef hash.  Oh, who are we kidding, we're never coming back here.'
author: Adam R.

description: Stopped here for lunch yesterday. Was pretty decent for a dive-y joint.  The thing that irked me was the guy with the tank top and long loose hair working behind the counter. Just seems unsanitary to me.  My bf ordered a cookies and cream milk shake.. Wow.. It was awesome! I had a chicken club sandwich and he had the corned beef hash. We were both impressed with the food.. The food came out quickly and we were in and out.
author: Yi L.

description:
Went here for breakfast around 9AM on Sunday. Had the Hector waffle combo - orange zest and pecan waffles (2), grilled ham (3 pieces), scrambled eggs (2) for $10.50. My friend had the sourdough french toast with blueberries (~$6.50). Both were very good.

However, I thought the original fountain shop diner decor was great. I would definitely go back again.

Friendly service, although at 9AM the outside seating and the side addition were not open yet.

Verdict: Make your homage to St. Francis and leave a happy worshiper.
author: Zoom Z.

description:
Ate breakfast here once a while ago but didn't remember the name of the place.  That was before I moved to the city so now I am writing a review.  Go here if you love:

Coat racks
Vintage candy
Breakfast, lunch, or dinner
Nice and interesting people
Booths
Ice cream and shakes
author: Xhris C.

description:
Overrated. 

It's places like this one that remind me why people bash hipsters. The food is OK, and yes, there are veg/vegan options, but the homefries aren't vegan and that angers me. The seating is uncomfortable and crampt, especially when they place you at the back of the diner right next to the bathroom so you have to watch people go in to drop a grumpy. The service was slooooow, and our waiter seemed to disappear for way too long at regular intervals while another server was practically having a menage-a-trois with the group next to us. Yo, can I get some service over heeeerrre? Oh, you're busy? Fine... I guess I'll just wait...

I ordered the no-huevos rancheros. My beans were runny and had a generally peculiar consistency. The biggest insult were the tortillas that were shoved onto the plate and into the beans where they got wet and made them difficult to operate in typical huevos rancheros-eating fashion. 

Even more annoying: our bill was delivered to us in the form of chicken scratch. Only the discoverers of the Rosetta Stone might be able to relate to our experiences trying to figure out who ordered what and how much we all owed.

As we left we noticed a cue of people waiting to get into SFF for their Saturday brunches. Clearly some people are willing to put image before quality, but I'll leave that to the guy in the tight, acid-wash lavender pants.
author: Eva V.

description:
The Devil Burger is the best vegan sandwich I've ever had. I don't know how they do it. I keep going back, waiting to have one be a little underwhelming, and it's never happened. The side salad that you can get with the sandwich is lovely and substantial. 

I like the breakfasts, too, though those are little more inconsistent. The tofu rancheros is very tasty, and they have a really nice vegan chorizo hash. 

The service is great! They get slammed on the weekends for brunch, so be prepared to put your name on the list and run to Dynamo Donuts for a quick coffee while you wait.
author: Marla W.

description:
Yummy yummy yummy. Breakfast is the best but also a good option for lunch and dinner. Best tuna melt in town. 

Plus great people watching and that includes the staff. I would really like to be a fly on the wall during one of those interviews. 

Yes long waits but maybe it'll be a bit better now that they've expanded into the space next door. Maybe...
author: robin b.

description: What a cool find.....brought my 5 year daughter in for an early lunch today.  The chicken-cilantro soup was really good - light and full of flavor.  My daughter was more intrigue with the retro-candy (brought me back to my grade school days - really, when was the last time you saw a pack of Duran Duran cards or Fun Dip??), but she ultimately had eggs, bacon and toast (kiddie portion was only $3.50).  Oh, gotta try the ice-cream (Mitchell's) with hot fudge.  Very good.  Anyway, cool vibe, great staff, and good food.
author: J J.

description: I didnt eat anything here that I couldnt easily find somewhere else. They serve typical california diner fare- vegetarian chili, mexican scrambles, pancakes, sandwiches... I have had all of these types of dishes at other places that do a much better job. For a city with so much to offer in this genre of food I dont see a real reason to go back to St Francis other than checking out the lastest fashion statements from the hipster servers.  They are all very nice hipsters though.
author: M K.

description:
Let me start off by saying I love old-fashioned diners, soda fountains and the like.  I am huge fan of the 5 dollar milkshake and I believe it goes perfectly well with a giant denver omelette.  I had heard great things about this place, so I jumped at the chance to try a malted here.

Thanks, but no thanks.  In addition to ignoring my friends and I for a good fifteen minutes both before we were seated and after we got our menus - despite the fact that this place was barely crowded - we were totally ripped off.  After our meal finally came, we were told that our milkshakes were "coming right up."  Another 15 or 20 minutes later, when it became apparent that we'd just been forgotten, we asked for them to go.  Now, I'm sorry, but when I pay 5 bucks for a "small" milkshake, I expect a little more than a six-inch high paper cup thrown at me.  

The bottom line is they couldn't be bothered to care about their customers, and no amount of old-school charm makes up for that.
author: Liliana S.

description:
We finally made it in to St. Francis, and we wish we came here years ago - fantastic.  My new favorite breakfast is the upside-down hog cakes - buttermilk pancake with bacon, cheddar cheese, and green onions.  My wife and I can never agree on a breakfast, as I always go for sweet and she always goes for savory.  This has both, and we both thought it was fantastic!

Our friends went for the vegan options and were very happy with their dishes as well.
author: Brian C.

description:
Over-rated.

Yuck!

This place USED to be good but now its hella slow, the food is garbage and the place is unclean. 

I dont think i would go back, Boogaloos has way better service and better food and its not far away (Valencia and 22nd).
http://www.yelp.com/biz/boogaloos-san-francisco

I ended up not eating the food (they did comp my meal), but I was just too grossed out.
author: Nathan U.

description:
Ah, a classic. With classic  too cool for school service.
Sat outside when our local friend brought us here on a great sunny afternoon. While we were waiting for our server to arrive (after checking in inside), we listened to a busser lecture the clearly tourist couple next to us for not checking in inside - I understand mentioning to people they should check in before just sitting down, but did we all have to listen to the 5 minute lecture?
I really should have tried a shake or fountain soda as that's what they are known for - and I really did love the striped paper straws (again, I am a sucker for gimmicks).  
My Arnold Palmer paired well with the turkey club -and I appreciated that the fruit salad was just that - and fresh.
author: Adriana K.

description:
Not worth the hype.

Stopped in to grab a quick bite, hoping to experience an adorable old-timey soda fountain before catching a show at the Brava Theater up the street. (We showed up at the St. Francis with an hour and half before the show started...had to rush out with to go milkshakes. Enough said.) Disappointed from the moment we walked in. The waiters didn't acknowledge us for over 10 minutes, and despite the 4 empty booths, then asked us to wait another few minutes before actually seating us. 

Upon ordering, the waitress argued with my 12-year-old over ordering from the Kiddie Meal...who asks a 12-year-old for ID over a waffle with whipped cream!

Waited too too long for the food and even longer for our milkshakes, the place was nowhere near crowded. 

Waiters were pissy and slow, milkshakes (when put in a to go cup) were such a rip.
author: Sophie I.

description:
Came back here a while ago with a friend for breakfast. Holy Crap! I don't remember what I got but I do remember thinking that it was one of the best breakfast places I've been to in the city. The sitting situation is kind of funky I think - you can't get a booth unless you are at least 3 people? So if you are 2 people I think that means you need to automatically sit at the counter or outside (unless there were a few 2 seat tables inside - I forget - just know it's small and there's always a wait for breakfast.

My friend did note that they could have sold some pastries in addition to the candy. We didn't see any, anyway.
author: Ken L.

description: Breakfast burrito review only!  So the breakfast burrito here can be customized any way you want it but for my first try, I had it straight up.  It comes by default with jack and cheddar cheese and eggs in the tortilla.  On the side come a salsa salad, black beans, sour cream and ranchero sauce.  Overall I'd say it was a decent breakfast burrito.  It definitely is filling with all the extras that are included, but it didn't leave a strong impression.  Not bad of course, but not really freaking good either.  Luckily the staff are super friendly!
author: Gene X.

description:
Wow....just...wow.

Story:
My band and I were in SF for a show at Slims. We had just finished our soundcheck around 10am, and were hungry as all hell. I searched for all the closest "breakfast" places nearby on my iphone (yelp app =]). This was the closest one that popped up. After finding parking a couple streets down, we turned onto 24th and noticed all of the amazing smells from restaurants from nearby Mexican joints and bakeries. We were almost swayed towards one of these, but decided to check out St Francis since they seemed to have actual breakfast which we were in the mood for. 

We were seated within 15 minutes of arriving, and the place was hoppin'. We read the menu and our mouths started to water, and learned that it was one of, if not the first (I can't quite remember which) ice cream places in SF. The staff was friendly and helpful in making our decisions.

The Order:
I ordered the Country Breakfast with 2 biscuits in sausage gravy, 2 scrambled eggs (you can get them any way you please) and hash browns. Now these has browns are amazing on their own (big chunky pieces of tater). But they have an option to "thing" your spuds. Oh...my god folks...they add sour cream, cheese, chives and their homemade salsa that tastes like it came from a legit Mexican place. Best potatoes I've ever had. The biscuits and gravy were out of this world. While I've had bigger biscuits, these were unbelievably buttery and deliscious, and the gravy was bomb. The guitarist in the band had the exact same breakfast I did and was equally blown away which is a feat considering his food snobbery. Our keyboardist had this awesome breakfast burrito and a coffee shake which was also amazing. 

The Verdict: 
Guys, this was hands down the best plate of biscuits and gravy I've ever had, and I always judge breakfast places by their pancakes or biscuits (usually both). The band has decided to come back here for sure next time we're in SF to try their lunch and dinner offerings. The best place I'd had before this was Ole's Waffle Shop in Alameda, which is also phenomenal.
author: Patrick R.

description:
This place makes me SO happy. 
Except when they are out of vanilla soy for my vegan dream-sickle shake.  
I can leave this place stuffed and as a vegan that makes me ecstatic. The last time I discovered that I loved their  mushroom sandwich and I dont like mushrooms.  
I haven't tried breakfast yet because I always need my milkshake and I can never make it all the way out there so early.  But I must walk past boogaloos and get there someday.
author: Kiera H.

description:
Vegan/vegetarian choices aplenty.  
Something here will take care of your hangover if the wait for a table doesn't kill you.
author: Megan G.

description:
Still rockin' the YUM food after all these years. The Spinach salad is SO yummy....fresh pecans, oranges with some feta cheese also! De-LISH
The have a great Vegan/Veggie menu also for your no-meat kinda peeps
author: Katy A.

description:
I was looking for the new ice cream joint in this part of town, you know the one with the weird name.  The one that everyone is talking about.  I found it, that Slocombe one, but a tourist bus full of Frenchies was unloading right out front, and there were no haute, lithe French men in site.  That and I spent my last bit of cash on produce at the local market and the Slocombe place only takes cash.  So I decided to save Slocombe for another day and move on.  I remembered that the St. Francis Fountain was nearby so I headed over there.

When I stepped into the restaurant, I felt like I had stepped into the set of Back to the Future.  Total 50s  vibe plus your standard quotient of hipsters.  After all this is the Mission.  The menus even look like they date back to the 50s..except when you look at the prices.  It never ceases to amaze me what people will charge for ice cream.  $7 for a banana split?  $4 for a milkshake?  What if it doesn't bring all the boys to the yard?  Instead I opted for a single scoop of Rocky Road, which set me back $3.  The marshmallows were a slightly orange hue, but the ice cream was the most ethreal scoop of ice cream that I've ever tasted.  Very rich in flavor and not the slightest hint of freezer burn.  

I'm not really a Mission chic, and I'm surprised that something this charming exists in the Mission, but I would definitely stop back on a spectacular sunny day for some more Rocky Road.
author: Amy Z.

description:
Awesome selection of vegan brunch food!

I have tried the blueberry, banana walnut, and chocolate chip pancakes. The chocolate chip pancakes were my favorite!

The vegan huevos rancheros and the vegan chorizo dishes were also really good.

The service is also great!
author: Meg P.

description:
I went in search of my daily Humphry Slocomb fix only to remember after getting there that they don't open until 12. It was 11:15, and I didn't have time to wait around for 45 minutes.

So to get my ice cream fix, I went here. Except that by the time they finished making my watery milkshake, it was almost 12pm anyway. Slow service and average food. Can't think of a reason to go back.
author: Mark A.

description:
Whoa whoa whoa.  What happened here?
I was out with my two vegan friends and in order to avoid another meal at Herbivore, I suggested this place so I could eat my bacon and sausage and so they could eat their "soyrizo" or whatever it is they call it.
This place has won a place in my heart.
The asshat servers from my previous experience were no longer there.  Everyone was GENUINELY friendly and welcoming.  Maybe this is the morning crew?  I remember only coming in the afternoons.  Hmm.
I was smart and avoided the spuds on things, and instead chose a two egg scramble and french fries.
Delicious!
One extra star for FINALLY finding something worth coming back for.
One extra star for the awesome staff.
author: Meh M.

description:
I love trying new restaurants and St. Francis proves exactly why-  It was amazing!  It's a cute spot, holding on to it's old-school-50's-ice-cream-shop type of thing.  They even give you paper straws with your soda!  Not a fan but it's a nice touch.  The staff seemed genuinely nice which added to the laid back feel of the place.

I highly recommend having your spuds "thinged" which means country style potatoes with melted cheese, tomatoes, sour cream, and salsa.  They went so well mixed together with my bacon and eggs.  I will definitely order the sausage patty again.  It tasted homemade and almost had a soy sauce flavor to it.  It's a little on the saltier side so if you're sensitive to saltiness you might want to pass.  But then again most breakfast meats are salty, right?

If you go to St. Francis, promise me you won't leave without ordering the waffle.  They are perfectly spongy and moist.  And if you find yourself closing your eyes while your chewing, don't worry.  That's perfectly normal.

St. Francis, you are going in to my permanent breakfast spot rotation.
author: Katie J.

description: So Good in so many ways! spinach salad, every vegan thing on the menu, and the Guinness float.
author: Kevin C.

description:
Wandering around the Mission, we stumble into St. Francis Fountain for lunch.  I never knew this diner has been around since 1918, almost 100 years.  It looks a little beat from the outside, but the inside has a huge counter with small tables in the front and booths in the back.

Probably the thing that impressed me most about this place was the many options for food.  Not only do you get your diner style fare, but there are a lot of vegetarian/vegan options available.  This is what make St. Francis Fountain unique.  I order the vegan Reuben on rye which has spinach, mushrooms, vegan chorizo, onions and 1000 island dressing.  I opt out of the sauerkraut.  The sandwich was truly outstanding!  With it, I order a side of mac n cheese which is baked with a bread crumb topping.  Also delicious.

For dessert, we see they serve Mitchells Ice cream.  So we get a hot fudge sundae.  It comes with 2 scoops vanilla and instead of the 1 scoop chocolate, we substitute for 1 scoop of coffee ice cream.  Thankfully I share this and it's really delicious.  Takes me back to being a kid again.

Our waiter was friendly and super awesome.  Thank you very much St. Francis Fountain, you are really 6 stars for me!
author: Janet H.

description:
I'm super surprised to read the negative reviews of this place. It's my neighborhood greasy spoon and I love it.

Sure, the wait staff are all a bunch of hipsters. Like, almost too hip. But I've never received rotten service from any one of them. In fact, they seem to work together really well to bring out food, refill coffee and enjoy the workday. They have fun. They're nice. And it's the mission, hipsters come with the territory. Deal with it.

The food goes from being typical breakfast stuff to way above average breakfast stuff. I think I've had every brunch in the mission at this point, and I couldn't be happier that this is the place a few blocks from home.

The coffee is just OK, so you sometimes see people walking in with cups from Philz. I don't think they take offense, though. I mean, it's Philz. The greatest coffee on earth. What the hell can you do?

Plenty of vegetarian options that aren't just meat dishes without the meat. The mimosas are reasonably priced and plenty tasty. Other highlights:

- Super tasty breakfast burritos
- Veggie sausage
- Tasty potatoes
- This thing that I can't remember the name of that blows my mind. It's this patty of awesome. I'll go ahead and call it the Patty of Awesome, since that's what I'd call it if I ran the place. The POA has soyrizo, eggs, potatoes, a bunch of other stuff and sour cream. This thing, the POA, is the most filling breakfast plate you've ever seen and it's a perfect way to start (my) Sunday.
author: Vegasauras R.

description:
I recently went here with my best friends who were visiting from out of town. I've heard nothing but great things about this place and couldn't wait to give it a try. 

Unfortunately...

The waiters have that typical, "I'm really cool, so I'm only going to kind-of serve you and act annoyed if you ask for anything" attitude. This was especially poignant when we ran out of cream for our coffee. 

My meal confirmed my belief that hipsters don't actually like food. The soy-rizo that looks like it's in an intestine bag at Trader Joe's is WAY better than the crap their putting in their breakfast burritos here. The black beans were watery and flavorless. And "salsa salad" means some shredded iceberg covered in sopping generic grocery store salsa mush. GEEZ...Your restaurant is in the MISSION - have some pride in your mexican fare. 

All things considered, it wasn't so terrible that I couldn't eat it. But there are way too many great breakfast options in SF to consider coming back here.
author: Laura R.

description:
Cannot believe that I haven't discovered this place sooner. ACK!! Better late than never, right?

So, my gal, Dalane, recommended yet another gem, the St. Francis Fountain. She mentioned that this old diner was more of a brunch spot, but was open for dinner as well. We sat at a booth by the back, and got served right away. After perusing the lengthy menu, I immediately noticed that it was a Coke and not a Pepsi establishment!  The straws were paperesque and reminded me of a combo of a pixie stick and candy cane. How awesome! I already loved this place and haven't even eaten yet! 
For my pre-race dinner (as Kaiser 5K was early the next morning), I wanted something hearty, so the cheeseburger was calling my name, but was undecided on the sides. There were about 6 different sides to choose from (garden or chef or caesar salad, fries, mac and cheese, coleslaw, etc.,). Being the cheese freak, I had to get the mac and cheese! Service was speedy, and within minutes, our meals arrived. Burger was superb and juicy with fresh shredded lettuce and tomatoes. Could've done without the onions, pickles, and mayo, but tend to like my sammies on the dry side anyway. Wished the bun was a bit thicker, as it got a lil' soggy on the bottom. Regardless, it was delish and totally enjoyable! The mac and cheese was the perfect amount, topped with some bread crumbs for texture, and not oily at all! 

This place is reasonably priced (burger was about $7)! 
Holy cow, while perusing the candy counter, I saw NKOTB, Yo MTV Raps, Knight Ridder, Garbage Pail Kids, and 21 Jump Street collector cards!? Are you kidding me? How crazy awesome is that!? Jaw breakers, lollipops, and other sugary goodies were also available for sale. 

Undoubtedly, I'll be back at SFF! It's a great place for families, tourists, and locals. Next time, I'll definitely have brunch, and try an ice cream sundae or milkshake. They serve Mitchell's ice cream (which is this Mango freak's fav!)
author: Gill C.

description:
I'd never been to St. Francis Fountain-- had never heard of it.-- but it was in the right place for dinner. I was walking from the bus stop to the Brava Theater Center, and the St. Francis Fountain on my way.

Dinner was a BLT, macaroni and cheese, and a vanilla shake. Both the service at the counter and the food were good. (Milkshakes are definitely better through paper straws.) Not cheap, but I wasn't offended by the prices.

I'll definitely try it again, when I'm on that side of town.
author: Bruce S.

description: Delicious breakfast in an old diner setting. I loved it the ambiance, food, and customer service.
author: Jessica M.

description: This is one of my favorite breakfast places. I go for the tofu scramble with spinach, mushroom and peanut sauce - plus some added jalapeños for added zing. I order fruit instead of potatoes and dry whole wheat toast. Delicious - a yummy big breakfast. And pretty healthy. I highly recommend this place for a good vegan breakfast.
author: Christine S.

description:
St. Francis fountain I think intimidates people to a ridiculous extreme. Come on! It's so much fun. You can get away with keeping your sunglasses on at the counter (my preferred sitting arrangement) and a hangover cure is served-up faster than any other diner I've been to lately. Not only is the waitstaff fun to admire and chat with, but their damn good at their jobs. The coffee is bottomless and the food is the sour cream and cheese cure to any all night whiskey binge. I love that it's a fun place to be and that the cheap prices don't compromise the taste. 

It's becoming a great tradition in our circle of friends to pop by St. Francis every few Saturday or Sunday late brunch mornings. It's not the best for groups and the wait can be kind of silly in the rain, but in our little corner of the mission, there is no one else serving breakfast quite like them.
author: Nicole d.

description: This is my favorite breakfast spot.  SO GOOD.  Love the biscuits and gravy, and pretty much everything else on the menu.  Check it out.
author: Jennifer N.

description: OMG! This is my favorite place for breakfast!! They have some unique items, as well as your usual favorites. This spot is super cheap and super tasty! It can get crowded, but well worth it!!
author: Lucia A.

description: Nostalgic atmosphere. Breakfast all day. Tofu scrambles. Greasy meaty bacon bits in egg omelettes. Vegan sausage/chorizo/cheese. Veggie burgers. Cow burgers...the perfect diner for a vegan and carnivore to find peace.
author: Sarah X.

description:
Oh, St Francis Fountain, I love you so much that I feel my heart could burst just thinking about you....

This is definitely my favourite breakfast/brunch place!!!  I love the 50s style wooden booths, I love the little candy store part that sells collectable NKOTB and Cyndi Lauper cards and lollypops called 'sugar daddy' (I meant to buy one of those last time I was there, but forgot!) and I love how cheap it is!!! 

The milkshakes are a little piece of heaven (...or hell, depending on whether you are looking at it from the point of view of my tastebuds or my thighs - because I can't come here without getting a chocolate malt!) I am SO glad that they got rid of the stripey paper straws though, because as cute as they looked, they were impossible to use.  The last time I tried to drink through one of them I sucked so hard, I felt like my eyeballs were gonna pop out - and I still didn't get any milkshake through it.

The chef's mess is DE-LI-CIOUS.  And huge.  It's scrambled eggs mixed with bits of bacon, peppers, loooooads of cheese and topped with sour cream and salsa.  Sooooo good.

Oh and the pancakes!!!!  Bacon, cheese and onion pancakes!!!!  Bacon.Cheese.Onion.In.A.Pancake.  Yes really!!! You must try them!

I came here a couple of weeks ago and we had to wait quite a while (the wait can be looooong at peak brunch times on weekends), so I was ravenous by the time we got in and ordered everything on the menu... well, a milkshake, the chef's mess, toast, biscuits and gravy (delish), pancakes and cornbread (with jalapenos - yum! If not a little, teensy bit too greasy)...

The huevos rancheros is tasty, and I also have it on good authority that the veggie reuben is awesome, as is the breakfast burrito.

I've started to notice the staff around town, thinking I know them, and then realising they work at St Francis...

Now go get a milkshake, bacon cheese and onion pancakes and sit back and take in the sights of the skinny-jean wearing hipsters at this awesome place!  YUM! :)
author: Melanie B.

description:
The current incarnation of this old time diner (and one time sweet shop) appears to be suffering from it's current trendiness with the 20-something self-consciously cool set.  While more scene than substance, it's the atmosphere and service that suffer more than the reliable, if pedestrian, food.

Without much competition for diner fare in the area, it will satisfy your needs (especially for breakfast).  It's been a few years (and probably a management change) since I've sampled lunch and a shake.  However, I'd recommend sticking to mid-week breakfast; it can be busy on weekends even though they have now added sidewalk tables.

The service was mixed; split about 50/50 between helpful and disinterested staff.  I didn't enjoy the atmosphere due to both the seemingly bored staff members, which can't be ignored while seated at the counter, and the loud, poor quality music system and corresponding raised customer voices.  Outdoors would likely be a better choice on weekends.  On a weekday, the atmosphere is generally more relaxed.

On the other hand, if you are under 30 and looking to be part of a scene, the atmosphere may be a positive.  And, the cooks continue to produce competent versions of classic diner breakfasts.  Expect to spend slightly above average for a diner ($15 per person for breakfast).

Note: See "about me" for a description of my ratings.  I'll try to use the full range of stars and to be consistent with Yelp's start meanings.  Any rating above 1 star has something going for it.  I see many people give only 1 or 5 which defeats the purpose of having 5 star levels.
author: Jice E.

description: Loved the bird hamburger with sum bacon, guac and chedda cheese n the employees are real nice
author: Jess L.

description: I LOVE this place! Comfy and cozy and old-timey atmosphere. I got turkey, bacon, and cheese on grilled sourdough with fruit salad and it was just perfect. I will be back!
author: Claire b.

description:
I decided to get a vegan entree the day I went there since I like soy chorizo and tofu scramble hash.  But it was bland and not very good.  Luckily I got a side of pancakes of banana walnut that were delicious.  I imagine this is the type of place you should get traditional egg dishes at.  The tofu scramble/soyrizo ended up being good the next day and I'm guessing it is because the spices/oils had time to marinate into the tofu.  It didn't seem as bland the next day.  Make sure to get the Cherry Cola to ensure your diner experience.

Since this place is just around the corner from my house I'm sure I'll try it again.
author: Sabrina A.

description:
I'm pretty sure that diners are my favorite places to eat in the world.  They are such a staple in American culture, the 2nd home of locals and travelers alike, places where you can sit at the counter with a piece of pie and a thick-rimmed cup of coffee and hang your hat for a while.  

St. Francis fountain is representative of my favorite type of diner - one with real history, and with a menu that addresses today's dietary preferences without getting too far away from the Blue Plate Special of decades past.   

Breakfast?  Yep.  Burger and a shake? Yep, yep.  BLT and and Egg Cream, followed by a piece of cherry pie?  Yep, yep, yep.

OK, if all of the above has sold you, I do have to disclose one caveat.  SFF is a Hipster Mecca.  It's the St. Francis Fountain of the Tragically Hip - they runneth over and spilleth onto the street.  That factor can range from slightly to extremely annoying, depending on the length the line and your level of hunger and tolerance.  Since my level of hunger is always at a 10 and tolerance at a 3-4, this would usually keep me away.  However, I like it so much that I find ways to go at off hours in order to avoid killing everyone.  So, this means 11:30am, 3pm, or some such similar hour.

OK!  Back to the positive - GREAT candy counter.  One of the best I have seen.  Hours are just what you want them to be - 8 to 10 - time for breakfast, lunch and supper, and not conducive to late night munchies.  

Burgers and shakes rock, which is the test of diner-worthiness in my book.  Booths are small and date or gossip-session perfect.
author: Liz S.

description:
Sorta shocked I haven't reviewed St Francis yet.  I used to live across the street and would occasionally get breakfast to go and have a kickass hipster-free backyard picnic.  Those were the days...

Fast forward to now.  I have to get in a car and drive there.  I have to use their bathroom and I occupy my time on line by pretending I'm going to buy something at Candy Corner just like everyone else.  It all feels so pedestrian.

And yet - I keep coming.  I bring my family here. I bring non-SF friends here. In fact, about 70% of the time when asked the question, "Where do you want to go for brunch?" this is my answer.  

Things I love:
* Veggie chili two egg scramble with a side of cornbread and fruit instead of potatoes (can be a bit tough for the gut if paired with their drip coffee) 
* 3 side meal: mac & cheese, cilantro chicken soup, and a house salad. 
* Tasty drip coffee
* Vegan sausage two egg scramble with a side of toast and fruit instead of potatoes
* Guinness float
* Their breakfast burrito
* MILKSHAKES
* Nebulous potato thing (split with friends cuz it's huge)
* Mitchell's ice cream
author: Melissa Y.

description:
First things first, I really like St. Francis Fountain. It's an old soda fountain, which is neat, plus, it has counter seating, which is neat, and it has vegan food, which is peachy keen. 

BUT.

I've been to SFF a bunch of times now (10+), and each time I've identified myself as a vegan ("Can I get the tofu scramble, vegan style, please?"), and only yesterday was I informed that the homefries, which come standard with all tofu scrambles, are fried in BUTTER and therefore NOT VEGAN. Many thanks to the server who finally filled me  in, but it's too bad nobody mentioned it previously. Yeah, I know I should have explicitly asked, so it is my fault, but in a city like San Francisco, if you're going to be offering vegan-enticing options like tofu scramble and calling things vegan on your menu, you probably want to be clued in to the fact that vegans don't want to eat butter and that some of them are too hungry or caffeine deprived or just plain stupid* to ask outright if you've put butter in the potatoes. The customer is always dumb, after all. 

Anyway, I love the thai tofu scramble (with fruit or beans instead of homefries, *sniff*), and the coffee is always good, and so is the vegan chorizo and the veggie burrito swimming in a lake of tasty beans. I hear they have soy gelato as well and can whip up some vegan 'shakes, but when I tried to order one, they were sadly out of soy. 

In conclusion, I really do like St. Francis Fountain a lot but wish they would knock it off with the butter potatoes.

*just because we try to eat ethically doesn't mean we're smart!
author: Jordan P.

description:
Great kitschy diner.  Really friendly -- almost approaching over-the-top friendly -- service.  Yummy food.  You can believe all the other 5-star reviewers!  

But I'm actually going to focus on the milkshakes, specifically the espresso milkshakes.  OMG!  OMG!  OMG!  

They use Mitchell's ice cream.  Perfectly blended.  Perfectly thick.  Perfect.  Really, the best coffee milkshake I've ever had!
author: Bevy M.

description:
I agree with this place having 4 stars total.

Yummy food but steeper prices. Great inside feel but you also feel a little rushed [for some reason] when you dine-in. For the most part nice service (the waitresses having the "punk pin-up" look are cool additions to the neo-50s vibe in this place) and vegetarian friendly food (yay!).

I'm definitely a fan of SFF. It's been too long since I've been and will have to change that soon.
author: Kai S.

description: cute spot, they serve mitchell's ice cream...hoping that it was homemade ice cream.
author: Tiff W.

description:
St. Francis Fountain claims to be San Francisco's oldest ice cream parlor and it certainly feels that way. If it wasn't for all the hipsters, you might think you were in a "Leave It To Beaver" episode.

"Gosh, Wally, those skinny black jeans sure are swell."

"Aw shucks, Beav,(heh heh, Beav) don't be such a dope and gimme back my studded belt, willya."

Well, you get the picture. 

St. Francis Fountain has a fairly comprehensive menu with solid sandwiches and hamburgers and an awesome breakfast selection. The "Chef's Mess" I consumed five hours ago is still occupying a substantial portion of my belly...and I'm not complaining. The old school atmosphere even compelled me to order my first egg cream. Here's an interesting fact, an egg cream contains neither egg nor cream. Go figure.

If that's not enough, they also sell "Knight Rider" trading cards. Talk about old school.
author: Josua P.

description:
Here we go: hipster hipster hipster hipster whine whine whine hipster hipster skinny black jean namedrop some band that hipsters dont even listen to anymore hipster hipster hipster hipster hipster. 

Okay. 

Now we can move on. Did you know they also serve food here? They do and it is wonderful.  The menu is extremely similar to Boogaloo's , unfortunately, it's missing some of the real shining stars of the menu - namely the plantain cake and "fake stake". But, the wait is much shorter. I can live with that compromise.

I've finally come to realize that I don't actually enjoy eating eggs (with a few exceptions) and so I am happy that this place does a MEAN tofu scramble. Tofu scramble w/ ranchero sauce and avocado and tortillas = most awesome brunch of all time. 

I love writing reviews when I'm hungover! Woo!
author: Maria D.

description:
I love coming here with my 2 year old or on a night out with friends. It serves both purposes- good kid-friendly food, or good late dinner with friends. The people that work here look like your typical Mission District hipsters- which can throw you off because they are not the friendliest at times. 

The shakes, sundaes, and food are great. True old school diner food. The chef's mess is great! So are the burgers and sandwiches. The meals are huge. I usually cant finish them. My son loves the fries and grilled cheese. He loves the sundaes too. 

I love the candy bar too! I reminisce every time I come in! Hello- Garbage Pail Kids, 90210 trading cards! Who has those?!

The seats are small- but they are original.  I guess people were smaller in 1918 :)
author: Angela L.

description:
I give this place a 4, and I'll tell you why it didnt make the cut on 5.

My wife and I went here after eating dinner next door, and got a milk shake.  Awesome Dream Shake by the way (your "old school" straw will fall apart... as for a 2!).  However, our server (who was a brunette with a symmetrical bob hair cut) was rude and not that engaging, and looked at us weird after we ordered only ONE milk shake for the both of us.  We were being romantic you stooge hipster.  LOL

HOWEVER!!!  Don't let that fool you.  We went for breakfast and the service was AMAZING!!!  We had a server who took our order, and he was SO... SOOOOOO enthusiastic that it was like talking to one of my close friends!  I recommend them for breakfast on the weekends.  And don't sit outside (  cus that's where we sit!  pppppt!!!  :)p  )

Their menu is extensive.  What we ordered was AMAZING... I had veggie chorizo with poached egges and she had corn beef and hash with biscuits and the biscuits were AMAZING! Fresh O.J. too!!! Definitely, we are now local patrons of this place.  THANK YOU MORNING STAFF!!!  You guys were wonderful!!!  But to the girl, who seemed to be having a bad night... I'm sorry to have made you look like you just discovered poopie on your shoes.  Still... suck it up.

It could very well have been that at breakfast we were dressed a little more street/hipsterish, which in our case is more cholo mexicano style (since we are mexican americans - thanks hipsters for stealing our cultural style!!!) and for dessert we were a little more dressed up  (my wife is a fashion instructor at a local college).  Still, just because the mission is half Hipster, half Mexican community, doesn't give this PARTICULAR waitress the right to be an elitist or even act like one for that matter.  I've read some other reviews and she seems to be the odd one out.  It's unfortunate, but the service staff in the morning are worth one bad apple.

This is now our regular dining spot on Sunday mornings, and living only 4 blocks away helps.  Last time I we went we had the Griddle Combos, and Eggs Benedict.  BOTH WONDERFULLY DELICIOUS!!!

Note to staff and owner:  Remember, this is our neighborhood, respect that we are not tourists.  YOU NEVER KNOW!!!!!
author: Wel S.

description:
So fricken good!  Every breakfast I've had here has been perfect and has hit the spot!  

The Chef's Mess is perfect!  Potatoes, bacon, egg, mushrooms and cheese with a side of sourdough toast is perfection to me every time!

The Huevos Rancheros is one of the best I've had in the city.  Oh yeah, the sauce has just enough kick and is evenly spread over the eggs and tortillas, but I have to say the black beans with sour cream and cilantro were the clear winner!   

Oh yeah, forget the coffee and order the Espresso Vanilla Shake.  It's so the way to go!  So great and delicious! 

Everything here is awesome!  The wait staff is great and it's fast.  It's not over the top and completely a solid place for breakfast.
author: Valarie A.

description:
Okay. Now is when I reveal what a huge hypocrite I am. 

Boogaloo's is the devil's den, but St. Francis Fountain -- that OTHER hipster breakfast enclave in the Mission -- isn't so bad. In fact, it's pretty good. I like it, and when it's not busy, I'll sneak in for a vegan peanut butter milkshake and I will REALLY ENJOY IT.

Damn it. 

The difference between this place and Boogaloo's is... They have good food. Duh. They have good VEGAN food, too. I mean, man -- their vegan milkshakes are awesomely delicious. And I've always had good service here. 

My friend Sara and I boldly journeyed here for brunch in a torrential downpour when our office out on ends-of-the-earth-Marin-Headlands Beach was closed during the big storms at the beginning of January. We basically had the place to ourselves (only a torrential downpour and 60-mile-an-hour winds could keep the hipsters away; they're like the Wicked Witch of the West, you know; they melt in water!). And as pretty much the only customers, we had a great time with the servers. 

They taught me a thing or two about my new (psychotic) CrackBerry (further evidence that hipsters are hypocrites themselves when it comes to technology; see my Boogaloo's review: http://www.yelp.com/biz/boogaloos-san-francisco#hrid:Z9uvuBpgNtfjQWRsq6YABQ).   They served us delicious vegan sammies and fries that left me NOT complaining about wanting REAL diner food. AND...

I met the milkshake alchemist. 

On first glance, you'd never know the depth of skill this girl possesses. But she can make you any kind of milkshake under the sun -- totally vegan, and you'd never know it. The flavors she concocts, back in her wood-paneled kitchen laboratory... Hot damn. That particular day, I tried banana walnut, at her suggestion. Oh yeah.

So my beef with St. Francis is, of course, that we really only get downpours torrential enough to keep the hipsters away about once every couple months. So I'm usually passing the Fountain by, groaning at all the skinny jeans lined up outside as I move on to the Sun Rise a few blocks up 24th.

Therefore I can only give them three stars. And yes, I'm punishing them for their clientele. But just know that I really want to give them more, and be satisfied that I realize I'm a hypocrite. 

Hipsters make the best vegan milkshakes. There. I said it.
author: Lisa T.

description:
CHEF'S MESS!!

I am a huge fan of a great breakfast, and when I go out to breakfast in SF, St. Francis is always my first pick. I come first for the Chef's Mess, a scramble with eggs, potatoes, bacon, tomatoes, green onions, cheese, and whatever else. I come second for the great location in the Mission and the cute hipsters that work here. 

Not sure where else I can buy a pack of Pee Wee's Play House trading cards while enjoying a great cup of coffee and breakfast. 

I didn't go for the full five stars only because some of their other breakfast entrees haven't looked that great. I can't stray from the Mess, so I can't say for sure, but I've brought friends here who haven't been blown away with their food.
author: Stacey J.

description:
We didn't have enough tattoos to sit inside, so we were forced to sit outside. I kid, it was actually a brilliant day, perhaps too warm, and sitting outside under the awning was fun. 

Come here on a Sunday and expect a long wait - but there is no difference between here and any other brunch place in that regard. The food is pretty good, and they have a couple of brilliantly named items on the menu - the Nebulous Potato Thing and the Chef's Mess. There is a Guiness float on the menu that was much ballyhooed during our wait, but no one ordered one. Maybe next time. And maybe I'll don some temporary tattoos so I can sit inside and actually rate this as a diner.
author: neil c.

description:
No, I do not think ordering a chocolate milkshake at breakfast is "aggressive." 

I love when you look at a menu and there are so many tasty vittles on there that the excite just overwhelms you like a tidal wave of deliciousness and good vibes. 

That is how I feel about St. Francis. You can opt for every egg dish as either a 2 egg scramble or a 3 egg omelet. Seriously, why is this the first time I've seen this! 
Does this kind of breakfast related ingenuity only live South of Mission? 

For your "toast" you can opt for corn bread, biscuit (bomb!), banana bread, or a wide variety of toast. 

Let me repeat that: banana bread, corn bread or biscuit! 

Man, how many people's Nanas do they have chained up back there baking this stuff! 

Absolutely delicious. I'll be back.
author: Gabe b.

description: The food here was great. I've had the side platter with soup, mac and cheese, and salad and have also had the tofu scramble and a banana milkshake. The food was great BUT the service is lacking. The staff is unhelpful and act like you should be honored to be at their cool restaurant. But for good food I can get over bad service sometimes.
author: Samantha C.

description:
Hello Milkshake! more specifically Hello Caramel Milkshake!

This was the perfect way to start a new week in San Francisco. We put our name on the list and waited for a total of whopping 5 minutes. I had the country breakfast and mmm hmmm I love those biscuits n gravy. Since I saw those milkshakes I figured I should get one too and I went for caramel. Good choice. 

The staff is funny and personable. Good food and a great staff is definitely a way to keep everyone coming back.
author: Maria A.

description:
Last Sunday afternoon found me groggy and in need of nourishment. My boyfriend (AT THE TIME, for all you stalkers just waiting for me to enter back into the dating world), who seems to get all of his calories from beer and whiskey, couldn't quite wrap his mind around my suggestion that we go out and get some brunch. Once I explained to him that MOST people require food, especially after a long night of drinking, he suggested St. Francis.

On the walk there, however, he began grumbling about it. Saying it would probably be a long wait to get a table, and moaning and groaning about the "hipsters" that hang around. It almost made me suggest that we try something else instead, but I'm not familiar with the Mission at all, so I stuck to the original choice.

Complaining about wait time and hipsters seem to be very common complaints for this place. Perhaps we were lucky, because we were able to just walk in and take a seat. A waitress came up pretty quickly and took our drink orders, and I was finally able to get that cup of coffee I so desperately needed.

We took to inspecting the menu and I quickly got overwhelmed. While my brain did somersaults as I tried to decide which out of, like, a GAZILLION, combinations of scrambles or omelets I wanted, my boyfriend groaned from across the table.

"Oh god, they're everywhere!" 

Freaked out, I immediately thought that there were bugs somewhere and I was ready to scream and run to the hills. But it dawned on me that he meant hipsters.

I looked around. 

Well, I guess there were a lot of "hipsters" there. I'm starting to think the word "hipster" is something applied to anyone that is thin, wears tight pants, and is under the age of 30. Frankly people, you're eating food at a restaurant on THE MISSION. Please tell me what you expect to find? 

I ordered a two-egg scramble with feta and spinach, and it came out pretty quickly. I'm normally not a potato fan (ironic, considering i'm irish as hell) but their potatoes rocked my mouth off! They were crunchy and well-seasoned. The scramble was just the right size, too. And there was plenty of feta to make me happy. It seemed a little crazy that my meal cost almost $10, but hey, being hip doesn't come cheap.

The service was kind of weird. All the people that came to our table were cool, though! But one girl took our orders, one girl gave me coffee, a DIFFERENT girl brought our food, and then some dude gave me a coffee refill. But whatever, I could care less, because everything they did was fast and friendly enough. They can't be TOO happy, you know. That wouldn't be cool.
author: Pamela D.

description:
Yummmy, yummmy.
Had a wholesome malt-shop date on friday night and I loved it.
This is the place to swoon and make "googly-eyes" at each other while sharing a classic hot fudge sundae generously topped with whipped cream nuts and yes a cherry. 
*AND* They have an all soy shake.
*AND* They serve a Guinness float.
I'm inspired to have a party here poodle-skirts and letterman jackets required. . .
author: Kia B.

description:
Reason to Come Back: Historical Value

Service Sucks and is over priced

I remember this place from my childhood, such fond memories!  Unfortunately those memories don't bring me back since new management took over the service of this place doesn't seem to want to cater to the Latino community which makes up the neighborhood.  Anthony is right this place reeks of attitude and pretense.  The prices definitely keep locals away.
author: A P.

description: One of the oldest diners in San Francisco, if not the oldest. The breakfast is really great here. Really great. At breakfast places I usually freak out and end up ordering WAY too much food - say two courses - and a side, and can never eat all of it. St Francis is one of those places, where even though there is an obscene amount of food in front of me, I can't help, but stuff it down. It's that good. Their chocolate pancakes are incredible, like big fluffy chocolate chip cookies, and their hashbrowns are perfect - salty, with a little bit of spice.  St. Francisc Fountain is also pretty famed for their milkshakes. I keep on meaning to try one, but never do....next time, next time.
author: Jessica T.

description:
Went in the mid-afternoon on a Monday before the playground with a little kid - people there but not crowded, so got to sit right down.  Nice waitstaff.  Soda fountain/diner style food - some updated & modern twists on things, veg/veegs options.  It was just fine.  I liked the chili and I like that they sell trading sticker cards too!  
PS I'm pretty sure the trading cards are authentic, the ones I got were dated 1986, the gum uhhhhh not so much a good idea to mow down on.
author: Dizzy L.

description:
Aw, St. Frannie's. A brunching institution, serving up hipster grease on the side (seriously, sometimes the servers here look a little...unshowered. But I'm not complaining, really). 

Anyhow, they've always indulged the seemingly Algonquin round table we end up being every weekend (table for 3! um, now 6, ok, 9!) without blinking an eye. They make a mean milkshake and put up with our crass last-night recaps shouted back and forth across the table. I docked them one star because they ran out of tofu on New Year's day, which after a 2 hour wait is unforgivable, in San Francisco.
author: Melissa G.

description:
St Francis is my new favorite-I have no money but still want to eat out-place.  Everything is super affordable, large portioned, and really tasty.
My friend closed his menu after about 30 seconds, and I was not long after.  I asked him are you having the country breakfast?  He's said yup, I said me too!  2 eggs your choice, home fries, and biscuits and gravy $7.50.  Are you serious?
What gets me the most is the service.  They must make these hipsters take happy pills.  I have never seen more pleasant, helpful, smiley vintage t wearing kids in my time in SF.  No surly, better than you attitude here!
author: Sarah M.

description:
I love that they serve vegan fake meats with cheese.  Its so contradictory. (but makes perfect sense-vegans can take off the cheese).

I wonder if the server's are told to be extra nice.  Its so nice it is borderline questionable/fake.

 Love the food.  I can't say its the best food but the overall vibe, ice cream, price, food, and staff make it worth multiple visits.
author: Amber L.

description:
Um, if we had a contest to see just WHO's milkshake brought all the boys to the yard, St. Francis Fountain would win...hands down. Just take a step inside their old-school, vintage-style establishment and take a look around. It brought the boys, the girls, the out-of-towners (read: me), the hipsters, the tattooed kids, the skater crowd and even the families.

Sorry Kelis, but you're milkshake's got nothin' on St. Francis. Why? You can get a thick, rich shake here with soy, in over ten flavors. I am sure you're milkshake only comes in one. And if that's not enough, they serve up some serious brunch items. Biscuits with sausage gravy? Um, my plate was clean when the waitress finally cleared it. Yep, I mopped up all that gravy with those biscuits. Not a speck left.

If you're in the area...hell, if you're in the state, find a way to hit up St. Francis and see for yourself. You'll never set food in the yard for anyone else again.
author: Leighann F.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here for dinner last night and really enjoyed it!  The sandwiches, fries, and salad were great. 
The atmosphere was really nice - it's a little bit harder to find places that are cozy and old-school like that in San Francisco. 

The only thing that bothered me (and kept me from rating it with 5 stars) is a policy that they apparently have.  Two people sat down in the back booth and were waiting for the rest of their party to arrive, when one of the waiters/busboy/whatever came over and borderline yelled at them over the St. Francis policy they have that doesn't allow people to sit unless the whole party is with them.  I think that he was rude and that the policy is a bunch of crap.  If you have people sitting down, and they are expecting more, OBVIOUSLY they are going to order a bunch of food and are PATRONIZING your establishment in the first place.  How the busguy treated the two customers made ME feel uncomfortable just being in earshot of the conversation.  The restaurant was NOT busy at that time, so the whole thing was completely unnecessary. 
Ultimately, you are operating your restaurant FOR the people that frequent you, and by making silly rules that enforce your wait staff to be unpleasant to paying customers, you may have ensured that quite a few people don't ever come back.
author: Rachelle P.

description:
I can certainly understand how someone might be turned-off by the hipster vibe of this place.  With A-Team trading cards and a Seattle grunge circa 1990 waitstaff, the place can give that impression.  

I was a little unimpressed my first time there and they wouldn't let my friend and me  sit anywhere other than at the counter...because the rush was about to start.  Well, 45 minutes later, the place was still empty.  Just was well.  The service that day was indifferent, but the breakfast was tasty.  Great French Toast!  I returned on a busy Sunday with three little ones in tow.  We were well accommodated, given good attentive service and again, the food was pretty darn good.  

I have to confess to having always liked diners such as this and I give St. Francis points for being cool, but not too cool and giving great food for a reasonable price. One of my favorites in SF for breakfast.
author: Charlie B.

description:
Being new to the neighborhood, we stopped in here for an early dinner/snack, lured in by the soda fountain and promise of a chocolate malt. We were not disappointed.

The food is just fine (the "nebulous thing" of home fries is pretty tasty,) but the service was kinda slow and I didn't leave with lightness of step. I'll definitely try it again, though.

Update: perfect place to go when you want breakfast at 9pm on a Monday night! Super friendly, helpful service...
author: Arwen O.

description: Great decor and the best chicken soup I have ever had - but my oh my the prices are ridiculous, the staff are always on some sort of weekend warrior come down (and I don't care if you have fantastic tattoos and a wonky haircut).  The LAST time I went in here it took 25 mins to get a shake and being 8 months pregnant you'd think they'd have hurried the fu#@ up!
author: Jo H.

description:
There are a number of reasons why I believe this place to be absolute tops when it comes to Bay Area brunch.  The diner has a traditional aesthetic to love.  Like any true diner, it features a bar that can accommodate lots of customers.  St. Francis is not a large establishment, but even on a busy Sunday the wait was not long at all.  

A few items that made this place worth the wait were the Nebulous Potato Thing and the old fashioned Dream Shake (complete with paper straws).  One thing I just can never turn down are the traditional biscuits and gravy; a dish that St. Francis has perfected seemingly just for me.

St. Francis Fountain earns five stars from me for taking a traditional American diner setting/menu and adding a very genuine dose of creativity to the formula.  They do a great job welcoming the latin flavors and influences from the neighborhood and translating them into a lengthy delicious menu that has something for everyone.  

Thanks for taking credit cards.  Service is fast and friendly.
author: Chadwick F.

description:
one of the first restaurants I went to when visiting this city.
I now live here and love coming to dine at this fine establishment
I have never had any bad customer service and the waiters are INSANELY POLITE and courteous.
great food selection and great shakes.
The only downside is the wait in the morning for breakfast...thats it,
but the wait is worth it
love this place and love the neighborhood
author: Alex M.

description:
If George McFly had been a hipster instead of an actual nerd, he'd have bought his chocolate milks at St. Francis fountain. This joint is a real retro prize, not one of those phony-ass 1950s chrome diner replicas. It's tiny, has more counter seating than booths, and everything is wood and formica. Ahhhhh...formica. Me like-ah!

Food is everything you'd expect: basic egg dishes, grilled sandwiches + fries, and milkshakes for dessert. It's all good. A Chef's Mess (scrambled eggs, bacon, taters, avocados, green onions, tomatoes and sour cream in a lovely, gigantic pile) will do you right. 

St. Francis even has a candy counter...although I doubt George McFly would have much interest in ironic "Magnum, P.I.," and "Gong Show" trading cards. When did Topps and Fleer become such trendy pussies that they make bullshit disposable cards for bullshit disposable hipstards?

Ahhh...but I forgive. Some of those hipster women are damn cute, no matter how high-maintenance their faux-hemian fashion sense may be. If you wanna feel the 1.21 "jiggawatt" buzz of swarming hipster bees, St. Francis is most definitely the place. And, of course, you can try to pick them up using the words of George McFly himself: "I am your...density."

It's too bad the prices aren't as 1955 as the decor, or else I'd drive the DeLorean here every day.
author: John G.

description:
I'm glad this place rocks because it's my nearest full service breakfast joint.  To say I enjoy the food here is an understatement.  I love their food.  It's good quality and damned tasty.  Plus the staff, despite their hipster clothes and complicated hairdos, is genuinely nice.  Really.

Stand outs for me have been the waffle, the savoury pancakes (How about a little cheddar chive action? Now that's what I'm talking 'bout!), the large potato dish (similar to the "Nebulous Potato Thing" at Boogaloo's), the eggs, the chili, and the milkshakes.  The milkshakes are truly transcendent.  Plus a large one is big enough to share.  

So get yer ass over to the St. Francis, beat the weekend crowds by hitting up for breakfast or lunch during the week.  Although that means you'll miss this little guy with the mullet who is literally my favorite waiter of all time.  He's just nice.  Really truly nice.
author: Bryna M.

description:
I live nearby and love breakfast food and veggie burgers. You'd think St. Francis and I would be a match made in heaven...but alas, one measly star. I have been here at least 7 or 8 times because I really wanted to like it! I am now resigned not to go back.

I'll break it down like this:
Food: 3.5
Price: 1
Atmosphere: 1
Service: 1
Neighborhood: 4

Portions are big and food is good diner- style, but over- priced. The wait staff could use a bath, a training on health code and a serious attitude adjustment ( the last comment refers to one staff member in particular, the rest of the waiters and waitresses are nice.) 

The last straw for me was a very negative experience with the aforementioned waitress, who forced 5 of us to squeeze into one of their very tiny booths. If the group had been all small people it wouldn't have been as uncomfortable but there were three large men among us. She was extremely rude about it, not even allowing us to move into one of the slightly larger booths or pull up a chair because of "fire code." After about 15 minutes of practically sitting in each others laps, another waitress came by and took pity on us and pulled up a chair. As we were walking out, we saw the same waitress behind the counter with an unlit cigarette in her mouth. Yuck! She must have been having a very bad day. Nonetheless, I won't be back.

Atmosphere is cute, but I can't handle the grumpy hipster crowd on weekend mornings. The neighborhood is about the only good  thing this place has going for it.
author: Chris L.

description:
Yelp seems to have a seriously unhealthy fascination with the idea of "hipster." Who the heck do you think was populating diners in the 50's? Probably some sassy teenagers. Nothing changes. Get over it. Shove some food in your maw and enjoy life as it happens. If you're really going to be bugged by who's around you when you eat, you need therapy, not a delicious milkshake of love.

That said, I'm about to call St Francis for my usual cheeseburger to go, because I live a block away and I work from home. Sometimes when I'm really sad I get into bed to eat it while reading a book. So awesomely decadent, and this is from an ex-vegetarian.  I'm moving to the East Bay soon (priced out of the Mission) and I'll miss it. A lot. 

I've also had a number of first dates here. I recommend it highly. Don't let my track record with the boys scare you. It's not the waffles, it's me.
author: tamera f.

description:
Excellent burger served on a sesame seed bun. It is a no frills burger that is executed according to the book. Definitely in the upper echelon of all SF burgers and by far the best diner burger I've had in SF. Fries are okay, not phenomenal.

They use Mitchell's ice cream, so you know their shakes, sundaes and other ice cream offerings are legit.

I'm also a fan of the chili, mac n cheese, pancakes and biscuits.
author: Adam L.

description: I found this place on Yelp while searching for chocolate chip pancakes--and it didn't disappoint!  The menu and atmosphere are similar to Boogaloos, but it's less overrun with hipsters (perhaps owing to its location on the eastern border of the Mission).  As a bonus, Justina was ecstatic to find some Dark Crystal trading cards at the vintage candy/tchotchke counter.  Oh, and you have to admire a menu that offers you "Nebulous Potato Thing" (their answer to Boogaloos' "Temple of Hash").  St. Francis Fountain is an instant addition to our short list of Sunday brunch haunts.
author: Joe H.

description: THe milshake I had was good, very thick. However unbelievably overpriced at $7 for a large shake. Shake was good, not outstanding in any way
author: Rahul G.

description:
I'm Lorelai Gilmore and I approve this breakfast: mint chip milkshake and french fries.

I'm Katie and I disapprove of this breakfast: mint chip milkshake and french fries; however, it sure was tasty. I chose to get a milkshake with flavored ice cream, but you can also go with the vanilla + flavored syrup combination if that's what floats your boat. The small was plenty big (enough for a regular fountain glass) and came with a very generous amount of whipped cream topped with a maraschino cherry. 

Any milkshake made with Mitchell's ice cream is bound to be good, and this one was quite good, but it could have used a few more seconds in the blender. Also, I love that they are trying to keep as many things from the old days as possible, but the paper straws are awful. (If you want to be eco-conscious, use compostable straws made from cornstarch.)

Milkshake scale: Most of the boys to the yard (http://www.yelp.com/list/how-many-boys-do-their-milkshakes-bring-to-the-yard-san-francisco)

P.S. The fries were pretty tasty.
P.P.S. I really want to go back for a real breakfast--their menu is extensive and has a whole lot of delicious-sounding options.
author: Katie I.

description:
Where uber hipsters go to dine.......
Honestly the addittude was so thick when I walked through the door, I'm surprised we were able to get a table. Our server had that air on nonchalance/indifference that makes me want to punch someone. I came here hungover, wanting comfort food and expecting great things. What I got was a snotty server, mediocre and lukewarm food and much irritation.
Honestly I do not get they hype. Did I come on an off day? Was that server an anomaly? I would love to think so because the menu looks great, the location is excellent, the old skool diner thing is totally my bag but for me the St. Francis failed miserably. Boo!


*** I don't have a problem with hipsters,  I just had a problem with the hipsters working here on the day I went in, they were all assholes.
author: Catty C.

description: I  LOVE this place not only because it has been around since 1918 but because the food is original and sooooo good. I was trying to be healthy that day and decided to get the french toast delight with yogurt, fruit & a sprinkle of granola. The french toast was light and fluffy and had an interesting crunch to it because of the granola. This place will have a line so prepare to wait. Service was attentive, decor was amusing, price was decent (under $12-$14) and food was amazing. I'm a fan now :)
author: Nancy Y.

description:
St. Francis Fountain is a really cute old fashioned soda fountain/diner, with a solid classic breakfast and lunch diner menu plus some creative additions. 

Noteworthy item: cheddar, bacon and green onion buttermilk pancakes... go ahead, put the syrup on 'em - sounds wrong, tastes so right.
author: rachel m.

description:
This place is such a scene... aannd i love it.  

I am willing to admit that all I want is to make a quick dash to the park on weekend mornings to jam in a full day of people-watching; but I am also willing to admit that I am usually too worn out from the night before to make it there before like, 3 or 4pm.  Problem solved:  St. Francis offers you Dolores-esque people watching, but with the welcomed addition of the things you need most on a weekend morning:  coffee, grease, and probably a milkshake.  

Notes to be "useful":  HUGE menu, dope vegan/vegetarian options -- including soy shakes and tofu scrambles, usually a wait (about 20 mins for a 4-top), great for takeout, must be tattooed to work there, the Chef's Mess is the best breakfast item on the menu.

I heart breakfast... and in the words of Michael S: "I heart hipsters" as well.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
I'd like to order the corned beef with hash but hold the ATTITUDE!

Man, I feel like I am an easy going guy and give people the benefit of the doubt but this place brought out my inner scrooge...where do I begin.

First of all...three empty booths  no sign of a mob coming in any time soon and the guy wouldn't let me and my partner sit in a booth because they're expecting a rush.  It's christmas eve and the weather is crappy outside!  What is he thinking about a rush???  Ok, so we sit by the window...

The waitress comes over like she could care less about anything.  Yeah, it''s Christmas Eve and she has a crappy waitress job but please show some kind of interest.  She plops the coffee down on the table and spills it (no "oops, sorry about that"), she treats the corned beef with hash (unfortunately with extra TUDE) the same way and to top it off, she totally ignores us when we try to ask for jam or jelly to go with our toast.  And the icing on the cake is when she gave us our bill and I wanted her to add some Duran Duran collector cards (I know....I know) on the tab and she added $8!  The sign clearly said $2 and I bought 3 (I know...I know) so either she failed basic math or typed in the wrong key.

Anyway, for mediocre food, it's not worth getting your inner Scrooge brought out by the surly and careless service.
author: Joe O.

description: Researched all day breakfast on yelp and decided on St. Francis.  I left at 3 and decided to walk the 45 minutes to work up appetite.  When I got there at 3:45, the sign on the door said closed--right next to the hours that said they were open until 9 on Sundays.  I checked the website, which also said they were open until 9. Someone  inside saw me and came to the door and confirmed they were closed for the day. I'm sure the food is great, but make sure they are open before you head over!
author: Erin C.

description: This place is pretty awesome. From the 50s ice cream shop theme to the vegan and vegetarian options makes this place a good find. The prices are fair and the service is always quick.
author: Kate D.

description:
I do not normally write reviews, but I feel that it is necessary. SO... it all started because I had had a long day and was doing laundry last week. I live near the St. Francis so imagine the temptation of a strawberry shake since my throat was hurting and I felt like I was getting sick. My friend happened to be picking up a to-go order and asked them to make it for me. I continually stopped by only to be ignored or assured that it was being made. I finally made it back after giving the servers plenty of time to finally complete the task of a small shake in a restaurant with only 5 customers in it. 

When I walked in, a male server walked up to me immediately and asked me to leave my SERVICE DOG outside. When I respectfully responded that she's a service animal, he responded with a snide, "well if you don't have papers then she really can't be in here." I never understand why people think I would need papers for my service dog that has a California Service Dog tag. I picked her up and said, "she has a tag, see?" As I held the tag out for him to read he asked me to still wait outside since it was a "to-go" order. 

Yes, yes, it's good customer service to ask me to wait outside when it's cold and I have sore throat, just because you don't like that I have a service dog. Nevermind--the fact that I was waiting on a simple shake for 30 minutes! It took me a split second to decide that I wasn't going to put up with anymore rude hipsters. Ultimately, the overpriced oily diner food is not worth fake smiling hipsters that are only there to look good. I give this place 5 thumbs down. I still don't understand why a server would waste the time to kick a service dog out instead of just making the shake and keeping a customer.
author: Sheerein H.

description: A seriously authentic place to treat your self to an experience and good food - well good San Francisco - great Americana!
author: James-Jimm P.

description:
Unnngh...

That's how I usually feel when I head in here for a Sunday hangover brunch.  And in spite of the excruciating wait, I always feel great when I leave, the food is just that good.

It's impossible to list the ways that this place rules, but I'll try - first the food, it comes out fast, hot and always perfect.  The nebulous potato thing rocks my world.  Second the decor...  gd, I love all the old fixtures in this place.  It's like stepping back in time to come in here, despite the uber-hip waitstaff.  Finally, even tho, yes, all the waiters are super hipsters, they're also all really nice.  No one's pissy at this place, so it must be a decent place to work.  The owner is also really cool and down to talk about the place in detail if you catch him at the right time.

This place is good for the heart, wallet and belly - doesn't get better than that.  The only reason I give it four stars is the wait in the mornings, even though it's part of the charm it's not for everyone.
author: Quietine X.

description:
I never get excited going here, I dunno why, I think it's the squished feeling I get in their booths. Maybe it's just me but I feel like 2 years ago the booths were a little bigger then one time I came in and the booths were squeezed together so close I felt like I was in skinny jeans.  I was ready to pop like the girl in Willy Wonka that needed to be juiced.

It seems like the hiring policy instead of requiring flare requires tattoos, which is endearing. I heart hipsters. 

Food is good, I wish they had pepper grinders with real peppercorns. I would definitely bump up the stars. They even have vegan/lactose-free options for milk-shakes! Pretty cool.
author: Michael S.

description:
I live three blocks away.  I think the proximity to St Francis accounts for at LEAST a 15% mark up on rent in this area.  Still, I hold no grudges.

I'm that girl who always gets the same 2 or 3 items no matter where she goes. At Cha-Am I order pad thai.  At In-N-Out I'll order Pad Thai (I can pull some strings).  At St Francis I'll order the two egg scramble with avocado, cheddar, cilantro, and salsa with the buttermilk buiscuits or the cornbread.  Oh Dear Lord just thinking about it is making me salivate all over my keyboard.

Also, this may just be by chance, but I'd like to think I have some sort of special give-me-free-things aura about me:
2/3 of visits result in me consuming FREE ICE CREAM.

Is there anything better than free ice cream?  I have yet to find it.  If you have any suggestions, you can send them my way and I'll be sure to investigate for my formal report on the subject.
author: Mari C.

description: The bacon is sooo good here! I have been going to St. Francis for a couple years now since moving to SF. I lived only a few blocks away so at first the convenience of it was a big selling point. Then, I tried the food. It's delicious!! Nothing fancy just good, solid food. The atmosphere is relaxed and the place oozes mission style. The waiters are always very nice and the service is great. Now, I live directly across the street. I never want to be any further from St. Francis Fountain than I am now. I am probably going there right now for a mint chip milkshake!!
author: Martin G.

description: I used to love this place and go there all the time.  I stopped going after they removed my favorite item--City Slicker (Veggie) Biscuit and Gravy.  It's a crying shame.
author: Napoleon R.

description:
Veggie 'rito in the morning, veggie 'rito in the evening, veggie 'rito at supper time, extra salsa and please hold the dairy. 

I just ADORE the service here! Especially that little brown haired lass with the darling umbrella tattoo on her ankle. Seriously. What a doll!
author: Lisa H.

description:
I started going to St. Francis years ago -- primarily because there was always a crush-worthy waitress or two. It quickly became a comfortable spot for me to have a late breakfast or early lunch and just read the paper and chat with other friends from the neighborhood. 

I'm a glutton for grilled sandwiches and St. Francis is always happy to make my special order and serve it up fast and tasty. They are one of the few establishments (bars included) where I can order a poinsetta and not have to explain to the server that it's a mimosa with cranberry instead of orange juice.

People seem to throw the hipster term around a lot on yelp. I decided to look it up on wikipedia and discovered I've been a hipster since 1986.  My apologies for ruining everything for all ya'll with 401ks and SUVs.
author: Tuffy M.

description: Service was way normal this time, so I'm giving St. Francis the full 5 stars it deserves.  Seriously, the food is great and SO cheap. And plus a million for serving breakfast all day.  I get pancakes cravings at the oddest hours...
author: Richa A.

description: WOW. Severely unimpressed. I've been here multiple times on dead weekday mornings. When brunch came up in conversation on one Saturday morning I highly recommended this place because I love it. We showed up and posted our name. When the host told us the table was almost ready and the folks sitting there were about to leave...we got our hopes up too soon. The folks sitting there just camped out for 45 minutes. Since we had a big group of 6 we had to wait for a specific table. The patrons were rude enough to just sit and talk without noticing the line of people waiting for their seats, and the host didn't do much in part of hurrying them along...some post-brunch chatting is fine, but for nearly an hour is not.
