author: Jennifer P.

description: After going here and only getting coffee quite a few times (it's' pretty good) I decided to actually try the food. The line is not going to be as long as boogaloo's (I promise) and you can still get delicious biscuits and "gravy".. or a milkshake if you'd rather. Instead of dealing with Valencia you can take a nice bike ride out to St. Francis. It's right across the street from Pop's if you feel like getting started on the boozin' right after breakfast.. probably the only time Pop's is tolerable anyway. Anyway, I digress.. I totally approve of St. Francis!
author: katharine s.

description:
The fam and I have found another good local breakfast spot to add to my list. St. Francis may be old-fashioned, but their new-school menu caters to all- even "veg-heads." We've ordered a vegan chorizo 2-egg scramble and a chicken, avocado, and jack 3-egg omelette. The vegan chorizo is even more tasty than regular chorizo! For the ambitious, you can "thing" your spuds (homefries) with cheese, salsa, sour cream, and green onions. With my breakfast, I had a very smooth large espresso shake! Perfect! Prices are hearty- fortunately so is the food! 

As first-timers, service was good overall. And yes, as mentioned in all other reviews, you'll find a hip all-female wait staff with ink galore. Hate 'em or love 'em, try the food first.
author: Leroid D.

description:
When I lived at the corner of 24th and York Street a while back, a friend asked me, "Isn't it difficult to, you know, live across the street from a bar?"

I ignored the perceived weaknesses and implied behavioral downfalls. Giving this question much thought, I answered "I can go anywhere and get alcohol. It's much more difficult living across the street from a place that will make me a chocolate malt or hot fudge sundae."

I gained 15 pounds living in that house...

... But it wasn't ONLY because of the ice cream treats. It was the Reuben Sandwich, the decent burger, the GUINESS FLOATS, the breakfasts... The MAC N' CHEESE (best in the city?)... It could have been anything, but the Mitchell's ice cream concoctions certainly didn't hurt. I think I may have eaten several salads here, too, but those weren't immediately suspect in my impending poundage- delicious as I suspect them to have been.

Sitting at that counter on a Saturday morning may have encapsulated some of my favorite moments in this city.

The St. Francis is an old school Soda Fountain restored faithfully to retain its charm. The 'jerks' have been replaced with indie chicks serving the reasonably-priced diner fare, so if 'hipsters' make you feel uncomfortable or self-conscious, you may not enjoy this place AS MUCH.

Enjoy, but don't enjoy too often...
author: Ben R.

description:
I live in the Inner Mission and used to be a fan of this place ... but the last two times that my wife, son and I have gone there we've gotten terrible service ... in the case of this morning it was flat-out rude.

Today (12/27/10 around 11 am) we brought over 5 family members visiting from out of town, so there were 8 of us total.  We signed up on the outside sheet and were told it would be about 15 minutes ... 15 minutes later we were told it would be another 15 minutes but we noticed there were 8 seats at the counter in two groups of 4 and, since we were the next names on the list, we requested to be seated there.

When a couple in our party started sitting at the counter the 20- (or 30?) something brunette gal behind the counter practically lost her mind ... she told us it was too crowded and to wait outside until she had our tables ready ... when I reminded her that we were the next names on the list, there were 8 stools available, and no tables open, she glared and barked "I want you to wait outside."

Well, that's the last time we go to St. Francis or recommend it to anyone ... instead we wound up at SunRise Cafe a little farther down 24th Street - better food, better service, better experience BY FAR.
author: LEONARD H.

description: My husband is vegetarian and I'm vegan at the moment. When we were in town looking for a brunch place I was excited to find somewhere that offered me more than a tofu scramble. I had vegan blueberry pancakes and sausage which was delicious and satisfying. My husbands potatoes were amazing. The staff were very friendly and attentive even though we were there during a busy Saturday morning. Looking forward to go back and try a soy milkshake!
author: Brandi S.

description:
I love the 50's!!! The cute everything about it. Well except for the rare woman in the workforce thing.

I love their menu with the reasonable prices & vast selection of everything you expect not only a soda fountain to be, but a diner to be as well. 

You could stop in for some ice cream, or a full on meal & leave nothing but happy.

& the candy counter!!!!! Where else could you find a pack of Dallas trading cards, NKOTB cards & candy buttons all reasonably priced & not on ebay?

This place is SWELL!!
author: Rebekah K.

description: HELLA HIP. Come here for breakfast, pretty good.
author: Hana G.

description:
What a Fantastic Place.  Amazing Service, Great Food, Awesome Vintage Trading Cards. 

I LOVE IT
author: Sarah Megan R.

description:
Okay, Okay, let me first say I love this place because it makes me (as a young 20-something) feel at home since the wait staff is real young too, I love the ambiance and camp feel to it totally awesome.

Look if you like deserts then this where the buck stops because this place doesn't play around they do up deserts like you wish they would from the old 1950's with the soda jerks and all. The food's pretty good, sometimes it falls to decent based on what you order. 

My advice stick to Breakfast, Burgers, anything w/ chili as well as Deserts and avoid the soups. Until next time
author: Sean V.

description:
Okay...yes...I'm giving St. Francis 5 stars.  This is not to say that it is making food on the same level as Coi or any other place I have given high marks to, but it is at the top of its game and delivers 5 stars in the HUNG-OVER BRUNCH CATEGORY.

Oh my ice-skating Christ...the "Chef's Mess" might be heaven on earth.  It is a plate sized omelette containing all the awesomeness you have ever wanted in an omelette including hash, the perfect amount of cheese melted throughout, and topped with a heaping amount of sour cream.  I took a bite of this masterpiece and promptly moistened the front side of my boxer shorts.  Yeah...its that tasty.  The corned beef hash was fantastic as was the kick ass breakfast burrito.

A top all of that we sat outside, the service was very prompt (and very kind), and the price was right.  Yes.  Yes is the answer you are looking for to your question "should I go to St. Francis?"  Yes...but I'll fight you for a table...and I fight dirty.
author: Ryan G.

description: This was my first time at st. francis and I lived in the mission my whole life. I had the egg sandwich with sausage; it was delightful. The service was slow and the white chick with the hat is not that fine! Overall I enjoyed being there in the mission.
author: Jason M.

description:
S'alright.  I had very high hopes for this place because it's so cute and I just love me some All American Fountain Food, but it fell short.  Very short.

I do have to say the macaroni and cheese was very good, but the sandwiches we tasted were just OK.  My mouth was watering for the ice cream treats to follow, but my hot fudge banana split did not have enough fudge, yo. My dining companion had selected the brownie sundae, but dang- that brownie was hard.

I'm going to stick to Swenson's in SF, and when I'm away from home I'll always be true to Vic's ice cream in Sac-o-Tomatoes; it's truly the best fountain I've found.
author: Karen W.

description:
So many good things to say about St. Francis it is difficult to begin.  How about delicious malts so thick and creamy you can almost chew it.  Breakfast served all day and nearly the full menu.  Practical combo dishes.  The four page menu is full of all types of fare for meat eaters and vegetarians alike.

The servers seem to get a little backed up when the place gets packed which may impact the amount of attention you get, but the food comes out fast and hot.

Definitely a fun place to take the family or even a date.
author: Ravi P.

description:
Stoked, brah! 80's Topps collectors' cards.  Alf? Bmx? Knight Rider? Tron? YES. aside from food and drink, you can come here as if you were going to an old tyme soda fountain (turns out they are one) and get random old candy (probably actually old) and cool packs of trading cards (you will pay way more than you did in 1982-7).  

Experience:  Yeah, yeah hipster this, fixie that.  I already knew going in that I would probably see/talk to/overhear/smell the b.o. of a dozen of 'em.  It's all good, you know why?  These were the nicest people I've ever been served by.  Who knows what they were saying when they went back to the kitchen, but who cares?  When it came to actual customer service, they killed it.  Absolutely killed.  Better service than I've had in this great food city, or any other.  Sounds unbelievable, I know.  I happen to be a customer service expert.  I could run circles around any service person.  These dudes were amazing.  I honestly feel the main reason I am gushing about this, is simply because they all took really good care of my kids, their twin cousins- who had their own table.  If you can nail that aspect of serving diners, you will have customers for generations.  Obviously, they have done so before me.  

Food:  Deeeeeelicious hotcakes.  I love hotcakes/pancakes.  The kids all had Kiddie cakes, which came out like a famous looking mouse.  Wonderful idea, they all loved 'em.  I had hog cakes, which is pancakes with green onions and bacon in the batter.  OINK.  devoured.  We also had some medium sized plates stuffed with large sized portions, which is kinda good, kinda bad, but in the end turns out to be way more than it looks like it's gonna be.  Great food.  I also had an espresso malted milkshake with an added shot (of espresso, ya big dummy!).  Waker upper!  These dudes also got skills making coffee drinks, which is a huge plus on an early Sunday morning after a really late Saturday night.  big plus for me and the lady.  

Outcome: We made it in close to when they opened, so we were able to sit right away at two adjacent booths.  When we left, the place was packed all over, with a long wait outside.  We won!  We will for sure be back, just as long as we go early.  Them hipsters like to wake up late!

Note: watch what you add on, the prices will creep up on the bill if you're not careful...  (something like a city health tax? extra bacon?) either way, you should be cautious wherever you dine I guess.  

Maybe I'll come get an actual fountain drink next time.  Root beer float.  That'd be swell.  aw shucks
author: Joshua K.

description: Does Jessica North that was on Chopped work here still??
author: Camille H.

description:
Every time I've been here, I've been very impressed.  The Eggs Sandhya (poached on an English muffin with hollandaise, avocado and bacon) is excellent every time (except one, when the bacon was overdone, but this was by far the exception to the rule of excellent food).  Service is quick and not unfriendly.

I don't live in the Mission anymore, so regrettably I won't frequent St. Francis Fountain as often, but I tell my friends about it now.

Be sure to thing your spuds when you go!
author: N M.

description:
My parents used to go here when they were young.

A Frisco tradition! Talk about comfort food!

Mels, without the crowds.
author: Danny S.

description:
My boyfriend keeps suggesting we go to this place -- being dragged into the Mission on a Saturday morning to wait in line with a bunch of hipsters looking me up and down,  to eat "OK" food is not my idea of a sweet time. The place is wicked filthy, there's no comfortable seating, and everything tastes the same. The taters aren't even redeeming. They need more coffee cream containers to go around -- I got the evil eye from someone I was sitting next to at the counter for nabbing what they thought was their creamer.

I only give it an extra star because the people who work here are all incredibly nice and speedy. If you're into that sort of thing..
author: Serene L.

description:
Nothing cures a Saturday night Pop's hangover, like a Sunday breakfast at the St. Francis!

Breakfast is absolutely the best. The avocado/bacon/cheddar scramble is the bees knees. The biscuits and gravy (carnivore or herbivore) will make your toes curl on a cold morning. 

I give it 4 stars because it's always busy and jam packed. I can't shame it for being super popular... but I'm hungry!

UPDATE: Up to 5 stars now, since you can go across the street to Pop's again for Mimosas or a Bloody Mary. Lushes rock out!
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Only in San Francisco...

Decent grub, and I love the old trading cards they have...

I felt a little out of place as I'm not a Mission hipster...
author: Nathan W.

description:
Love St Francis Fountain. One of my favorite San Francisco establishments.

The atmosphere is really cool with a blast from the past quality but with only the cool parts (except for the creepy mannequin at the candy counter that scares me half to death every time I'm leaving...). 

Servers are all really relaxed and courteous and seem to have fun rotating between iPods as there is always some cool music (to my untrained ears) being played. 

Food is the clincher. Seitan (wheat gluten) has became one of my favorites since discovering it here. I almost always get a Devil Burger or Phil's Grill and am always satisfied. 

Only warning is be prepared to get desert regardless of your best intentions.

Really great, unique restaurant worth checking out.
author: Mike F.

description:
My girl took me here for brunch the other day and it was terrific. I had corned beef hash and she had a scramble. Both of our meals were cooked to perfection and were served all on one plate so you get to eat the meal as a big yummy mess. The coffee wasn't bad and I received refills promptly. 

Thanks for carrying on the tradition of bad ass diners.
author: Jonathan P.

description:
St. Francis Fountain has been a San Francisco land mark for many years. St. Francis Fountain used to make their own ice cream and candy. 
Luckily someone took over the restaurant  and this San Francisco landmark 
is still open. However, I am sorry to say that the food and service are below 
average.
author: Claudia B.

description:
Mmmmmmmmmm! :)

That's all I've got to say about the food. Oh! And that the portion sizes were awesome {we couldn't finish our breakfasts, and as we carried out our packaged left overs, felt like it was money well-spent}.

On to the other stuff - 

Definitely not a fan of the wait, nor the tiny, crowded dining area, and my non-hipster husband and I felt a little out of place surrounded by all the skinny jeans and neck scarves and battered chuck taylors. Oh, and the prices were a little bit too...enthusiastic for a diner. But the service was friendly, the location is great, and, like I said, the food was mmmmmmmmm!
author: Jelisa S.

description: They've made a couple changes at the fountain that are causing me to knock it down to 3 stars. They no longer let you call and pick up orders before 3 on the weekend. What a downer, I usually want their food to-go. And... They stopped taking substitutions. For example, when I asked for a turkey Reuben, they wouldn't sub the meat. I never understood why a turkey Reuben wasn't on the menu in the first place, but now I can no longer get it.
author: Kirsten S.

description: Nice grungy waitstaff with bigfoot tees. Cornmeal bread tasty, omelette heartily fat, good potatoes - course I'm a ketchup coater, so what do I know?  Wanna go back to try their milkshakes.
author: Peg S.

description:
Although all of the wait staff is painted and undoubtly ride single track bikes the food is "off the chain".

Great outdoor seating, great Mac n' cheese,  water service is excellent, candy cigarettes for the kids. 

Be sure to get there before 10:30 am weekends to beat the Brunch hipster crowd. 

Only downside: The bathroom is basically in the dining area so if "morning coffee" does more than wake you up, better order an oj instead.
author: Joe G.

description:
Love a good breakfast joint and this place doesn't disappoint! Tucked away on 24th street in the Mission is this old style 50's joint that my folks probably ate at in their teens.  The booths are small and intimate (for small framed folks from the 50's) but that adds to the charm.  Breakfasts are down home, bacon, eggs and flap jacks. It's hard to screw up breakfast!  Burgers are good as well, make sure you leave space for ice cream!  Beat the hoards and get there before 12 if you don't like waiting.

Jump into a 50's time capsule! Hope nothing ever changes with this place.

Update: Minus one star from my orginal review. Went this past presidents day weekend, the waitstaff all looked like they went out the night before.  The sign up list went ignored, sheesh us standing at the door waiting went ignored, we had to say "excuse me, were waiting to be seated!" only to get dissed by that bleached haired poodle grumpy chick.   Yes we see you are busy, acknowledging your patrons is the LEAST you could do.  This was at 1:30-2 in the afternoon well after the breakfast rush, nobody appeared to be in charge.  Sure angst and grungy seems to be the theme, but when it carries over into the service it leaves a bad bitter impression... or is that the whole idea? Expressions on the waitstaffs faces read "go away...go away...go away!"
author: B H.

description:
I have memories of eating grilled cheese and slurping on milkshakes here with my grandma back in the day. And indeed, this place is even more old school San Francisco than my grandma. Old school as in the 49ers franchise was founded here. We asked the waiter about that rumor, and he said we were sitting in that very booth! One friend almost wet himself with excitement over that one. From that moment on, we knew we'd have a great breakfast at St. Francis Fountain.

While there have been slight changes since the old days, most of the changes are for the better, including a large menu with an awesome selection of vegan items. Friendly service from the laid-back staff. Hipsters-blah-blah-hipsters. Who cares? If a hipster is someone who plays the Purple Rain soundtrack during breakfast, I say them's my kind of peeps! They also carry an odd array of '80s trading cards, including ALF, Mork & Mindy, and He-Man. It's sad that the '80s are now considered old school, but it's still fun. I'm such a wannabe hipster.
author: Michie L.

description: I loved this place as a kid and have recently enjoyed getting a late night cone. I always double check the hours of operation before heading over so imagine my surprise when I arrived at 9:30 on 3/7/14 and the place is locked down tight. They even had the hours posted in the window and they should have been open.  I'm pretty bummed. I guess there's no guarantee with this place. Sorry for the delayed review.
author: Kristin W.

description: I had an early flight out to SF and was meeting my friend for brunch. Like most people there, she didn't have a car, so I had to take the BART from SFO and attempt to find this place in the Mission. (If you are from or have lived in LA, you understand my frustration of not having a car...) So I walked down 24th St. from the BART station thinking, where the heck am I? This feels like the hippy version of Inglewood! I should have brought my mase! Finally found the place, cute little corner diner type shop, everything on the menu sounded scrumptious, I love breakfast food any time of the day! Ordered the corned beef hash, eggs over medium, with biscuits and a side of country gravy. The first bite tasted so good, but by the 3rd bite, I realized it was my hunger causing the illusion. The food was just OK, I can find faults in each item: The hash was a bit too greasy, the medium eggs were too easy, the biscuits were too dry, and the gravy had about a cup of green onions in it. I probably will not go out of my way to eat here again.
author: Claudia Z.

description:
I was greeted with smiles!
I knew nothing walking in.
Picking a shake took me a while.
The nice girl who was all smiles made my day.
She surprised me with a chocolate caramel milk shake.
It made magic boners in my pants.
I do like milk shakes, and this place's shake would bring all the boys to the yard... it brought me there.
author: danny e.

description:
3.5 stars after my first visit earlier today for lunch. The creamsicle ice cream soda is totally delicious and I love the fact that they have Boca burgers on the menu.  I haven't tried breakfast, but I'm sure I will soon.  I like the whole soda fountain thing and totally imagined myself 25 years ago sitting at the counter marvelling at all the shakes and sodas. Okay, who am I kidding? Even in my mid-thirties, I was marvelling!

I do agree with a couple of the previous reviews.  The attitude is a bit much, as is the tragically hip vibe. I've been over that for a LONG time and I'm waiting for the day when it becomes uncool. Normally, I don't really care (I mean, I LOVE Boogaloos), but it was kinda over the top.

All in all, a good place. I'll bring the husband for breakfast so he can enjoy the famed chocolate chip pancakes.
author: Abby W.

description:
Missing the star because we waited for almost an hour, added the star back because they (the manager came and spoke to us personally 4 times)  were nice about it and comp-ed the drinks for our 7 person party.   

Fresh juice, strong (get your own) coffee, (yum in my book) good food, I just wish they would have stated my omelet came with potato's.  I would have rather  something a bit lighter with it.  BTW - fantastic espresso shakes!
author: Tricia M.

description:
Had an awesome breakfast here last weekend despite a long wait in the on-and-off rain. While waiting in line got a cup of hot coffee from the waitress. Ok, maybe it's because she knew this guy in line with us. Anyhow, it almost made up for the fact that she kept coming outside hollering at the top of her lungs for those lucky parties of 2.

The cornbread is really what left the lasting impression. I expected a molded muffin shape but to my surprise found a thick slice of browned, warm cornbread sharing real estate with my scrambled eggs. AND seasoned with something special (green onions?)
author: Carin R.

description:
Wow.  I was just poking around on Yelp for a good breakfast place and came across St. Francis Fountain.  It is wonderful.  Everything I read about it in the reviews was true.  The waitstaff is highly tattooed and very friendly.  The place is very vegetarian friendly.  The nebulous potato thing is really good.  The granola was out of this world.  Coffee is strong and flavorful.

The only neg thing anyone at the table said about the breakfast was that the sausage had fennel, which he doesn't like.
author: Amy S.

description:
So many vegan options I experienced menu overload. I hate when I want to try everything and can't. 

I ended up with the vegan rancheros, which was tofu scramble with ranchero sauce and vegan cheese (Teese? Follow Your Heart? They taste the same to me, so I don't know), black beans, pico, and corn tortillas. It was all pretty good, but I feel I ordered wrong. Ordering Mexican-ish food at a non-Mexican establishment in the Mission is stupid, right? I wasn't thinking. Plus, they need to figure out how to get that vegan cheese to melt. I know it's a little tricky, but it can be done. It was just shredded and stirred in with the tofu, and while I didn't mind it, I could have done without it altogether.

Next time I'm trying the Vegan Thing, or maybe the vegan pancakes. Vegan pancakes! Nobody ever has vegan pancakes. Definitely should have tried those. I was too full for a soy shake, but that's also on my list for next time. 

Great atmosphere and friendly service, and tons of vegan options. Love it!
author: Ashley P.

description: This place is cute and old fashioned.  They make their own ice cream and it's quite good.  They are really good for people with food restrictions.  It's a little pricy but I enjoyed it.
author: Maria S.

description:
Old school diner with fun tunes, greasy food (the fries are. so. good.), delicious malts, and also a selection of veggie options!  I left there soooo full- had the burger with all the extras, fries, and vanilla malt.. yummmm.

Things to consider: I hear there is usually a long wait (small place) but we got a booth right away.  Also, if you don't like louder music and hipster kid waiters, then get your pompous head out of your ass and just enjoy the place for what it is: A DINER.  Read: not a fancy shmansy place for dinner, just a semi dingy place for deep fried anything.
author: Allie L.

description:
I've been here twice, once for a milkshake, once for food....

On the first visit, we were ushered to a seat instantly....

On the second visit, we approached and noticed a pretty large crowd waiting outside to be seated...  It was a Saturday morning (afternoon if you want to be a stickler about it), and we were about to give up and go else where...  We decided to find out how long the wait was...  Much to our surprise, he said only about 3 minutes, and I think we were seated before that....

So a star for that...

The milkshakes are amazing and they offer a TON of flavors, and the extra shot of malt might change your life...

So a star for that.

They offer a vegetarian chorizo w/ either real eggs or a tofu scramble...  I ordered it, with the corn tortillas, and I ate every last piece...  I was full about halfway through, but it was too ridiculously good to stop eating.

So a star for delicious food!!!!!!

The staff is really friendly, pretty attentive, and the ambiance of the place is SICK!!!  I mean, COME on...  They sell Michael Jackson Collector cards!!!!  It's heaven for anyone brought up in the late 70s/early 80s...

So another star for that!!!!!!!

Lastly, I award my fifth star to the location....  24th and York isn't necessarily hard to get to, and it is tucked away in a quiet, non-crowded part of the city...  and if you're anything like me, after living in downtown for almost 4 years now, you hate people.

Long review short???  Get your ass here right now.
author: Jess R.

description:
The quintessential brunch place in my neighbourhood.  The staff is very friendly and helpful.  The food is good comfort food: not fancy, but sometimes exactly what you want on a Sunday morning.  It is vegan friendly.  It is a real joy of mine to sit outside with friends eating brunch.

If you are coming here for brunch on the weekend, I would recommend arriving before 10 a.m.  The crowds get quite vicious at right about 10 a.m.  This applies for both Saturday and Sunday.

In terms of food, I'd recommend the vegan strawberry soy shake with real strawberries.  For non-vegan types, I've heard that the nebulous potato thing is not to be missed.
author: Douglas P.

description:
When this place opened I was really psyched to have a breakfast place in the neighborhood.

I'm disappointed.

The food is mediocre. It is not as good as Bugaloo, or the Pork Store, or Just for You. But that's not what makes me angry,

What makes me angry is signing up for a table and having the St. Francis staff give that table away to two parties who arrived after me.  I was standing in between the outdoor tables and the sign up sheet waiting for my table when I see the hostess usher two parties who came after me into my tables. When I pointed this out to her she says

 "I called you".

Really? I am standing right here. I didn't hear you. You must have whispered the name.

She made very little apology, nor did she ask the seated party to give me the table I had signed up for before them. Then she explains that she couldn't have seated me anyway because the rest of my party weren't with me. 

Well, I explained, they are across the street at the park, waiting. It is quite difficult to make a 2 year old stand here on the sidewalk with nothing to do for an indefinite period of time, dig? Whats the problem with letting him and my husband play in the park across the street until the tables are ready?

But there is more.

While I was waiting for the table I passed the time chatting with a homeless friend of mine from the neighborhood who told me that she once bought a hamburger there and was told she would have to make it take out, and was not allowed to actually sit at the St. Francis to eat the 10 dollar hamburger she has just dished out money for.

This woman does not smell bad and doesn't mess with people if they don't mess with her. I think it is appalling that they did this to her.

It also got me to thinking, did they just give away my table because I am out here talking to a homeless person?

I will never know the answer, but it matters not because the food here just simply is not that good, nor is it any cheaper than other breakfast places in the city.
author: ellen c.

description:
Okay, okay. So . . . this place is as hipster as it gets, it's true. And, yes, I don't totally enjoy eating my [aw crap, it's 2pm already] breakfast to The Hyphy Movement Vol. 1 complation cranked all the way up to 11 . . . but . . . but . . .
They really do a mean breakfast, okay? And the vege options are all over the dang place, instead of being limited to the point of depressing, like SOME places. [They even rock the soyrizo!]
So, maybe it's a hole in the wall with a bunch of kids at the helm, but it's a DINER. Not the Four Seasons Hotel Restaurant. Yes, your server has a hangover, but eh, so does everyone else in the dang place.
author: Erin P.

description:
I love this place.  I'm sorry, I know that some people think it's a hipster breakfast enclave and that the food sucks.  But, I love it.  Despite the hipsters (whom I hate.)  That is how rad St. Francis Fountain is.

Why, you ask?  Let me tell you: cheap awesome greasy diner food that cures hangovers.  You can order for pickup (which is convenient for me as I live two blocks away.)

The reason I REALLY love this place?

Vintage trading cards in the original packaging.
-Star Wars
-Duran Duran
-Cyndi Lauper
-The Goonies
-Dallas
-Dune
-Garbage Pail Kids
-Growing Pains
-Pee Wee's Playhouse

I could go on and on and on... it's like a cheesy slice of my childhood rigth there behind a glass counter.

I love it!
author: Kate R.

description:
You should eat here.  No, really, you should.  Cheap and really delicious and very authentically 1950s.  The wait staff is just great - tattooed and friendly..  (Especially that one guy with the beard.  Smiley guy.  I heart him.  I think he genuinely IS that happy.) 

Get the Thai Tofu Scramble and be a happy little soul.

Skip the burger.  It's not that great.

But anything for breakfast will make you happy!
author: Jill K.

description:
We love getting breakfast here!  The chicken,pesto and feta scramble, the Chef's Mess, and the Nebulous Potato thing are among our favorites. 
They also have great shakes.
author: Katie V.

description:
Honesty, retro diners kind of depress me. Not sure why, but they always remind me of sad little towns in the Midwest.

They also usually have nothing good for a vegan to eat.

4 stars for St. Francis though... I opened up the menu and had one of those overwhelmed moments where there were an unexpectedly high amount of veggie friendly choices. Too many choices!

I went with the vegan chorizo hash and tofu ...
Delicious.

Plus, no wait at all for a booth at 9AM on a Saturday morning.
author: Trey F.

description:
The hashbrowns are NOT VEGAN and they do not use a vegan spread for their bread.  However, the tofu scrambles are good, and the staff is also very friendly. 

The only other strike against it is that it's a total hipster dinner, but maybe that's your thing.
author: megan t.

description: Incredible service, great food, wonderfully historic building.   My partner and I enjoyed every minute eating at the Fountain
author: Lloyd P.

description:
My fiance and I went to St. Francis one morning on the weekend to get some Eggs Benedict for her. I am always up for a new restaurant, so I went along.

I got the Huevos Rancheros which are a personal favorite of mine. Loved them! They are delicious, the tortillas are yummy, the beans are very flavorful and the side salsa salad (try saying that 3 times fast) is good too, and I don't even like any salads.

I can also report that the EB are really good too. 

The only issues I have with this place is the wait (but where isn't there a wait on a Sunday brunch) and the cost. It is a little pricey for a brunch menu.

The servers are good, although sometimes I can't figure out which one is actually mine since they all help out. But that's a good thing.

Also, I grabbed a Reuben last time I was there. It was also quite tasty. Now the hard part will be deciding between the HR and the Reuben. :(
author: Josh C.

description:
They have a breakfast dish called "Tofu Thai".

Now, I can have Thai for breakfast, lunch, and dinner.  I think I've found heaven...
author: Marsha Z.

description:
greasy spoon diners make me smile wide ... especially when they successfully deliver comfort food that is so satisfying, a post-meal nap is mandatory.

My big bear hug of a food plate consisted of two eggs over easy, potatoes, cornbread and a side (three big pieces) of bacon.  So delightfully delish and generous in portion that I needed a little assistance from my table mate, who had the huevos rancheros.  Now, I can't say that I tried any of his dish because ... are you ready for this ... he ate the damn meal too fast and left me no chance to sneak in a bite.  believe it.  i'm eating, chewing, chomping, enjoying ... look over, boom.  gone.  and based on my powers of observation, i'll take the plate licking as a sign that it didn't suck.  

the only crap thing is that i don't like the location, but that's not really their fault.
author: Sarah K.

description: I enjoy coming to this place do to there vegan options. We are vegan and live in the South Bay. Today we came and they are out of vegan cheese. The last time we were here they were out of wine for mimosas. I really wished they were more prepared to serve there customers. Especially those that travel to come here.
author: Quang T.

description: We ordered the Chefs Mess and a spinach omelet and while both were good it didn't stand out from any other breakfast diner. I'll tryout the burger and shakes. Maybe we can boost up the review.
author: T L.

description:
Ok, so I have been a neighbor of St. Francis for over 4 years now, and I have seen it go up and down with all the local hipsters, bikers and otherwise. I have to agree with the previous post - it's still a great place to go and get some grub. Sure the wait staff can be a bit....um...alternative?, but I always have a good experience. They accommodate just about any request with the menu and even my kids love seeing their favorite waitstaff and asking them all about their tattoos, piercings, etc. I have never EVER seen them act shady - even when they get a difficult customer (it's the mission after all). My only complaint is that I used to love going on the weekends and now I actively avoid it due to the hordes of brunchers waiting outside. Where did you go my cool indie hangout? Ah well, I will still be going back. 

Highly reccommended: The nebulous potato thing - yum.
author: Nick R.

description:
What can I say that hasn't been said?

As I've been told, over and over, this is the diner where the 49ers were formed. Back booth, center, there ya go, history and stuff.

But besides that the food is almost always beyond good. The chef's mess convinces me that it'll give me a heart attack right then and there but GODDAMN IT I CAN'T RESIST. Also, pancakes with bacon cooked into them? Who are these people and why do they hate my arteries so much? I wake up some mornings craving this place.

The staff is always great too. So there you have it. Another great review.
author: Terra T.

description:
My coworkers treated me to lunch here today. It's my 30th borthday. (Yes, I'm even yelping on my birthday!)

I LOVE it here. The waitress gave me my hazelnut milkshake for free and my coworker bought me some old school garbage pail kids and Growing Pains trading cards from the front counter! How cute! Oh, that Ben Seaver, he was totally a fag. 

It's the cutest little diner in the world and I'll totally be back.
author: Matthew M.

description:
One of my favorite breakfast spots in the city(ive never eaten anything else on the menu since the breakfast is super good.)
the service is always perfect and the workers are super helpful to resolve any food situation(even if it was my fault for mumbling my order) i would highly suggest saint francis for a meal which is very much worth every dollar spent.
:D
author: Elliott G.

description:
The St. Francis is fantastico. 

The Burger with/ Avo. and Jack was delicious. 

Service was friendly, chipper, upbeat, welcoming and fast. 
We went on New Year's Day and got there just in time for sit-down service. I noticed how so many peeps from the neighborhood would come in for a cup of coffee, or take out or whatever. It seems kind of Self Serve sometimes but it's such a little community hang out. Hipsters galore.

The kitsch is through the roof.
author: Mary Ella D.

description:
I'm sure a lot of people think they live on the best block in SF but if they don't live near 24th and Bryant they are halfway retarded.  Either that or they haven't been here.  Which is a good thing because one of the best things about the block is it's never crowded.  You can always get a seat at any of the awesome places right on this little patch of hipster heaven.  Shit maybe I shouldn't give this place 5 stars or more people will come and I won't be able to get a seat!

Anyways back to the review --- This is seriously the best breakfast I've had anywhere in the Bay.  If I was a world class athlete or didn't care if I weighed 500 lbs I'd eat breakfast here everyday.  Seriously it's that good and I don't even eat breakfast during the week.

I've tried most of the things on the menu and for breakfast you really can't go wrong.  The Chef's Mess with Banana Bread is my go to order.  For lunch any of the burgers or chicken sandwiches are great except every now and then my fries have been cold but you don't have to put up with what David Foster Wallace calls the Professional Smile or the opposite Professional Scowl.

Then of course there's the ice cream and shakes which are classic and delicious.  Take my advice and just get the small shake.  It's so good you can get by on quality not quantity.

When Adam Richman from Man-vs-Food comes to SF he should definitely stop here.

About the only improvement I'd make is ditching the Tapatio for Red Hot.
author: Jason S.

description:
This place is GREAT...but don't order the food...food = 2 stars...BUT, you ask...what makes the other 3 stars? Well:
-cabbage patch kids cards 
-magnum PI cards (with gum in the pack from 1986!)
-gummy rats
-New Kids on the Block trading cards!!!!!!!!!!
-double scoops of mint chocolate chip ice cream
-candy dots YES the ones that come on the paper
-3 inch dia. jawbreakers
-ring pops
-dum dums
-wax lips
author: Kristen Y.

description:
I've brought friends here for brunch several times, the service was great every time, and I'm yet to hear a bad word said about the place. Even the gaggle of Yelp CM's was in love.

Personally, I love the milkshakes here, they are supreme!
author: Marc S.

description:
I admit I was little skeptical of this place after some of the reviews I had read.  I feared being out of place it what seems to be a hipster's paradise.  But, I thoroughly enjoyed my breakfast here this morning.

After a short wait for a table, we were ushered inside kitsch central. The room is totally old school.  Very old school.  And the kitschy displays of trading cards from Three's Company, Dallas and Growing Pains gave me a good chuckle.

The bf loved loved loved his food which I think was called The Mess.  I had some biscuits and gravy which was served with scallions on top which was an interesting touch.  Their home fries and sourdough toast are super yummalicious.

I have now overcome my fear of feeling out of place and will soon be back to this place!
author: Jeff P.

description:
Excellent, excellent food. Adorable decor- supposedly its the oldest fountain shop in the city, and they still have a ton of old signs and stuff on the walls.
We had a mixed party of meat eaters to vegans, and not only was there something for everyone, but all of it was amazing.

The wait was a little long, but they really worked on keeping people moving and checking on available tables. We just headed down to L's cafe down the block and picked up some coffee while we waited.

Once we were seated (outside, the inside is pretty darn small), the waiter was extremely quick and friendly- until it came time to track him down for the check- I think we had to wait over 1/2 an hour to close out.

Moderatly priced for the quality of the food. I would reccomended heading out to this place with one or two others and grabbing a seat at the bar.

One side note- the waiter was wearing a Linda's Tavern tee shirt (which is where we usually eat breakfast every Sunday here in Seattle) so it was an eerie reminder of home.
author: Tori B.

description:
Can the waitresses get any hotter?

Do I sound too much like an old fashioned man when I say there is really something about a meal (two eggs scrambled dry with wheat toast) that hits the spot brought to you by a beautiful woman? St. Francis understands this to a T. They even have a beautiful man as well. Something for everybody! 

Oh and they have a candy collection to die for and Mitchell's Ice Cream which is just amazing!
author: Chantelle T.

description: OH MY GOD! OHMYGOD! This place is my new favorite brunch place. I had never heard of it before I went today. We waited in the rain for about 20 minutes and when we were finally seated, we were NOT disappointed. My hubby ordered an oreo milkshake which my husband, myself and our friend all attacked like vultures. Everything from the ice cream to the whipped cream was to die for. I ordered french toast with 2 eggs and spuds and i "thing"-ed my spuds which means adding sour cream, tomatoes, and green onions. For only about 12 bucks, I got 2 plates of food. The french toast was delicious, the eggs (simple, sunny side eggs) were also fantastic and the "thing"-ed spuds? So decadent! A flavor explosion. This place not only uses incredible ingredients, the portions are huge and the prices are great. LOVE LOVE LOVE!
author: Hanan H.

description: We were told to expect a wait, then when we got there walked right in.  Cool people, a fun buzz abounds and the food was GREAT!  Priced fairly, quality ingredients and we were out of there in a flash.  Great for our 12-year old vegetarian son even!  We can't wait to return!
author: Russ S.

description: I have to start this review off by saying I've only eaten at this restaurant on two occasions so this review will only be based on a couple of visits. I've also only had breakfast here. My first visit was a really great experience. The breakfast I ordered was prepared perfectly and I loved everything I ordered. Service was good, the place appeared clean and I liked the old school atmosphere. Had I written a review after that meal, I would have given this place at least four stars. So here's the problem. When I went back a second time, my experience wasn't quite as good. The meal I ordered didn't measure up to the last one. I ordered something different but I don't think that should make a difference. So I can only attribute it to the possibility I didn't  have the same cook the second time around. That would make sense. What is troubling is the one item on my plate that wasn't prepared properly were two freaking fried eggs. I think that at a minimum, a cook should be able to get those right. They were overcooked on one side and that's the one thing that bugs me--when eggs are left too long on the grill and they get brown. When I make that mistake at home (it's rare but it has happened), I toss the things and fry myself up a couple more. I did takeout this time so I left without looking at the carton before I left the place. That was my mistake. So now I'm on the fence about this place but have decided to give it a third try. I really like their menu and the fact they have a lot of selections for vegetarians and vegans so it could be a great go-to place for me when I'm on that side of the city. For right now, however, I'm going to stick with the three stars. It wasn't like my entire meal the second time wasn't good. If my next meal meets my standards, I'll raise my rating. On the other hand, if my next visit isn't a positive one I'm going to have to knock off a star and that will be it for me. Hopefully, that won't be the case.
author: Rabbit B.

description:
Wow. Talk about a gem. A friend invites me for breakfast here and I wasn't sure what to expect. Actually I thought it was a park with a coffee stand and...well, a fountain. Oops. Fountain as in old soda stand with burgers and milkshakes. Haha.

I sit down and the coffee comes first. Strong, a flavorful like a good cafe should have. I proceeded to have a spinach, garlic, tomato and swiss omelette. Oh goodness. The garlic was apparent when the food was on its way and tasted even better. You knew that had just minced or chopped it minutes earlier. The sourdough toast was good - slightly buttered so you could feel free to eat it solo or add a dash of jam. The homefries were tasty and mixed with some onions for some added pizzazz. Good touch.

And I got it all for $15 including tip. I call that a great meal. The staff did seem a bit harried and eager to get us ordering but that wasn't a big deal. Parking can be a bit spotty - I knew it was my day when I got a space *right across the street from the diner*...haha! 

Check this place out! Definitely good food...and I only had breakfast!
author: Aaron F.

description:
i don't get what all the hype is about.  this place has a huge line pouring out of it on weekend mornings and for what?  mediocre eggs and run of the mill pancakes?  no thanks.  i'd rather go someplace else where there's no line, better food, and a less pretentious atmosphere.

i've been here for lunch as well and it's the same ol' thing... burgers and sandwiches, blah blah blah.

the one neat thing is the straws they provide for milkshakes... red and white striped paper straws.  which i guess isn't even THAT neat since they begin to disintegrate after a few sips.
author: Lauren P.

description:
This place is so delicious and yummy and affordable... and did I mention delicious? I get the breakfast burrito, my boyfriend always gets the banana bread- BE SURE TO GET THE BANANA BREAD- and always, a milkshake. 

A hint: DO NOT consume all of this while in the restaurant. Get your milkshake to-go, and perhaps share a plate. They fill their plates to the brim which is amazing and it's all so good. Friendly staff, too. I love this place. Tell only who you must. It's a bit hard to get a table on the weekends but it's worth the wait!
author: Rebecca L.

description:
One of my favorite breakfast/weekend spots. You will see me nursing morning-after-drinking symptoms here. I highly recommend the Chef's Mess, its the perfect breakfast combination, its a scramble done RIGHT.

Great place to sit outside and get sun, and the candy counter is rad. Tron Dark Crystal, and Micheal Jackson trading cards to purchase.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
St. Francis Fountain is my go-to brunch place.  Parking can be a pain sometimes but the walk (for me) isn't so bad.  It feels really good walking past the crowd spilling out on the street at Boogaloo's and knowing "You'll still be waiting for your seat by the time I'm munching my Eggs Sandhaya."

Everyone else has pretty much said it all--50's style fountain, great food with lots of vegetarian options, strong coffee, friendly staff, (usually) fast service, and old school candy and trading cards.
author: Kevin H.

description: Fabulous!  This little unassuming diner kicks up some seriously inventive, kick-ass food. I had the "hog cakes", aka bacon pancakes with green onion and cheddar cheese. With just a little syrup to give it that sweet & salty taste, I was in heaven. The corned beef hash was like nothing I've had before, and I mean that in a good way :)  I had an old fashioned chocolate malt shake to help wash it all down. Stuffed!
author: S M.

description:
Really cool old ice cream parlor turned hispter diner.

We arrived at 9:30a.m. on Saturday, 15 minutes later there was a crowd...good timing.

I ordered 2 waffles, 2 poached eggs and bacon,  My companion had an omelette with tomato, bacon, cheese and green chilies, comes with house potatoes and your choice of bread.

I really enjoyed the waffles and poached eggs on top (that's how I like it) but the bacon was way over done.  For thick cut sliced bacon it should not be so crispy.  I also tasted my companions omelette and house potatoes.  I thought the house potatoes rocked, the omelette was okay. I didn't like that the tomatoes were cut into huge chunks and were barely cooked.  It made the omelette taste a little bland.  I also thought they overcooked the eggs a bit.

However, I did like the decor and the menu was full of choices, also caters to vegetarians. 

I enjoyed this place enough to want to come back and try something else.
author: Inga B.

description:
I love St. Francis. The food is great, definitely above and beyond normal diner food. They have lots of vegetarian options (I recommend the veggie reuben) and of course lots of great things for meat eaters as well.

I have only gone for dinner as I hear that it's packed in here at breakfast time. There's hardly ever anyone around during dinner time though so service is always fast. Everyone that works here is super friendly too. Even just the cute 50s diner vibe (not in an annoying cliche way though, don't worry) is worth the trip out to St. Francis.
author: Emily F.

description:
Maybe it's just me, or maybe it was just today... But I had a really mediocre experience for breakfast this morning and feel like I paid $14 for having not a lot of food.  I got the griddle combo with eggs that I wanted cooked omelet like and the waitress told me I would have to pay extra for an omelet like egg.  I think they would have tagged on $2 more dollars and then I would have never gone back again.  I just had them scrambled but it looked like what I wanted.  
I especially don't like that this place feels like an extension of the experience of Boogaloos - there are lines out the wazoo on weekends.  I just have to say that I don't think it is worth it  (though i do like there malted milkshakes.
author: Leslie I.

description:
After a night of drinking and no limit solider-ing and cash money-ing with some friends, i felt the best way to make it up to my girlfriend was to (attempt to) wake up early and take her out for some sunny saturday breakfast.  so bright and early 09:00am, the adventure started...

in between morning matches of street fighter hd remix, i scoured yelp for the most magical breakfast spot in the surrounding areas.  Basing our decision wiith a telephone, we were  passing up reviews on mama's in san francisco, (we decided to skip out on the 40 minute wait)  MHOP (millbrae's house of pancakes) had a 10 minute wait but an uneventful phone call.  I soon remember a cute, little, malt shoppe-looking place close to my work.

The st. francis fountain.

my new favorite breakfast spot.

We got there around 11-ish ( i REALLY like street fighter) and had about a 20 minute wait for a table.  It would have been a shorter wait if we were willing to perch up on the counter.  We need something more intimate, so we waited patiently for a small table, sandwiched between two other small tables in a kiddie corner at the front of the "fountain."

I ordered the tofu scramble with "thing" on my spuds.  My girlfriend ordered corned beef hash and was over joyed with the quality of the coffee.  

The tofu scramble was very good.  I've been wanting to have it and this was a good way to start the tofu scramble experience.  The potatoes were just as good, if not better.

My girlfriend said that the corn beef hash was alittle lacking in the corn beef department, but was still good nonetheless.

We will be coming back here....alot.

probably me more than her...because i work so close...

sucks for you girlfriend...sucks for you.
author: Rommel B.

description:
It gets crowded on the weekends, especially on a sunny day. The workers are friendly, and fast. It didn't take more than 10 min for mine and my boyfriend's food to come out. They have tasty vegetarian reubens and extra thick a good malt shakes. "as thick as you want it"

For the amount of food we got, it was pretty cheap. 2 meals a side and large milkshake for $25.
author: Pauline B.

description:
The Chef's Mess is def. what St. Francis Fountain is all about. It's like a scramble w/ cheese and sour cream on top!  
And get this, it comes w/ either a side of cornbread, banana bread, white or wheat! 

Everything there was great.  Service was fast and efficient!  When we got there, it seemed like we were going to be waiting for an hour, since we placed our name on the second sign sign in sheet.  But surprise surprise, it was just a bit over 30 minutes for the wait.  
Also tried their pancakes, which was just ok.  But it wasn't bad either.  

Everything on the menu wasn't really expensive either.  $7-10, which is average.
author: AhLin C.

description:
I don't understand the 1 and 2 star ratings for St Francis. I absolutely love this place. It just might be my favorite brekky spot in town. The Chef's Mess? Nebulous Potato Thing? The cheddar bacon green onion pancakes???!!! Holy Poopy-Pants. The shakes?? I damn near ate my own hand with the spoon in it they were so good. The service was great for my friend and I. Prompt and with a smile. I wish I would have caught the dude's name, but he rocked a quasi-Boy Scouts hat. He was great. 

Anyone who gets hung up on the whole hipster thing might have a decent complaint if they were eating the staff and not the food. You don't have to eat the skinny pants wearing guy that looks like he rolled out of bed five minutes after he got to work. Hipsters are people too, they just happen to love PBR and silly bikes.
author: Big W.

description:
To: pancakes
From: glenne

yo pancakes-
come 2 dinner with me at st. francis 2morrow. i miss u cuz i never wake up in time 2 c u, but at st.F we can meet up and be bff 4eva again.

-glenn
ps. bring those foos strawberry and milkshake. they is hella tastey
author: Glenn E.

description: Hey, you guys changed your coffee. I don't like it. Change it back please. I still love you just the same.
author: Dave F.

description: A total of ten customers, at least two people on the floor and the place is falling apart.  This may beyond rescue, and I'm not sure it's worth it.  I hadn't been here is a long time and apparently I hadn't missed anything but misery.  We walked in around 6:30 before a play at Brava Theater across the street and all was well until we noticed there was a group of about five huddled by the front door and they weren't being seated or talked to by anyone else.  We pushed around and grabbed a couple seats at the counter and noticed a very agitated guy two counter stools away.  Finally he yelled out at the waiter who kept walking by us without a word of encouragement and asked if his food was being cooked.  The waiter tried to ignore him, but this guy looked very street smart and rough, so after a couple stand off's the waiter went into the kitchen which I could see from my seat, and asked what the hell was going on with the order that wasn't being cooked or delivered.  So waiterboy came out and told angry customer that the order was almost ready which was not the truth.  We kept being ignored all this time and waiterboy was actually matched on the floor by waitergirl who appeared to be equally inept.  About 20 minutes so far and not a peep about our awkward status, but what we saw finally delivered to angry customer told us not to order 'food' at this time.  Not sure in angry customer ordered and omelette or an egg casserole, but it was hideous as a vision and smelled gross.  There were a couple of dueces that seemed to be fetching their own water and condiments after waiting way too long, but the place was really dead and I still can't imaging what this place does to pay the bill's.  Finally waiterboy came and asked what we wanted and we said we each wanted a small shake, it is a fountain, and he gave us each a glass of water and disappeared again.  We waited another 20 minutes and nothing ever appeared, so we got up from the counter and walked out as he looked as us with a look of contempt only the dying can display.  It will  be a long time before I darken the doorway of St. Francis Fountain again, but I wish them well.
author: Stu S.

description:
I LOVE this place. The food is great, the wait-staff is hot and usually tattoo'd, and they have an old fashioned candy counter. FUN DIP! Sundaes! Patty Melts! Flirting with waitresses who charge a "sass tax" (inside joke).

It helps that I can walk here in the morning from my house in a sleepy daze, too:)
author: Jacqui M.

description:
I thought this was an out of the way "secret spot" for a while but have decided that its just far enough away from everything that it just doesnt get all that crowded. You will wait on Sat and Sundays for a good 30 min but they seem to have the lines and waits under control. Free coffee while you wait helps too. 

I usually will walk from my house on 18th down Mission and then make the "colorful" walk down 24th every Sunday all by my lonesome to sit at the bar and enjoy a little breakfast. Apparently it is owned by the same people as Boogaloo's on Valencia/22nd. 

Staff is great and they sell Garbage Patch Kids in the case...

Update:

This place has been over run. I drove by last weekend because i really wanted to have a cheeseburger and the line out front was rediculous. So sad... I swear they were filming a hipster cartoon or something. 

Loss of star. 4 to 3.

Staff still rules though.

Word._____________
author: A W.

description: Total retro 50's diner run by 60's era looking hippie kids on an urban hipster block of 24th St. in the Mission. The Huevos Rancheros are brilliant.
author: Jon W.

description:
We've come here twice in the past two weeks.

First time, my boyfriend and I got burgers with cheese and/or avocado with a side of fries and homefries. I also got a strawberry straight shake. The burgers were very diner-esque, perfect portion, and tasty tasty tasty. The buns were just the right softness, and the cheese was melted fine. The fries were pretty good (medium thickness and crispy enough) and the homefries had good seasoning. My strawberry shake definitely hit the spot.

For our second trip there, we got a chicken salad and a reuben with chicken vegetable soup. I loved how the soup was served piping hot. It was a little salty though. The reuben was very good, not too salty, not too greasy. Bread was perfected toasted with just enough butter and went well with the melted cheese and just the right amount of pastrami. My boyfriend's chicken salad was good enough (not disgusting and not amazing). We also got a mint ice cream for dessert. I like softer ice cream, so I thought the texture was great.

Both time we spent between $26-32. Service is a little on the slow side, but still quite friendly.
author: Angela H.

description:
This is more of a 3.5 stars for me. I'm getting old and hate waiting in lines amongst the hipsters for a brunch. But, it's also fun people-watching and it's a super-cute place.

I like the menu too. It's fun to read and offers some nice diner-style options. I keep ordering the Country Breakfast with biscuits and gravy and eggs. It pretty good. The pancakes were also pretty good.

I've been here for dinner too. It's a good time to go because it's usually pretty empty. However, I don't think the biscuit was as fresh as ordering it earlier in the day. My friends ordered the hamburger, grilled cheese and fries and those looked pretty good.
author: Thanya S.

description:
I'm honestly not all crazy about the food: aside from the stupendously creamy and salty mac n' cheese and the very large malty shakes it's pretty average fare. 

However, the nicest staff in town and the great corner location in the middle of an area dominated by tacos makes this a must-stop. If you're a Missionite you'll be likely to see someone you know, and it's a great place for a conversation if you arrive with a friend. 

Favorite moment: got there on a sunny afternoon and ordered a burger to go while spotting a friend at Pop's across the street. Wandered over to Pop's to chat while I waited, forgot about the meal until one of the unbelievably nice staffers walked my burger over. How sweet!
author: Ulrika A.

description:
Vegan Chorizo is better than the real thing!  YUM and you don't feel like a grease bomb hit you afterwards!   Black beans are really good - not spicy, but well flavored.   My favorite:  scrambled eggs with chorizo, black beans, served with a little side of salad that is lightly dressed and a couple of corn tortillas.  As with most brunch places, the portions are obscene, so half of a plate usually gets the job done for me. 

I didn't realize it was hip..wait...Am I hip? And if I am, am I ironically hip?
author: Maria C.

description: I have been coming here for years now and the food is always spectacular. The clientele who frequent this establishment has inevitably changed but what can you do? The employees here have to put up with a TON of bullshit from their newer "fru fru" clientele. I would like to say bravo to St. Francis Fountain for maintaining delicious food as well as having a very welcoming, AND PATIENT, staff.
author: elly w.

description:
Ok. As an extreme breakfast connoseuir this place has a certain appeal. It's close to my house and has bacon tasty enough to cure most hangovers.

My first time here the breakfast was excellent! Service was friendly, attentive, and our server didn't think twice when I ask for whipped cream to go on my blueberry pancakes. One problem though.... I was still drunk from the night's debauchery and anything with whipped cream is special to drunk people.

Second time here, I brought Melissa H. with me based on my fond memories of the blueberry pancakes. Wow! what a difference inebriation makes! The food was very average and the service was BAD. What!?!?! Is there a blueberry shortage? These are not the pancakes I remember :-)

Third time! Yes. I'm a glutton for punishment but I had to know the truth. So I decided to use my monk-like patience and brave the saturday morning pile-up. I put on a plain old t-shirt and some regular old jeans. Dressed like this, I am basically invisible. I certainly can't be pegged as a hipster, yuppie, geek (well maybe...),  or any other classification. 
The verdict? Long wait, friendly hipster crowd, great service, average to below averae food (bacon was still good though). It's not worth the wait on weekend mornings but I would definitely check it out at a slower time just to try the creamsicle shake. MMMMMMM.
author: Ed V.

description: Your average run of the mill greasy diner food, but totally worth going to if only to eat the nebulous potato thing. So good, so, so good!!
author: Kathryn M.

description:
great for the hang over, but weak on the service, which is huge in my book.

Pretty much every one who works here needs to chill on the coke binges, or the attitude or whatever it is they are taking too much of,  and like, step it up a notch with their custie service. The customers seem only to come here to show off their cheap mondays and koi fish tattoos and the wait staff will turn their nose down at you because they think they are better. (Is it the confusing idea of "status job"?)  The food is good but seriously, the service has just gone soooo downhill, even in the past few months which is a total shame because it has so much potential to be awesome. 

I am sorry I had to give this such a bad review, the service just keeps getting worse and worse and it makes us Mish stomping saturday night kids sad.
author: Delilah S.

description: Delicious breakfast gut bomb, nostalgia, great neighborhood, friendly service - hurray!
author: J F.

description:
I fall back in-love with this place every time I eat there. It's THAT good.

First, understand that the waitresses are bitches. It's a fact of life...get over it. They can be bitches because they're cute and work at one of the most-popular spots in the Mission for their breed. They can afford to scowl at you and roll their eyes when you request anything special. Get past this, and your dining experience will be stellar. (They are good at giving you attitude, but even better at keeping your glasses full with water and coffee.)

This is one of the best places to take a vegan/vegetarian friend in the city. Hands-down. They have a ridiculously extensive menu and the prices are about on-par with what it is in San Francisco. (Anywhere else and it'd be overpriced, though.) I've had a pretty big portion of the menu and everything is good, which is key in a place that you choose to dine at with a group. I've taken several people here and they all loved it. The location is a little harsh (24th and York ain't exactly the safest spot in the City) and the wait can be pretty intense on weekend mornings, but all of this is waived when you take your first bite of their biscuits'n'gravy or a sip of a Guinness (yes, the beer) float. 

And, ho-hah, you can have vegan shakes/ice cream and they have vegan sausages and the like! (And the shakes are done the old-fashioned way. Makes it even better!)

Also neat: the collectible toys and candies and cards. This place is a mecca for anyone obsessed with pop culture.

Thing your spuds. You'll thank me later.
author: Danyell K.

description:
We love to swing by after Roosevelt Tamale Parlour for dessert.  The Buster Brown, warm brownie with ice cream, raspberry sauce, walnuts and whipped cream.  People are crazy about the tofu scrambles, and it's such a great neighborhood.

I'm a married gay man, so this dessert is what porn used to be to me.  Don't miss it.
author: Enzo L.

description:
A very pleasant diner experience, especially if most of the bands you listen to are named "The [something or other]".  The wait for brunch for parties larger than 2 can get up around the half hour range on the weekend but the weather will be good, the sun will be glinting off your chain wallet just so and your retro T-shirt with a random state slogan will look perfectly aged so what's your rush?

I have only been here for breakfast.  When you get to your table expect the coffee to come fast and furious.  They were way on top of the coffee situation.  The cornbread is absolutely fabulous.  Ask real nice like for some honey, go all Pooh Bear on that c-bread and then munch away.  Yummmm.  The omelettes I've had have been great; the ingredients taste really fresh.  

Have you ever had to wait a really long time for your dinner and someone says "What did they have to do, kill the cow?"  That's really funny.  If you have a friend like that who you haven't strangled with a tube sock yet take them here and they won't even have a chance to use such a witty one-liner; the service is fast!
author: Steve B.

description:
Wonderful place to get a simple, greasy breakfast. After a sleep in on a lazy weekend day, when you just need some biscuits, potatoes, or eggs, this is the place you want. The wait wasn't short, but with a donut or coffee from Dynamo across the street the wait can even be fun! I had a big scramble and really enjoyed it. 

Definitely want to come back for a milkshake!
author: Daniel F.

description:
I guess I've only come here during off-peak hours because I've never seen the alleged hipsterfest.  The candy and trading card counter, no doubt, doesn't help the cause.  Incidentally, much of the stuff featured at the counter is stuff from MY childhood and I'm older than most of the hipsters pollutting the Mission nowadays.  Fucking fakers.

Oh yeah, I like the food here.
author: Frankie D.

description:
The service has gone down hil! 
I sat at the counter and ordered. Then I moved to a table to eat with friends (6 ' away) and when my food was ready they just placed it at the counter and didnt say anything. Ok this could be my fault for not saying anything to the waitress, mabey she didnt see me. But the reastaurant was half full and then the same waitress sat in between were my food was and where I was now sitting. She was eating her own breakfast...Crazy. I got up and took my food to my new table. 
Anyway when we were done I went to pay my bill and the other waitress told me she left with my check!  Where did she go you might ask.... apparently she went down the street to get coffees for her and her fellow waitstaff. I quess the dont think to highly of the coffe drinks the serve there if they have to get take away for themselves!

Anyway we created a new check and I paid and while I was crossing the street I saw my waitress crossing the other way ( with her tray of coffees) .She then proceeded so yell half way down the block..." did you pay!!!" 
Unbelievable! 

The food was consistant as ever! Very good! It will always bring me through the door... but now I'm going right back out and going anywhere else ...!
author: Marc S.

description:
The St. Francis is like that boyfriend who's really wonderful and does everything right and he should be just perfect for you, but somehow he's just not quite it.  That's how I feel about the St. Francis. I really like this place. I can't recommend it highly enough. I will continue to go here frequently, but it will never quite be my favorite, yunno? It'll always just be good enough, but not quite everything I hoped and dreamed. 

Good choice for breakfast or lunch. There's usually a long line for breakfast on the weekends, but it's probably worth it to wait. Excellent selection of vegetarian dishes, with various fake meats like veggie chorizo and veggie sausage. Plus, soy milkshakes for the vegans out there. And then, yum, the Mitchell's ice cream for those of us who enjoy dairy. Mmmm...I remember my hazelnut malted fondly. Plus, for us meat-eaters in the group, also plenty of burgers & sausage & other delicious dead creatures. 

They always play excellent music - usually some sort of retro soft punk, like the Violent Femmes or the Buzzcocks. And the waitresses are all hot. Lots of extremely hip people with tattoos frequent this place. 

The only thing, though, is that I've been to the St. Francis several times now, and I have to say that I'm not quite as infatuated with it as I was at first. I still really like it a lot, and we'll continue to be friends. But despite that flutter in my heart I felt the first couple of times, I know that the St. Francis will never be the "one."
author: Melinda K.

description:
When my visitors ask "What's a hipster?" I take them to St. Francis. Am I right or am I right?
 
Food is good, milkshakes are awesome, and the counter of bazooka gum and garbage pal trading cards is a trip down memory lane. Another great find in the Mission!
author: Susan L.

description:
I have to say that I really do enjoy this place. And I generally dislike American food and diners, through and through, but the St. Francis Fountain brings diners to a new level, if you ask me. The Caesar salad is top of the line, with ample croutons and dressing! The tuna melt is not bad either, and the milkshakes are made with Mitchell's ice cream. Basically, a no-fail situation. 

A healthy mix of mission locals, hipster and non-hipster alike, although I guess hipsters like diners (or anything old-timey, for that matter) because that's the general vibe going on in there, but hey, that's cool. Really efficient service and no standoff-ish feel to it, which happens on occasion at other hipster enclaves, like ritual coffee roasters on Valencia. You could just be yourself here, and enjoy some great food in the mission while you're at it. 

On weekend mornings, there can be a wait, but nothing like the wait at Boogaloos or the lines at Tartine. Overall, I'd say it's pretty much a go. Everyone who I have taken here has liked it a lot.
author: Shannon R.

description:
This place is great--breakfast anytime and yummy sandwiches.  And, no matter how many pricey places I go to, nobody's croutons beat St. Francis's on the caesar salad.  And, for me, that is absolutely crucial.  I am constantly on the search for excellent crouton and dressing mix.
Anyway, enough of my idiosyncracies, this is a fun place to go.  It's a little overpriced for what you get, but, usually, the waitstaff is friendly and fun and it's nice to have a reliable, old-timey place.
Plus, they have lots of old-timey candy, although they don't carry Sprees.
author: Jessica L.

description:
He must despise me. I left a pear on the bedstand as a gesture, to say sorry. 

At the diner. He didn't share pancakes-- and usually does. 
I'd go as far as say, he'd been sulky. His tone-- when he said things like, pass the syrup-- was harsher than the stance of his shoulders. Otherwise a broad sturdy shelf that wrapped around me so easily, at St. Francis the sides of his arms sort of whipped and snapped at the plate between us. Like an angry child. And I hated it. 

I'd said, please.

"You're too guarded," he said. 

Outside, the cement was black colored from rainwater-- air smelled of it. That touch of weather, made cheeks dew kissed. 

My cheeks, were hot.
author: Jenny T.

description:
Total trip down memory lane. I went here as a child and loved it then. It was closed for awhile when I was down in Los Angeles, but when I moved back up here to NorCal. I was touring one day in the city (now live in Fremont) my then BF (now hubbie) in my old "hood" and saw it was open!

Wow! I was so presently surprised not only did they have all the cool fountain goods I got there as a child, but they had some updated sandwitches that were adult worthy too!

Been there since 1918 save for 2002-2003. That's like almost 90 years of continuous service! 

Must be doing something right.
author: Valerie F.

description:
Another great yelp vegetarian recommendation and Excellent morning after meal. Two of us had the vegan chorizo scramble breakfast and it was amazing. I only wished I could eat here every day for a week and  try everything. I can't remember any of the other options besides something like four tofu scramble variations and a huevos rancheros option. Gotta go back.

I think we waited about 30 minutes for a table. There was a big crowd outside and a sign up sheet hanging near the door. Willingness to sit outside got our largish group of five sat quickly (for some reason it seems like SF lacks tables). Our server even had a Linda's shirt on (similar eatery here in Seattle). We signed up and walked over to L's for coffee anyways. No problem with the wait or eating outside, it was nice out and well worth it. The server ended up getting off and disappearing but someone else helped us and we weren't in any hurry so no loss there. Having only one bathroom was a little disappointing though.
author: Bryan M.

description: Delicious vegetarian options, generous portions, and the relaxed atmosphere were all the reasons we made this our first meal back after being away for a week in the desert. Best decision ever! The hearty comfort food here is a good remedy to placate any hungry beast, and my grumbling belly at the time was a tough contender. It's always so hard to decide on just one thing here, so don't try and instead bring a friend or two and share. We got the Side Platter (bowl of mac & cheese, cup of chili, and caesar salad), the Veggie Mess, and the corn bread. The vegetarian chili was especially delicious since it was on the lighter and healthier side being a three bean chili without fake meat. The chili is NOT another lackluster attempt in the futile fight to make 'meatless' taste 'meaty', so give it a try if you haven't already. The Veggie Mess should be called Hangover Heaven since it is a heavy pile of starchy potato and faux meat covered in gooey cheese heaped on a plate - complete bliss when you have an insatiable appetite. Mac and cheese and corn bread were solid and the caesar was a nice complement to the heavier plates. The only thing on the menu I've had and didn't love was the S.F. Rueben, but then again a veggie Reuben is a hard thing to pull off unless you're Native Foods. Food coma is imminent so enjoy those cups of Joe the servers pour so generously.
author: Carrie G.

description:
Where can you go to get a chef's mess, a chocolate shake, and a set of New Kids on the Block cards? Yup, St Francis!! This place is really yummy and the service isn't shabby either. 

The only flaws are that: it's street parking, the food takes a long time to make, and last time we went the milkshake machine was broken so no shakes for us! Other than that, yummy yummy food! :)
author: Pika C.

description:
We didn't feel like going to far on a rainy afternoon.  So our host for our weekend trip to San Francisco recommended a diner we can walk to.  It was not walking distance!  A few blocks is NOT walking distance.  I'm from Los Angeles.  Anything over two minutes on foot is not walking distance!  Okay... I'll stop complaining.

Maybe it was from being so tired from snowboarding in Tahoe the day before or it could be from walking 500 miles to get there but the food hit that spot.  I swallowed my Chorizo Hash & Eggs in like a minute.  Maybe the food was just okay but that day the food was awesome!

The place seems like its been around for some time and I hope it stays around until I visit San Francisco again in the future.

The diner is a bit small and felt a lil claustrophobic sitting so close to another group but I'm just a whiner from Los Angeles.
author: Andy I.

description:
Malt malt malt, malt.  Malt!  Malt malt -- malt malt malt malt...

I don't even know what it is but it sure makes a great shake.

Good food, nice waitress.  Props for the first menu I've ever encountered to use the word "nebulous"
author: Chris L.

description:
It's Sunday afternoon. I'm on the couch at my friend's place, and we both realize that we've slept in. I mean we've seriously slept in. She wants breakfast; I just want something to eat. So we walk the six blocks or so to St. Francis Fountain and add our names to the tiny (for this time of day) waiting list.

We get a seat, and I'm happy I decided to wear my beard today. Checking out the wait staff, I would have felt naked without one. Looking over the menu, I saw lots of egg dishes, which led me to think I really wanted lunch. Plus, they had a large fountain menu with Mitchell's ice cream. I actually wanted a blended root beer float (sometimes known as a frozen root beer or a root beer freeze). That was too "off the menu" for them, which was disappointing.
