After all, it's not like they didn't have the ingredients... or the blender because I wound up ordering a chocolate shake with my Modesto Pesto chicken sandwich. (By the way, I regularly drive through Modesto, and there aren't as many hipsters or as much pesto as the menu here would suggest.)

Anyway, my friend swore that the best huevos rancheros in the City can be found here. I was skeptical, but then again, I'm not an egg man. While I appreciated both the sentiment and the sentimentality of the red-and-white paper straws mentioned by other reviewers, I was delighted on my second visit to discover a plastic straw came with my milkshake. Now unencumbered by 1930's technology, I declare their straight chocolate milkshake the best ever.

Prices were reasonable for the value.
author: Timothy O.

description:
yeah, it's pretty good.  It seems like people get pretty hyped up about a diner in the mission run by hipsters just for the sake of supporting a diner in the mission run by hipsters, but the quality is pretty much there with this place.  I had the burger since the guy from Myth Busters claims it the best in the city, and it hit the spot for sure!  Best in the city?  Definitely not, but it a good juicy burger.  It was so juicy that it was disintegrating the bun but a few tactful turns in my hand and I was able to get that sloppy beast down the hatch.  Not a huge burger, which means I probably felt better on my walk around the Mission afterwards.

I will say that this is the most hipster place I've ever seen aside from Delores Park on a sunny Sunday, but I don't see the same attitude problem people talk about, including both the clientele and patrons.  Be prepared to wait awhile before they yell your name out, this place gets stupid jammed.  I wouldn't wait half an hour to get in, but if you get get a counter spot fast, take it, it's worth a visit.
author: Jon S.

description:
So... continuing the sage of our mini vacation to San Francisco, we explored the streets around the Mission district after enjoying our stop at Dynamo Donuts.  We'd decided we wanted lunch but didn't have our hearts set on anything in particular.  

After wandering a bit we noticed a little place called St. Francis Fountain on the corner with a grip of hipsters waiting to be seated and some great music playing in the background.  We figured any place with this many people waiting must be good, so we put our names on the list.  We checked out the menu while we waited and my eyes were immediately drawn to the Corned Beef Hash.  My mind was made before we even sat down, I LOVE good hash and its been awhile since I've had any.  We only waited about 10 minutes despite the line and were seated at the counter which only added to the cool vibe.  The inside looks like an old-school fountain shop with church pews for seats in the booths.  I of course got the hash with two eggs and a side of cornbread, and my wife got the Chef's Mess (2 eggs scrambled with homefries, bacon & mushrooms, topped with melted cheese, tomatoes, sour cream & green onions) and a piece of banana bread.

This is some of the best hash I've had in a long time.  My personal favorite is the corned beef hash from Harris Ranch but this is a close second.  Oh and the Chef's Mess was delicious as well.  There must have been 3-4 slices of bacon in there, they definitely didn't skimp.

I wanted to take some pictures of the food but my wife informed me that "cool people" wouldn't do that lol.  Even though I'm not a hipster, if I lived in San Francisco I'd make this a regular breakfast stop.
author: Michael W.

description:
What a splendid dining establishment this is. Who doesn't like this place? Maybe Jesus wouldn't. 

I bet he would. I bet he would accept all the eclectic patrons of this fine restaurant.

That's it then. Everyone loves St. Francis. I've only been once though. Maybe next time I won't like it. Then, it won't be everyone...
author: Jack H.

description:
The food here is delicious... totally homestyle. Every time I come here though, I leave feeling like my torso is just a solid mound of nebulous-potato-thing and chocolate-peanut-butter-malt (o snap!). DEFINITELY without a doubt one of my favorite places to go for a delicious, hearty breakfast. Seriously, for what you get the prices are pretty fantastic. Like I said, always stuffed when I leave. The atmosphere is fun and quirky too :o)
While the service is friendly, it can take a while to get anyone's attention. It's not that they are lazy or anything like that, they're just always *that* busy. So for that I had to do 4 stars :o/  (although I really didn't want to).
author: Gail T.

description: Great comfort food breakfast. Hearty hash browns and soft biscuits make this an awesome spot for breakfast. If you're a fan of good bacon be sure to order it extra crispy!
author: Daryl J.

description:
Just because your hot doesn't give you to be a bitch for no reason. Get it through your hard headed, tattooed self. Holy shit the waitresses are bitches. They wouldn't sass me if they knew I could summon wolves.
Other than that the CHEF'S MESS IS FUCKIN KILLER. Other than bitches for waitresses the place is tight yet a little pricey.
author: Cole M.

description:
Slow, rude service and mediocre food.  

I came to St Francis based on the Yelp! reviews and a friend's recommendation.  When we showed up, there was no one there, but we still had to put our names on a list and wait to be "seated".  When they finally came to seat us, they said "oh, just sit anywhere."

We ordered almost immediately (nebulous potato thing and strawberry waffles).  About 30 minutes later they actually arrived, well after other people who were seated after us were served.  The waffle was soft, not crispy and, aside from the orange zest, pretty boring.  The nebulous potato thing was luke warm, like they'd had it sitting out for 15-20 minutes.  When we were done, we asked the only person who we'd seen in a while for our check, only to be told "You get your check from your server, so you'll just have to wait."
author: Michael D.

description:
Delicious!

I had the vegetarian reuben and I am no vegan/vegetarian. their milkshakes look delicious. Line moved quickly. A lot of hipsters, yes, but it comes with the territory.
author: Luke J.

description:
I think this is one of my favorite places for breakfast. It's conveniently located across from Pop's. I like the atmosphere and the booths. The service was great and the food was yummy!!!

Come on the weekend and they have the Benedict special. I got the egg benedict with bacon and avocado. It was sooo good! My friend got the green onion, bacon, and cheese pancake. I thought it was gonna be weird but I was wrong! It's delicious! I'm usually picky with Chai drinks cause I don't like them to be really spicy but their chai was perfect. Spicy and sweet.

Oh, have I mentioned the boys are cute?
author: Perry S.

description: Loved the decor, the super vegetarian & vegan-friendly menu, and the ability to order latin-inspired food alongside an egg cream. I got the tofu rancheros... others at the table got eggs, something with biscuits and gravy, and a shake. Everyone left full and happy.
author: Robyn M.

description:
First, the menu at St. Francis Fountain overfloweth.

There are lots of option, almost to the point it's hard to decide on what to get if you're eating there for the first time. 

I had hamburger and fries. Very tasty. But I definitely want to return to try the breakfast.

Staff was super friendly and helpful, always a plus. And they have Mitchell's icecream, plus plus.

And it's right next to Brava Theatre, for those of you looking to catch a bite before a show.
author: M O.

description:
Rarely do I have to take such exception to the Yelp crowd.  How can you rate this place this highly?  The staff and the place looks filthy, the booths are made for midgets, and the food is mediocre.

I had a tofu scramble, probably one of the sadder that I've had in SF.  I will give the place credit for having tofu scramble to begin with, so this is a bittersweet review.  I hate to knock a place that has tofu scramble (so few breakfast places for the vegan crowd...), but come on now.

I had a soy-shake which was excellent.  And I mean $5 shake excellent.  So they get bonus points for being so damn vegan friendly.  If only the food and service wasn't so bad.
author: Nelson A.

description:
You should all know, I dislike the Mission.  I don't know why, I just do.  So with any place in the mission, I have an innate bias against it just because of it's location.  With that said, I have found several places in the Mission that are pleasantly surprising.

St. Francis Fountain is definitely pleasantly surprising.  It reminds me of The Creamery in Palo Alto, only more intimate.  I had a burger with cheddar, jack, bacon, and avocado with some of the better fries I've had in San Francisco.  And damn was that ever a good burger.  The wait staff was friendly and responsive and the overall experience was great.

The most disturbing thing about the whole experience was that the three of us went in there at 4pm and the sun was high in the sky only to walk out two hours later to a clear night sky.  I can't deal with these shorter days, dammit - it screws up my whole biological clock.
author: Kurt C.

description:
I like that this place has character.  They've got all these little knick knack things on the wall across from the counter that remind me of the stuff they'd target towards kids that you'd stare at in the check-out aisles when you were a kid at the grocery store ...  in the 80s.  That being said, this restaurant is very much a local neighborhood brunch place much like Bugaloo's and Just For You Cafe.  Aside from that, their wait for breakfast was pretty nonexistent.  This almost always wins points in my book!

That being said, their food is eh, alright.  Their eggs are good but their potatoes, which took up way more of my plate than I wanted it too, were disgusting.  I'm a big fan of having potatoes with my breakfast so I was pretty disappointed.  And their orange juice came in this little tiny sippy cup!  I don't like having to ask for a re-fill every 10 seconds!  Overall it was just eh, okay.
author: Jean A.

description:
Only here at St. Francis Fountain, you can have your ice cream at breakfast, revisit your childhood with Menudo, A-Team and Mork and Mindy cards, and eat a meal with your vegetarian friends, without the guilt of ordering meat.

The best part about St. Francis Fountain, you can substitute, add or change up the menu to your liking. The staff, laid back and extremely generous with the coffee!

Great bacon. I'm in love with the Nebulous Potato Thing with extra sour cream. Must go back for the hotcakes.
author: Judy L.

description:
The veggie burger with cheese was very tasty.  The mac and cheese was good but too oniony for my liking.  And the Buster Brown (brownie, vanilla ice cream, raspberry stuff, whipped cream, walnuts) was sinful but delicious.  The place wasn't busy and the service was fast and friendly.

The cons:
* no lock on bathroom so my friend burst in on some poor kid on the john
* by other yelp reviews I thought I was in for a lot more vegetarian options but, unless you want breakfast (and what breakfast joint doesn't have tons of veggie options?), it's pretty slim pickins for veggies (boca/veggie burger, grilled chz, veggie reuben, veggie chili).
author: Lindsay D.

description:
I'm married to the son of a preacher man, and he has converted me... to the joys of Sunday brunch.  Of all the places we've sampled, St. Francis Fountain is my favorite.

Yeah, there's a wait, but things move at a good pace and I've never waited longer than 45 minutes.  (If you ask, they'll let you have some coffee to help while away the time.)  The food is always tasty, the milkshakes thick and delicious, and the servers are really sweet.  I've never felt a "cooler than thou" vibe from anyone working there.  The menu has something for everyone, from vegan to carnivore, and the portions are just right.  I'm a firm believer in the power of their "nebulous potato thing."  It'll brighten your day.

Can't finish the review without mentioning the candy counter.  It always gets a smile out of newcomers.
author: Justina K.

description:
Just started going to this place.  I am a bit biased because it is so close to my house.  The crowd is hip.  The food is good. The bill isn't too big.

Also, the wait isn't very long.  Get in. Get food. Get out.  Simple enough for a guy like me.
author: Thadd L.

description:
Everything else is just hype compared to the saint. Any one who ever kicked it in the pulpit and ate a sunday, knows what I mean. the only remaining Ice cream joint in SF that is still the same. Double rainbow when it was on 24th and noe was the only thing that compared but you couln't sit down and get a sunday delivered to you or get a ukfin egg cream where else can you get a egg cream (back eastin jersy is the only place I can think of) I haven't been back here since like 98  I'm going soon.

so read the reviews which stated all my biggest fears... then I went

so's I went and...
It's not the same it's lame, really sad. I wanna go back in time. the decor was the same but it was like some shoemaker set up shop inside of an ice cream parlor. No class... there goes the neighborhood...go back to what ever suburb you came from and give me back my history. The mission used to be full of people who tried to look decent and had culture. Now it has been diluted by people who take pride in the grunge and sport tatoos because some other fuck did it.  then move to the city because they're daddys suburban money afforded them the privledge to run away from his cultureless existance...Now your here raizing and monoculturing my hood. man go fuck somewhere else.
author: Rhasaan F.

description: Yummmm! Creative fresh diner style food!
author: Stacy H.

description: The ultra-cool waitresses are way too cool to do the job properly or with any amount of urgency whatsoever, we ordered food to et and some to take 'to go', they didn't even start making the 'to go' food until after we were done eating our meal, which made us super late and when I suggested jut taking that off the bill she literally sneered 'it'll just be a few minutes'. I wondered what took her so long to process my credit card and just now when I looked at my bank statement, she had wrongly charged my card for someone else's order on top of my order and never even told me about it. what if my card had been at the limit and I would have gotten charged an overdraft or something? the food is OKd and the candy novelties are hip, but i would avoid it at all costs.
author: Susanne A.

description:
love ice crea and want have ice cream even though you are lactose intolerant? hipster fetish? Mission Lover? Ice Cream and Gelato?

yeah. this place has all four. I only apply for the first and the last one.
author: Derek Alistair J.

description:
love this place and the fact it's within walking distance from my house...plus you run into so many colorful characters from general (no wait that's riding on the 9) anyway good sandwiches and the array of side orders is amazing (mac and cheese, salad, homefries etc) Much love for the dreamsicle milkshake, though depending on the maker, can be kind of uneven. But the perfect blend of milk sorbet and whatever else is in there is delightful. 
On a somewhat unrelated note, my ex hated this place cuz he got extreme food poisoning at least a couple of times...but I've never gotten sick and I know at least a dozen other ppl who haven't.  Oh well, he can rot in davis, I'll be enjoying the hipster cuties here...
author: Marie W.

description:
The food and service is fabulous.  The wait, not so fabulous.  But that is to be expected on a Sunday at 11:30 am.  They were able to accommodate 6 of us with an outside table and a 45 minute wait.  I didn't mind it so much.  The sun was shining and I was with good company.  The other 5 were suffering mild to severe hangovers and neither the sunshine nor the company seemed to lift their moods.

When we got seated and were all served our drinks from coffees to milkshakes, and pitchers of water, spirits were lifted.  I'm picky about my coffee and was craving philz down the block, but was pleasantly surprised by their coffee (it was probably Folgers.  When I lived in Florida, we used to always go to this breakfast spot for their incredible coffee.  I moved to Chicago and visited Florida a few months after the move.  My friend and I went to the breakfast place and I asked the server about the coffee.  Sure enough, it was Folgers.  At least I admit to it.  Maybe I'm not so picky after all.).  Our server was both attentive and adorable.  Even if the food and coffee were terrible, I'd go back for him.

I had the vegan chorizo hash.  Yum.  I've always wanted to try chorizo but not being a pig or cow eater, I haven't taken the plunge.  My friend also ordered the vegan chorizo hash and said it tasted very close to the real thing.  The serving was big, but not too big and was coated with the perfect amount of grease.  Everyone at the table was satisfied with their meals.  A few had different scramble combinations, one breakfast burrito, and a burger.

I really would like to give this place 5 stars, but being another blown up Mission brunch spot with entirely too long of a wait, I have to drop it to 4.  Oh, and if you get there and would like to wait with booze, you can go across the street to Pop's and have a mimosa and the restaurant will call you when your table is ready.
author: Zoe H.

description:
I have only been here twice but both times it was great.  My boyfriend loved his food as well.  There are too many things too choose from (and plenty of vegetarian choices) so it takes us a long time to decide what we want.  
We saw someone order the Guiness float our first time there and my boyfriend had to try it.  He did not like it at first but once all of the ice cream was stirred in he did.  Once we added a squeeze of chocolate to it it was even better.  I could not have much of it (plus we were there for breakfast,  not what I usually drink).
Everyone there has been really helpful so far and we have not had to wait in any lines.
author: Nam Kirn D.

description:
Please don't go here on the weekend, thank you. I lived across the street and this place is just too darn good. Super veggie friendly and just plain friendly. Love, love, love me some Francis.
 Tofu scrambles, veggie chili and cornbread, soy vanilla milkshakes, Boca burgers, and if you are a cow sucker this is the spot for an egg cream (if you don't know, fuggetaboutit).
author: Steve R.

description:
Ok, so I totally wanted to give this place 5 stars for pure nostalgia factor... but I can't.

I used to come here all the time with my parents when I was young, I would always get the tuna melt with a vanilla shake and then some good ol' fashion licorice.

Well, I went back since I was a kid a couple of years ago and have to say I was disappointed.  The food itself is pretty good, it's simple food, no frills.  The service is annoying, it's Mission hipsters who think they are too good to serve you.  I don't like the fact that they have tofu scrambles, what is that ???? I mean this place is a diner, not a cool, hip new-age restaurant.

Anyway, it 's unfortunate that such a great place like St. Francis Fountain  has turned into nothing more than just an ordinary place with bad service.  I do love the way they've kept the exact same way it looks, the super old booths and the super old school decor is great!!
author: Michi R.

description:
I hate to go here on weekends for brunch, only because it is JAM packed with people and impossible to get a table. However, because I live just around the corner, I have the luxury of coming on the weekdays for breakfast or linner- much better. And I'm a bit offended at a previous posters implication that this is a sketchy neighborhood! I walk around by myself at night all the time and have never felt unsafe, much less during broad daylight. Just because this side of the Mission isn't crawling with people in skinny jeans, doesn't mean it's sketchy! 

Anyway, enough of my little tirade... their shakes are amazing and huge, and I especially love their sourdough french toast, which they top with some yogurt and granola, which I've never had before. I'm more of a meat eater myself, but my husband really likes the veggie food here. The wait staff has always been very nice and attentive, but then again I tend to avoid weekend brunch times.
author: Nicole A.

description:
I have so many warm and fuzzy feelings about the original St. Francis with its house-made candy counter, beautifully sparse menu of inexpensive items, and quiet environs (where WERE all the customers besides the old-timers who knew the family that owned it back when St. Francis was a wee lad?) that I admit I had major qualms about patronizing the more recent, amped-up, muscley, tattoo-ridden, St. Francis-on-'roids edition. The lines. The seemingly surly waitstaff. The new, pricier menu selections. The dense thicket of hipsters. Could I afford it? Did I have the thick skin and testosterone? Was my wardrobe up to the experience?

Well, all is well: the vegetarian and vegan selections especially rock - I'm besotted with their vegetarian reuben. The staffers turn out to be less miffed than extremely pressured and busy. The candy counter may be gone but it seems like the new owners nonetheless did the best they could to preserve the original ye-olde-soda-fountain '40s-'50s ambience. You DO eventually get in.

P.S. The featured photo is truly frightening - yuck, you wouldn't want to step on that on the sidewalk. But don't be afraid - the food is tastier than THAT looks.
author: Kim C.

description:
FOOD: FOUR STARS (* * * *)
My boyfriend and I ordered the "Chef's Mess" (a concoction of eggs, cheese, bacon and other veggies in scrambled form--somewhat like an omelet but more mixed up) and the Banana & Walnut pancakes.  The Chef's Mess was fantastic, all of the flavors being perfectly balanced and complementary with one another (creamy cheese with salty bacon, etc).  The Banana & Walnut pancakes were great, although a tad on the dry side, as pancakes tend to be.  I would get both again, however they had many varieties of pancakes and I would probably try a different kind next time, perhaps with whipped cream to up my calorie intake.  The coffee was pleasantly strong and tasty.

ENVIRONMENT/SERVICE: THREE STARS (* * *)
Despite a multitude of hipsters in front of the restaurant, presumably waiting to get in (or congregating to head to the nearest American Apparel?), we didn't have to wait long, probably 10 minutes at most, and we were there at the prime-time brunch hour of 11:00am.  The service inside the restaurant was average--I felt it took a bit too long to have anybody come by for the drink orders, but other than that, it was fine.

VALUE: FOUR STARS (* * * *)
The prices are certainly reasonable for what you get--this isn't IHOP with a $5.99 all-you-can-eat Pancake-a-thon, but neither is this bourgeois territory.  Two $$ is entirely appropriate.  The Chef's Mess was $8 while the stack of three Banana & Walnut pancakes was around $7.  Coffee came in at $2 per mug with free refills.

Average of
FOOD: FOUR STARS
ENVIRONMENT/SERVICE: THREE STARS
VALUE: FOUR STARS
================
AVERAGED GRAND TOTAL: FOUR STARS

Estimated price per person (excluding drink):
$9-11

Would I recommend it to others?
Yes.  I think this is a great SF breakfast place for pretty much everyone.

Would I return?
Yes.
author: Benjamin L.

description:
Love the look of this place - the old signage, neon lights, wooden booths, red Naugahyde & steel barstools. Authentic and nostalgic feel.

Love that the menu has veg & vegan options. Very cool.

Don't love that I waited 17 minutes (after ordering) for a take out malt. Is it really that complex? And really don't love that the "large" malt was precisely 16oz (in a 20oz cup), because the tragically hip server spilled a good portion of it as he was pouring it from the tin. That wouldn't have bothered me so much, had they not charged me $8.49 for the damn thing. $8.49 for a malt? Really?

I love to support small, independent, locally owned places, and this one is near my house. I really want to like this place, and to be fair, I have had more positive experiences there in the distant past. But this visit kinda ruined it for me. Bummer.
author: Laura G.

description:
I used to live a block away from here a year ago.  Although I am a complete Oakland convert now, I do miss having such a place so close by.

While the food is closer to 3 stars, getting the chance to be in this beautifully restored space during off hours is a true delight.  Everything from the phone booth to the fan fixture to the sign hanging over the street...
author: Anjel V.

description:
Despite the spot being smothered with hipsters like their perfect pancakes are smothered with butter, this is my favorite breakfast/lunch/sundae spot in the city. I have been going here since I was 5, yes, really there are still SF locals here, and although I am pretty sure the majority of the patrons at the St. Francis Soda Fountain are LA hipster transplants, I can ignore that for the amazingness that is their food. I love the simple, unstuffy feel of the atmosphere, the tiny booths are great to sit at, but I love being front and center at the counter.

The best three breakfast items are (in no particular order) fried egg sandwich with bacon, chorizo and egg scramble, and their pancakes. Simple dishes, but some how St. Francis makes them divine. Perfect portions, I never leave feeling too full, and I always clean my plate, and am tempted to order a sundae...but maybe thats just me :)

PLUS the best prices for really great food!
author: Sophie T.

description:
I went here with my husband and toddler on New Year's day.  It was an OK experience.  I had the chorizo and eggs due to the raves I read about it on here! but I was quite disappointed.

Their country biscuits with gravy was "to die for" though - my husband's exact words. 

The milkshake was ok. Maybe I should have gotten the vanilla? We got the chocolate.  Toddler, of course, loved them.

I don't think I'd ever treck over the bridge to come here again... if it was a couple blocks from my place of residence, I might be a frequest guest.
author: Mary C.

description:
Finally a place where you can get breakfast all day that beats out the neighborhood Denny's. It's not like it is hard to beat out Denny's but it is hard to find a place that will make breakfast at night, right. 

The place looks much like the way it was opened back in the twenties. All of the booths and counters have to be at least 30-40 years old which gives it character, but with character comes the aging lines of time. It was easy to recognize where to sit in the booth because the butt prints of diners' past marked the landing zone with cracks and holes in the leather. The booths stand up straight like wooden castles that surround your party. 

The food feels like they throw the kitchen sink at you. We had the french toast delight and the chef's mess. The french toast was anything but french and instead resembled the desert mountains of the west right after the first snow storm of the year. The toast was deep in the mountain floor under piles of strawberries, pineapples, nut, apples, raisins and sugar powdered granola. Ribbons of yogurt lined the lodes of french toast. I enjoyed it just as much as the 49'ers... the 1849ers upon discovering gold at Sutter's mill. The contrast between the different textures and flavors, made the whole dish enjoyable with little nuggets of delight in every bite.

The chef's mess was what it claimed to be with eggs, cheese, sour cream, green onions and of course the most important ingredient... bacon. With these ingredients, its like shooting fish in a barrel when it comes to making something tasty. Rather than make your stomach feel like it hits your knees the mess was lighter and energizing.

The food was hearty but not overbearing. It seemed that the waiters were not eating it though because they were both morbidly skinny. I am coming back next time I feel like pancakes late, yet I don't want to feel like a bloated whale afterward. You won't find food that will confuse you, instead it will be as if you are coming back to the family owned diner of your hometown, where everybody knows your name.
author: Mark L.

description: The Chef's Mess is delicious! And I loved the homemade Banana Bread. This breakfast was a pleasant surprise and I can't wait to go back for lunch or a milkshake!
author: Barbie L.

description:
my boyfriend and i go here every weekend.  kind of embarrassing that they know what i want to drink and eat before we even sit down BUT pretty cool they remember none the less :)  

highly recommend this place for sure.  great vegetarian menu, good atmosphere/vibe, good tunes, cool candies n what not and excellent service and staff.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
Yummy mac & cheese, great/super friendly service, and freaking fantastic anything shake.
My friend got fantastically ill off of the chocolate chip pancakes, which is always a good sign.
author: kristin n.

description:
First look at the waitstaff and I thought to myself, "Now there's a bucket-full of attitude waiting to happen."  Yes, I was being completely judgmental and classist against some punk-rock hipsters.  And I was so wrong...

I've been there so many times I can no longer count. The staff is all really friendly, willing to talk about their Megadeth t-shirts without a bit of irony, and the food and shakes are rockin'.

Breakfast is best, especially the nebulous potato thing.  Shakes are made with Mitchells, which can't be beat, and the wait is never as long as it seems.
author: cindy p.

description:
Lots of classic diner fare plus re-worked vegetarian and vegan options! The tofu scrambles are good, so is the veggie reuben. The cornbread is spicy and delicious, and the soy shakes are *fantastic*!
The food can be hit or miss when they're busy on the weekends. 
If you're looking for a server job, lots of tats seem to be a pre-requisite, so the un-inked need not apply.
author: Veena S.

description:
I'm so relieved to have found an American food place near SFGH.  I was here last week and I am very pleased with the quantity and quality of the food I ordered.  And my Chocolate Shake was to die for!!!
I was here 7 years ago and I remembered having a good experience, but now that I work near by, I will frequent this place much more.
author: N A.

description:
I came here with a group of friends who live in the neighborhood, and I must say this place is a treat! :)  They made one of the best grilled cheese sandwiches I've had, and just to cheese things up I had the option of getting macaroni and cheese on the side.  I must say, it was fantastic!  I'm a cheese fiend, and St. Francis Fountain did a fine job of satisfying a demon craving!

That aside, the diner was absolutely adorable!  And not in that "touristy" kind of way like at Lori's in Union Square!  I just didn't like sitting next to the restroom....  Oh, well....

I'm a fan and definitely plan on coming back! :)
author: Jacqueline T.

description:
This place has totally grown on me.
The first time I tried it, I was kind of, what's all the fuss?  A few more tries and it's deservedly on my list of regular places.  I instantly loved the decor - old fashion soda fountain with booths and a big long counter at which to consume your malted milkshake or your banana split.  Lots of hipsters of course, but lots of other people too.  It feels nice and homey, the staff are always nice if not always super attentive.
I usually go for brunch and it's always pretty damn good.  Weekend brunch specials excite me - The Benedict is really awesome.  I usually avoid anything with bacon as it's always burned almost past recognition.  There's also a lot of vegan options which I'm not interested in but I'm sure many others will be.  
I've come here for lunch and the sandwiches are good, and there are yummy sides like mac and cheese and soup and chilli - true diner style.  I've also come here late at night to sit at the counter and get a banana split and I'll admit it - I felt special.
Be prepared to wait on the weekends - they've recently taken over the space next door to deal with their high weekend volume but its not always in use.  Grab a cup of Philz on the way, write your name down, and enjoy the weekend bustle as you wait for a damn good brunch.
author: Jane F.

description: Great Place long wait on weekends for breakfast but the foods good and the enrgy from all the college kids is great. fun place to go great food
author: Nick L.

description: Good breakfast, cures the hangover right up. Service is pretty slow and it's pretty busy on the weekends, but the food is worth it
author: Caitlin S.

description: If you haven't enjoyed brunch at St. Francis, you're missing out.  This place is more than your neighborhood diner, it is an institution, similar to Tadich Grill and the House of Prime Rib, and maybe one of the oldest diners around.  And while diner offerings stir up memories of eggs, bacon, potatoes and white toast, St. Francis does that and more.  While having all your diner favorites like eggs Benedict and piled high French toast, they also have all your favorite veg options for the most discerning of palates.  So, next time you're on 24th street, stop by St. Francis and enjoy one of their lovely milkshakes, but get there early or be prepared to wait, this place is always packed.  One last thing, this place is stocked with your old school favorites like garbage pale kids trading cards, bazooka gum, and cry babies!  Enjoy!
author: David M.

description: Tons of Vegetarian options. I got the 2 egg scramble with potatoes and toast, it was SUPER delicious! Great place for breakfast or lunch.
author: Melissa S.

description:
Now this is Comfort food!
An old diner/fountain shop that looks like they kept the same decor since 1954.
The food is a special twist on classic american breakfast and diner food.
The shakes are a definite must.
Worth the wait on busy mornings
author: Chuck D.

description: Cute, no fuss diner in the midst of a sea of mexican eateries. This place is great to get a full meal and offers promising diner food. I had the chicken soup and salad with mac and cheese and the mac and cheese stood out the most. It had just the right amount of creamy cheesiness and the crispy top layer. The waitress was really friendly and offered to help out. Beware though, the menu is really long in case you don't dig this. Personally, I don't mind reading a novel to get to my meal. My friend ordered a cheesburger with fries and it was huge. She thought it was okay but it looked hella good when she was ripping into it. She says she gives it a 2.6 "it was okay" as she makes the so-so hand gesture. Eh, too bad, mah food was good.
author: Justine C.

description:
The food is okay. I've had better from other greasy spoon diner joints. There's nothing there that's outstanding if you factor in the price. The country breakfast is good. The hash browns are good. It's just not worth 9 bucks. You should be able to leave a greasy spoon diner for around 10 bucks a person including tip and tax but ended up spending ~15 bucks a head which is insane which one considers the other alternatives in SF.

The wait staff is genuinely nice and friendly but could be faster.

The kitschy souvenirs are contrived and it doesn't seem like there's a genuine enthusiasm in the 50's theme.
author: Andy L.

description: Unique twist on classic brunch food. A little intensely hipster, but worth braving the scene and the long wait for the food.  Mitchell's ice cream used in the shakes! Get banana.
author: Kacie O.

description:
Hopping with gloriously tattooed hipsters and soothing my Sunday morning hangovers with endless coffee while I wait patiently, lusting over the sexy lingerie in the window next door. I love this place. It has never failed me, not even once. 

The eggs benedict is to die for, and the nebulous potato thing is a deliciously sloppy pile of indulgence. By far my favorite brunch in the city.
author: A. M.

description: It is a quaint restaurant in the Mission and it had a few people waiting outside to eat at this place - it must be good, right? I didn't like the chili cheese fries but I did really enjoy the Macaroni & Cheese, which my boyfriend had and also shared with me. My bacon cheeseburger was yummy but nothing really special. And of course, my boyfriend and I got a Butterscotch Italian soda and a banana shake to share. ^_^
author: Jessica S.

description: This place always seems to be slammed.  Is it the food? the prices? Naw...I think it's more of the scene.  Man, I felt out of place without the tight jeans, greasy hair or major B.O..Just playing!!  The sandwiches were average to me so people must be lining up for their breakfast. I'll have to come back and check it.   The place is pretty cool though and the servers are  friendly.
author: Ramon L.

description:
I been here twice. 

Great friendly service from waiters both times. Thank you

I had the "Huevos Rancheros" both times
although they still taste a bit like canned food (the salsa, beans, etc)
but so do all "Huevos Rancheros" I've had everywhere unless made at home from my grandmother in Mexico. 
This ones taste good enough. 
I love that they pour coffee everytime! The music is great! The ambiance is great. 
I need to try the milkshakes and other items next time. 



My friend didn't really enjoy this place because the crowd looked like too Hipster style, they looked like "Lindsey Lohan"  type to me... 
He feels the Mission is changing to what it used to be and is being overtaken by this crowd... 

But since I'm just way out of these hipster crowd, I don't really even notice. I like it because is an escape from my social circle.
author: Geena T.

description:
we used to come here about every weekend because, quite frankly, i love eggs benedict. 

their eggs benedict is quite tasty.  but, be warned, it's only offered on weekends, it is not served after 3pm and it's one of the most pricey things on the menu.  once we discovered how to make delicious eggs benedict at home, however, i became less inclined to spend 11$ every sunday.  

we stopped in again last weekend and i opted for the lunch food over the breakfast food.  my tuna melt was indeed melt-in-your-mouth and the side of mac and cheese was perfectly cheesy and had a nice crispy layer of crunch on top.  not sure it's a reason to make this my weekly brunch stop, but it was satisfying enough to keep me coming back.

rather long lines on weekends at brunch time.  kind of scattered wait service (friendly .. but sometimes just confusing..).  they also apparently serve mitchell's ice cream so that's cool too.
author: Lily B.

description: I love this place. The food is great (and I'm not really a huge fan of breakfast), and the atmosphere is awesome. They have great outdoor seating, and the inside of this place reminds me of the diner scene in Back to the Future. The last time I was there they were playing nothing but 80's pop, which made my meal that much better.
author: Matt F.

description:
Right around the corner.  Bitchin' brunch and I had a pretty sweet bacon cheeseburger yesterday.  Theres a bunch of veg options on the menu too.

It seems like this is the only non-mexican spot in a 10 block radius.  

Well, as long as you don't count the pizza joint on 24th and Potrero.

Which I don't.
author: Adam C.

description: St. Francis Fountain and Creamery is one of the old diner haunts in the City. Classic diner food, burgers, fries, shakes and the like are the specialty. Happy to see it is still around.
author: Jonathan F.

description:
I went to this place yesterday morning for the first time because my friend and I were craving some greasy spoon type fare.   This place hit the spot!  I ordered the biscuits and gravy with a side order of bacon (oh yeah, my arteries are closing up just from typing that sentence) and surprisingly the gravy was so much better than I thought it was going to be.  This really didn't taste like your run of the mill canned gravy.  It has some spices and flavors going on that I didn't expect from this joint.  And the bacon, well don't even get me started on the bacon.   I know me some bacon, and this was pretty duuuurned good bacon.  This wasn't some limp-dick, see-thru, paper-thin, bacon you might get at Denny's or IHOP or some other chain type place.  This bacon was thick, salty, and crunchy, just the way it's supposed to be.  The homefries weren't half bad either.  Normally homefries aren't my thing, I always find big chunks of potatoes to be too dry and starchy.  But these were mixed up with little bit of green onions and probably cooked in a nice amount of oil/lard/something to keep them somewhat moist.  

This place is a little heavy on the hipster vibe, but the waitstaff was actually really nice to us.  We sat at the counter so maybe that's why we got a little more attention since they're right in your face while they grab silverware or make the coffee.  But they were johnny-on-the-spot with the coffee and water refills.

Folks are right, it's not the cheapest greasy spoon in town.  But I'd go back for that gravy!!!
author: D L.

description:
I love this place! Incredibly good food with great service. We always get greeted like we have been coming here for years(even though we just discovered it a few months ago). The service is excellent because the friendly staff totally goes out their way to back each other up and make sure everyone is covered for everything.
They even bring us water and heaps of compliments for our dogs.
author: dianne p.

description: Just your cute neighborhood diner with a great selection of desserts.  It has tasty offerings for the vegetarian, vegan and carnivore.  I'm a regular there for breakfast/brunch so I enjoy going.
author: Marjorie G.

description: great potatoes holy moly!! service mediocre at best, cool points for the coat rack stands at each table! very original! however didnt appreciate the hair in my coffee!!! gross! how do i know it wasnt mine? i have black hair thats why! this was a short light brown hair. killed my appetite. worse part , i paid for it . not a big deal but its the principle that counts for me . will not come back :/
author: Christina M.

description:
Ate my first ever patty melt here. Yes, I am aware that I am little off. Had to ask what it was exactly, and upon ascertaining the facts, I knew it was right up my alley.

It shaped my expectations of patty melts for the rest of my life, and I'm glad it did the treat justice. Haven't found one quite as good around L.A. yet, but at least I can fall back on the expensive as balls one at Jerry's Famous Deli.

I personally didn't get a shake but ended up siphoning some from my peers. Twas fairly bomb.

Very homey feel to this place. Supposedly this is where the idea for the San Francisco 49ers was hatched, so that's cool. Employees hooked us up. I considered buying some packs of Yo! MTV Raps cards.

/end of experience
author: George D.

description:
if i spend the night in SF, i almost always wind up here for breakfast. the food is terrific! i highly recommend the "chefs mess" with the cornbread. the chefs mess is a jumble of goodness. eggs, bacon, potatoes and mushrooms; topped with lots of cheese, sour cream and diced tomatoes. they make their own cornbread so it is very fresh, warm and tasty!

the service here has always been pretty good. well, except for the fact that everybody that works there look like hipsters. ie: looks unhappy/depressed, skinny jeans, fashionable haircuts, tattoos, etc. but that doesn't bother me at all. i just expect it. lol!

the price? pretty fair. i usually walk away with a to-go container with what i can't finish while only paying about $14. not bad.
author: Sally Q.

description: This breakfast joint was superb. Super friendly service. The food didn't take to long to come out and it was delicious. I ordered the homemade corned beef hash. I would recommend that you try this place out. While not everyone is a meat eater, their menu had vegetarian selections as well. Go ahead spend the roughly 9$ per plate and grub down.
author: Ryan P.

description: This is what diner food should be. Cheap, tasty, and with lots of milkshakes. The line is huge but it moves quick. I scarfed down my country breakfast and was deliciously full all day. Sad I didn't have the egg cream chocolate float, I know I would have loved it (mmm egg cream).
author: hello y.

description:
St. Francis gets a lot of my business simply because it's the closest place to my home with edible food. Plus, it's open until 10pm when many of taquerias have closed down.

I like that I have several options for veggie and boca burger constructions. I wish I wasn't trying to watch my girlish figure, though, because I'd love to try the shakes at some point.

The crowd can be annoying on weekends, but the rest of the week is okay.
author: Jere K.

description:
The food has never let me down - chef's mess without sourcream is perfect hangover food. The wait isn't. The only reason that I'm not rating them higher is that they're a diner with a candy counter that gave me the I-hate-you-but-I'll-act-tolerant smirk when my friend and I brought her (silent, sleeping) baby. And they know me. And what they know about me is that I'll tip a minimum of 25% because anything less isn't ethical in a city as expensive as this.
But I've slung a few eggs in my day and can move on with my life, sans-child.
author: Mer S.

description:
St. Francis is the place that put "nebulous potato thing" on the map. It's not the place to go for coffee, but it's got your brunch needs covered (plus Philz is only 4 blocks away). 

This place is very hipster and on a weekend around noon you will be waiting. But hey, it's not as bad as Boogaloos. Plus the wait staff is nicer. The food is better too.  Plus there's a new underwear shop next store. Jesus, what more do you want?
author: eliah g.

description: Great for milkshakes at the counter.  Very Mission place.  We go regularly.  Don't forget to get some Mr. T bubble gum or other old school 80s candy on your way out.
author: Tim O.

description:
I want a hot fudge sundae please, and someone to help me eat it after spending the day wandering all over the Mission. I love the St. Francis, though I haven't been in a while, it pleases me to know they're keeping it real. Contextually, it's like a weird, icecream-and-candy-coated history lesson atop all the great and varied cultural stuff that is 24th street. The non-ice creamy foodstuff is actually decent, diner fare too. But I'm more apt to get some tacos and save the Fountain for dessert. 

Hrrr now I'm realizing I forgot to eat dinner, whoops. :D hungrrrry!
author: Kamio N.

description:
Hidden amidst the tacquerias and panaderias is the St Francis Fountain, which used to be an old ice cream shop. It's since been transformed into a happening breakfast spot. The food is very good, with creative dishes and names. I've only had breakfast here.  All of the food was fresh, the vegies were not overcooked, the pancakes and eggs were fluffilicious.

Recommended for breakfast meetings during the week. Avoid on the weekend unless you can bear waiting an hour.
author: Spoon G.

description:
We live about 100 yards from this place, and that's one of the best parts of living in the Mission. 

There's always a wait for brunch, and there's a good reason for that. Everything is good, especially the pancakes and the corned beef hash. My roommate swears by the Nebulous Potato Thing. 

Also good for ice cream, most notably the brownie sundae and the iconic Guinness Float. Oh and great burgers.

St. Francis is def. a Scene Kid Diner, but the way I see it, that only results in a better soundtrack. Ladytron at brunch? Yes, please.

Great job!
author: Jeff R.

description:
I don't like their biscuits or anything they make with potatoes. 

However, everything else there is pretty damn awesome. Especially their dreamsicle.
author: Jon G.

description:
I really like this place. They have a really good selection of food, though it isn't always clear what you're getitng. Once or twice, normally when ridiculously hungry, I've managed to order "big sounding" food and recieved a paltry plate of nothingness.

Their shakes are **amazing** and add at least 2 stars to my rating.

The wait staff are mediocre, there is one girl there that has a killer walk, I feel as though I begin overly salivating whenever she walks past :( kinda embarassing. 

Generally you don't get everything you ordered, or its wrong - but hell, its worth it for the shakes!
author: mike o.

description:
I will say, yes the food is good and if I could get it myself, I would go back.
This is the 2nd time I've been here, food was good but the service put me in such a bad place I have decided it's not worth it.

From the start our ( my friend's & my ) interaction with the server was a tad strained because we asked for something he clearly wasn't interested in providing.  We tried to smooth things over by killing with kindness but at that point, we probably had simply given him a card to be granolier-than-thou.  The food came very quickly but every interaction was prickly.  We didn't get coffee refills and god knows we were smart enough not to ask.    

On a slightly humorous yet telling note:  for someone from Los Angeles ( me ) to complain about attitude, it's gotta be bad.

Instead of I recommend Boogaloos, the Pork Store Cafe or Curly's ( in North Beach )
author: mike s.

description:
Due to the Lunch Rush that never materialized, the waitperson insisted I leave 4 adjacent seats at the counter open (me sitting in the 5th), thus forcing me to sit  next to an all-elbows woman who was hacking up a lung. 

I will never be able to stomach the Devil Burger (seitan sandwich) again... but I will be back for the vegan banana walnut pancakes with real maple syrup.
author: Unfriendly V.

description:
I can't believe the beating this place is getting on Yelp lately. I moved a block away from here a few months ago, and this place (and Taqueria San Francisco) is my standby!

Hipsters? Yes. Crowded? Yes (at the predictable times, duh). Cheap ingredients? Sometimes - the syrup is Jemima knockoff and my iced tea comes from a soda fountain. On the other hand, they have the freshest, best veggies I've seen for their sides; in fact, the very best side salads I've had in a diner. Try the Caesar - real Parmesan (which almost never happens) with romaine! Delicious!

In terms of food, I stick to a couple favs. The Bird is hands down the  best chicken burger I've ever had, well worth the money. Additionally, you can't go wrong with anything on the menu involving grilled chicken. Their fries are tasty - and ice cream sodas are great too, the soy ice cream they serve is delicious. My only culinary disappointment there came with one of the combo breakfasts, which was just too messy and didn't have enough flavor. However, I just went back today for scrambled eggs and pancakes with a fruit cup (again, fresh, delicious produce) and loved it. Great pancakes are HARD to find in a diner, but these guys know what it's all about. Even the fakey syrup couldn't fuck 'em up.

In terms of these service complaints, I don't know what other yelpers are talking about. I guess first impressions are everything - and mine was charming and delicious. The service was sweet without being condescending, not to mention attentive. (Kids come here all the time, after all) I never leave the place without being thanked on the way out, and I always get my order taken within a couple minutes of walking in the door - and the food about 10 minutes max afterwards.

Listen, LA would KILL for a place like this. St. Francis is what a diner should be, the perfect balance of cheap and chic, and I'm happy to be a repeat customer.
author: Jasper L.

description: Sometimes I get plagued by indecision. After a delightful hike with the girlfriend, we sought sustenance. Driving through the Mission this establishment caught our eyes. We went around the block and found a magic parking space feet from the door. Our meal was served---I had the pesto chicken sandwich with chili and fries. Everything was perfect with one exception: for some reason they do not serve Heinz ketchup.
author: Cameron K.

description: This place is my absolute favorite place in the entire city! I usually go for dinner but they serve breakfast items all day. They have Mitchell's ice cream which is a really good quality ice cream. I always try to get the nebulous potato thing when I am there and a chocolate coke, because it IS an old school soda fountain. The service is always nice and the diner looks like you just went through a time warp back to 1950's. In the evening, I can usually find street parking but parking in the morning is a nightmare. Still, the food is so great that we manage!
author: Sandi Y.

description: This place is a gem!  Open since 1918, this old-school soda fountain/ice cream shop/diner is a delight.  The staff is fast and friendly (and tatted up and hipster-y if you're into that kind of thing ;)) and they offer a great selection of breakfast fare, sandwiches & diner food.  I'm an omnivore but I love the fact that they are so veggie friendly here, there are plenty of tofu or seitan options (and I don't mean that in the "there are 1-2 options" kind of way) and even even soy milkshakes!  I ordered the Modesto Pesto sandwich, nothing special, I can make better pesto & the chicken was pretty dry but that won't deter me from coming back.  Their chicken cilantro soup was absolutely delicious and next time I'll order a whole bowl, not just a cup.  I love the authentic retro ambiance and there are fun trading cards and gum (21 Jump Street anyone?) and paraphenalia to add to the old school vibe.  If you're in the 24th & mission area, this is a definitely a great place to grab some lunch or just a sweet snack and relax.
author: Suzanne V.

description: My hubby and I wandered in here one sunny afternoon after checking out an apartment nearby.  I was very impressed by the wide variety of entrees on their menu, particularly for vegetarians. We each ended up having ice cream and sitting at the bar, which was lovely. I hope to come back and sit in the little wooden booths some time. I like it here.
author: Anne Y.

description: I came here after finding it on yelp and decided to give it a try. My friend and I absolutely loved this place! It really is a 50's style diner/malt shop. I decided to come here because of how vegan friendly it seemed to be. The menu is a couple pages and it truly is vegan/vegetarian friendly. My friend had vegetarian chili which she thought was really good. I had the vegan blueberry pancakes which was soooo delicious! I also ordered a vegan butterscotch milkshake. It took a very long time for the shake to come out so they didn't charge us and I ended up. Tip: Ask for a couple straws because the straws are cool looking paper ones which end up being useless after a few sips. I'm really bummed I didn't find out about this place until the day before we left SF :(  I will definitely come back here!
author: Liane E.

description: I had one of the best cheeseburgers I have ever had in the Mission here. The food is good, the atmosphere is interesting, and the decor looks like it hasn't changed since the place opened. They still have the original wainscot and booths. Check out the candy counter when you go. 3 words: Garbage Pail Kids, oh yeah.  I guess that's actually 5 words.
author: Ned G.

description: Food was great. Great service. The place is a little small and yes sometimes you have to wait to be seated. Outside area has a couple of tables for a warm day. Overall I had a great experience and will come again. They have a good menu for breakfast and if your vegetarian they have some items in the menu to pick from.
author: Jessica L.

description: Who cares if hipsters like to eat here? This is the Mission, young adults who are into fashion and indie rock live here, deal with it. When you are hung over and craving diner food, this is the spot. The portions are huge, the service is attentive and polite, the prices are the normal over priced brunch prices I've come to expect anywhere.  I just don't understand other people's beefs about this place. What, exactly, is a "disappointing french fry"? It's a greasy spoon diner for crissakes! Love it for what it is.
author: bonnie b.

description: Awesome old style fountain bar. 2 great reasons to come? The Coca-Cola float, and the vegan chorizo. Came here on a hot summer day, sat outside under an umbrella and ate, drank, & chatted the afternoon away.
author: Mark B.

description:
Sometimes before I go to bed at night, I think about how good St. Francis would be in the morning. Seriously.
I like the City Lover.
Yes there are cool kids there, but maybe people just need to admit to their hispter lust.
author: Sarah M.

description:
My girlfriend and I split a tuna melt and a large salad for dinner.  You really can't do too much better for $13.

Service is sometimes slow if it's busy and you order a shake, which I believe the waiters have to make themselves.
author: aaron f.

description:
Love it here. Get up early and hit it or stop complaining about breakfast/lunch lines in the Mission. 

St. Francis: 

HOME of Eggs Sandia (sp? should I buy a "y? is there an "h?" can't recall) (eggs benedict but with avocado and bacon v. the ham--so good). 

HOME of "Honey, for some reason, I woke up craving the St. Francis waffle" waffle.  

HOME of a truly nice Reuben that hits the spot. 

HOME of the Dreamsicle. An object deserving of its name.

And, sure, sure, HOME of Central Casting for Mission Hipsters. What are you doing there? Not beating but joining? Not waving but drowning in St. Francis' gravy??? It's. So. Good. Besides, you look cute so early in the morning! 

And the light in St. Francis bouncing off those beautiful booths is so lovely.  And the staff really is a group of good-natured people. You can feel that. Nice way to wake up.
author: Julia W.

description:
This place is one of a few places in the world where vegetarians and vegans can rejoice in the gluttonous behavior of eating fake meat. Their potatoes are one of the best I have had, mixed with parsley, they are delicious. The veggie breakfast patties are tasty and texturally great. Cornbread here is also amazing, fried slightly on each side before serving. I would recommend this place to anyone.

The other cool factor of this place is it used to be an old soda fountain back in the day. It looks like most of the fixtures are still there.

I would've given this place 5 stars, but i found a piece of bacon in my potatoes. Had it been any other type of meat besides bacon, i might have vomited. It did not touch my mouth though. Noticed it well before coming close to that.

Looking forward to my next visit though.
author: Siavash G.

description:
St.Francis is the best place for a milkshake!!! Actually I had a Chocolate Malt. It was soooo yummy!!!! I also had the The Bird Burger. Which is grilled chicken with lettuce, tomato, onions, and mayo. I had my burger with home fries. The burger was alright but my fries were too much for me at time of night. I can see myself eating the home fries at breakfast. 
I love how the restaurant had vintage posters and oldies but goodies snacks. They even had big chew chewing gum, shirts, and some old baseball cards for sale. 

I gave it four stars because my burger could have been better. But I'm totally coming back for the shakes and sundaes!!!! 

Oh...and the staff there were really upbeat!!! :)
author: JACLYN T.

description: Dickhead at the bar told us "we are closed" at 9:02pm when the hours clearly stated they close at 10. I fully understand not wanting people coming in at 9:50, but 9:02....come on. Shame too, normally had ok experiences here.
author: Zach M.

description: This is the first time I have had ice cream for breakfast because the soda drink "Dreamsicle" sounded too good to pass. And I am glad I didn't! The place is a hipster magnet but good breakfast joint. I liked the interior. And anyone who has a garbage pail poster is awesome in my book.
author: Jessica C.

description: Friends introduced my partner and me to this place and we love it. I love the traditional feel and the friendly service; whereas my partner loves the hearty food - especially the malted drinks. I recommend the Cheff's Mess and to get there early.
author: Scott L.

description: My friend and brunch partner Jon said let's go here today.  And damn we had a good brunch.  It's not every day I come across a new brunch place that I like, but this one was impressive.  Old 1950's style fountain bar and wooden, high-backed booths.  Lots of old memorabilia all over the place in an outer mission, gritty location on 24th.  And the food was homey.  I ordered pancakes, eggs, and bacon.  Pancakes were like homestyle and the waitress was very attentive.  About 14 bucks for breakfast - not the cheapest but about right for San Francisco for most decent places.  I'm adding this one to my brunch list.
author: Vivek A.

description:
So I'm kind of stuck between 3 stars and 4.  I'll define the difference

+4-5 stars for:
5- The soda fountain
5- the milk shakes
5- the vintage candy collectibles (btw if you ever buy vintage collectible gum - don't eat the gum for godsakes, its 30 years old!!)
4- the counter service
4- the table service
4- the food (yummish!)

+3-4 stars for:
3- General cleanliness
4- Service personality

-2,000,000 stars for:
the greasy server dude with the dirty white tshirt, dirty mullet hair cut, overgrown facial scrub, and 2 full inches of visible asscrack who had the gall to touch my food.
Yes, its true.
After watching him walk back and forth behind the counter wiping his nose with the back of his hand and hitching his disgustingly low and sloppy pants, he blew me away when he delivered my food at the counter. The scene: a potato that was hanging over the edge of the plate, so in the spirit of dirty, germ-coated service, he oh-so-helpfully nudged the errant spud back onto the plate with his begrimed index finger. Which I'd just seen him using to wipe his nose.
W.T.F.

I didn't see him the last time I went to the St. Francis, I can only hope its because he doesn't work there anymore.

Otherwise, I really like this spot - I took my dad there before Christmas and ended up with Vintage bubble gum and SuperGirl collectors edition cards in my stocking because he'd snuck back there and stocked up on goodies.

Let's give it a 3.5 with a thumbs-up tacked on.
author: Megan B.

description:
This is no question one of my favorite breakfast spots in san francisco. the vibe is nice, cool decor, neat neighborhood, only a few blocks away from the 24th/mission bart stop. it's pretty cheap, too!
the vintage candy they sell is super awesome, but don't expect to eat it (depending on which kind you get). The Dallas Trading Card Gum is for the trading cards, not the gum.
oh, and the milkshakes are super legit!
author: Andrew C.

description: Really good breakfast place. Ate here for Sunday brunch and the wait was about fifteen minutes. Good table/coffee service, really nice waiter. The banana bread and cornbread are delicious, and I love places that serve soyrizo and have vegetarian options.
author: Faith A.

description:
Went recently for a Saturday afternoon lunch and was very disappointed with the service.  They sat us in the back or annex part of the restaurant and we were pretty much ignored for most of our meal despite the fact they there were at least 8 or so wait running around.  

Out order was set on the pick up shelf by the cook and sat there cooling for at least 5 minutes, while 5 or 6 waiters kept passing the food.  I eventually had to flag one person down to let them know our food was up and it still sat there for another of couple of minutes before someone finally thought to pick it up and bring it to our table.  Needless to say the food was warm at best.

It drives me nuts when no one is the waiter for that section.  One person took our order, another brought us water, another brought us coffee, another brought a malted milk and another brought us our food.  With all the staff running around you would think they would get it right. 

I mentioned the service to the cashier and all she could say was that they were busy.  Not even an apology.  It will be awhile before we return there again.
author: Cole B.

description:
let me tell you, this diner, unlike majority of the diners in sf, have more vegetarian/vegan selections than anyone else. i always feel like a loser when ordering from a place that doesn't recognize or respect vegetarians like me. yes, it's sad for me but disappointing for food places.

anyways, fountains is a local gem in the mission and one must consider it done when looking through delectable selections by fountains. i tried their NEBULOUS POTATO THING, and it's crazy good that you got to order 1/2 of it when trying it for the first time (maybe i'll go for the mile later!) ... wasn't in the mood for the classic diner fare such as shakes, but i will most definitely try other selections. sucks that they're not 24 hours, because i would go here and love it as much as i would want to!

oh yea.. the decor and the look of this diner holds a special place in san francisco and the mission district, an institution indeed! one must appreciate the beauty of this dilapidated diner and then eat from this dilapidated diner! no pun intended! =)
author: Marc K.

description:
I am so lucky that this place its so close to my house.  Otherwise I may have never discovered it and by default neither would any of my friends.

The chocolate milkshake will cure ANYTHING that may be wrong with you.  

Breakfast is worth the wait, coffee is really good, they do eggs right and try the waffle!

The side platter was invented for me.  I love lots of items and usually end up ordering too much.  But with this I get soup, salad and mac and cheese.  

I want to go there right now but they are sadly closed at this hour.

Totally recommended.
author: Jill N.

description: Oh man, I loved this place. We went on a sunny day and sat outside, had mimosas, and tasty breakfasts (burrito, vegan chorizo hash, crazy omelet). Yum. And the servers were all really sweet. After all of that goodness, we went inside and bought genuine Cyndi Lauper, Duran Duran, and E.T. trading cards/stickers. I was a happy camper, to say the least. Oh, and we had a bacon donut from the place across the street pre-brunch. Oh man, oh man, whatta day.
author: Rikki D.

description: It's all about Hector's Waffle!!  They use orange zest, chopped pecans, and a little bit of anise seed.  It is absolutely amazing!  I drive from the Outer Richmond just for this breakfast delight.  The menu covers the spectrum of diner food, but I find this place far from "greasy spoon".  They serve up fresh, diner style fare.
author: Colby J.

description: Always a must go place to go to whenever I'm in the mission. Their seitan burgers and chocolate chip pancakes are awesome! I haven't tried everything on the menu but the food is good and not too pricey. Only thing I wasn't a fan of was no paper towels or toilet paper in the restroom.
author: Christopher L.

description: I wish I lived closer to this place.  While the food isn't especially creative or anything (it's standard diner fare), it's got all the right food to satisfy your brunchtime cravings, at a reasonable price and with plenty of vegan options.  I myself went for the breakfast burritos, which were solid.  There was a short wait for a table at 10am today, but nothing crazy.
author: William C.

description:
I finally ate at this joint this morning, after weeks of hearing from my buddies about how dang good it is.  I hate when they lord yummy restaurants over me making me feel all left out and stuff.
Needless to say (see above star allotment) I loved this place.  The waiters were sexy, even though they were aiming for hipster cute in their tight pants and scruffy faces.  They provided good service, though I will concede that we were there at a non-busy time of day.  I wanted to order an old-fashioned malted milkshake made with Mitchell's ice cream SO BADLY but my friend slapped me with the words, "It is only 9:00 in the morning."  I am going to have to go back for lunch.
Her scramble mess thingy, though not vegetarian, was amazing.  The home fries are crispy goodness, and my eggs were small, but cooked well.  I was a bit disappointed in the homemade biscuits--kind of dry.  Overall, a yummy find.  I will be back.
author: Lacy T.

description: I really enjoy this place.  It's a hidden local spot really.  If you're in the mood for some good old well prepared diner food and a nice frosty milkshake than look no further.  I don't believe St. Francis has changed since it opened; still boasting a random area to buy candies (I never understood candy buttons...) and small wood booths.  I recommend the "toaster" sandwhiches and the chocolate milkshakes. Yummy.
author: Mary H.

description:
Long wait but always worth it!!!  This is my favorite brunch joint in the city.   I love their fluffy delicious pancakes (buttermilk or chocolate chip) with a side of fresh fruit and scrambled eggs.    Or their super yummy spinach, jack cheese and mushroom omelet.   Seriously, I was not a fan of omelets but St. Francis has converted my taste buds.  

 I go there all the time with my fiance and we bring our friends.  St. Francis has never let us down.  Their service is great, the staff is very attentive and the general atmosphere is welcoming.   

Ooh, I almost forgot about the dessert.  If you have any room left (which is hard given the large servings) definitely try out their desserts.  My favorite is the Battleship ice cream.   =)
author: JR Kaz K.

description: A friend told me that this place had "the best tofu scramble in town," and I'm not one to pass up a tip of that nature.  Turns out that this 50's-style diner (authentically so, minus the cheesy revamping that that phrase might make you think of) has not one but *four* tofu scrambles on the menu!  The one I tried (Tofu Mex) was great, and came with more potatoes than God.  Wow.  Menu also has four different kind of mimosas, all with creative California flower names ("bougainvillea" == champagne + OJ + cranberry juice), and all made with freshly-squeezed orange juice.  Totally unpretentious and yummy food -- this one's a keeper.
author: Nori H.

description: Looooove the wooden-walled booths and all the chocolate goodies in the cases.  It's what Friendly's always wanted to be.
author: Andi T.

description:
This old-school 1950's style soda shop is a great place for breakfast food. My friends and I headed over around lunchtime on a Saturday absolutely famished. The wait wasn't long at all to be seated at one of their booths. I had the Chef's Mess (scrambled eggs, bacon, tomatoes, potatoes and cheese with a dollip of sour cream on top). The eggs were light and fluffy with just the right amount of the other ingredients as to not overpower the eggs. And it was nicely presented, not messy looking at all. I got the cornbread at my friend's suggestion and wasn't disapointed, although of course it can't beat real southern cornbread. My friends got the huevos rancheros, mixed veggie omelette and corn hash which all looked good. I was tempted to order a dish called The Nebulous Potato Thing just because of it's name but resisted for fear of overdosing on carbs and fat. I hope to come back one of these days with a potato-lover who will order it so I can get a taste.

Oh, maybe just one more thing: I'm a coffee lover (ok, ok, maybe a bit of a coffee snob) and thought my first cup here tasted a little burnt. Subsequent pours were fine.
author: Trinh T.

description:
St Francis Fountain - serving non-ironic breakfasts since 1918, and ironic breakfasts since 2003.

No really, I'd give anything to see a time-lapse history of the customers here.  It pre-dates the latinization of the Mission by at least 20 years, and at some recent(?) point in the past seems to have come full circle into a major destination (widely attributed to hipsters, yes--but just because the waitstaff is 100% tattooed, tight-jeaned and wearing shirts from The Knockout doesn't mean there aren't plenty of plain old vintage diner-lovers here as well--or are they synonymous?).  Having never been to Boogaloo's, I don't know how this place holds up as an alternative, but a 15-minute wait (Sunday, 11 AM) for a vintage wooden booth and an encyclopedic menu complete with veggie versions of just about everything (I went with the veggie chef's mess and I can tell you the faux-rizo was the bomb) is an ok deal in my book.  Of course, for all I know the cult following is only going to get worse and pretty soon the new alternative will be somewhere on Bayshore Blvd.  But for now, SFF is a truly unexpected gem (and, for better or worse, a prime example of a popular place that I never heard mentioned outside of Yelp).

Of course, this review cannot be considered complete until I come back for the milkshakes.  Yes, that rationalization will do nicely:  it's my *duty* as a thorough Yelper to swing by for a shake, and the sooner the better...
author: Wes M.

description: My boyfriend and I had lunch here on Sunday and it was fabulous. I had the side platter with yummy chili, just spicy enough, Caesar salad and mac and cheese plus cornbread. It was very filling and delicious. My bf loved his dish as well, the chefs mess with biscuits (which he swooned over) The shakes were good as well, very thick although a bit expensive ($5 for the large) its a lot of shake. We will definitely be coming back.
author: Meg L.

description: Yet another fine vegan find. This place has really  yummy tofu scrambles. I got the italian tofu scramble, and my boyfriend got the mexican tofu scramble, and they were both delicious. One note for other vegans out there, they don't automatically take the butter off the toast (a little dumb considering you are probably vegan if you're ordering a tofu scramble instead of eggs, but it is the mission afterall) and there is no margarine, but you don't really need it if you scoop your scramble on the toast. They also had a vegan boca burger, a veggie ruben, veggie chili, and soy ice cream shakes, although we didn't try them since we were stuffed. I was tempted to get a shake, but I proabably would have exploded.
author: Jeani H.

description:
Be sure to watch your step at the St. Francis Fountain otherwise you will trip over the irony spilling out the front door. Ah, the hipsters and their love of irony. They have it all here from mullets to Amish-style jean skirts, in fact if you are carrying your hipster bingo card you will get four corners before you pass the third table. It's cool though, the hipsters have a place to call their own. On top of that it's a welcoming environment, both from the patrons and the staff. Our waiter was a really cool guy, the kind you wouldn't mind grabbin a seat at the table and talking of his exploits as opposed to taking your order.
We went looking for food of the guilty pleasure sort, because dieting season is around the corner, and we found it here. Nice big greasy hamburgers with a side of cheese fries and a chocolate milkshake big enough to sustain a small village in Uganda for fours days. It all made it's way into my belly. I walked out satisfied and had to fight the urge of stopping by the candy counter and pick up some Garbage Pail Kids cards on the way out.....ah, irony.
author: Bucky K.

description:
The St. Francis was a charming, unassuming, family-owned, old-time soda shop, with homemade ice cream, homemade candy, (their turtles were heavenly) homemade mayonnaise, a modest but nice menu with filling comfort food, and nice staff. I always loved going on Fridays for a bowl of their clam chowder and a burger made in their hot air oven. The clientele consisted mostly of locals, kids coming back from school and grabbing a cone, stuff like that. It was about as authentic and genuine as you could get. Unfortunately, business didn't go too well in the 90s, so the family had to sell it, after owning the place since its inception in 1918.

Two owners later, the St. Francis, now with a grill, has a larger menu, infused with california style cuisine that is all completely average, no more homemade ice cream, (it's winchells, still good, bot not *as* good.) the candy counter has now been replaced with collectors cards that would make any gen xer wet their pants, the staff can range from being attentive to indifferent to just rude, and the clientele (and staff) mostly consists of twentysomething white hipsters.  

To summarize: Zero charm, overpriced nothing food, spotty service with a certain degree of attitude, and clientele that is often just as obnoxious. You can smell the pretension from a block away. 

At this point, I feel that the whole restaurant should be air-lifted and forcibly relocated to westside mission somewhere on Valencia or Guererro. Put it right next to boogaloos or something. It'll blend better.

SF lost a great landmark when the St. Francis was sold. 

I wish I could give it 0 stars.
author: Jonny P.

description:
The only reason I'm giving this place 4 stars instead of five is because it seemed like someone called Central Casting and had them send 50 of the most stereotypical hipsters to the St. Francis Fountain for Sunday Brunch. If I saw one more arm sleeve/blond dreadlock/fedora/ironic vintage dress/adults in children's plastic sunglasses, I was going to throw my DIVINE egg white scramble and home fries covered in cheese and sour cream at Snow Patrol sitting at the next table. 
My god, people. MY GOD. 
Mikey and I were in awe. It gave us the giggles, the clientele was so dramatically uniform.
Do these people have jobs? Did they read about this very specific look in some kind of underground, organic, Burning Man 'zine? I thought I was in an alternate universe where really current artsy types who refuse to listen to music anyone has ever heard of pay $9 for eggs.
Oh. Nope. I'm just in the Mission. 
Hipster robots aside, my and my J. Crew chinos had a really great breakfast with a really sweet server who was busting his ass to bring "Tre" his soy milk and did it with the kindest smile on his face the whole time. The menu was fantastic, creatively written and appealing to the various whims of hipster diet. It was really hard to narrow it down, there were so many great looking options. 
I'll definitely be back to try some non-breakfast items and I'll be sure to bust out the polyester dress I wore to my parents 1973-themed Anniversary party, paired with my Addidas shell tops and a do-rag...
author: Beth S.

description:
st. francis fountain is great.  just discovered it recently.  hipster heaven and you might have to wait for a table, but the food is fresh and very tasty.
I've had scrambles two times and they were both DELICIOUS.  hubby had corned beef hash and breakfast burrito, and loved them.  portions are big, and our stoner waiter asked if we would like "toast or a fresh baked good" with our breakfasts.
