I had the corn bread with ortega chilis both times, and man, is it good!  
the place is a total throwback, and you feel like you've gone back in time (except for the hipsters and stoner waiter - who I like a lot, he definitely gets the job done!)
sit outside on a nice day.
author: char s.

description: Went with a friend who loves this place. Not to hipster and good service overall. Fairly inexpensive with good sized portions. Also you can't beat being able to get a breakfast burrito and "knight rider" trading cards at the same time.
author: Jerry M.

description: This is an authentic, old-fashioned soda fountain, established in 1918, that was rescued by new owners a few years back. They kept the vintage look, but other changes make this less than what it used to be. The ice cream, once made in-house, now comes from Mitchell's, which raises no major complaints but doesn't quite match the quality of what was once served here. Ditto for the one-time house-made candies, now replaced by pre-packaged novelty chocolates. But the menu, which features sandwiches, soups, and salads, is still moderately priced, as are the excellent sundaes.
author: Gourmet G.

description: Still a quality diner after all these years. Food...good, shakes...good, Gunesss float...gooooood! Don't try to go for breakfast on the weekends unless you want to wait out on the sidewalk for an hour with all the other fools that don't realize there are so many other good places they could already be seated and enjoying their breakfast at, all up and down 24th. But any other time you'll be treated right. They even just added outside tables on York st. when it's sunny.  Nice. An extra star for making sure each waiter has at least a hundred visible tattoos for your viewing pleasure.
author: gabriela l.

description: Damn good gut busting comfort food.
author: Thomas K.

description: I tried the nebulous potato thing and it lived up to it's name. the booths weren't the most comfortable, but it was nice enough.
author: Mark H.

description: Pretty good!  The breakfast always good, the lunch has been good and the service is pretty nice.  I have seen lines waiting outside the door and have luckily been able to avoid that experience.  I'd have to say the Chefs mess and the nebulous Potato Thing are excellent, but I think I have an obsession for potatoes, if you don't like those probably better try something else probably equally as tastey.  Oh and I thought the icecream was nummy too.
author: Rebecca D.

description: I'm from the South where Waffle Houses are aplenty. Since I moved to California I've been having withdrawal. Finally, at the Fountain, waffles! And lots of them! I had the strawberry ones and I will be having them again. Possibly tomorrow morning. The servers are great (they look you in the eye while you order and loved presenting the food... keep in mind, this is a diner) and the outdoor seating in the sunny Mission is critical. I went on a Saturday at 10am and didn't have to wait for a table. Good coffee.
author: Regina S.

description: Good place to sit down, have a milkshake and a sandwich or soup. I went to this area of town for Dynamo Donuts and decided I should eat some real food and St Francis was just down the street. The waiters were very friendly and the milkshakes were great. The chili wasn't the best I'd ever had but the fried cornbread was yummy.  I'm sure I'll go back probably for breakfast one day. I didn't even get to try dynamo but the milkshake was a good replacement LOL
author: Rodney P.

description: This is a classic, so glad it's been brought back to life. Great shakes and burgers, really fun breakfast spot. If Richie Cunningham lived in the Mission, he'd be here all the time.
author: Nish N.

description: Whether your thing is salt/grease or sugar/sweet, St. Francis is the joint. If blinded by breakfast options or the hottie who serves you, go with the Chef's Mess. Pretty much everything eggy and cheesy that you'd want fried up in a stately pile. For lunch I recommend the '49, though doubtless a fully loaded Egg Salad sandwich with bacon will not be to everyones taste. Order one anyway and I'll eat yours. I love this place and rarely leave without a pack of weird trading cards. So it's got that going for it, which is nice. Oh, and they just added four outside tables for the nice weather. Hup!
author: Jeremy W.

description: Went here excited because I heard it was the oldest ice cream place in SF...and I came out...excited that it was the oldest ice cream place in SF. The milkshake wasn't anything to rave about, and the BLT was way too much lettuce, the fries were burnt and had no flavor...so I am happy I went for the experience, but I doubt I will be returning anytime soon. :(
author: Josephine J.

description: I've never had the non-ice cream food here, but I think it deserves stars because it's so goddamn old and cute, and they make good sundaes too.  The tattooed, hipster servers are memorably friendly too.
author: Daniel S.

description: 50/60's diner nostalgia, line of hipsters, hangover clinic, people-watching heaven: all of this and more. But nothing else. Nebulous potato thing = clogged arteries (please have a look at the photo), BLT was good but you know, can you really make an horrible one? We also had a gravy-something but , to me, that was worth a thanksgiving dinner table, not a 1st of January morning. Ok, I'll extrude an opinion now...this kind of food is not for me (even though I really do like Boogaloos on Valencia - lemon cornmeal pancakes, yum!).
author: Dario B.

description:
this place is exactly .5 miles from JayBee's, and my buddy matt's new place, therefore making it the coolest place in the world at the moment (according to matt).

it's cool. old fashioned diner type decor. bubble gum cards a plenty for sale. counter seats, a few tables in the window, booths in back. i had a burger and fries for $7. seemed like a fair price for product to me. staff are ultra hip and super nice. matt says it's packed for breakfast.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm.

i have spent many mornings and dollars here enjoying a mimosa with my meatloaf sandwich, while swiping forkfuls of my friends biscuits and gravy and watching all the hipsters outside. 

yes, the wait is long. especially around 1pm when everyones waking up. but, its SO worth it. so very deliciously worth it.
author: Ameigh F.

description:
I went here for dinner on a weekeday night with my friends and my boyfriend. It wasn't terribly crowded and it seemed pretty cool. We sit down and order up what turns out to be amazing grub. (Get the potato salad instead of fries, for the love of all which is holy!) My boyfriend and I had an amazing hot fudge sundae banana split. I am almost salivating just thinking about it ! The only caveat was that the service was somewhat lacking; I don't know if it was just a poor staff to customer ratio, but, the service wasn't all that great, but, not terrible either. I will definately give it another shot; the positives far outweigh the negatives.
****UPDATE****
I went back this afternoon with my boyfriend and had absolutely TERRIFIC service. Matt (look for him, great guy) was extremely attentive and didn't make me feel like a huge jerk when I accidentally spilled a glass of water all over the table. AWESOME!  And my sundae was delish; you should totally go give this place a try.
author: Jessica R.

description: Er, how did I miss this place? Went on a Sunday morning, a bit of a crowd outside but we got seated really quickly -- none of this forty-five-minutes-in-front-of-boogaloo's nonsense. Coffee was good and bottomless, and Hector's Waffles still make cameos in my dreams.
author: andy d.

description: We were disappointed with our lunch here  which may be due to the fact that we ordered the wrong items-in this case turkey avocado clubs. This sandwich is essentially a Subway sub (same kind of turkey and nasty shredded lettuce). Their fries are also not good. The only redeming item was the spinach salad. Perhaps we should have ordered breakfast or a burger but quite frankly I doubt we'd go back.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description:
this place is by far the best diner i've been to.  it's got old-school charm, great food, excellent service - what else can you ask for?  the staff is always friendly - the few times that i've shown up early to wait for my friends i'm offered a seat at the counter as soon as i walk in, with hot coffee to wake me up while i wait.
the nebulous potato thing is a MUST ORDER!!  my girl friends and i have made this place our official galentines day(like valentines day, but ladies only) brunch spot.  i'm actually taking my cousin who's visiting from out of town there this week - i can't wait!
author: kristina h.

description: For a fun breakfast/lunch spot this place is sooooo good.  Lots of great breakfast and lunch everythings.  Love it.  Great authentic old 1950s diner (with, ok, just enough loveable sexy hipster flair for a hipsterless ever-hipster-crushing (or not) gal or guy.)  I want to return for a milkshake and to pick up some of the old school candy, still, though.  Love the bottomless mugs of diner coffee, too.  Everything looked soooo good.  Biscuits are great.  Omelets I'd call basic but good and satisfying.  Homefries were addicting.  Love it all.  Really good all american breakfast.  Yum.
author: Today Y.

description: 5 stars for having vegan options especially pancakes. Had the blueberry pancakes and they didnt taste all heavy and wheaty like the ones at dharmas in capitola. These were awesome. Wife had the french toast which she liked, daughter had the kids grilled cheese and fries, both were very good as well. Grilled cheese had a yellow and white cheese and loaded with butter. Perfect. Will definitely come back to try the potato plate which i kept eying on another table. Very friendly staff, even when very busy.
author: Rav R.

description:
Takes you back in time
To hamburgers and milkshakes
At the five and dime
author: HaikuReview X.

description:
best bacon in town.

ice cream, shakes, real malts. 

coffee is full of hate. FULL of hate. sure to wake my hungover ass up on a sunday afternoon.
author: dawn a.

description:
This place is so cute! I had it on my list of places to visit in SF mainly because of the vegan shake and ice cream.

My boyfriend and I ended up having lunch here on our last day in town.  The guy next to us had ordered the Vegan Chorizo Hash with Tofu, and it looked sooooo good, we BOTH GOT IT.  

It was pretty amazing: in the center, a tofu scramble with ranchero sauce, and surrounding it, vegan chorizo mixed in with diced potatoes, with three soft, hot corn tortillas on the side! 

It comes with a side: I got mine with a side of veggie chili--it wasn't as good as the Whole Foods canned variety, but was topped with scallions--and my boyfriend got a side of home fries, which were really good, nice and firm, and covered in herbs.

He got the "Dream" shake (orange sherbet and vanilla, topped with whipped cream and a cherry), and I got the vanilla "All Soy" shake.  The ice cream they use (I hear it is a local ice creamery, right?) IS SO GOOD.  I didn't see vanilla beans but would have guessed they were in there.  It was so very vanilla-y, and with a cherry on top.  

The server was staight-up abrasive, very unhelpful.  The bill came out to $43, which I think is kind of expensive for 2 diner-style entrees and a shake.  But the has was very good, and so was my shake, and I'd go back for either!

We ended up getting some 80s trading cards which was fun.  The lock on the bathroom door was broken, which was scary!, but one of my favorite things about the place was the old-school "BORAXO" powder hand soap dispenser in there.
author: D P.

description: Honestly, I have a soft spot for diners. And it's near my home. So I end up here more often than I should, considering the health quality of diner food. But the wait staff is always kind and I love taking my friends here when they visit me, because its quaint and inexpensive.  Sure, there's a wait at lunch time on Saturdays, but even then it's not that bad. If you are only coming with one other person, its great, more than that, you will have to wait a bit longer than others.
author: Dani S.

description: oooh vegan/vegetarian brunch lovers....hello st francis fountain! very casual environment but serious comfort brunch food with an extensive menu for vegan/vegetarians and non-vegetarians. Have to try the veggie mess- delicious and sooo much that had to bring it home as well as the veggie double burger (it has seitan in it). Just make sure ur party is there and u can put ur name on the clipboard. We had about a 10 min wait only because the rest of our party was not there. Service was friendly, fast and overall just fine and prices are very reasonable! Don't forget about the milkshakes and the crazy hommage to 80's candy at their counter!!!! Truly worth it, can't wait to go back! Btw, if ur waiting go up 2 blocks to Victorio's Bakery and grab a cafe con leche!
author: sue c.

description: The line is long on the weekends - better to come with only one other person and sit at the counter.  Cool wooden booths, your typical hungover hipster servers. The big plus was the egg and cheese - for some reason people on the west coast seem to think there should be mayo in an egg and cheese - NOOO! They do it wonderful, two big buttery pieces of sourdough, two melted slices of cheddar, hard fried eggs.
author: amy b.

description:
i truly adore the surly staff and the sometimes bland, but still good diner-esque food.  i love the milkshakes (mmm how can you not love a milkshake?).   i love the candy counter and i love all the old cards you can buy (80s style - like nkotb and growing pains and garbage pail kids and monsters of rock).   i love the fact that this place is not a replica - it's actually old!  

they recently changed the menu, which is ok, but they did remove one of my favorites - the chicken fajitadilla.  sigh.  

i must, in all fairness, give out a warning that you had better heed.  do not, under any circumstances, think it's ok to eat the gum out of one of these card packs.  please.  i beg of you.
author: Sharon M.

description: When I pass by, I'm remembered of the time I picked up a spoon, opened the freezer and found a St.Francis box of ice cream. This was exciting. Hel-lo-oh St.Francis ice cream! It was watermelon.  And I was salivating.  I got a spoonful and -bleck- Gross!  It tasted like it would after licking 50 envelops, and I like licking envelops! But that was something else.  Don't worry though, the ice cream served now is brought to you by Mitchell's.
author: Glu C.

description: A  friend and I went here for breakfast. Since my diet is vegan, we asked what was good that was vegan on the menu. The waitress said, "the vegans seem to like this", it was vegan chorizo hash & tofu, we chuckled because of the way she said it. Anyway, it was really delicious, thanks waitress person!  My friend, not vegan, got the porta-melt, and she really like it. We both got our own - no sharing - all soy-shake, this is one rich drink, very tasty. I recommend this place, it is really awesome, no doubt.
author: Brian S.

description: There was a waiting list of 8 people around noon, but at 1pm I got in with no problem. Chef's Mess was decent, a very large omelette/potato scramble thing that I couldn't finish. There was a fruit fly that kept trying to land on my food and one of waitresses sweatshirts was covered with dog hair. It seemed to be the only non-Mexican place in the area and has colorful hippyish clientelle
author: Yaroslav B.

description: Came here with my lady this morning to try this place out. We both just thought this place was mediocre. I ordered the Chef's mess which was good for what it was and my girl ordered the Waffle combo which she thought was descent  but could of been more crispier. Also we both shared a chocolate milkshake which we both thought was really good. After reading other reviews saying the service sucked I thought it was descent. Overall I thought this place was just mediocre, but I gotta say the milkshake was really good and this place really made me feel like I was in the 50's especially with the old trading cards and candy they sold.
author: Jay S.

description: Fresh quality diner food. Friendly staff. My favorites: bacon-cheddar-onion pancakes, chicken cilantro soup. chicken pecan salad, meatloaf sandwich! Did I mention the corned beef hash? Or the big salads? Or the great orange juice?
author: J. R.

description: If we didn't live in the neighborhood, I wouldn't go there.  Food is okay-- with a few notable highlights.  Service is blah.  It is great for ice cream at the counter and for those candies you just can't seem to find any more.
author: Shannon T.

description: The only diner I've been to in the city that is worth going back to.  The bacon, cheddar, green onion pancakes area culinary delight and the biscuits and gravy are the best I've had here in the city.  Ask a waitress about "Bob's Special Salad" and get an interesting story.
author: matthew w.

description: A great place to stagger to when you wake up late in the morning with a hangover. Good hearty omelettes, potato and egg scrambles, and much more. Plus nice quick service and strong black coffee!
author: Nick O.

description: awesome milk shakes, super friendly staff, great music playing. A great little treat for a burger/shake stop in the middle of the heart of the 24th street taquerias. Its such a little out of the way treat, and SO NICE to be able to go and get ice cream, and sit down at the counter and be waited on, very old fashioned style.  Not like crowding into a too small icecream shope like bi-rite, which just ruins the experience.... this place is comfy and fun.  I also saw the most adorable plate of pancakes for a little girl next to me, that one of the chefs made into the shape of a bunny with banana and chocolate chip eyes, and a strawberry nose.
author: Best M.

description:
i love their food but i saw a mouse running across their floor.  which means there is more than one mouse.  which means there is mouse poop in the food.

but their milkshakes make it all worth it.
author: Elisette B.

description:
We liked coming here on weekends for what we call "hipster breakfast." 

But I'm afraid we need to find a new hipster breakfast spot where the waiters will fill your coffee mug at least 3/4 full every time and they don't take 15 minutes to bring the check after you ask for it and then have the audacity to ask you to leave 10 seconds after you sign your name because there are hungry hipsters outside waiting  for your table. 

2 stars for the food. 1 extra star for the cute justin long/keanu reeves look-a-like waiter.
author: L. Renee D.

description:
If there was one reason to not live in the Mission, this is it:  I'd eat here every freakin' day and they'd need to install a special cargo-sized door to roll me in and out.

Their eggs are always tasty, no matter how they're prepared.  I've had 'em every way imaginable, and they rock.  And the Nebulous Potato Thing?  There's a very good reason that they offer a half-portion size.  Unless you're an ambitious sumo-wrestler-in-training, I'd recommend going with the smaller size.  The big one should come with a warning along the lines of "so damn good you'll want to eat the whole thing even after unbuttoning your pants."  Not much else to say except that everything's quite delicious.  Especially their homefries.  Mmmmm...

Oh, and if the throng of hipsters waiting for a table outside concerns you, don't worry...even though they can't do anything about the hipsters, the wait is never as long as it seems.
author: H K.

description: this place has great breakfast lunch and dinner if you want standard diner food. I do have to say though that the service here stinks largely due to the servers who are never anything but rude.  Having worked in food service for a long time I really understand how much it can stink, but getting frustrated  and snapping at customers who ask for things like glasses of water is a little much.
author: zachary m.

description: Awesome place to get a ice cream shake
author: joe H.

description:
oh san francisco... how i miss your hipster hangouts.

it was on a sunday afternoon that my friend took me here... the thought of it being brunch only hitting me now... and the place was packed, not inanely packed like boogaloos or anything, but with enough cowboy shirt/tight jeans/bike messenger attire entrance cluster that is the only fitting way to be re-welcomed back into the city, and particularly, the mission.

yes, it was my first time here, and yes, i was pleasantly surprised. it was pretty cheap - my random assortment of ceasar salad, homefries, and biscuits and gravy amounting to less then $10. and with a chocolate milkshake to boot, there was no better way to start my day.

the food itself isnt spectacular, but good enough to not make you shutter at the thought of coming back. i didnt like the fresh green onion on top of my biscuits and gravy... and i love fresh green onion! the dish was also not as warm as i would have liked, and yet my ceasar salad was not as cool... hhhhmmm.... at least my chocolate milkshake was neither cold enough to be ice cream nor warm enough to be milk.

anyway, its worth a meal. not for everybody, however, seeing as how they probably dont have the 'best of' anything in the city on their menu, but they do have pretty decent everything, its good for those french toast, tuna salad, and ice cream cravings.
author: N. B. K.

description: So when I first moved to 24th st. St. Francis was totally empty. all the time. it was crazy how popular it has become over the past 3 years. I blame Pop's. Anyways, food is amazing, servers are nice and relaxed, kindof pricy...but worth it!
author: Kara E.

description: the apple pie a la mode is pretty cathartic on a day where nothing is peachy.  I like to look at the waitstaff sometimes, so what?
author: aleks k.

description: I ate here for the first time today and feel like I have finally found a greasy-spoon rival for It's Tops. I need to go back a few times to explore the menu but it has all the trappings of a great fountain diner...small booths, lunch counter with stools, and old-school milkshake makers & glasses. If you like authentic 50's diners, it's a must. I had the espresso shake and it was awesome.
author: Bill R.

description:
my favourite place to eat in the city! i would eat there every day if i could! and trust me, living down the street from the St.Francis makes that no easy task! the best parts about it?

- the food! mmmm butterscotch milkshakes. mmm mac'n' cheese. mmmm french toast! could there be anything better?? plus! they just updated their menu to include more vegan/vegetarian options!

- the original staff rocks! their totally cool, friendly, and are damngood! at their job! (i say "original" because they hired a few new girls whom i dont know well enough to say anything) 

- the place is totally authentic. the little candy counter is too cool (my roomates and i collect the vintage playing cards. my favourite so far is the MegaMetal pack). and, outdoor seating on a sunny sunday afternoon makes the food taste even better. genius!

the St.Francis is honestly too good to be true.


but! be warned the place gets pretty busy on weekends. and their freezer is currently broken for the second time this summer. BUMMER. still worth it though!
author: Jaei P.

description: Consistent good hang over food. The atmosphere is old diner type -laid back comfortable large portions -vegetarian options- tofu substitutions -always appreciated.
author: Angela O.

description: There is nothing more divine in this city than to eat brunch outside at St. Francis Fountain on a warm, sunny day.  The food is delicious and there are many more vegetarian options than at most restaurants.  I recommend the huevos rancheros and the nebulous potato thing. My mouth is watering just thinking about it...
author: Alexandra K.

description: While the food may be tempting, the service  and attitude needs to be addressed. On three separate occasions, I have had a member of the staff attempt to talk down to me.  My experience is not unique.  I have heard of several other experiences that are either similar or worse than mine.  I'll spend my hard earned money elsewhere.
author: Anthony U.

description: Best breakfast place in town, hands down. Reasonable prices, friendly staff, and a delicious menu with something for everyone (carnivore to vegan). The owner and staff pour their love into this place, and it shows. For a decadent treat try the chocolate chip pancakes....oh so good!
author: Allison S.

description: Awesome 1940's styled diner (wish it was still the 20's though). The food here is great. St. Francis has THE BEST CHILI I've ever eaten- and it was vegetarian to boot! The desserts are even better. Get the blue berry ice cream soda with vanilla soy- yummm. The candy counter also has a nice selection of 1980's candy. Magnum PI gum? Sure. This is one of my new favorite hang out spots.
author: Hyena G.

description: Just came here for dessert. Yes, they've been around forever, and the decor will absolutely remind you of that, right down to the graphic design in the signage and menus. We split a Buster Brownie and a Dreamsicle milkshake (two paper straws!), both classically delicious. But for added coolness, take note of the candy display. Knight Rider trading cards!
author: Maximillian M.

description: I have to agree with a previous poster - this place was way better before the ownership change. Back in the day, it was a family business wtih homemade ice cream (I'm pretty sure) and they were always really nice. My ex-girlfriend and I used to go there and share milkshakes and stuff on dates. Now it's been overtaken by hipsters, sigh. My ex (yes, we're still friends) and I tried to go to the new St. Francis twice and here's what happened: First time we went for dinner, we were the only people there. My friend is a Pisces and sometimes takes a long time to decide on what to eat. The hipster waitress came by a couple times and we weren't ready. The third time she came to our table, she rolled her eyes at us and sighed really loudly. I don't know what her problem was - it's not like anyone was waiting for our table or as if she had anything better to do. Second try - we never actually ordered or ate because no one ever came to take our order. Again, it was not crowded, and the waitress (different one I think, not sure) just kind of ignored us for maybe 30 minutes or so. We were really hungry so we left and went to Casa Sanchez. Sigh. I wish this Mission gentrification crap would just stop and go away or maybe implode on itself in a hailstorm of ironic glasses and skinny jeans. Maybe the upcoming earthquake will shake things up again.
author: Dorothy W.

description: There is a rumor that the SF 49ers football team was thought-up in the farthest back booth. Could be...who knows! But the food is good and also cheap (Hipsters can't afford much after all those tattoos). When it's sunny, and it's always sunny in the mission, the outdoor seating is awesome. A chill place in a chill part of town. A great place to enjoy a lazy weekend breakfast or lunch, just remember to wash your hands afterward!
author: Ben R.

description: I love diners. If I could pick any era to live in asthetically, it'd be the fifties, and this comes close to my dream come to true. Super classic, with booths, counter, and double-strawed shakes. Their food isn't mind-blowing, but their menu is varied, and they have good vegan options. Their vegan shakes are really, really good, without that usual beany flavor you get when you go with soy. The service is fine, and yeah, this place is made for hipsters, but hey, what in the mission isn't these days. I happened to wait on the owner at my restaurant the other day and he was really nice guy, just trying to make a good place to eat. Snap on some suspenders, fedora, and roll up your sleeves (to show off your tats, of course) for a classic meal.
author: isaak b.

description: One of my top choices in the mission for breakfast.  Sometimes overly crowded, but often one of the best and easiest places to just stop by for a good breakfast without hassle.
author: Joann M.

description: St. Francis really is "as good as it gets" as far as diners go.  I always used to avoid this place because the wait looked so long for Sunday brunch, but the queue actually moves pretty fast for how many people are waiting.  The service is always prompt, they always get my order right and the food is just plain good.  The menu is huge, they have a ton of ways to customize your order, the vegan/vegetarian selection is great, they serve Copa Loca soy shakes, and Tapatio is sittin on every table.  There's counter, table and outdoor seating and a lingerie shop next door.  I've also found my heaven on a plate here: black beans.  I wouldn't have guessed the black beans would be so wonderful at a diner, but perhaps the fact that the ad for a cook is ONLY in Spanish should have clued me in.  Bomby!
author: Katherine K.

description: 2 words - huevos. rancheros.  The best in the city.  (Oh, and it doesn't suck that you can have a decadent milkshake alongside your spicy egg masterpiece.)
author: Julie L.

description:
My friend tells me "Let's go to St. Francis for brunch." I'm wearing some sneakers and a hoody and some jeans, and I say "Uhm...I don't think that I am dressed appropriately for the St. Francis." He gives me this weird look, shrugs his shoulders and tells me to come along anyways.

To those that are new to San Francisco, you might want to remember to include the word "Fountain" at the end...because most of the people that I've mentioned "St. Francis" instantly think (like me) about the hotel. Oye...

Anyways, we went here for Sunday brunch and it was mondo tasty. I had a version of their eggs benedict, though it had tomatoes and fried bacon instead of the ham. Quite good actually. I also had an order of the biscuits and gravy...pretty good, though the biscuits were super dry, dense and kinda powdery (even with the gravy, my mouth was drying up) and the gravy itself...there was something in it that made it taste weird...not sweet or hot or anything...but it was off...like someone threw in a few too many ingredients. Hmm...

Otherwise, the food was tasty. So, now let me explain my "only 3 stars" rating. (1) We sat at the counter, because we could care less where we sat...we were hungry. So we were able to hear a few of the conversations from the employees. One was an arguement over who got to take the counter. After a few moments of watching the two girls arguing, I came very close to saying, "OYE! BITCHES! Shut up and just take our order and serve us! GEEZ! Why don't you just go up to every customer, look them in the eye and say 'I could care less if you eat or not today because I'm a bitch.'" Because that's kinda what it felt like. (2) I ordered coffee, because it's how I roll. I couldn't get anyone's attention to refill my coffee, and had about a cup and a half of it the entire time. Ask my friends...they will tell you that a cup and a half is not even near enough to satisfy me. Better yet, since I'm sitting at the counter, you would have thought that perhaps they might have been better at refills. Oye again...

While this has nothing to do with my rating, my friend and I were giggling about this...ok, it was more me giggling than anything...they still have the original neon signs above the door, and one of them says something about they make their own candy locally and fresh or some junk. But, the candy they sell is all Wonka stuff. I kept saying, "Where are the Umpa Loompas in the back making it?"

Oh...and another cool thing...they have Duran Duran trading cards from like...the 1800's...that's kinda cool...I think...
author: Nicolas H.

description:
This is my go to brunch spot. I love the environment, food, and wait staff (for the most part.) It was the original soda fountain in San Francisco and they do a good job of maintaining the look and feel of an old soda fountain. Plus, the milkshakes are delicious. When i moved to the city i  frequented the St. Francis 3-4 days a week. Don't let the hipster wait staff scare you off, they're friendly. Plus, it provides a great aesthetic. 

As for the food, the scrambles are great; tons of fresh veggies and plenty of cheese. I've never been much of an omelet gal but I've heard they're good. When I'm feeling glutenous I go for the biscuits and gravy, delish. The breakfast burritos are tasty as well and definitely try the vegan chorizo. On that note, for all you veggies out there, they have a wide variety of vegetarian options. They're tofu dishes are tasty as well as the veggie rueben. 

The St. Francis isn't five stars because the coffee is bad and the food isn't five star quality. If your a mimosa person they're available but pricey and bloody's aren't offered. I keep going back because the food is consistent, the service is good and it's fun.
author: K B.

description: Awesome, old school divey diner. Great breakfast spot with killer waffles and pancakes. Hits the spot after a late night.
author: Elizabeth N.

description: Not sure why I haven't written a review of this great, great find.  It's been around for several years and keeps getting better.  I think that the old spagetti western folks own this place.  all I can tell you is that it ROCKS-- Our family goes here every chance we get.  my new favorite is the chirzo scramble-- vegan of course.  The portions are a little too big for me, but I always take left-overs.  Kate loves the eggs benedict, M loves the hash-- gravy and biscuits.  The service has gotten better.  THere is really nothing bad I could think of saying about this fabulous place.  THANK GOD IT'S HERE!
author: Princess P.

description: I must've been starving when I wrote that other review.  Attitude everywhere. We dread going back but continue to just b/c it's so close to home.  We make sure to set aside at least an extra half hour for the service to catch up...we wait forever for beverages, food and, especially, the check.  GOD...I hate that.
author: Sandy K.

description: This is just about the greatest place to go for ice cream, breakfast, or a burger.  The staff are friendly and attentive, you actually can get beer (and mixed champagne drinks, of all things), and I love the booths (as well as the phone booth in the back).  I never liked most of the 1950s-1960's retro gum and candy they sell there, but it's cool that there's still a place you can get that stuff.
author: moosedog i.

description: This is solid diner food with a Nor-Cal spin  - vegan and veggie options galore.  Large portions, lots of cheese, sour cream, and grease available if you want it.  If you leave the St. Francis hungry, it's your own silly fault.
author: Mary H.

description: I give breakfast a high 3-star rating, maybe even a 4, but dinner's more like a low 3. The location is a really nicely preserved (as opposed to restored) fountain-lunch counter, with few updates to either the menu or the decor. I wish the execution were as impressive as the environment. It's definitely 20's, as opposed to 50's... consider the wood booths, the old phone booth, the tiny floor tiles. The staff are Mission hipsters, surprisingly lacking in 'tude.
author: anita c.

description:
the online menu does not do it justice
theres quite a few things missing on theyre online menu for breakfast
they serve VEGAN PANCAKES
do u know how happy i was when i saw that?!
i ordered the strawberry vegan pancakes - the pancakes had a hint of cinnamon - yum!
you can order REAL Maple syrup - omg drooling just thinking bout it and overused it just a bit when i was there

we ordered a side of fries to share - a lil bit on the salty side but it was purty good
it had the skin on it
the ketchup was not heins - i can tell that much

we sat in the booth - pretty squishy small booth
im uncomfortable hangin my stuff on the coat racks so i kept it on
it wasn't hot anyways so didnt bother me so much
you will definitely touch the arm of the person sitting next to u especially if they are a medium sz guy

there was only one person working in the beginning
(the other one showed up later)
so it took him awhile to take our orders
but otherwise it was all good
food came in moderate time

but they ran out of the only soy ice cream - so i'll get a root beer float next time

they sell candy in the front plus certain trading cards - that was cool
prices were very decent overall

i cant wait to go bk jus a lil inconvenient for me
author: Janet W.

description: Awesome hangover food.  Great service to boot.  I wish I lived closer cuz I'd be here all the time.
author: Rachel N.

description: A solid four stars for a delicious tofu scramble. I need to come back to try more of the menu, when I'm not so mercilessly hungover...I may even enjoy it more.
author: Beth G.

description: I love love love love their chicken soup.  They have a bunch of vegetarian options and belly busting options, too!  I come here when I'm feeling down and need a pick-me-up with great home made soup, a fresh salad, and a plate of the mess (I think that's what it's called).  Home fries, cheese, sour cream, salsa... yum!  I'm a tubby mess after I leave this place...
author: D A.

description: I don't know why this place doesn't have 5 stars - it deserves it. I bounced in here this morning, high because I made it out into the sunshine before noon, and was met by a friendly waitress and an extensive menu. Holy gaucamole, you can get Thai style scrambled eggs, a Guinness ice-cream float and delicious house fries. I couldn't finish my feta & spinach scrambled eggs with banana bread and a side of house fries (all for less than $9) but it wasn't for want of trying. The decor is also pleasant; an understated old-school diner style-ee. I will be back, mayhaps for the Thai scramble if I'm feeling adventurous enough.
author: starla o.

description: My favorite little diner in all of SF. Tons of veggie friendly items too. You will find the place on a Sat. or Sun. morning by the line of hipsters overflowing out the door. But go on a weeknight or for a late lunch on the weekends, and there is no wait at all. The service is attentive, but not overbearing. The prices are fair for the amount of food you get. I love the veggie chili, and the veggie burgers. The breakfasts and/or french fries and veg chili are the best hang-over cures I have ever had. (maybe that explains the long lines on weekend mornings). And the chocolate shakes are so good it'll make you think you've been transported back to the 50s in this cool little diner that's been around forever.
author: Frank B.

description:
just okay food for high prices. i got something called the nebulous potato thing along with an omlette...where was the nebula? it sounded so amazing! and when i got it, i was so let down. 
it's cool that they have guiness floats. too bad they're disgusting. but that could just be because i hate guiness, but if you like it, i bet it's neat.
the cute lil nostalgia toy stand is awesome though (^-^)
author: Nicole G.

description: The waitresses were arguing over whether ketchup counted as one of your 5 servings of vegetables a day. They sell Garbage Pail Kids trading cards. The chocolate malts are thick, nicely sized, and tasty. Meals are reasonably priced and reasonably tasty. High school punk-rocker Nate would have been here every night. Salaried work-a-day mission hipster Nate shows up every other Saturday morning for brunch.
author: nate c.

description: I finally tried the infamous Guiness float...and it was somewhat of a disappointment. was nice & frothy, but maybe my expectations were a bit high. maybe i was expecting a sweet 'n savory type of float, but really...beer and ice cream don't seem to mesh well regardless. my patty melt, on the other hand, was divine in all its beefy glory and adorned with a nice & greasy pile of sauteed onions. I think i've found another favorite joint near my buddy's place, which happens to be just across the street.
author: Chris C.

description: Next time i'm in that there mission, i'm going to get dessert here.  I had a couple of pretty delicious, although kinda greasy sandwiches.  And all the while the uber-hipsters were making sundaes and shakes that looked sooooo good. Oh and the uber-hipsters are really nice too. Great service y'all!
author: luke b.

description: I took my friend from Germany here. I figured would give her a taste of a good old fashioned Diner. She loved it. I explained what a country fried steak was and she got that. I had a banana Milk Shake with real banana it was awesome!!
author: Miray V.

description:
ah, small-town charm in the mission.  not really.  more like an over-sentimentalization of the good old days.  the days of being served a char burger by a mustachioed woman named bertha are gone.  but you can come here and cry into your five dollar soy shake about it. 

or you can get a patty melt and real shake,  pay too much money, cringe at the uneasy tension between la misión and the mission, and cringe just a smidge more when you realize you're part of the problem.

good times!
author: Wayne B.

description: GGGGGREAT Breakfast! Some of the best bacon I have had in the city. And Biscuits and sausage gravy. YUM! Breakfast - Yes, but dinner...not so much. I went once in the evening and it was pretty disappointing. So stick to the AM hours and you will not go wrong!
author: Kent T.

description: potentially one of my favorite places to eat. ever. great ambiance. awesome shakes!! delicious food. AND it's a san francisco staple. anytime i have friend in from out of town... this is where we head. no complaints yet.
author: Ashley A.

description: They have really good diner food plus their milkshakes are SO GOOD! They can make a traditional one or one made out of actual ice cream (I'm blanking on the name), but otherwise it's an institution that's been there for awhile, on the inside it shows the prices of yesteryear and you can sit at the counter while you eat your burger, breakfast or drink your milkshake.
author: Gina R.

description: Yeah for this place!!!!!! Their Grilled Cheese kicks ass and their milkshakes are an A+. It is hipster central but hey, doesn't everyone love good eats?
author: Roxane S.

description:
My two friends from Rubicon (Sarah+Nicole) suggested St. Francis Fountain --YUM!
We went a Saturday morning and sat at the counter...it was great...we were starving...but had seriously one of the nicest servers I've ever experienced talk with us while we waited for plates of hot wonderful food. (I think his name was John).
I can't wait to go back and try the milkshakes!
author: Amy C.

description:
this place has such a history! it's been around for like 75 yrs (although under new ownership) and has kept original fixtures - the oldest soda fountain in SF!

the food is good.  milkshakes are excellent. breakfast is satisfying and quick - all american style.
author: Erika Y.

description: Ate there for lunch yesterday, I loved the vanilla malted milkshake, and the NY ruben (on wheat, not rye), service was prompt & pleasant...headed there now for breakfast.
author: Brandy S.

description: maybe I'm elitist about my corned beef hash or maybe St. Francis Fountain is just not the place to get it. no matter, I was sadly disappointed at the lackluster plate of mostly potatoes and nary a serving of said "corned beef" that was supposed to be an essential part of my dish. or maybe they're trying to be true to their namesake, the patron saint of animals and are surreptitiously discouraging me from meat/animal consumption? hmmmmmmmm......
author: ray e.

description: Even though this place is overflowing with hipsters, I still love going here. The wait staff are remarkably friendly, and usually pretty quick. There is usually a wait, but I've never had a problem getting seated within twenty minutes no matter how long the line seems to be. Really great breakfast dishes, and SUPERB banana bread served warm. Your coffee cup won't ever run dry here either.
author: Jade L.

description:
praise to st. francis! my friend visiting from boston went away thinking SF was the raddest place ever, and i believe our brunch experience at SF contributed to his delight. i made my party of five wait while i took a picture of our food plates, if that tells you anything. 

additional bonuses include:
- they're not stingy with the avocado in their breakfast burritos. we're talking chunks, people, CHUNKS.
- you can choose from corn bread, banana bread and biscuits
- lots of veggie and vegan options
- just a ten minute walk from my house in po-hill
- outside seating for those frigid summer days
- won't break the bank
- despite his multiple tattoos (see other reviews), our waiter was friendly and capable.

yes!
author: jean w.

description:
I'm a fan.

I just finished eating here last than two hours ago and had to yelp about it (since I tend to forget).  

I definitely think this is a good place.  My friend wanted to come here because he's in search of good diners in SF.  Mel's just doesn't count.  The feel and the service was exceptional.  The wait staff is very laid back yet attentive at the same time.  The whole vibe is very chill and cool.  Parking isn't too much of a problem since it's close to Cesar Chavez which is great.  

Getting to the food, I ordered the vegan chorizo hash and my friend had the country breakfast.  They give good-sized servings here.  I was content with my size and didn't feel cheated at all.  The chorizo hash was really good.  It tastes home-cooked and they don't use a lot of oil at all so I don't feel sick afterwards.   

Overall, I'd highly recommend this place for breakfast/brunch on the weekends.  It's outside of the traditional cow hollow or noe valley turf which is great.  There are much fewer yuppies out here and more laid back people.
author: Scott L.

description: The portions at this place are very good. The food is good for the price, their corned beef hash is really great. It's hard to find places with corned beef hash that taste like they arn't straight from the can.
author: Alice K.

description:
great for the hangers both over and under.

had the chef's mess...much easier on your constitution

Get there EARLY as it gets lined up quicker than an NBA player on game night
author: Beer L.

description: I'm updating my review and giving it another star, making it a solid 4 star experience.  We've had some really friendly service recently and as always, the food is really good.  Its also a great place to bring the pooch on a warm, sunny day as they have outside seating.
author: Landy G.

description:
disappointing, worth a second try. had been excited to try this place. 
first off annoyed, we got there and requested a table and were told this was the busy time so we had to sit at the bar, 3/4 of the tables were empty the entire time we were there. next i am allergic to bell peppers, i ordered the corned beef hash......with  per the menu "green onions" meal arrived and was 40% bell pepper, and i could not eat it. if you are going to stress there are green onions stress bell peppers also, hash is typically potatoes and onions only. the dreamsicle shake was great. service so-so, took 10 plus minutes to flag our waitress down to get the bill. 
worth another shot, but bummed it did not meet the standards i had set for it on round one.
author: Adrienne G.

description: mission hipster hangout.....same owner as another hipster breakfast place in mission.  They make very good burgers and kick ass milkshake (they get their icecream from mitchell's I believe). They also have candies from 80's....they had knight rider bubblegum.....memories. Impress your indie girl/boyfriend, pretend you know what's hot.  It's in heart of mission - so don't go there driving your newly leased bmw :)
author: ji k.

description: yeah, I miss the old, pre-hipster place too, but it's ok. A lot of the details seem kinda half-assed, and could use a little more care and love, but hey, it's still a great place for ice cream and diner food. Service is definitely *not* the highlight, so be prepared to fend for yourself, hopefully this'll change. C'mon St. Francis, you can do better!
author: Jeremy H.

description:
This place is cute just because it's so old.  They still have the old booths, posters on the walls, and coat racks.  

However, they play hipster-y music (doesn't really go with the decor).

Oh but they sell weird things like gummy rats, huge jawbreakers, and Beverley Hills 90210 trading cards.  In case you're looking for that sort of thing.
author: Emma H.

description:
you can hate all you want on the hipsters, but don't you go hating on st. francis.

this is the BEST breakfast place ever.  the omlette options abound, and with the option of banana bread instead of toast, it wins over all other breakfast spots I've been to in SF.  and the wait, yeah, it sucks, but that's cause it's good.  if there's not a line on the weekends, then it can't be a very good brunch spot!  if you want to go without the crowd, the breakfast is served all day long (love that!) and the dinners are the best comfort food on a rainy night ever.

and finally, not only is it old school, it makes you sound old school - like you're going to church on sunday morning - only way more satisfying.  yay st. francis!
author: Sarah X.

description: Great diner standards and super tasty treats made from Mitchell's ice cream. The price is right for low cash evenings and you can always get some $2 Tecate across the street at Papa's to round out the night.
author: Angela K.

description: My boyfriend and I usually go here twice a month on weekend mornings to get some breakfast when we are too lazy to cook.  Their breakfast is great, I've had their country breakfast with bacon (yum)- and my BF's all time favorite is Hector's Waffles (waffles with orange zest and pecans). My only complaint is that Friday mornings aren't considered "weekends," and therefore I can't order my favorite eggs benedict. Overall a great place to eat- but at times (depending on the waiter)- service lacks.
author: Josie W.

description:
i've had better breakfasts in my life, but the st. francis has the right combination of great atmosphere and decent food to keep me coming back.  i can imagine this being a very hard place to come with a group, because there is usually a line, and counter seating is pretty prevalent.  so i recommend coming with one other person - i've never had to wait longer than 5 minutes when i'm only with one person.  

as for the food, i can highly recommend the chef's mess, and i also recommend getting a biscuit with gravy as your toast option.  as it is , this will fill your stomach for most of the day.  but if you really want to go crazy, get an old-fashioned strawberry shake too.  it is one of the best i've had (in-n-out also comes to mind), and never lets me down.

for lunch, i've only ever had the patty melt, but it was great.  

when you're all done, head over to pop's, across the street, for a cool, refreshing can of hamm's.
author: jeremy f.

description: For a weekday brunch it's great; I probably wouldn't come here on a weekend. I like their huevos rancheros and their fresh pico and their potatoes. Their biscuits and gravy is sort of weird and I can never keep track of whether I actually like them or not. Ice cream things, when their freezer is actually working and they have ice cream, are very good.
author: Heather R.

description: I give it 2 stars for the food quality, taste and service. The extra star goes to the atmosphere (it takes you back to the old fifty's) the decor and old traditional malt shop feel is what you get once inside. The price is also average. The ice tea that my boyfriend got was watered down, the eggs was not over-easy but rather under-cooked. I may come again..but i hear the weekend is a terrible time to come in, maybe on an average weekday brunching is good
author: Ateh M.

description: I would never wait to eat here- sorry, I just don't think it's worth 30 minutes hanging out in front on 24th street. But if you can make it here before 10am on any given weekend, you're usually ok. Breakfast is consistently good (and fast!) and they offer a wide variety of options. My new favorite is the veggie reuben sandwich, though. I don't know how they can make something so seemingly simple taste so delicious! It's phenomenal. Plus, they have Mitchell's ice cream  and champagne. It's a pretty easy winner.
author: Lisa L.

description: I used to come here for lunch about 12 years ago. I would get an egg salad sandwich and some ice cream, or maybe just ice cream. I even remember getting a cottage cheese/pineapple wedge salad once.  Since then the ownership has changed from the original family to some folks well versed in the restaurant business.  If you like those cheap and good brunch places in the mission, but have cast them out for the 30-40 minute wait, St. Francis Fountain is your answer. The benedict is excellent and one of the few places in the city where you can get a really good waffle. This place has been around since 1918, and has warmly improved over the years without losing the retro feel.
author: Paul S.

description: Great atmosphere.  I love it here.  Waffles are yummy, nebulous potatoes are fantastic.  Vegan chorizo hash was just ok for me though, the fennel seeds added a nice flavor but it could've used some salt.
author: Linda L.

description: What drew me in to the place was the old diner interior and the fact someone told me they have the best shakes.  The food was alright, the shake was alright, and the service was alright.  That pretty much sums up this place: it's alright.
author: Violet S.

description: It's all been said before, better than I could have, so I'll just confirm that this place lives up to the hype.  The pie isn't as good as Mission Pie, and the breakfast isn't as good as Mama's, but everything is more than satisfying, and the service is efficient and friendly.  Love the authentic retro!
author: Freeman F.

description: MMM chocolate malts, veggies burgers, all sorts of good breakfast treats, cool old fashioned candy, beavis and butthead cards, and they always give me the window seat!
author: Jo L.

description:
I unabashedly hate the Mission.  I also hate hipsters.  So when Bam-Bam forced me to meet her at St. Francis for breakfast this morning, I grabbed my fixed-gear-spoke-thrashing stick and begrudgingly headed over.  But, and possibly to save face with all the Mission-ites out there, I also happen to love good food.  And this place had good food.  Not great, but definitely good.  The three egg omelet was perfectly cooked and sized (with fresh avocado inside...mmm..), the biscuits and vegetarian black pepper gravy was dynamite, and the coffee (although a bit thin for my blood) was filled at the rate in which I drank it.  
The Jew in me also liked the fact that for the two of us to have a full breakfast plus a few beverages, we spent just over $20.  Then again, the hater in me almost threw up when the hipsters started to come in en masse.  Apparently this place gets packed on weekends so it was a good thing I went on a weekday morning...otherwise there would've been some really bruised up waif-boys and some girls pissed off because of some broken cheap-as-shit-oversized-ugly-sunglasses.
author: Zev K.

description: The wait might get you on a Sunday morning but go early and experience the old diner with just classic dishes. Standard breakfast fare is the best. Great atmosphere minus the Mel's diner over-the-top-ness.
author: R K.

description: After the hype and recommendation from a native San Franciscan, I wasn't all that impressed.  We ordered a patty melt, a blt and a chocolate milkshake.  The patty melt was lacking in taste, the fry portions were skimpy, and the milshake, while good, doesn't touch a Ruby's Diner milkshake any day.  Overall, not bad, but not fabulous either.
author: Jennifer W.

description: I think I found my new home. I love this place!! They have a great selection of candy- jaw breakers and trading cards to gawk at.  Guiness floats?! How can you beat that? The staff are super friendly and the food is pretty amazing. I might be here
author: Marianne s.

description: Best weekday breakfast. On weekends maybe you can get a table before 11am, afterwards is usually too crowded. They have a Guiness float and lots of vegan options on the menu.
author: d v.

description:
i love this place...they make strong mamosas for 4 bucks  
* lots of veggie options
* kick ass sundays
* 21 jump street trading cards 

need i say more
its a stones throw away too ...basically best place ever!
author: celest i.

description: Yesterday was my first time at this landmark establishment. Had all the requisite trimmings to insure its stature as a bonafide fountain (vinyl booths, soda gear, candy, counter with stools) - All very cool - It may just have been that they weren't appropriately staffed for the holiday but the service was really poor - took forever for them to take our order and then they forgot to bring out the kid's grilled cheese sandwich and it arrived a good 7 minutes after everything else had been served. I will definitely go back since I think this may have been an anomaly but would say they need some help managing the place - Food was fine - what you would expect and prices reasonable - The ice cream, milkshakes etc all looked like the real deal -
author: ellen d.

description: Gone is the homemade candy counter, but I think you can still find Michale Jackson trading cards,  get the shake to go.
author: John C.

description:
I am NOT a hipster.
I have a thick french accent that definitively doesn't sound cool nor local.
Yet Saint Francis is and has been remaining my favorite place for brunch in 4 years now.

I've seen waiters come and go, but the food has stayed immutably good and satisfying. I have tried real hard to find eggs benedict that can top theirs (or at least be comparable), with no succes so far. They have the best hollandaise sauce period. And I make hollandaise, so I know what it should taste like!

If you want fancy (=not much on your plate) don't come here. That'll leave more banana bread for me! (Ha)
One disappointing dish (cause you have to complain huh?): the mac&cheese. But I read how people love it, must be done right then.
author: Laure b.

description: Everyone has to go here once. I went here as a kid. It's awesome. Sometimes we would cut school shhhhhhh and hangout. The nun at my high school also took me here once when I was having a high school mellow drama moment.
author: Pink G.

description: Went on Tuesday around 11am...I had two eggs with bacon and sausage, apple juice...partner had 3 egg omelet with sausage....$25.50 with tax.  Whatever.  Never had the lunch stuff there so can't comment, but the breakfast was mediocre, lots of potatoes, bread and jam.  Sorry, can't rave.  Typical younger "Flo" waitress made the place.
author: William G.

description: This is one of my favorite places to have breakfast. Excellent food, laid-back atmosphere and minimal wait time, if any.
author: Jon R.

description: Food = Excellent.  Shakes = Excellent.  Malts, ice cream, beer, Guinness float all excellent.  But, if you're here on Saturday or Sunday morning it is packed with aging hipsters that didn't realize the early '00s are over.  These are the types that still listen to Postal Service and Death Cab.  I once spit on one of these hipsters because they looked prettier than me.  I'm a guy, and don't look pretty, so I had to spit.
author: Ben H.

description:
Ok, have to totally change my review here, will leave my original below.  Just goes to show good service goes a long way. 

My Tia was visiting on a Sunday.  She's vegan. Not much vegan within walking distance from my apt. So i bit the bullet and said let's go to St Francis.  I'm glad the bullet was bit.   The service was a complete turn around from my previous experience.

We went later in the afternoon and only waited 5-10 minutes.  Very friendly service from the moment we walked in the door.  It didn't hurt that our waiter had a Cheap Trick t-shirt (my Tia was/is a huge CT fan).

Next hurdle:  the food.  Tia had a vegan sammich and ordered one to go for lunch the following day.  My niece had a pesto chicken sandwhich she enjoyed.  Mom had something with spuds & corn bread.  i had 2 eggs with corned beef hash.  final verdict:  All so damn yummy.

So all in all, improvement beyond improvement!


 ===

Snotty service from hipsters.  Crappy attitude from hipster clientele.  And they crowd here on weekends despite the food that is as mediocre as that other crap joint, boogaloos. oh u evil harbingers of gentrification!
author: Lito S.

description: I dig this joint. Reminds me of Happy Days, friendly staff. My friend and I were offered a free sundae, not kidding. Plus, they have an array of 70's, 80's paraphenalia for sale (gum packs from days of yore, i.e. Close Encounters, et al, even Andy Gibb cards). The menu goes on for days, which can be a bit overwhelming, I had the Chef's Mess which was excellent. Booth and counter space, take your pick!
author: wayne s.

description:
Mmm. A dark, poorly lit place for food. Yum! I like it here. It's not the best food but, lately, it's been hard to find somewhere to eat unhealthy fatty stuff that's not fast food.

I had the chef's mess which is just a sloppy messy pile of food! Delicious! Of course, anything with cheese and sour cream is delicious in my book.

Bonus: I got a cute waitress too.
author: Tracy Y.

description: The food is delicious and the prices are reasonable but the wait is just too damn long for weekend brunch!
author: Ruby F.

description: St. Francis has been part of my weekend routine for quite sometime now, and never fails to deliver an awesome brunch.  I reccomend getting the Nebulous Potato Thing with added vegan chorizo and avocado and a cup of coffee.  Its the perfect breakfast to mull over last night's hazy memories with friends.  The fact that they sell Magnum P.I. and A-Team trading cards (and so many more) is a huge plus.  The service is always awesome, whether making great reccomendations or keeping me from seeing the botoom of my coffee cup.  Good shit.
author: Gianpaolo P.

description: The vegan rueben is awesome, made with spinach and chard in addition to the sauerkraut and something that must take the place of traditional 1000 island dressing. I'm not vegan or even vegetarian and I loved it, specially with fries and a decidedly non-vegan vanilla malt (vegan option available). Servers have a little attitude and are snitty. I wouldn't go on a weekend morning, but rainy Saturday dinner was just fine.
author: Dan G.

description: Brunch/ breakfast @ St. Francis- woohoo!  Great tattooed, hipster staff that continually keeps your coffee cup full with high test dark.  Food is generally very good with good pancakes/ sausage combo (the real maple syrup is worth it).  I dig the nebulous potato thing and some of the scrambles as well.  In general, I leave there with a big ( overly-caffeinated ) smile on my face.
author: Tim A.

description:
best on weekdays
the girls are always nice to me
the food is good
great "away from Valencia, yet still Mission hipster" type of place
author: City G.

description: I live in the Mission and there is a general lack of good ole American food in these parts.  I was just happening by this place and poked my head in and decided I needed to come back and give them a try.  Apparently it is quite the SF institution.  I loved it.  The authentic decor makes your feel like you're in a Back to the Future diner - and the food reminds me of the little grill I grew up with many years ago. And all the wait staff was friendly but in a chic kinda cool way.  I was just there for lunch - the tuna melt was perfect and the fries were divine.  And I splurged and got the oh so yummy milkshake.  I will go back to this place many times.
author: Clark H.

description:
***UPDATE: one star removed for the removal of VEGETARIAN GRAVY (our favorite item, and primary reason for going) from the menu, and the PRICE INCREASE of everything else***

st. francis fountain has some of the best breakfast in town, and i actually prefer it over the diner i work at, all you knead. st. francis has tasty-ass vegetarian breakfast and it costs slightly less than boogaloos. 
the milkshakes are amazing, because they use mitchells ice cream.

i suggest you go in the late afternoon to avoid the severe infestation of cool kids and the servers being stressed out and incapable of delivering the usual half-hearted friendly service (which is fine with me... i just want the shit i ask for and maybe a "thank you" when the check is dropped of)

but still gets five stars because the scrambles and homefries and vegetarian pepper gravy are so full of tasty taste. and i have a high tolerance for unfriendly servers (because i am sort of one myself... )
author: Renee L.

description: Great brunch place! They serve breakfast food all day - or at least well into the afternoon. Good, basic egg scrambles, coffee, toast and stuff. I totally want to try a milk shake too - didn't seem right with breakfast though. It's a funky old fashioned soda fountain type place, with some outdoor seating, which is nice on a sunny Sunday morning. The service is good, if not overwhelmingly friendly. There was a wait when I went, but not too bad, unless you're starving. Prices are quite decent. Definitely recommended.
author: Caitlin H.

description:
mac n cheese = comfort food

1 word to describe this place: authentic

i love it here so much that i made a video from the booth.
there is another one later on in this review too. i find everyone there laid back and nice and not hipster/snobby. everyone is always really warm and no attitude, ever.

simply da best.  the mac n cheese can be that thing that turns it all around for me.  if i had a choice between a half dozen oysters and the mac n cheese - it would be a very very tough choice.  

it's a crawl under the covers sort of food.  it's like the entire diner is giving you a hug when you eat it, it's so PERFECT.

creamy,  real chedda cheese, crusty on top and breadcrumbs. 
It's all about the breadcrumbs if you're doing it the old school way.

here's a 10 second video i did at the counter.

http://www.flickr.com/photos/veronicavangogh/2422123892/
author: Veronica V.

description: The brunch food was standard breakfast fare, although better prepared than most places.  Our group of 7 was seated and served promptly.  But then our waitress never reappeared -- not to check if we needed anything else, not to refill our glasses, not to see if anyone wanted coffee or dessert.  We waited 10 minutes until she reappeared to serve another table, and we waved frantically to get our check.
author: Walter R.

description: A great little diner that did the retro thing right. They refurbished the existing hardware and recreated your typical decorations and are well stocked in candies from a long ago era. However, atmosphere is not all St. Francis has to offer. They have your traditional egg any style breakfast, tasty waffles, and some Mexican style staples. I will admit that my sausage, although bursting with flavor, was a bit overcooked. Fair prices and an alternative staff create a well-rounded diner. Only low point is that it is overrun with Class 5 Hipsters, but sometimes that just adds to the entertainment.
author: m p.

description:
this place is awesome. as soon as i walked in i was in love. they have a huge assortment of old school trading cards and candy that brought me way back. where else can you find authentic tron and garbagepail kids trading cards? amazing! 
didn't have any food, but the milkshakes are awesome. blackberry, very tasty. great way to start the day. the place smells great so i can only imagine how delicious the food is.
i love the atmosphere and the old paper straws they have. feels like a diner out of the 50s, only run by nice hipsters rather than squares or girls in poodle skirts. there's nothing like a slice of good ol' americana.
author: Meredith B.

description:
Parking:  Difficult 
Food:  Average (better than Denny's Grand Slam)
Price:  Moderate
Service:  Don't expect a smile or friendly service

I'll cut to the chase.  This place sucks.  Here's why.  St. Francis was recommended to me by a friend.  I live in the Southbay so, I drove 50 minutes to get there for breakfast.  My daughter and were seated right away.  After 15 minutes, I stood up and asked a waiter to take my order.  He told me to "sit" and wait for him.   A few minutes later, he took my order and the food came out rather quickly.  Halfway through my breakfast, I realized he forgot my coffee.  I didn't bother to call him out on it because of his bad attitude.  The food was average (not great).  I complained and got a discount off my bill.  I wouldn't go back or recommend to a friend.
author: Kiet N.

description: i like this place. a lot. the food is on point, the seating is sensible, and the waitresses are pretty good at refilling the coffee without being obnoxious. and coffee milkshakes.
author: Kyla W.

description:
Things I love:
Endless summers
Good friends
Bacon/potatoes/strawberry milkshakes at the St. Francis.

There's always a wait but it isn't anything to cry about. Food is consistent, coffee is your basic diner coffee (go to Philz afterwards for some real coffee), and the atmosphere is stellar. I like sitting at the counter but when the weather gets just right it is nice to be outside watching the Mission life go by.
author: Emily D.

description: this place is great. i haven't yet ordered a  burger from this place, but the breakfast if off the hook. i've been here twice so far and i've ordered the chef's mess and the corn beef hash. both very good. they also serve incredible milkshakes and ice cream here.
author: Cedric F.

description: Come here on a Sunday morning and have your eyes set on SF's scenester mecca after a long Saturday night of partying with booze and coke at the local Beauty Bar. If you can get past all of the fixed gear bikes, acid-washed skinny jeans, full body tattoos, abnormally large hair and butt-plugs, this place is pretty fanf*ckingtastic. A cure to any hang-over, really....the staff are reasonably kind and the price is right. Obviously all the vegetarian/vegan options are St. Francis' selling-point which makes this place so desirable to such a....limited clientele. Nonetheless, totally worth the 20-minute Sunday morning wait.
author: Jessica U.

description:
Good food for a reasonable price. I haven't been disappointed yet and I've samples many items from across the menu. Service is good--once you sit down. I think the busiest time is for brunch on sunday. But otherwise there usually isn't a wait. 

I love sitting at the counter because you get to see the staff make all of the shakes and ice cream desserts. Yum.
author: Tara C.

description:
Delicious. 

The espresso milkshake w coffee ice cream cannot be beat. 

I can't believe I live 5minutes from this place & just found out about it.  Good hangover food, large portions, good vibe & friendly staff. So many great choices on the menu, especially for breakfast.  

I will definitely be returning. again & again & again.
author: Willow B.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE. Me and my girlfriend go here almost every weekend for brunch. The omelets, orange juice, pancakes, and veggie gravy with biscuits are some of the best breakfast I've had in SF. It's the same food as Boogaloo's only way better. I don't mind the rampant hipsters. I have lived in San Francisco for three years now and have managed to stop judging them. If you do mind hipsters, you might want to avoid this place. Later in the day/week the hamburgers, or boca burgers, and shakes are quite satisfying at a decent price. The service isn't great but it isn't bad either.
author: Kyle J.

description: Saturday morning, tired from friday night... St Francis is always there for us!! Most of the staff is super nice, just one of them looks "too cool" to serve us but does her job alright... I like sitting at the bar, which usually doesn't have wait, and enjoy the french toast delight or the breakfast burrito. Perfectly located in 24th St!! Yeap, I love it.
author: martha s.

description:
Ok as far as food goes but the place is really filthy.
When was the last time they cleaned this place?  I was thinking about calling the board of health just looking at the counters and cabinets from the bar where I sat.  I wonder what the kitchen looks like?  If it's any thing like the front area I would suggest you eat at your own risk...
author: John V.

description: St. Francis Fountain USED to make its own ice cream but since they switched ownership, the ice cream is now Mitchell's, good but nothing special.   I went there yesterday and found the sandwich ordinary except way overpriced and the hot fudge sundae no different than Baskin-Robbins.  The old St. Francisco would also make their own fudge and chocolate sauce.  The 'candy' portion of the place is a joke and I'm sure the chocolate sauce is Hershey's.  What a shame....
author: David P.

description: all this place has to offer is nostalgia for an old fashion ice cream parlor-esque diner. the food itself is mediocore. if you grew up going to St. Francis Fountain then you probably love this place. i didn't, but i can understand the appeal and can appreciate it for what it is. plus the orangesicle drink is pretty good.
author: Regina C.

description:
This is the real deal with bonus tracks...

Great banana splits, malts (with so much malt that you can crunch em) and vegie burgers (made with your choice of faux-meat dammit!). 

Best veggie burger I've found in SF so far. Excellent fries, skinny with skins. Knock-out breakfasts. As long as you're coming for soda jerk food you're going to be happy. But don't expect 50's bubble gum music, the closest thing you'll find to the 50's outside the egg cream is the cute rockabilly waitress (does she count?).
author: Justin L.

description:
my favorite diner in san francisco! i found it on yelp (ofcourse) and decided to go with a friend. we waited about ten to fifteen minutes.we were seated and as soon as i got a look at that menu i started salivating. so many frikkin options! i got a scramble with soy chorizo and cheese, a side of potatoes (yum) and some banana bread.Ahhh! it was one of the best breakfasts i'd ever had. my friend got the same thing as me except she got biscuits. those biscuits were so good that they still come up in our conversations. the scramble was so cheesey and the soy chorizo so delicious omg and with the potatoes and some ketchup wow. if you put all of it in your mouth,including a bite of the buscuit, at once you will soon discover it taste like sex in your mouth.
i went back a second time,and things only got better.i got another scramble, this time with cheese,mushrooms,onions and pesto.and that was an even better combo.my goal is to come here and try every combination possible until i discover the best one.when i do i will update this review,expect to hear from me again!
author: Peeta B.

description: God, do we love the St. Francis !  Excellent food in an old-time fountain setting.  It's always packed (esp. on weekends), so prepare for a bit of a wait.  They seem to keep things moving, though.  You write your name on a pad outside the door and kind of hang out.  On sunny days, there is some outdoor seating.  Good burgers, sandwiches,  - nice fare for breakfast or lunch.  I laways have the turkey club - and never miss the "nebulous potato thing".  It is to die for : home fry-type spuds w/green onions, sour cream, and salsa -  drenched in 2 types of cheese.  Absolutely amazing.  They also have a cool candy counter with some nostalgic candies and cool trading cards.  A bonus: up and down the street, there are a lot of bakeries to get delicious cookies.
author: Mary N.

description: Happened upon St Francis Fountain with my boyfriend the place is cute and old time-y, standard classics...lots of people in-and-out for ice cream.
author: carrie b.

description: awesome vibe to that place , perfect for breakfast and brunch the tomato sauce on the breakfast burrito is a killer , would love to go back and try different things , people who work there are very very friendly
author: NAEL K.

description:
24th Street is, in my humble opinion, the last authentic commercial street in San Francisco.  24th has largely resisted the gentrification that has befallen Valencia Street, etc. and is lined up and down with diverse shops and restaurants that do what they do very well, and don't try to be anything they're not.

Among these is the St. Francis Soda Fountain.  Forget everything you think you know about 1950's-style diners--especially if that knowledge was imparted from such establishments as Lori's downtown.  St. Francis Soda Fountain is the real deal--from the paper straws to the design of the menus to the old-fashioned powdered soap in the bathroom, it's clear the management has paid close attention to detail, and doesn't take their customers for suckers.

Apparently, St. Francis used to make their own ice cream, but in recent years have switched to Mitchell's (which is almost the same thing).  The first time i sat down at the counter, i ordered a single-scoop in a cone, and was told they only serve it in a glass dish unless you're getting it to go.  Apparently that's the traditional way these things are done.  i appreciated that.  

Recently my girlfriend were on 24th waiting for a show to begin, and we decided to stroll in for a small bite to eat.  Among the best deals on the menu (and there are quite a few...it's a tough decision) is the bowl of chili and cornbread.  We both decided on that, having no idea what we had bargained for.  The chili was absolutely delicious, full of veggies and covered in cheese, but the best part was by far the thick chunk of cornbread that came with it.  Moist and buttery, with a dense, substantial consistency and baked with chopped jalapeños throughout, then pan-toasted just prior to serving for a nice, crispy outside.  Without a doubt the best i've ever had.

i'm looking forward to trying the huevos rancheros next time...
author: J. Brandon L.

description: The food here is not awesome, not even for diner food, but the ambiance is pretty great. Even though your server will undoubtedly spend much more time before the mirror every day than you, don't be scared off by the hipster flair.
author: Daniela P.

description: Ok so best breakfast experience of my life!!  I was lookin for a place to get a decent omlette.....found this place on yelp and decided to try it out and I'm not regretting it!!!  I ordered the chicken, avocado, cilatro omlette w I think it was jack cheese.  Whatever it was it was tasty as hell.  Eggs cooked to perfection, tasted fantastic, good sized portions as well.  Their home fries/potato things were the shit and I am not a big potato kinda person in the morning. They were  kinda crispy...lightly seasoned.  I didn't want the bread that came with my meal so the waiter offered me a cup of fruit.
