I'm always a little wary to order fruit from places because more often that not, the fruit is kinda sour and not fresh tasting.  Not in this case!  Everything was freakin fantastic.  Cute little diner...good music....reasonable prices.  I can't wait to go back and try something else :)  I would have given the place a 5 but the floor where I was sitting looked like it hadn't been mopped in months!  Come on peeps ya gotta have a little bit of cleanliness!
author: karla k.

description: I've recently started venturing back here after a few year hiatus. The service is MUCH better. MUCH- I actually look forward to coming back here. Food is always delicious.
author: Mr. Marie T.

description: Fast, tasty comfort food in a clean, cozy diner.  The waiters are friendly, efficient, and total studs.  Don't miss the Modesto Pesto grilled chicken sandwich.
author: Aaron Z.

description: After my first experience here, I figured it could've been a fluke and wanted to try it again. The food is just okay, but the variety is amazing for vegetarians (both visits I had two different tofu scrambles with the standard potatoes and biscuits.) Tofu eggs anyway you can imagine them!!! After my first, less than ideal encounter with their staff, I was hoping for a change. In short, my order came out wrong (which is fine, I worked my way through college at a restaurant!), but no one ever came to check on us. EVER. I had to go up to the counter to ask for my meal to be changed (alright, I'm over it, the food should be here quick, it only took 5 minutes initially! :)) Friends are more than halfway through their meals so a friend flagged down another server to make sure it was coming. We're told it is. Server finally comes by and takes away plate with wrong food. My friends finish their meal, their plates are cleared and our bill is dropped off. I let the woman (not our server) know that I still haven't gotten my meal!!! It comes about five minutes later. St. Francis, we won't be hanging out anytime soon :(
author: Stacy Q.

description: Tasty vegan breakfast/brunch!  Their new vegan menus is outstanding.  We always look forward to eating here.  Reasonable prices, great atmosphere, and delicious food.  Recommended!
author: D. B.

description: "Momma said there'd be days like this, there'd be days like this my momma said (momma said, momma said!)"--this is the song that just randomly popped into my head this morning. That should have been warning enough to get back in bed and pull up the covers, but no, I went out into the world. Some allergy is making my eyes look like I've spent the day crying and I didn't notice until after going out into public that in my fitful sleep of the night before I had somehow managed to work a giant upwardly mobile knot into the back of my hair. So why am I telling you this? Other than because I can? Because on days like this I want my Momma to scoop me into her lap and spoon feed me Kraft Macaroni and Cheese.  As this is not an option I can at least search for a culinary equivalent. With its retro stylings and tweaked diner menu, I took my foggyheaded self straight to St Francis. Veggie chili topped with cheddar cheese, sour cream, and green onions with a generous slice of warm, crispy-on-the-outside-soft-and-buttery-on-the-inside corn bread was EXACTLY what I needed. It was a hug from my innards outwards. Generally I think a lot of their food is pretty good, if not somewhat expensive, but when it comes to their comfort food selections (aforementioned chili and cornbread, other baked goods like banana bread and biscuits, milkshakes, soups) they live up to their holy title. Amen.
author: Hallie R.

description: milkshakes are ah-mazing. five stars for an old fashioned soda shop anyways.
author: Kerissa B.

description: so sweet and there's tofu scramble. all the waitresses are kind. soy milkshakes. something called a 'toasty vegan.' its perfect.
author: aerin w.

description: You can order anything you want anyway you want it when you come here. Swiss instead of cheddar? Fine. Eggs over easy on the fried egg sandwich instead of over hard? Done. Substitute scrumptious black beans for potatoes? Every time. And the black and white milkshake is a meal in itself. Friendly, fast service, really delicious food.
author: Francisca J.

description: I didn't have high expectations for St. Francis Fountain, i'll admit.  i was killing time this weekend with some potential roommates while we scoured the desert of mission flats, searching for something livable.  "there's this hipster diner on york," suggested one po-roommate, no doubt already imagining the vegetarian possibilities for his non-meaty-flesh eating self.  we agreed, because we're all easy going (which is why this apartment, when we find one, is going to be awesome).  four milkshakes, one veggie biscuits and gravy and one avocado BLT later, we were happy as five clams, albeit homeless clams.  our servers were amazingly attentive - we had two different people waiting on us and they were totally on top of our water and coffee.  we should have tipped more (sorry guys!), so i'm trying to make up for it here.  it's slightly pricey for a diner (nothing under $6 pretty much), but what are you going to do?  sometimes you just NEED a chocolate milkshake when you're standing on the corner of York and 24th.
author: Ariel D.

description: Best. Milkshake. Ever. Not to mention the burgers. It's a very Pleasantville-meets-punk-rock vibe. The staff, who is way cooler than I could ever hope to be, couldn't be nicer. Great for a hangover brunch or for a protein fix after a half marathon -- just depends on the weekend.
author: Heather S.

description: Mediocre but passable diner fare served by hipsters with attitude; attitude despite the fact that they work at a sweet hokey little diner. Hmmm. . .?
author: Ben B.

description: nothing like a dirty coffee milkshake to cool off a burning hangover. cutie patootie wait staff, a plethora of divine breakfast choices, good tunes and rockin vintage candy. what more can a girl ask for? well i could ask for a build your own waffle/mimosa/bloody mary bar but i just don't think they have the space to accomodate my wishes since this place is packed on the weekends. but its still sublime and one of my favorite breakfast/lunch spots in sf.
author: CTP p.

description: best breakfast after Boogaloo's  the lines are just as long, but the service is slower, and there are usually more hipsters milling around in front, but such is life. i favor their potatoes over Boog's but they aren't as good at eggs. keep up the good work.
author: Jared Z.

description: I used to love this place growing up. This is place is only a block up from where I lived growing up and we used to go there all the time for their ice cream.YUM! but UNFORTUNATELY they changed owners.... the service there is rude. from my experiences I can say that if you are not white or look somewhat white, then you're treated so differently like you don't belong there! I wish it was like before..(sigh) PLEASE PREVIOUS OWNERS GO BACK!!!!!
author: Maria H.

description:
the best dining experience in san francisco!
they saved my withering heart from losing faith in finding good service in the city!
the food was AMAZING!!! i actually read the reviews here and decided to try tofu scrambles and being from a culture that lives by spice, i loved the Mex T.S.!!! my friend and i were almost screaming when we got the food.

and more than anything, what a great service.  we were greeted by friendly smiling ppl who asked us to sit wherever we wanted.  our cups were always full.  a mistake on the check was confirmed with us before fixed.

but, the soy gelato, i think it was vanilla, was not that great...

at any rate, the next time i'm in SF, this will definitely be my first stop!!!
author: t l.

description: "i could eat here everyday. they have great breakfast, great lunch, and all sorts of kick-ass fountain sodas and milkshakes. most of the waitresses have serious attitude problems but eveything else is so good it's worth it."
author: amanda w.

description: love this place.  some items are better than others.  get the potato nebulous thing!! or the meat lovers can get the corned beef hash.  don't get a biscuit.  so far the only place to get biscuits in this town is the pork store cafe.  I never had a milkshake here, b/c i'm always stuffed after i eat, but i know they're good.  they gotta be.  love the fountain feel.  like i'm marty mcfly and have a green down vest and biff wants to crush me for being in there, but i just eat and ignore him.
author: chreesh b.

description: I'm really glad that they reopened this place... for the one reason, and one reason only: frozen chocolate bananas.  I haven't been in lately, but I really REALLY hope they're selling these bad boys when I get back.  The perfect desert after stuffing my face with a fat plate of chile colorado at Roosevelt's Tamale Parlor, which is just down the block (something about the coolness of the frozen banana and the spicy chile colorado... yummm).  Next time you go in, ask them what the hell happened to making their own ice cream?  A few days after they reopened they told me they were learning how to make their own, not saying that Mitchell's isn't a brilliant choice, but are they going to make their own?  Because that would be cool.
author: Margie N.

description: For me, St. Francis Fountain lost a star today. The vibe there has always been laid back and do what you want, be as you are...totally relaxed...with great food (amazing biscuits) and "I like you, I really, really like you" service that couldn't be beat. Today my friend and I were actually served "A RULE" along with our pancakes and eggs.  My friend Luis, who ordered a MOUNTAIN of food (they REALLY should have liked him for that) simply wanted his pancakes ahead of his sandwich. He was told by our waitress that "we don't do that!". This clearly falls in the consumer category of "what is the big deal?" What would have been the big deal to serve him his pancakes before his sandwich? When a restaurant suddenly starts ordering the customer instead of the other way around...what will be next? The classic "NO SUBSTITUTIONS" screaming out on the menu? For a down-home place that feels as good as eating in your mother's kitchen, mama has to be more flexible.
author: Steve Z.

description: What are all of you people smoking? I don't care if your staff is drunk, as long as I you take my order. Instead, I ended up paying way too much for a mediocre sandwich and getting terrible service because I didn't have super tight jeans or look like a heroin addict.
author: dan s.

description: I like this place. I wasn't very fond of the interior, but I can understand how it can be cute to some people. (My friend happened to love it.)  I went for brunch with friends on a weekday and although it is small and full, it did not feel crowded. Our party of 3 quickly became a party of 5 when two more friends happened to be in the area and we were quickly allowed sit at the two joined booths in the back with no problems. The food is good and reasonably priced. All five of us ordered something different and everyone left satisfied. I found the customer service to be good and would go there again.
author: Justine L.

description: St. Francis has been around a long while though it's been through a few owners. Hubby has fond  memories of going there for ice cream when he was a wee lad, back in the halcyon days when if was safe for elementary school age kids in the Mission to walked to their neighborhood school on their own. I believe there was a slump in the 90's. I remember a local family ran it for a while, but it never took off, probably because the food was  ordinary and the atmosphere dead. When we heard there were new owners, we decided to try St. Francis again. When our happy little family of four walked in, I could immediately feel the hipness quotient drop several notches. And this was when you could still walk in at 11:30am and have your pick of tables. The food kept us coming back - ice cream mocha- yum! and I'm particularly fond of eggs Sandhya. And the staff has been nothing but pleasant, even making nice with the young 'uns. Maybe they are surly only to those of their own kind. Alas, the time came when the wait to be seated became longer and longer, and finally, the death knell, the little yellow wait list pad, appeared. So, we don't usually go anymore on week-ends, but we get the same food without the wait at other times of the week.
author: Kara P.

description: st. francis has yummy french fries, milkshakes, and cherry cokes which is what matters most to me.  i also enjoy their veggie offerings and i am always tempted to buy some pee wee cards or 20 year old candy bars.  plus, everyone is always nice.  if i opened up my own restaurant (and i will one day) st. francis would definitely be a mild influence except mine would have veggie sausage!
author: Kristie P.

description:
dear guys,

st. Francis has a monopoly on brunch this side of 24th street.  But i have a feeling that if Roosevelt Tamale house and La Torta Gorda also served mimosas, they would give Francis a run for their money.  

first let me say, i am not ugly, nor am i bitter . . . but one can not help but remark on the "look at me" staff there.  i'm pretty sure you're not allowed to wash your hair if you work there or weigh more than 105 pounds, male or female.  dont' get me wrong, i very much enjoy checking out camel toes as i eat my eggs (i do!) and i got nothing against skinny people. . . . but it makes you wonder . . . 

no brown people or fatties work the front, only the back.  san francisco doesn't do "too cool" because we are not and we leave that to other people and other cities.  we can't compete and most of us don't want to.  my point?  if you moved that place to williamsburg there would be 2 or even 3 brown super models working there.  

in conclusion, st. francis is a no brainer for dinner, lunch or brunch.  you'll find something suitable and filling, greasy in the way diner food should be.  it doesn't knock your socks off unless you're starving or hungover.
author: Claire D.

description: fun diner / ice-cream shoppe for hipsters, with penny candy!
author: John M.

description: ate here twice over the weekend, which were my first and second time ever eating here. first was for breakfast and i got the avocado, tomato, cilantro breakfast burrito. it was fairly delicious with black beans on the side (which i love), my only qualm was with the salsa. it was kind of bland and tasted like stewed tomatoes. reminded me of the "salsa" my mom used to can when we were kids. my second experience was far better for lunch (although i still ordered breakfast). i got the spinach and feta scramble and added tomato. everything was delicious from the scramble to the potatoes. i enjoyed and savored every bite til near explosion. the waitress even gave us some extra milkshake that wouldn't fit in someone's glass which was totally nice. overall.. a great food experience and added to my enjoyment of s.f.
author: Kim H.

description: i love little old diners like this!  i had the vegan chili with cornbread, and both were excellent.  the menu was so extensive, i had trouble making up my mind.  unlike  a lot of other diners, they have an excellent selection for vegans and vegetarians, which is really nice.  it's all 50s style and they have a section where they sell candy.  they had garbage pail kids and cyndi lauper trading cards!  the staff was friendly and the service was quick, and i look forward to going there again.
author: Kate W.

description: Overrated...maybe 3 stars because of the vintage/cool factor, but my hard to come by dining dollar deserves better food for the price.
author: Craig S.

description: unlike yelper Leanna S., i have not had any run-ins with short-skirted waitresses and illustrious peeks at their ya-yas. i should be so lucky. it might make me increase my ratings. admittedly the nostalgic americana, hipster atmosphere, and servers are better than the food. go with a healthy appetite and eat at a fast pace. you will hit the spot. it's better that way. have a shake and some candy on the way out.
author: Virginia A.

description: i'm sort of addicted to their nebulous potatoe thing. its a meal in itself. service was great and hello??? all the old school card candy and gum stuff. who could ask for more. maybe next time i'll try the ice cream product. i was just too full and it was a little early for a cold, sweet snack. but i'm going back for sure. i do wish i lived closer though.
author: Mama Jaz C.

description:
the eggs are ok, the shakes are good. the bacon and the sausage ... a disaster.  it's the schitzo kitchen, ladies and gentlemen.

i prefer usulutan a block up the way... especially on weekends when the hipsters form an ironic crowd out front, as if they're onto something.
author: Combi C.

description: scene-factor increasing heavily but food is tasty and how can you disparage a place that sells vintage candy and 80s era trading cards
author: hunter w.

description: i love this place & would eat there all the time if i could. i got the nebulous potato thing & it was perfect; the milkshakes are killer too. a great diner in the true diner tradition.
author: gina e.

description: my home away from home... Great chef mess, chicken soup, shakes, malts, salads! what is vegan chorizo?, I dunno, please can I have more dark great coffee! rocken music
author: Missy I.

description: i had a decent time here. i really enjoyed all the vegetarian and vegan options they, had it was outstanding. they also maintained the old school dinner feel to the place. i guess we got lucky, but i heard the line here could get ridiculous. overall, it's hispter.
author: Jeorge J.

description: you gotta love a place that serves guinness floats for breakfast. service was mission hip (tatted up and glamorous) and food was 1950s stellar.  the french toast + granola/fruit/yogurt combo hit the spot, accompanied by the knife covering jose gonzalez. gotta love brunch when it comes with new music discoveries.
author: Albert C.

description: I hate to have to give this 1 star, but the reason being is that the serving size of my ice cream was tiny and yet so expensive. I ordered the Dusty Road and the 2 scoops of ice cream were the sizes of half a tablespoon and there was hardly any whipped cream or fudge on it. For almost $7 --I expect to get my money's worth. I guess because the economy is bad and food is so expensive that they are jacking up these prices and making the servings smaller
author: alexandria s.

description: Great ice creams. Annoying hipster staff that are too cool for school. I'm glad the fountain is still there though ,and they are committed to preserving the place. Their breakfasts are good, but I would go to Sunrise cafe at Folsom and 24th  if you really want to have a great meal.
author: josie b.

description: I was heart-broken this evening when I went with my roommate to get a sundae only to find-out it's closed. There are newspapers covering the windows. Are they remodeling (someone please tell me yes)? If not, can someone please tell me where the strikingly handsome boy with the blue eyes is now? I went there just to sit at the counter and have him serve me sundaes--especially when he wore that brilliant blue shirt that matched his eyes.
author: Wildfood S.

description: You know how on Yelp when you do a search for a place it always has a similar place and the phrase "you might also consider"....? Well if you do a search for St. Francis Fountain, I highly recommend that you go to the offered alternative. The place is not a neat old diner. It's a tired old diner, much in need of some soapy water applied to most surfaces, followed by a paint brush. Their burgers are okay. But couldn't stand up against a Jumbo Jack. They weren't serving fries. The Chef's Mess was a rather colorless, unappetizing pile of vegetable matter and cheese, which had about as much eye appeal as the contents of a Mexican barf bag. The chili was very watery. The very dry mac and cheese was ok. The service made me feel I had not so much slipped into the past, as it made me feel that I'd been rudely transported to some greasy spoon in some depressed rural  backwater . The biggest disappointment was the milkshake. I'm a big lover of shakes and after reading a good number of reviews here on Yelp, I was excited. I must admit it was very thick. But it had been left mixing so long that it had lost that sort of icy crystaline texture which is one of the primary qualities sought by a true shake aficionado. It was very like the ones that first came out of shake machines at MacDonalds about 45 years ago. The service, if you want to call it that, was minimalist. All I can say, given all the kudos in other reviews, is that they must make some kind of world class fries. I won't likely return. And the check was nearly $45 for 3 people.
author: Rellsky S.

description: What a diner should be.  My friends and I didn't have to wait long for a outside table and this was during the weekend brunch rush.  Food and prices are great.  Didn't get one but the milkshakes look fantastic.  Would recommend for city folks and out of town guests.
author: Angela C.

description: I'm very local to this diner and I have enjoyed many breakfasts there in the past.  unfortunately my most recent experience was far below par.  first of all the service was horrible and I had to fight my way through attitude to even get to a table when there were only two tables seated in the first place.  second I noticed a little stand-up on the table that mentioned the restaurant will add 5% onto the bill as a surcharge to help pay for their employees' heath benefits.  i don't think this is fair because whether the employer wants to supply health benefits for their employees or not, it is not the burden of the customer.  so remember even if you tip a mere 15% you are actually paying 20% towards the unhelpful, and even rude service.  just remember that when your bill comes and you drop a 20% tip, and think about if you really want to be tipping 25% at a diner.
author: J M.

description: After eating here, I am full! It's hard to find an affordable and filling vegan breakfast in this city, this is the place. I have been forced into going to the Pork Store and Boogaloos too many times, waiting in line for an hour only to have pretty much one option to eat, including nasty hash browns (pork store) which is damn ridiculous. This place has a big variety of vegan options and they have vegan milkshakes. The staff have always been friendly too.
author: Lynn R.

description:
If your jeans aren't skinny and your hair isn't asymmetrical and your bike isn't a one speed, don't worry. Just because you're not a hipster doesn't mean you should be intimidated by the scene at St. Francis. Smile. Show no fear. Rock your cargo pants and clean, shiny locks. Remember, real hipsters can't admit they are hipsters and really are defined by the standard accoutrements, ipso facto they can't judge you by your own appearance. I know it's just a technicality, but it's what I kept telling myself when I moved to the Mission. 
That's my advice for those who have mentioned the rather homogenous scene, and for those who have noticed those complaints on Yelp and been turned off. Because if that's what's keeping you from you from enjoying a lovely heaping plate of Nebulous Potato Thing, biscuits in country gravy, a vegan Ruben or a Dreamcicle, it's not worth it. Mmmm, greasy St. Francis,  my one of many vices. 
Now, if you'll excuse me, I need to tuck my jeans into my vintage boots and get myself down to 24th and York, because me and my good-looking friends have to fuel up after another night of drinking PBRs at, oh I don't know, the Edinburgh.
author: Kiddle L.

description: The tall blonde girl with short slash long hair on one side is a beezy, everyone else is cool. They get your orders wrong a lot but its pretty good food. Too many cool kids.
author: nothing n.

description: i went here on sunday around brunch time and the wait was pretty long. but definitely worth it. i like the interior of st. francis. it has lovely booths, and even a telephone booth. i don't think there's a phone in it, though. instead of being one of those places that tries to look old, it actually is old. i did get some 'tude here from one of the waitresses, but it was my bad. you see, there are two kinds of milkshakes here. the ones with the syrup, and ones with mitchell's ice cream. i started to order the kind with the syrup and the waitress corrected me, saying that people always get the shakes mixed up and she didn't understand why. i smiled at her and explained that it was my first time. the milkshake was delicious. and to eat i got eggs, home fries, and biscuits smothered in vegetarian pepper gravy. oh my god those biscuits were so delicious! i ate bites of my friends' foods and they were good, too. i couldn't even finish my food, i was so full. it's definitely a place for hipsters, but i don't care. i would eat at st. francis fountain for my last meal.
author: Oleya P.

description: i wont lie, the food is good but not great. ive eaten here before but was never impressed by their service. but what made me finally write a review for this place was my visit there this past week. i came here on my hour lunch break with a friend. we're both familiar with st francis since its been in the neighborhood for years and now we both live down the street from it. when we got there, no one else was there waiting for a table. then about 5 minutes later a family of 5 came and signed up and were called to be seated before us. i could understand if they probably had a booth available so i really dont trip off that too much. then when we finally were seated at the counter, i noticed that a group of 3 that got there after we did got their food served first before they had even taken our order! and i know they didnt forget about us because we were right in their faces the whole time. by that time, almost 40mins had went by and i had to leave. right when were getting up from our seats, they ask if we wanted to order. for me, even if the foods good but the service is a mess, ill pass. my friends say that why they dont go there either.
author: vicki g.

description: If you love brunch - especially new places to eat brunch - I would absolutely consider a stop at St. Francis Fountain.  That said, there are PLENTY of great places in the Mission for great brunch and better service.  I found St. Francis Fountain to have good breakfast/brunch food, in line with places like Boogaloo, however, the service sucks compared to many places.  It's not that the servers want to be rude, I think they just happen to hang out with the same crowd that eats there regularly, which is to say they drink a lot on Friday and Saturday nights.  Having to show up early on Saturdays and Sundays after hard nights of drinking is not at all fun and even less so if you have to serve the very same crowd that you partied with the night before, knowing full well they got way more sleep than you did.  Hence, the food is great for "the morning after"; just don't expect any smiles, thank yous and/or any other niceties.  Have fun!
author: Justin L.

description: It is unfortunate that this place is so hit or miss since this is one of the only places for american diner food here on the dirty end of 24th Street.  I was a fan when they first reopened, but since, I've had to reevaluate my one-time love.  True, back in the day it wasn't the scene-y mecca it now is, but aside from the ridiculous line on the weekends, that isn't really an issue for me.  The food is decent and the ambiance is charming.  I take issue with the snotty and often sub-par service.  Dear St. Francis Staff,  You are cute as hell, but why must I be treated like I'm bothering you if I order a milkshake?  And why do you disappear as soon as I'm ready to get the check?  Boo.  I'm too impatient to wait on the weekends and will walk halfway up the block to get a phenomenal torta at La Torta Gorda, but if I'm playing hooky from work during the week, a visit to the St. Francis is still on my agenda.
author: Amy R.

description: i love st francis! best fried egg sandwich ever.  and only 4 dollars. totally sweet and triumphant.
author: Pearl A.

description: i like this place, i get register love so its all good,  but i wouldnt advise going there on a nice weekend, because its quite the scene, but if you do, get a vanilla milkshake and go across the street to pops and get a shot of bourbon and pour that shit in. good times..
author: Greasy w.
